DOC.HEAD: Slain Nun Remembered as Peacemaker
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Fond du Lac service, quotes from archbishop; picks up 6th graf pvs, `The Rev. Tom ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MI2
DOC.TEXT: Mourners bade farewell Friday to a nun killed in a Nicaraguan ambush, saying her life was forfeited to violence in a world that needs peacemakers. Nearly 300 friends and family members attended a memorial service at the home church of Sister Maureen Courtney, one of two nuns killed Monday evening when their pickup truck was attacked by assailants in northeastern Nicaragua. Some wept as a coffin draped in red roses was borne between two rows of women parishioners. ``We feel a right to be angry at this senseless death, this loss of innocent human life,'' Archbishop Rembert Weakland of Milwaukee told mourners at an evening service in Fond du Lac, about 50 miles north of Milwaukee. ``If we are encouraged by their example to move from here to make this world a place of peace and love through the mutual service we give to one another, then senselessness will be turned into fullness of life,'' he said. About 20 Nicaraguans who have worked with the Sisters of St. Agnes sang a Spanish hymn, ``Pescador de Hombres,'' and several prayers were said in Spanish. Sister Courtney, 45, a Milwaukee native, and Sister Teresa Rosales, 24, of Nicaragua were members of the Fond du Lac-based Sisters of St. Agnes. Auxiliary Bishop Pablo Schmitz of Bluefields, Nicaragua, a native of Fond du Lac, and Sister Francisca Colomer, 24, of Nicaragua were wounded in the attack. Sister Courtney's body was flown to the United States on Thursday night. An earlier service for her was in Milwaukee, and a private burial was scheduled Saturday. The Rev. Tom Wittliff, a Roman Catholic priest and family friend, told mourners in Milwaukee that Sister Courtney was a victim whose sacrifice would become a Eucharist for others. ``On that road in Nicaragua, whatever traps were set, whatever shots were shot, the spirit of Christ was being continued,'' Wittliff said. ``The world has enough of the military, it has enough clowns. What the world needs now is people who will give.'' Sister Jean Salchert, a member of the order, prayed: ``Give us the courage to put our life on the line. Where there is war and violence, may we be peacemakers.'' Two protesters carried signs outside. One said, ``Stop the bloodshed and Contra aid.'' Another read: ``Contra Aid, Murder by Proxy.'' Sisters of St. Agnes in Nicaragua said evidence at the scene implicates Contra rebels in the ambush. The U.S.-backed Contras are fighting the leftist Nicaraguan government. The Nicaraguan government has blamed the ambush on the Contras, although a spokesman for the rebels on Wednesday denied any involvement in the killings. Sister Collette Hartman, a friend of Sister Courtney's, said members of the International Commission for the Protection and Promotion of Human Rights were investigating the ambush.

DOC.HEAD: Former HUD Accountant Pleads Guilty to Federal Theft Charge
DOC.TEXT: A former accountant for the Department of Housing and Urban Development pleaded guilty Friday to one count of theft from the U.S. government for allegedly embezzling $1 million from a HUD rent-subsidy program. Douglas R. Turner entered the plea before U.S. District Court Judge James Carrigan as part of an agreement that called for three other theft counts to be dropped in exchange for his guilty plea. Turner, 38, could be sentenced to a maximum 10 years in prison and fined up to $250,000. No sentencing date has been set. Turner was indicted Aug. 29 for allegedly embezzling $1 million from HUD and putting the funds to his own use. He has been free on personal recognizance bond since that time. Turner was a $28,000-a-year supervisory accountant in HUD's Denver regional office. Prosecutors say Turner used a government computer to electronically transfer about $1 million from the HUD Section 8 rent-subsidy program to the bank account of a real estate company he owned, Green View Developers Inc. Green View Developers was not eligible to participate in the program. The transfers occurred between December 1988 and May 1989, and turned up during a routine audit, prosecutors said. Investigators said Turner apparently found an account number for a housing project once used by HUD and made charges to that account to make it appear the Section 8 program funds were being spent legitimately. He allegedly used this system to wire money on at least four occasions from the U.S. Treasury into the Colorado State Bank account of Green View Developers. When the investigators began investigating Turner's role in the affair, they allegedly found a burgeoning stock portfolio, recently purchased real estate and a $500,000 custom home under construction. They said Turner also bought a car with the money. Assistant U.S. Attorney James Allison said FBI and HUD investigators have so far seized property worth $470,000 from Turner that will be used as restitution in the case. The Justice Department has also filed a $1 million civil lawsuit against Turner in an effort to recover the remainder of the embezzled funds. The civil and criminal actions are a cooperative effort to recover the money, with the $470,000 already seized to be the only restitution in the criminal proceeding, said Turner's attorney, Dianna DeGette. Turner's case emerged at the height of concern over allegations of widespread fraud in the Denver HUD operation. U.S. Attorney Mike Norton said that investigation is still continuing.

DOC.HEAD: Official: `Cheesehead' Column Backfired on Royko
DOC.TEXT: Mike Royko says people in the Fox Valley are ``cheeseheads,'' but the region's officials believe the newspaper columnist has been outfoxed. The east-central Wisconsin area is busy trying to lure Chicago businesses, and local officials say a series of insults by Royko only helps their cause. Greg Hunt, vice president of economic development for the Fox Cities Chamber of Commerce, said Royko's column introduced millions of readers to Fox Valley and let them know ``we are among the safest communities in the nation.'' In its promotional effort, the region compares itself with Chicago. One postcard shows a chalk outline on a sidewalk, depicting a Chicago murder victim, compared with a chalk outline of a hopscotch game in the tranquil Fox Valley towns. The implication brought a stinging attack from Royko in his column in Wednesday's Chicago Tribune. ``Most of the cheeseheads are fine citizens, content to chomp on a bratwurst, burp, yank on the underside of a cow and wear long red underwear to formal social events,'' the Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist wrote. ``There's nothing wrong with long red underwear, but up there they wear it as an outer garment.'' Royko wrote that people in Fond du Lac, a community in the Fox Valley, ``appear so tranquil that their eyes are glazed, their jaws hang slackly and a few drooled.'' Fox Valley Marketing Inc., a business development group, sent a series of postcards to about 500 paper-related buinesses in the Chicago area. About a dozen businesses have made inquiries. The cards maintained that Fox Valley has many advantages over Chicago: faster-moving traffic, a more productive work force, cheaper energy, safer streets, better industrial sites and more affordable housing. Royko, a sharp-tongued defender of Chicago, didn't like the postcards, but he gingerly confessed it was silly to get angry. ``Like it or not, crime has a role in our history. Countless movies and TV drama have been made about Chicago's gangsters. That's all part of our image. And while we might not be happy with it, when was the last time you saw a hit movie about a Wisconsin farmer kissing his cow?'' he asked.

DOC.HEAD: From Defiance to Surrender: Noriega's Final Two Weeks in Panama
With PM-Noriega, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a look at Noriega's life in Panama since Dec. 19, based on news reports and information released by the U.S. Southern Command from interviews with Noriega associates:

DEC. 19 _ President Bush orders U.S. troops into combat in Panama City on a mission to seize Panamanian dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega to face federal drug charges in United States. Noriega, aware of increased U.S. military activity, goes to Colon, 50 miles north of Panama City, to inspect a new military facility. Seven hours before the invasion he visits a Panamanian Defense Forces officers' club on the military side of the international airport. DEC. 20 _ American forces attack and announce within hours they have smashed Noriega's forces. Noriega flees the club when the airport is attacked and eludes American troops by driving around Panama City in circles. He avoids contact with PDF forces, fearing a trap, and does not take charge of his troops in the fighting. In a radio broadcast recorded in advance, he tells Panamanians: ``We are in trench warfare now and we will maintain the resistance. ... Our slogan is to win or die _ not one step back.'' DEC. 21 _ Bush says U.S. forces will scour Panama for ``as long as it takes'' to capture Noriega. An ``agitated'' Noriega spends several days at different locations but most of the time is at the home of a relative of Marcella Tason, his personal secretary. While in hiding he considers but rules out fleeing to the mountains. He also was believed to have contemplated going to Cuba's embassy, but backed off because that compound was surrounded by U.S. troops. DEC. 24 _ Noriega ends up in the house of the mother of his mistress, Vicky Amado. Reports say her teen-age daughter called the information number set up to take tips on finding Noriega and that the 82nd Airborne Delta Force sent a five-man team to seize him but missed him by 30 minutes. Noriega contacts the Vatican Embassy and within a few hours a rendezvous is arranged and a representative of the Embassy picks Noriega up at a Panama City Dairy Queen and drives him to the nunciature, according to some reports. Other reports said Noriega drove to the Vatican after learning of the surrender of one of his closest commanders, Luis del Cid. The Bush administration demands he be turned over to face drug charges and intense negotiations involving the Vatican, U.S. government and new Panamanian government ensue. DEC. 25-JAN. 2 _ Noriega stays in Vatican Embassy with minimal hospitality, living in a small room on the second floor with no telephone, a broken TV set and a Bible. JAN. 3 _ After being assured he would not face the death penalty in the United States, Noriega decides to surrender. He asks only that he be permitted a few phone calls, including one to his wife in the Cuban Embassy, that he be permitted to wear his uniform, and that his surrender be kept secret until it was done. He leaves the Vatican Embassy and surrenders to U.S. authorities. JAN. 4 _ Plane carrying Noriega arrives at Homestead Air Force Base in Florida. At an arraignment in U.S. District Court in Miami, Noriega maintains he was a political prisoner. A judge enters an innocent plea on Noriega's behalf after Noriega refuses to enter a plea to drug-trafficking charges.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Noriega-Kingpins
DOC.TEXT: Here are some of the major figures sent here in recent months to face drug charges: _ Luis Arce Gomez, a colonel dubbed ``the minister of cocaine'' while serving as Bolivia's Interior Minister in 1980-81. Arrested by Bolivian authorities Dec. 10 and turned over to face a 1983 cocaine conspiracy indictment by a Miami grand jury that alleged he charged traffickers protection money. Arraigned on Wednesday. Being held without bond in a federal prison south of here. A 1983 U.S. effort to extradite him from Argentina failed when he was released from custody there. _ Eduardo Martinez Romero, 36, a reputed financial wizard behind the Medellin cocaine cartel. Flown to Atlanta on Sept. 6, the first person extradited from Colombia in its current crackdown. Being held in isolation at the federal penitentiary in Atlanta to face federal charges there he laundered $1.2 billion in drug money. _ Jose Rafael Abello-Silva, 35, flown to Tulsa, Okla., after his Oct. 29 extradition from Colombia. First indicted in 1987. A federal grand jury in Tulsa this week handed down an amended indictment tying him to cocaine conspiracies with reputed Colombian cocaine kingpins _ Pablo Escobar-Gaviria, Jorge Ochoa-Vasquez and the late Jose Gonzalo Rodriguez-Gacha. Assistant U.S. Attorney David O'Meilia said in Tulsa that Abello is the ``most significant'' defendant in American custody linked to the cartel. _ Victor Eduardo Mera-Mosquera, 36, a convicted cocaine smuggler. Turned over to U.S. marshals by Colombian authorities Dec. 24 and flown to New York. Mistakenly released from federal detention in New York and fled to Colombia before his trial in 1984. Convicted in absentia of drug conspiracy and distribution, and faces up to 30 years in prison. Faces trial on a subsequent charge of co-directing the U.S. operations of a continuing drug enterprise that smuggled more than 2,200 pounds of cocaine into the United States. _ Guillermo Juan Bueno Delgado, 54, a Colombian hotel owner and investor flown to Tallahassee on Nov. 4. Faces 1985 cocaine indictments in Florida, California and Illinois alleging involvement in cocaine conspiracies. _ Roberto Peter Carlini-Arrico, 38, taken from Colombia to Orlando on Oct. 14 to face 1986 federal and state charges of racketeering and conspiracy alleging he helped smuggle more than a ton of cocaine into the United States. Pleaded guilty Wednesday to federal smuggling count but still faces the state charges. _ Bernardo Pelaez Roldan, taken to Detroit on Oct. 14. Convicted in absentia there in 1984 on conspiracy to possess cocaine with intent to distribute. _ Ana Rodriguez de Tamayo, 50, a Colombian taken to Miami on Oct. 14. Co-defendant of Arce Gomez on the 1983 charges. Pleaded guilty Tuesday to conspiracy to import cocaine. _ Luis Del Cid, a former Panama Defense Forces captain described as Noriega's right-hand man. Surrendered to U.S. forces in Panama on Dec. 25 and faces charges here in the Noriega indictment. Also brought here since the U.S. invasion was a Panamanian pilot, Daniel Miranda, who is a Noriega co-defendant, and a federal investigator said another Panamanian co-defendant, Eduardo Pardo, was arrested Wednesday in Panama. In 1987, U.S. authorities were delighted by the extradition of Colombian cocaine kingpin Carlos Lehder Rivas, taken to the United States on Feb. 4, 1987, after a shootout at a jungle hideout. After a federal trial in Jacksonville, Lehder, 40, was convicted of conspiracy, cocaine importation, operating a continuing criminal enterprise and eight counts of possession of cocaine with intent to distribute. Sentenced in 1988 to life in prison without the possibility of parole, plus 135 years. Being held in the federal prison in Marion, Ill.

DOC.HEAD: Summary of Charges Against Manuel Antonio Noriega
With PM-Noriega, Bjt and PM-Noriega-Indictment Text
DOC.TEXT: Manuel Antonio Noriega was named in drug-trafficking indictments unsealed Feb. 5, 1988. An indictment in Miami alleges that after he took control of Panama in 1983, Noriega ``utilized his official positions to provide protection for international criminal narcotics traffickers,'' including the Medellin cartel. The cartel is said to be responsible for 80 percent of the cocaine reaching the United States. Fifteen other people also face charges in the case, and proceedings have already begun against four of them. The indictment charges Noriega with 12 counts of conspiracy, racketeering, importing drugs and traveling to further the conspiracy. Specifically, it accuses him of: _ Accepting a $4.6 million bribe from Colombia's Medellin cartel to protect shipments of cocaine, launder money, supply drug laboratories and shield drug traffickers from the law. _ Allowing smugglers to use Panama as a way station for U.S.-bound cocaine. _ Using his official positions before and after he took power in 1983 to provide protection for international narcotics traffickers. _ Arranging for the shipment of cocaine processing chemicals, including those seized by Panamanian police. _ Laundering cartel narcotics proceeds in Panamanian banks. _ Allowing cartel leaders to shift operations to Panama to escape a crackdown in Colombia after the assassination of that country's anti-drug minister of justice. _ Traveling to Havana so Cuban President Fidel Castro could mediate a dispute with the Medellin cartel after Panamanian troops seized a drug laboratory that Noriega had been paid to protect. Noriega could receive up to 145 years in prison and more than $1.1 million in fines if convicted of all charges. A grand jury in Tampa also indicted Noriega on three counts of marijuana trafficking. The Justice Department has said that Noriega would be tried in Miami first because the case against him there is stronger.

DOC.HEAD: List of Potential Obstacles to Noriega Prosecution
With PM-Noriega, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief look at some legal issues that could be raised by the defense for Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega in proceedings on drug trafficking charges: _ The defense could try to force the government to drop charges by seeking court disclosure of classified information pertaining to Noriega's relationship with the CIA. _ Pretrial publicity nationwide could make it difficult to assemble an unbiased jury. _ Evidence seized during the military invasion of Panama could be subject to exclusion if the warrantless search violates Noriega's Fourth Amendment rights. _ The arrest and transportation of Noriega could have violated U.S. law and provisions of both the Panama Canal Treaty and the Geneva Convention. _ The court could lack jurisdiction because Noriega could be considered a political prisoner brought to the United States illegally. _ The case could be dismissed if the court finds Noriega is being selectively prosecuted to force him into concessions on control of the Panama Canal and the governing of Panama. _ Noriega could be immune from prosecution if courts recognized his stature as de facto head of state of Panama. The judge in the case has already rejected this argument but it is subject to appeal.

DOC.HEAD: Some of Noriega's Comments
With PM-Noriega, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are some comments made by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega about his and Panama's relationship to the United States:

``The humble, the poor and the blacks, they are the utmost authority of the people.'' _ Noriega speaking of his humble origins while characterizing his opponents, the ``rabi-blancos'' or ``white butts,'' as rich and white.

``A man is not the problem. The problem is Panama's canal and the presence of a foreign army in our territory.'' _ Noriega, in March 1988, claiming the United States was behind his nation's unrest and rejecting calls to step down.

``This machete says, `Not one step back! ... This is the machete of Panamanian dignity, of Panamanian valor.'' _ Noriega, in April 1988, addressing a meeting of 300 Latin American labor leaders, waving a machete and vowing keep fighting U.S. efforts to oust him.

``There cannot be conversation if the (U.S.) aggression continues, aggression at whatever level, whatever magnitude, whether it is psychological or economic aggression.'' _ Noriega, on May 21, 1988, saying he wants recognition of his hand-picked provisional president and a reduction of U.S. forces in Panama before he agrees to end his standoff with Washington.

``Pardon the ignorance but we cannot understand how these rich candidates in the United States don't use the flag to solve the problems of the blacks in New York, of the poorer classes, of the minorities, of those who have no heat, of the foreigners. ... Those are pretty themes for democracies.'' _ Noriega, in May 1988, complaining about his role as campaign fodder for American presidential candidates.
``A commander doesn't abandon his ship in stormy weather.'' _ Noriega responding to questions about whether he would step down in the face of pressure from the United States, May 1988.
``The gringo piranhas want to do away with me.'' _ Noriega, blaming the United States for the failed coup attempt in October 1989.
``I was unarmed during this time. ... I'm a man of peace. I fire on my enemies, not against my brothers.'' _ Noriega, after unsuccessful coup attempt in October 1989.

``We are in trench warfare now and we will maintain the resistance. ... We ask the world for help, with men, dignity and strength. ... Our slogan is to win or die, not one step back, and onward in the step of conquerers.'' _ Noriega in radio broadcast after American troops arrived Dec. 20.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Propose Cutting Energy-Saving Programs, Sources Say
DOC.TEXT: President Bush plans to cut four energy conservation programs by 85 percent next year, sources say, a proposal critics say would belie stated administration concerns about the environment. In the fiscal 1991 budget the president unveils Jan. 29, Bush will propose spending $30 million on the programs, the sources said Thursday. This compares to $200 million the programs are pegged at this year. Chief among the victims will be the $161 million weatherization program, under which the government supplies poor families with insulation, weather stripping and other energy-saving materials. Also slashed will be a program that will distribute $25 million this year to save energy in schools and hospitals; one that will spend $10 million to help states publicize conservation measures such as van pooling; and another budgeted at $4 million that assists states in providing energy-saving counseling to businesses and individuals. Spokesman Roger Meyer of the Department of Energy, which administers the programs, and spokeswoman Dede Spitznagel of the Office of Management and Budget, which draws up the budget, declined to comment. But lobbyists who support the programs criticized the proposal. ``If this is true, it would be remarkable that a president who's concerned about energy conservation and global warming would ignore a program offering serious conservation potential,'' said Meg Power, lobbyist for the National Community Action Foundation, which supports programs for poor people. The Department of Energy claims that from the weatherization program's start in 1977 through 1988, it paid for the weatherproofing of 1.8 million American homes, saving an equivalent of 4.5 million barrels of oil annually. The department says that between 1978 and 1988, the program that helps conserve energy at schools and hospitals disbursed 22,413 grants worth more than $700 million and saving $1.9 billion in energy costs. Jeffrey Genzer, counsel to the National Association of State Energy Officials, noted the programs were favorite budget-slashing targets of former President Reagan. When he presented his first budget to Congress last year, Bush proposed eliminating federal spending on them. ``What we hoped for was this president would be turning the tide of the last few years and trying to support energy efficiency,'' Genzer said. ``If these numbers are correct, that wouldn't be consistent with that view.'' Bush, who has pledged to make environmental concerns a priority of his presidency, signed a proclamation Wednesday designating April 22 as the 20th annual Earth Day. He said the day ``should inspire us to save the land we love, to realize that global problems do have local solutions, and to make preservation of the planet a personal commitment.'' For the 1991 fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1, the Gramm-Rudman deficit reduction law requires that the president submit a budget with a shortfall of no more than $64 billion. Budget experts believe this means Bush must find about $40 billion in savings in his $1.2 trillion budget. The two sources, who spoke on condition they not be identified, said they were not certain how the $30 million would be spent among the four programs. But one said it was likely the money would be distributed in the same proportions by which it is now spent. Sources said previously that Bush also will propose cutting from $1.4 billion to $1.05 billion another program that subsidizes the home heating bills of about 6.1 million low-income American households.

DOC.HEAD: Romania's Freed Press Digs Out Horrors of Ceausescu's Rule
With PM-Romania, Bjt
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Two days before he was ousted, Nicolae Ceausescu, the ``best son of Romania,'' held the limelight in the state-run press. The newspapers Dec. 20 published 12 photographs of him on a state visit to Iran. Three days after the dictator and his wife, Elena, were executed on Christmas Day, the daily newspaper Truth published its first anti-Ceausescu cartoon, a ``Report From Hell,'' which showed the former first couple in a boiling cauldron. ``We protest!'' shrieks Elena. ``We want to boil only in a golden cauldron!'' The press has been using its new freedom with a vengeance, informing Romanians each day of more excesses committed by the reviled Ceausescus. On Dec. 26, Truth began serializing excerpts from ``Red Horizons,'' the memoirs of former counterintelligence chief Ion Pacepa, who defected to the United States in 1978. In his book, published in the West two years ago, Pacepa chronicled how Ceausescu and other Romanians tried to steal Western technological secrets and recruit Jimmy Carter's brother as an ``agent d'influence,'' or spied on Romanians abroad and at home, sending and executing death threats. Elena Ceausescu was portrayed as a domineering, crude woman who relished listening to tapes secretly made each week at her children's apartments and the homes of top officials. ``What can be read in the pages of this book appears to be the fruit of a sick fantasy and yet, every word is true,'' Truth said as it introduced the Pacepa excerpts to Romanians. ``The publication of this book played an uncontested role in revealing in all its hideousness the true face of a dictatorship which with diabolical cunningness had managed at the outset to outfox a part of the world,'' the newspaper said. The United States and other Western powers originally cultivated Ceausescu for his relatively independent foreign policy within the Warsaw Pact, moving away only when Ceausescu's rule grew harsher and other Pact countries began to reform in the mid-1980s. The personality cult Ceausescu built during his 24-year rule took on the trappings of worship and pervaded practically all aspects of public life. His portrait lined the streets in Bucharest and other Romanian cities. Now, the leader formerly called the ``genius of the Carpathians,'' the ``hero among heroes'' and the ``founder of a new country'' is called ``Romania's No. 1 terrorist,'' a ``paranoid'' and a ``Doberman,'' an allusion to pets he reportedly fed with imported meat. His portraits and books have been burned by angry Romanians who suffered widespread food and energy shortages and were spied upon by the Securitate, Ceausescu's secret police. ``He called himself with the most abject impudence `the most beloved and esteemed,' but he talked like the illiterate peasants from the beginning of this century,'' Ion Marin wrote in Truth in an editorial titled ``Vipers.'' Mrs. Ceausescu, the second-most powerful person in the country, ``added to her name the title of scientist of `world repute,' but she omitted to say that she could not write and she could hardly read at all,'' Marin said. Elena, whose official title was ``Academician Dr. Eng. Elena Ceausescu,'' was trained as a chemist, but officials said privately even while she was in power that her title was merely political. Truth on Thursday published Elena's school records and marks, showing that she dropped out of school, like Ceausescu, after the fourth grade. In other recent articles and editorials, Romania's avid readers learned that: _ Thousands of women died seeking abortions over the past few years due to woefully inadequate medical conditions linked to Ceausescu's near-ban on abortions. Ceausescu decreed the virtual abortion ban to encourage procreation. Roamania's new interim government swiftly lifted the law. _ Mrs. Ceausescu had deposited in savings the equivalent of $130,000 at the official rate of exchange for her daughter and each of her two sons. _ She canceled Romania's subscriptions to international news agencies to save $75,000 annually and stopped delivery of all foreign newspapers to keep Romanians isolated, according to the official news agency Rompres. _ Ceausescu's obsession with being photographed cost the country $28 million. All the pictures were heavily retouched so he would look younger. As soon as Ceausescu was overthrown Dec. 22, Agerpres abolished censorship and pledged to inform subscribers in Romania and abroad ``in an honest and civilized way.'' On Jan. 2, the facelift was completed with a name change. Agerpres, an acronym for Agentia Romana de Presa _ Romanian Press Agency _ now is Rompres. Aside from the desire to break with Ceausescu's era, the name change may have been prompted by a desire to get rid of unkind jokes. ``Ager'' in Romanian means quick, or quick-witted _ a description that always gave Romanian and foreign journalists a laugh when applied to Ceausescu's docile news agency.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Noriega's Gone, Now Comes the Hard Part
DOC.TEXT: Manuel Antonio Noriega is in U.S. hands and President Bush is claiming total victory for his Panama gamble. Now comes the hard part. Ahead lies the unglamorous task of helping Panama, staggered by sanctions and Stealth fighter bombs, restore its once-vibrant economy. Panama has been in a steep economic decline for more than two years, partly the result of the punitive sanctions imposed by the United States in its campaign to oust Noriega. Beyond that is the cost of the U.S. invasion of Panama which, according to some estimates, dealt a $2 billion blow to the economy. Entire neighborhoods were leveled and scores of businesses were wiped out because of looting. The Reagan administration had systematically dismantled a host of programs designed to increase Panama's exports and to attract U.S. investment. Partly as a result, Panama's per capita income has dropped from $2,000 a year to between $1,600 and $1,700. Reversing the decline won't be easy. Panama is burdened by a foreign debt listed at $543 million. Fresh money from the United States, aside from emergency relief, is not in the offing because just about all the foreign aid money is already earmarked by Congress. The administration doesn't have the authority to help Panama by taking funds from another aid recipient. The United States can restore the trade and investment benefits but the impact is not expected to be felt for some time. At least Panama's new government can count on the $370 million in assets which were frozen by the U.S. government last year and which now are being unfrozen. Also, the capital flight that took place under Noriega has been reversed since the invasion. For a time, Bush will be able to bask in victory. Americans in Panama, who walked the country's streets in fear just weeks ago, are now being regaled as heroes, particularly the troops who helped force Noriega into humiliating exile. The international protests over the U.S. invasion, reflected in votes cast at the United Nations and the Organization of American States, have been displaced somewhat by the outpouring of popular support shown for the U.S. action by the Panamanian people. In a country accustomed to military domination, rarely have the prospects for civilian rule been brighter. U.S. officials have reason to hope that the United States will be able to turn over the Panama Canal to a stable, democratic government at the end of the century when U.S. control over the waterway ends, according to treaty obligations. Still, the pitfalls are many. For one thing, Panama's democratic roots are shallow. The last time Panama had an unambiguously fair election was 1968. The winner was dumped by the military after 11 days in office. The expectations of the Panamanian people are running dangerously high, and the country's embrace of the United States could turn to wrath if, over time, the aspirations for a better life are unfulfilled. The United States is insisting that Panama needs a strong defense force to replace the one _ now decimated _ that Noriega led. U.S. officials reason that a weak military would not be able to defend the canal adequately, but some Panamanians are worried that a powerful successor defense establishment would, like the one run by Noriega, dominate the country's political life. Perhaps inevitably, the invasion produced tragic loss of innocent lives; an estimated 300 Panamanian civilians are believed dead. And the heat of battle produced some decisions that came under widespread criticism. There was the controversy over the communications techniques of the U.S. military _ the playing of boom-box music through stereo speakers in a bid to thwart suspected eavesdroppers and perhaps to drive Noriega out of his Vatican Embassy sanctuary. Under Vatican pressure, the soldiers threw in the towel and agreed to silence the din after a few days. Wednesday night it was Noriega who threw in the towel. For all its problems, Panama's prospects seem better than his.
EDITOR'S NOTE: George Gedda has covered foreign affairs for The Associated Press since 1968.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: The weight of office off his shoulders, Ed Koch now simply wants to take off weight. Just four days out of City Hall, the porky former mayor presented himself Thursday as the new pitchman for a weight-loss powder, unabashedly touting its reputed benefits and his own overstuffed profile. ``I know I'm fat,'' he said. ``I can tell you how I know I'm fat. I see myself in the mirror, naked. Horrible.'' Koch's fatness is not news to New Yorkers, whom the mayor entertained with a series of celebrated and unsuccessful diets during his 12 years in power. Standing 6-foot-1, he gained 44 pounds in office, to 244 now. Cash is the new ingredient in his effort to drop 30 or 40 pounds. Free from the strictures of government ethics, Koch, 65, has agreed to have his Ultra Slim-Fast weight-loss program documented in television and print ads. ``Obviously I'm promoting this and I will be paid, there's no question about that,'' he told reporters. ``There's nothing wrong with that. We live in a capitalist society.''

Billy Joel says he feels like part of his family has been taken when others claim ownership of his songs. Joel told Rolling Stone magazine in the Jan. 9 issue that he's ``not all that rich'' and may, in fact, owe money. The 40-year-old singer is touring and has just released ``Storm Front,'' his most successful album in a decade, but he said copyright disputes over some of his past songs have made his financial status questionable. ``For better or worse, your songs are your kids. Then somebody comes along and tells you that they're not your kids anymore. The bank is going to take your kid,'' he said. He said part of the problem is that artists are ``knuckleheads when it comes to business. Money isn't why I did what I've done with my life. I did what I did because it made me happy. But I'm tired of getting it taken away from me by other people who haven't earned it.'' Meanwhile, he says people too often misunderstand his relationship with his wife, supermodel Christie Brinkley, ``as if somehow Christie and I don't love and hurt and feel the same things that anybody else does.'' ``What do they think we do _ walk in the door and fly around on gossamer and glitzy gliders? Don't people realize that the minute the door closes, all of the silly rock star-supermodel stuff goes right out the window? Then it's just me and her and real man-and-wife time,'' Joel said.

In a first for television, the title sequence for the new Shadoe Stevens adventure series ``Max Monroe: Loose Cannon'' has been turned into a music video that will soon be seen on MTV. The music video uses the hit single ``Tied Up'' by the popular European group Yello. The video features Stevens and co-star Bruce Young along with Yello members Boris Blank and Dieter Meier. ``I'm one of Yello's biggest fans. Yello is inventive, experimental, intelligent and has the sound of the '90s,'' said Stevens, who is also host of the radio show ``American Top 40.'' Parts of the video will be seen each week during the title sequence of the one-hour CBS-TV series premiering tonight. Stevens stars as the unconventional police detective who will do anything, no matter how wild, in the pursuit of a criminal suspect.

Gabonese President Omar Bongo, offering cash and an assortment of traditional gifts, married the daughter of the president of the neighboring Congo. State radio said the marriage of Bongo and Edith Sassou Nguesso, a 27-year-old doctor, took place in a family ceremony in Oyo, the home village of President Denis Sassou Nguesso about 250 miles north of Brazzaville. Bongo, 54, who has three children from a previous marriage, offered about $170 to the families of his new wife's father and mother, along with two pieces of fabric, a headscarf, a men's suit, a pair of women's shoes, a shovel and a hoe. In August, when rumors of the marriage began to circulate, Bongo refused to confirm or deny them. ``People should stop concerning themselves with something that's none of their business,'' said Bongo, who has been president of Gabon, a country of 1.5 million on Africa's West Coast, since 1967.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Can Get a Fair Trial, Experts Say
DOC.TEXT: Here are some questions and answers on the legal situation surrounding former Panamanian dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega, who surrendered to U.S. authorities and now faces trial on drug-smuggling charges. The answers were distilled from interviews with experts, including two professors specializing in international law and the American legal system, and a lawyer in international practice. Q. Can Noriega get a fair trial? A. The courts will say he can. What's the alternative? Are we supposed to say that someone's notoriety prevents him from ever being brought to justice? The question is not whether people have reached any conclusions or have any impressions in the case, but whether they can put aside their impressions or opinions to judge guilt or innocence. Q. President Bush has called Norega a thug; other officials have had equally harsh assessments. Can a jury be found that is not affected by these characterizations? A. The emotions will quiet down by the time the case comes to trial, which may be a year or a year and a half or more. People will forget. The judge in the Oliver North trial was able to seat a jury that claimed to not have seen, heard or read about North's televised testimony in Congress. Q. Will the manner of bringing him to this country cause problems? A. This is a matter of controversy. One expert said whatever international law problems are raised, once the government has custody of someone it doesn't matter how it obtained custody, so long as he gets due process from now on. Q. What are the biggest problems in bringing Noriega to trial? A. Another expert questioned the legality of Noriega's apprehension. Under federal law, there will be the issue of whether or not Noriega's property was reasonably seized and searched. Under international law the problem will be whether the terms of the 1904 extradition treaty between the United States and Panama were properly adhered to and whether the Panama constitution itself was violated. Other problems under international law go to the issue of whether the U.S. armed forces have the right to apprehend a fugitive from American justice in another country without the express consent of the foreign government. Without detailed information, lawyers presume the Endara government consented. Q. If you were his defense lawyer, what would be your tactic? A. You would want to attack the credibility of government witnesses as hard as possible. Based on what we know, all or many of them appear to be drug dealers or people with long criminal records. You want to pound away as much as possible on the idea that you can't convict anyone on testimony from such shaky and shabby people. Q. Will the military activities that brought about Noriega's surrender be a continuing factor? A. This is an area that is a mine field, where the United States is really flirting with serious violations of international law and risking being branded an international lawbreaker and exposing Americans in the future to be targets of kidnappings. But he volunteered to come out of the Vatican Embassy and surrender himself to Drug Enforcement Administration agents and put himself voluntarily into the hands of the American law enforcement and criminal justice system. Q. What are the biggest issues facing prosecutors? A. The indictment is a year old and reflects events that happened a long time ago. There may be some problems with evidence and with witnesses. Another possible major roadblock will be maneuvering by Noriega's lawyers to subpoena documents, government officials including possibly even the president of the United States. Q. Won't the way evidence was obtained in Panama, breaking into Noriega's residence, be a problem for prosecutors? A. The U.S. attorney in Florida claims he has enough evidence in Florida to successfully prosecute Noriega and does not need the documentary evidence seized in Panama. He presumably would not have brought the indictments in the first place unless he had already compiled sufficient evidence. Q. What happens to Noriega if he is acquitted? A. The issue will be raised, shall he be extradited to Panama or deported as an undesirable alien, in which case he would have to find a country that will take him _ possibly Cuba or Nicaragua. He could also face charges in Panama regardless of whether he is convicted in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Historian Warns That East-West Euphoria Has Evaporated Before
DOC.TEXT: A new peace group formed in the euphoria over democratic movements in Eastern Europe is being warned by an old-timer in its ranks that upheaval in the communist bloc does not mean the cold war is over. ``There will be very, very tough times ahead for a peace movement and for all Americans,'' said James McGregor Burns, the historian who won the Pulitzer Prize nearly two decades ago for a biography of Franklin Delano Roosevelt. ``The cold war, in my view, is not over,'' Burns, a fellow of the Humanities Center of Williams College, said at a news conference Thursday announcing formation of the Committee on Common Security. ``There is a residue in the Soviet Union of bitter feeling against this country and there is a residue in this country of people who feel equally bitterly toward the Soviet Union,'' the 71-year-old historian cautioned. ``I lived through a period, namely World War II, when we were equally euphoric about the future of Soviet-American relationships,'' Burns said. ``Within one year of the ending of World War II, that partnership was dissolved.'' ``Once there are setbacks, and there will be many setbacks, there will be recrimination, there will be defeatism, there will be a falling away from the peace movement, people will give up the fight,'' he said. Burns told reporters, however, that the new committee ``plans to persist, and will be there during the bleak times ... as well as the very euphoric moments.'' A principal objective of the committee, a project of the Institute for Peace and International Security of Cambridge, Mass., will be directing spending from military to civilian purposes. In contrast to Burns' view, George Rathjens, a professor of political science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who wrote the first study paper issued by the new committee, said, ``I start with the thesis that the cold war really is over.'' The Rathjens paper calls for establishment of a joint panel by the House and Senate committees on armed services and foreign affairs to study U.S. military commitments. It says Congress should ``begin at zero and build upward within the context of findings made by the special joint committee.'' Rathjens argued that the United States should scrap attempts to improve delivery of nuclear weapons against the Soviet Union, ``put them on ice and get rid of a lot of those weapons, put them in mothballs if you like.'' ``We can reject all efforts at strategic modernization at this time,'' he said. ``None of that is required.'' Rathjens said the international situation also justifies ``withdrawal of substantial numbers'' of troops from Europe. Marion Anderson, director of Employment Research Associates of Lansing, Mich., said her group, which studies defense spending, estimates the budget cuts suggested by Defense Secretary at $17 billion a year and ``we think the military budget can go down a great deal more.'' ``Just for starters, about $170 billion a year is being spent on NATO,'' she said. ``Why shouldn't that be pulled down by about 75 per cent. We're talking about real, real big money like cuts of around $100 billion.'' Gerald W. McEntee, president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employesl said the union will mobilize its lobbyists ``to provide some education, to provide some political heat, to provide some political clout to the members of Congress.'' Feminist author Betty Friedan predicted, ``There will be in the next months and within the year, an eruption of this political movement in this country, just as underneath the surface of stagnant communism, nobody could have predicted the formation'' of democratic movements in Eastern European countries. Paul F. Walker, co-director of the Institute for Peace and International Security, said the group plans to hold seminars around the country.

DOC.HEAD: Three-Month-Old Tot Was U.S. Army's Youngest `Prisoner'
With PM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Douglass is cq
DOC.TEXT: When U.S. troops stormed the home of a Panamanian military officer during last month's invasion, they found only his 3{-month-old son and a babysitter. ``In the end we were his captives,'' Lt. Col. Douglass Colbert, a chaplain, said Thursday of little Eloy Alberto Diaz. Eloy was sleeping at his home in the residential section of Fort Amador, a military installation shared by Panamanian and U.S. military forces, when U.S. Army soldiers broke in a few minutes after the invasion began early in the morning of Dec. 20. About 300 yards away Army units were fighting with a Panamanian military police company and American tanks had opened up on the nearby Panamanian Defense Forces headquarters. Eloy's father, Capt. Ramon Diaz, was commander of a special Panamanian anti-terrorist unit at Fort Amador as well as head of a detachment`in Veraguas, 150 miles west of Panama City. He surrendered. The boy's mother, Jeanette Vazquez de Diaz _ Miss Panama 1985 _ was at her mother's house at the time of the invasion. Colbert said that the morning after the assault, ``I saw this American soldier in full battle gear walking down the street with a baby bottle sterilizer under his arm. Behind him was this young woman with a baby. ``Later on, the soldiers came by the house with the baby and told me they did not know what to do with the baby. I told him we would take care of him. They brought him to the house,'' said Colbert, whose home is also in Fort Amador. Mrs. Diaz said she could not immediately get near the Amador area. ``It was two days later that someone called me to tell me that my baby was at the chaplain's home. I had been going crazy,'' she said. After two more days of worrying while she waited in refugee centers, Mrs. Diaz managed to contact Colbert and shortly afterward a military jeep took her to the chaplain's home. ``It was a very teary meeting, as you can imagine,'' Colbert said. ``Everybody cried.'' Mother and baby spent Christmas in the Colbert house. ``The neighbors found out`about the baby and they brought gifts for him,'' Colbert said. ``He and his mother are now members of our family.'' Colbert said Capt. Diaz remains a prisoner at Fort Clayton, another U.S. military installation.

DOC.HEAD: Government Plotting Bacterial Attack on Salmonella
DOC.TEXT: Bacteria that are harmless to humans but deadly to salmonella are being tested as a way for food processors and packagers to eliminate a common cause of food-poisoning, the Agriculture Department says. ``It will take at least a year to grow the bacteria and test their performance as a natural control mechanism,'' said Richard Whiting, a research food technologist with the department's Agricultural Research Service. But he said this is the first time anyone has tried to use a predatory bacterium to ensure food safety. The bacteria are named B. bacteriovorous, B. starrii and B. stolpii. All are rod-shaped bacteria known as Bdellovibrio. They are common in soil and water and often swallowed by humans swimming in rivers, lakes or the ocean. Whiting said that under a microscope the predatory bacteria squeeze through the cell wall of salmonella and begin feeding, causing the salmonella to die in about 30 minutes. Studies will determine whether they can be commercially adapted as a spray to stop salmonella and other bacterial growth in meats, eggs and powdered milk during processing, said Whiting. They might also be added to packaged meats sold at grocery stores, he suggested. ``We're interested in how broad the Bdellovibrio's appetites are,'' said Whiting. But even if adapted for commercial use, Bdellovibrio should not be considered a replacement for current salmonella preventions such as good refrigeration and thoroughly cooking meat. ``I look at this as a form of insurance,'' he said of the discovery. The Agriculture Department estimates that illnesses caused by salmonella and other food-borne bacteria have a $1 billion to $10 billion economic impact through lost wages, decreased worker productivity, medical expenses, industry production losses and destruction of products.

An Agriculture Department scientist says he has`found hundreds of varieties of rice that repel weeds without the use of chemicals, says the department. ``Utilizing this natural defense could lead to a savings in herbicides and reduce the amount of chemicals a farmer uses,'' said Robert Dilday of USDA's Agricultural Research Service. He has identified 191 rice varieties with some ability to naturally repel the weed known as ducksalad, 132 varieties that fend off redstem, and 15 varieties that are resistant to both. He also found six types of rice that resist broadleaf signalgrass, a weed that competes for nutrients and sunlight. Dilday works at the research service's Rice Production and Weed Control Research Laboratory in Stuttgart, Ark. He said field tests have shown that weeds on average would not grow within five inches of the resistant rice plants.

A major soybean organization is pushing for a change in federal policy it says will make American farmers more competitive on the world soybean market. ``World markets are growing 3 percent to 5 percent yearly, but the United States is losing both soybean income, export volume and market share,'' Marlyn Jorgensen, president of the American Soybean Association, said Thursday. The United States is still the single largest producer of soybeans, but its lead is slipping. Foreign growers as a group now produce more than half the world crop, said Jorgensen's organization in a statement. ``If current trends continue, South America alone will outproduce and outsell the United States by the year 2000,'' said the ASA. Jorgensen blamed federal government soybean policies and suggested a change he said should be made part of the 1990 farm bill. He said his organization did not yet have a congressional sponsor for its proposal, but has been talking to Rep. Dan Glickman, D-Kan., chairman of the House Agriculture soybean subcommittee. An aide to Glickman said the proposal is ``one of several options'' being considered for the 1990 farm bill, but that it is too early to say whether it or any other will be adopted. The plan calls for _a voluntary loan program with rates set by a formula based on cotton and corn target prices, acreage reduction programs and traditional price ratios of soybeans and corn and cotton. _an equity payment equal to the difference between the adjusted county soybean loan rate and the posted county price for soybeans. _a graduated income support based on the level of soybean stocks. _the selling of crops rather than forfeiting them to the governmentn Jorgensen said that under the plan, farmers would make planting decisions based on market prices, not government support programs, but would also have government back-up if prices are too low. He said it also would prevent government stockpiling by encouraging farmers to go to market with their soybeans rather than forfeiting them to the government for benefits.
