DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press erroneously reported Wednesday that the cease-fire between Contra rebels and Nicaragua ended on Nov. 1, 1988. It ended on Nov. 1, 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Legal Experts Doubt Noriega Can Claim `Head of State' Immunity
With PM-Noriega, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Manuel Antonio Noriega's status as a deposed head of state probably won't do him any good in U.S. courts, legal specialists say. Although international lawyers disagree about whether Noriega could be prosecuted for his official acts, most say he can't claim immunity for common crimes _ such as drug-running _ that weren't part of his official duties. ``It's going to be hard for Noriega to say, `If it is true that I was trafficking drugs ... I did that pursuant to my responsibilities as head of state,''' said Bruce Zagaris, a Washington lawyer who co-chairs the American Bar Association's committee on international criminal law. Noriega's lawyers have suggested that he should be entitled to immunity because of his office. Earlier this week, one of his former attorneys, Neal Sonnett, said Noriega ``is entitled to `head of state immunity.''' But early last year, after Noriega was indicted, U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler ruled that the Panamanian leader had no grounds for such a claim because the State Department had never recognized his political legitimacy. And even if Noriega were considered a legitimate head of state, experts say he probably couldn't claim ``head of state immunity.'' ``First of all, it's not clear that there is such a thing,'' Columbia Law School professor Lori Fisler Damrosch said, ``although, as you might expect, several recently deposed heads of state did make such an argument.'' One was deposed Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos, whose case may offer the closest parallels to Noriega's. After he sought exile in Hawaii, Marcos claimed that the ``act of state doctrine'' gave him immunity to both civil lawsuits and criminal prosecution in the United States. The courts ruled against him. ``The doctrine,'' the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals said, ``is meant to facilitate the foreign relations of the United States, not to furnish the equivalent of sovereign immunity to a deposed leader.'' In other words, a deposed ruler might be granted immunity _ but only if the U.S. government considers it advantageous. In Noriega's case, as Ms. Damrosch said, ``the views of President Bush and the executive branch are quite clear.'' The Marcos case differs somewhat from Noriega's because Marcos was living in the United States when he was indicted and his alleged crimes were more closely related to his official duties. Legal experts were hard pressed to recall another case of a foreign leader being prosecuted outside his country. Most cited the war crimes trials after World War`II in which high German officials and Japan's prime minister, Hideki Tojo, were tried and convicted. But they stressed that such trials were extraordinary and provide no precedent for ordinary criminal prosecutions. One scholar, Alfred Rubin, a professor of international law at the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University, said the Noriega case reminds him of British prosecutions of Malay sultans in Southeast Asia in the 19th century. In the first such case, he said, a claimant to a sultan's throne was charged with piracy in 1840 after he intercepted British shipping in an effort to seize control of a Malay state. A jury ruled that the act was political, not criminal, and acquitted him. ``And so the British, sulking and mad, exiled him to the Seychelles,'' said Rubin, a strong critic of the Noriega prosecution. ``British history is full of all sorts of attempts at imperial domination, and we're just going through all their mistakes now.'' But even Rubin offers little comfort to Noriega when it comes to the ``head of state'' defense. ``As far as I know, there is no such doctrine,'' he said. ``I think it's been made up by the defense attorneys.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Postpones Meetings to Concentrate on Soviet Unrest
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev was reported Thursday night to have postponed all contacts with foreign leaders to concentrate on growing unrest in the Soviet Union. A spokesman for Britain's opposition Labor Party said the Soviet Ambassador in London, Leonid Zamyatin, had told party leader Neil Kinnock that Gorbachev was postponing all such meetings for the rest of the month. The news sent the Tokyo stock exchange tumbling 500 points, or about 1.5 percent, off the Nikkei average in early trading Friday. The Labor Party spokesman said Zamyatin delivered a personal message from Gorbachev to Kinnock, who had been scheduled to meet with the Soviet leader in Moscow for talks on Jan. 16. The message said the meeting had to be postponed because ``political events in the Soviet Union'' required Gorbachev's ``personal attention and participation,'' said the Labor spokesman, who in accordance with British practice declined to be identified. The latest unrest in the Soviet Union has involved Azerbaijani demonstrators on the Soviet-Iranian border trying to force open the frontier and reunite with their brethren in Iran. The KGB sent border troop reinforcements to the area Wednesday to stop protesters from smashing guard towers and security alarms. Also, Lithuanian Communist leaders met with Gorbachev on Thursday and said later that the Kremlin leader failed to sway them from their decision to split from the Soviet Communist Party and pursue local independence. Gorbachev has vigorously opposed the Lithuanians' decision, but the No. 2 party official in the Baltic republic said the president promised Thursday not to interfere.

DOC.HEAD: Nikkei Closes Down
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 38,274.76, down 438.12 points, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Sends `Nation-Building Forces' to Help Repair Panama
With PM-US-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: With the principle goal of Operation Just Cause met _ the capture of Manuel Antonio Noriega _ the U.S. focus is on repairing Panama's basic services and utilities destroyed or disrupted in the invasion. Call the troops landing in Panama ``nation-building forces,'' the Pentagon says. ``Civil affairs personnel ... people who provide police service and assistance to utilities and that kind of thing,'' Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams told reporters Thursday in describing the specialists sent to Panama. The number of U.S. servicemen in Panama stands at about 25,500, the same as it was shortly after the invasion, as combat troops are withdrawn and replaced by military police and civil affairs specialists, Williams said. ``So what you have is a change _ even though in some cases the numbers may stay roughly the same, you have a change in the complexion of the force,'' Williams said. Gen. Colin Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, arrived in Panama on Thursday to meet with Gen. Maxwell Thurman of the U.S. Southern Command and work out a timetable for withdrawal of the troops. Prior to the invasion on Dec. 20, about 12,000 U.S. troops were stationed in Panama to guard the canal under the terms of a treaty under`which the United States is to turn the waterway over to Panama in the year 1999. The civil affairs specialists include active and reserve, officers and enlisted men, bankers and garbage collectors. To date, about 140 reserves from around the country and about 110 active-duty specialists from the 96th Battalion at Fort Bragg, N.C., have been sent to Panama. About 25 of them arrived during the first 48 hours after the invasion. Their purpose, according to the Pentagon, is to help the Panamanians repair and restore basic public services such as telephone, water and electricity. A group of combat engineers is expected later with bulldozers to destroy what is left of the Commandancia, the headquarters of the Panamanian Defense Forces, said Pentagon spokesman Col. Miguel E. Monteverde. The specialists are similar to those who were sent to Japan and Germany following World War II. ``They are experts in government and municipal services,'' Monteverde said. During the briefing, Williams said fighting had all but ceased in Panama. In other developments, the Pentagon spokesman said one of Noriega's bodyguards overheard U.S. servicemen discussing the invasion hours before it occurred, but it was unclear whether the incident enabled the ousted Panamanian leader to evade the Americans. ``There is some evidence that some officials may have had some advance thought that this operation was about to happen. But there isn't a lot`of evidence that actions were taken as a result of that,'' Williams said. ``A bodyguard, during a debriefing interviewl said that two U.S. soldiers had been overheard discussing their positions for H-hour. And that supposedly happened at 10 p.m., three hours before the attack was to begin,'' said Williams. ``I have no other details.'' Noriega is believed to have escaped from one of his residences minutes`before a U.S. commando unit arrived just after midnight Dec. 20, and fled from house to house in Panama City in the days thereafter, according to military officials. Noriega found refuge in the Vatican Embassy on Dec. 24 and turned himself over to U.S. officials Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Very Low-Calorie Diets Dangerous in Wrong Hands, Doctors Say
LaserPhoto CX2
DOC.TEXT: Overweight people fighting the battle of the bulge can diet themselves to death in improperly supervised very-low-calorie programs that are used by more than a million Americans, doctors warned today. Such liquid diets require management by a specially trained physician, and by a behavioral psychologist and dietician, the doctors wrote in the Journal of the American Medical Association. Although the diets are ``unquestionably safer'' than their liquid-protein predecessors, which were blamed for at least 58 deaths during the 1970s, they still have dangers, said the article's authors. ``The recent and zealous marketing of various formula products to physicians, as well as the public's appetite for such diets, could lead to yet another round of complications and fatalities,'' wrote the doctors, who are from the University of Pennsylvania, Columbia University and Harvard Medical School. Very-low-calorie diets provide 400 to 800 calories daily through a high-protein powder. The dieter adds water or milk and drinks the liquid three to five times daily instead of eating food. After 12 to 16 weeks on the regimen, the dieter gradually resumes eating normal food. Such diets, like the Optifast program used by talk show host Oprah Winfrey in her celebrated 67-pound weight loss, should be avoided by people who need to lose less than 40 pounds or 30 percent of their body weight, said the authors, two of whom are consultants for the maker of Optifast. People with certain heart problems also shouldn't go on the diets, they said. Short-term health problems from the diets can include dehydration; an imbalance of electrolytes, the chemicals that carry electrical impulses sparking the heart to pump; inadequate blood pressure after standing or sitting up rapidly, which can cause fainting; and increased uric acid concentrations, which promote gout, the authors said. Long-term complications could include severe abnormalities in heartbeat _ the culprit in the liquid-protein-diet deaths _ especially by dieters who lose control and go on eating sprees during ``refeeding,'' the authors said. Such problems can be headed off early or prevented entirely with proper supervision, the authors said. In November, Ms. Winfrey announced on her show that she had regained 17 of the 67 pounds she lost a year earlier. But ``she has maintained 75 percent of her weight loss, which we consider to be consistent with an average patient going through the program,'' said Jim Parsons, a spokesman for Sandoznutrition Corp., which markets`the Optifast program. Intensive supervision is a requirement of the program, Parsons said Thursday in a telephone interview from Minneapolis. Optifast, which costs about $3,000 and requires at least a year's commitment by the patient, has been available since the mid-1970s and has been used by more than 600,000 patients, Parsons said. It contrasts sharply with products marketed directly to private physicians, with the promise of greatly increasing their`income, said Thomas A. Wadden, associate professor of psychiatry at the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine and co-author of the journal article. Wadden said as many as 12,000 doctors are now providing very-low-calorie diets as part of their outpatient practice. ``The problem is that`these persons are going to help their patients lose weight, but the patients are destined to regain the weight, because they have not learned to modify their eating, exercise and dietary habits,'' Wadden said. Liquid-protein diets of the 1970s used a poor-quality protein, while the newer diets use high-quality protein, plus vitamins and other nutrients, said Wadden. Similar programs have come under fire before. One program, Medifast, was called the ``Outrage of the Month'' in July by Public Citizen Health Research Groupn The Washington-based consumer watchdog group blasted Medifast's marketing company, Jason Pharmaceuticals Inc. of Timonium, Md., and its subsidiary`Research Institute of Maryland for telling physicians that enrolling 15 new patients a month could increase their profits by $62,000 annually. Patricia Kail, a spokeswoman for Medifast, said that ``was blown way out of proportion _ we don't go and say the physician can make `x' amount of dollars.'' She said the program has been used byM 400,000 patients during the past 10 years without any reports of deaths or serious complications.

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrators Cheer U.S. While Noriega Waits in Courthouse Cell
With PM-Noriega, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Most demonstrators outside Miami's federal courthouse cheered the United States for bringing Manuel Antonio Noriega to Florida, and those offering contrary`opinions were targets of angry shouting. As the fallen Panamanian dictator awaited his arraignment Thursday on a 1988 drug indictment, about 40 policemen and U.S. marshals watched over two groups of about 50 Panamanian exiles demonstrating outside and more than 100 journalists. ``No one will go until this thing is fixed,'' said Carlos Villarino, a spokesman for the Panamanian Refugee Center in Miami. He said he wanted Noriega to spend all of his possible sentence in a maximum-security jail, adding: ``I want him to have to ask permission to breathe. I want his dignity destroyed like he tried to destroy ours.'' A shouting match began when a group of about five exiles said the U.S. invasion violated Panama's sovereignty. The group called for newly installed President Guillermo Endara to hold free elections. ``We regret that (Noriega) was taken to the U.S. to face justice here,'' said Silvio Cordoba Quinonez. ``What happened to Panamanian justice? Are we nobody? Endara has to preserve our sovereignty.'' Jose Cepero, a Cuban-American who held a sign saying ``U.S. Hands`Off Panama,'' was surrounded by a mob of Panamanian exiles who tore the sign and shouted insults. ``Panama is a free country. The Panamanians should decide what should happen to Noriega,'' Cepero said as police escorted him to safety. Federal marshals secured the 10-story courthouse, using two-way radios, metal detectors, binoculars and weapons. Officers were stationed throughout the building, at all doors and in the streets outside while Noriega occupied a basement cell before his arraignment. ``Obviously they've increased security,'' said a receptionist for Daniel Horgan, chief U.S. marshal in Miami. ``But he won't make any comment.'' The receptionist refused to give her name. About 20 marshals _ about double the usual number _ guarded barricades at the prisoner entrance to the courthouse, and pedestrians were forced to walk on the other side of the street. Plainclothes marshals equipped with binoculars scanned the surrounding neighborhood from the roof throughout the day, instead of the normal twice-daily practice when prisoners are being moved in and out of the building. Hours before Noriega was to reach a ninth-floor courtroom, two airplanes flew overhead with banners saying ``Bye Bye, Tony'' and ``Rent This Ad When Fidel Falls,'' showing Cuban-American solidarity with Panamanians. Private security officers supplemented the radio-equipped marshals in the courthouse, and a half-dozen Miami police officers kept an eye on a growing array of news crews with satellite dishes and towers sprouting from their vans. Two Miami officers patrolled the front courthouse plaza where a few Panamanian exiles expressed support for the prosecution of Noriega. One woman wore a T-shirt with the words ``Noriega Enemy No. 1 of Panama,'' and a man's shirt read ``Democracy for Panama'' in Spanish.

DOC.HEAD: Ethics Committee Investigating Durenberger's Condo Deal
DOC.TEXT: The Senate ethics committee is widening its investigation of Sen. Dave Durenberger to examine a deal in which he made a profit by renting his Minneapolis condominium to himself. The Minnesota Republican disclosed the new area of investigation Thursday and also said he has asked the panel to determine whether it was proper for him and other senators to run non-profit organizations that raise money from special interest groups, he said. A think-tank Durenberger helped found is embroiled in allegations that the senator used the organization for political purposes. The ethics committee already was investigating allegations that Durenberger laundered speaking fees and used special interest groups to underwrite trips to Boston to visit his marriage counselor. Durenberger said in a telephone interview Thursday from Minneapolis that the committee decided at a meeting Dec. 21 to investigate real estate transactions he used from 1983 to 1987 to get reimbursed for stays in a condo in which he owned an interest. ``That's fine with me,'' Durenberger`said of the expanded investigation. ``I think it's logical that the ethics committee take on any issue in which there may not be a specific rule and help the Rules Committee give specific definition.'' The House bars its members from being reimbursed for staying in a home in which they own an interest, but the Senate does not. The ethics committee's staff director, Wilson Abney, declined to discuss its investigation. Durenberger sold his downtown Minneapolis condominium to a partnership, in which he was a member, and later to a company owned by his former campaign manager. In both instances, he continued to live there but used Senate funds to pay his rent. Durenberger collected at least $9,947 in living expense payments from the Senate from July 1983 to June 1987. Documents the senator provided to the Rules Committee on Dec. 22 disclosed that Durenberger signed back-dated real estate partnership documents to justify reimbursements for 1983. Durenberger signed the documents in mid-1984 and dated them July 1983 to reflect an oral agreement made in 1983 to form the partnership with a friend, Roger Scherer. Durenberger aides say the back-dating was proper since Durenberger and Scherer did make the agreement. Minnesota state Sen. William Luther, a Democrat, charged in his Dec. 28 complaint that Durenberger```may have committed serious violations of law (including violations of the Internal Revenue code) and Senate rules'' through the real estate transactions. Luther charged that Durenberger failed to disclose the partnership and income from Scherer to the Senate and that the partnership may have been a phony attempt to claim tax deductions available to landlords. The ethics committee hired a special counsel last fall to investigate accusations that Durenberger earned $100,000 in violation of Senate honoraria limits through a contract with a Minneapolis publisher. Durenberger on Thursday denied allegations that he used his think-tank, Americans for Generational Equity, for political purposes. He resigned as chairman of the once-controversial organization last month. AGE contended that working-age adults were being shortchanged by government help to the elderly. Paul Hewitt, a board member whom Durenberger ousted as executive director two years ago, claims Durenberger muzzled the organization's staff to avoid hurting his reelection campaign in 1988. Durenberger, who raised money for AGE from many of the same organizations that contributed to his campaign, denies the allegation.

DOC.HEAD: Provisional Gov't Seeks Closer Ties With Moscow
DOC.TEXT: Romania's provisional government is developing closer ties with Moscow than the Communist regime it replaced, welcoming Soviet offers of aid and expecting a productive visit by a top Soviet official. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze is to arrive in Bucharest on Saturday for the first consultations between the new government and the Kremlin since dictator Nicolae Ceausescu was toppled Dec. 22 and executed with his wife Elena on Christmas Day. Silviu Brucan, a top foreign policy official, said Thursday the new leadership had assurances from the Kremlin that Romania will get extensive assistance, including plentiful energy supplies for the harsh winter. Unlike other East European revolutions, which have pulled former satellite nations further`from Moscow, Romania's uprising appears to have strengthened what had been deteriorating relations between Moscow and Bucharest. Ceausescu had long pursued maverick foreign and trade policies. His refusal to follow the reforms of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev estranged Romania and the Soviet Union even more in recent years. ``From the Soviet Union, we expect massive assistance,'' said Brucan, a former ambassador to the United States. ``We have been promised from the top in Moscow that we will receive aid in oil and natural gas to help us overcome this difficult winter.'' Brucan did not say whether this would mean additions to the traditionally large energy supplies from the Soviet Union, paid for in latter years by Ceausescu`with food exports. Ceausescu used the energy largely for industry, imposing drastic curbs on heat and light consumption in freezing, dark homes and offices. Romania now is led by the National Salvation Front and one of its first acts was to lift the harsh decrees on energy saving. Soviet Embassy sources said another issue that is likely to come up during Shevardnadze's visit is the Soviet republic Moldavia, which consists largely of territory annexed in 1940 from Romania under a secret protocol to the Hitler-Stalin Pact. Moldavians, who speak the same language as Romanians but were forced to use the Cyrillic alphabet under Josef Stalin, want more independence from the Kremlin, raising speculation they may seek eventual reunification with Romania. Brucan glossed over questions on the issue, indicating the new leadership wants to avoid strains with Moscow now that the Soviets have expressed support for their revolution. While seeking aid from the Soviets, the new Romanian leaders are also cultivating ties with the West, severely damaged in recent years by Ceausescu's human rights policies and self-imposed isolation in international affairs. Otto Lambsdorff, former West`German Economics Minister and influential head of the Free Democrats`_ the junior partner in the Bonn government _ visited Bucharest Thursday to discuss economic aid. West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher and French Premier Roland Dumas are expected next week, Foreign Ministry spokesman Constantin Girbea said. Romania's new government has pledged to move the country toward democracy and to hold free elections in April. Meantime, it has overturned many of Ceausescu's most hated decrees, legalizing abortion, street demonstrations and free travel. Private property has been reinstated for peasants and the death penalty abolished. But many Romanians still are wary that the new leaders`have too many links with the old Communist party. Men like provisional President Ion Iliescu and Brucan rose under Communism to high positions, only to fall from Ceausescu's favor and spend years in political isolation. Brucan said the provisional government plans to present a new election law by the end of January. In a reversal of earlier declarations by the National Salvation Front, Brucan said the Front intends to field candidates in the planned April elections and will ``take part with all its might.'' The half-dozen parties that would also run say they lack the resources and the time for a fair contest against the Front, which controls the mass media. In another development Thursday, news reports said families whose homes were destroyed in fierce fighting in Bucharest after Ceausescu was overthrown will move into spacious apartments built for the late dictator's associates. The daily newspaper Truth, which replaced the Communist Party daily after the revolution, said 110 of the apartments built along the Boulevard of the Victory of Socialism, the dictator's pet project, will be turned over to homeless familiesn

DOC.HEAD: Government Stops Work on Massive Dam Project
DOC.TEXT: The government suspended work on a $1.17 billion dam project to persuade an environment activist to give up an 11-day-old hunger strike, news reports said. Sunderlal Bahaguna broke his fast after the government announced it was stopping construction work on the Tehri Dam, Press Trust of India news agency said Thursday. There was no indication if the government decision meant that the project would be scrapped. However, state-run television said Bahaguna would meet with Environment Minister Maneka Gandhi to discuss the dam, billed as the largest hydroelectric project in south Asia. The dam, 140 miles northeast of New Delhi on the Bhagirathi River, has been criticized by environmentalists and geological experts who say it is located in an unstable seismic zone and will inundate valuable forest and farmland. Bahaguna, who has been awarded the Magsaysay award for his efforts to protect the environment, has been an outspoken critic of the project. The dam is scheduled to be completed in 1996. Its reservoir is expected to displace 70,000 people, including 30,000 in the town of Tehri, which will be submerged.

DOC.HEAD: Death Toll in Bangladesh and India Tops 260
DOC.TEXT: The death toll in the cold wave chilling Bangladesh and northern India passed 260 with reports that 22 people died of exposure when temperatures plunged to 37 degrees. The latest victims, all in Bangladesh, were mostly homeless and impoverished people lacking shelter and adequate clothing. According to tallies from newspaper and news agency reports Thursday, at least 104 people in Bangladesh have died of exposure in the past three weeks. The death toll for the same period has reached 160 in neighboring India, according to news reports. Most of the deaths occurred among people sleeping on the ground in cities or in poor rural areas. The victims included a sadhu _ a Hindu holy man _ in the western state of Gujarat, the Times of India said. Sadhus wear little or no clothing as part of their way of forsaking worldly goods.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Senator Quits Law Firm Over Angolan Dealings
DOC.TEXT: Former Republican Sen. Paul Laxalt has announced that he is resigning from a law firm that recently drew fire from conservatives for representing the Marxist government of Angola. Laxalt will leave the firm of Laxalt, Washington, Perito and Dubuc to form his own company, according to Tom Loranger, his spokesman. ``The principal reason for leaving was that he wants his independence,'' Loranger said in announcing Laxalt's resignation Thursday. Loranger said Laxalt, a close friend of former President Reagan's, will remain as a senior counselor at Laxalt, Washington. Laxalt, who represented Nevada until he decided not to seek re-election in 1986, will form a new firm, The Paul Laxalt Group, that will specialize in government relations, Loranger said. Loranger said he could not comment on whether the law firm's decision to represent Angola played any role in Laxalt's leaving the firm. Conservative groups had criticized Laxalt, Washington for signed Angola as a client. ``We find it difficult to believe that someone who was so closely affiliated with Ronald Reagan would knowingly associate himself with such a repressive regime,'' said J. Barry Bitzer, executive director of the Conservative Alliance. In Angola, the United States supports the rebel group of Jonas Savimbi, which is fighting the Soviet-backed central government.
DOC.HEAD: First Lady Gets Second Dose of Radiation
DOC.TEXT: First lady Barbara Bush has undergone the second of 10 radiation treatments for eye irritation caused by her immune system disease. The 64-year-old first lady received the 10-minute radiation dose early Thursday at Walter Reed Army Medical Center. She suffered no aftereffects and returned to the White House for her normal daily activities, said her press secretary, Anna Perez. Mrs. Bush is undergoing 10 consecutive days of radiation treatments in an effort to eliminate swelling behind her eyes that has caused her double vision and tearing for months. The eye problem results from Graves disease, a condition in which the thyroid gland becomes overactive. The condition was diagnosed last winter, and an earlier radioactive treatment and drugs rendered the thyroid inactive. Treatment with a powerful steroid, prednisone, has failed to correct the eye disorder, so doctors are using low-intensity radiation aimed at swelling in the small muscles that control the eyes as the next therapy.
DOC.HEAD: Administration Rejected Recycling Tax
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration considered but rejected the idea of proposing new taxes on various materials in an effort to encourage recycling, an administration official says. The official, who spoke on condition he not be named, said Thursday that the proposal had been given a good chance of becoming part of the president's fiscal 1991 budget request to Congress but that it was finally rejected by the Office of Management and Budget. OMB Director Richard Darman stripped the proposed tax _ along with other so-called ``user fees'' _ to avoid charges from congressional Democrats that President Bush was violating his no-new-taxes pledge, the official said. The proposal would have imposed new taxes on paper, glass, plastic and metals that were not recycled. The Environmental Protection Agency, which favored the tax concept as a way of encouraging greater use of recycled materials by U.S. industry, wants to reduce the nation's output of waste by 25 percent by 1992. Bush, as part of his 1988 presidential campaign, promised to ``make a national commitment to reduce waste by recycling and developing technology that produces less waste.'' By making products made from virgin materials more expensive, supporters of the tax had argued it would encourage businesses to use more recycled materials.
DOC.HEAD: Agency, Watchdog Group Clash On Recall Performance
DOC.TEXT: A federal agency says it began a record number of investigations of possible automobile safety defects in 1989, but a consumer advocacy group charges that the ``phony numbers'' are ``a smoke screen.'' The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said Thursday that it launched 213 defect investigations last year, the highest number in its 20-year history. Additionally, the agency said it influenced a record 7 percent of the recalls ordered in 1989, when 6.7 million vehicles were recalled for safety problems. But the Center for Auto Safety, a watchdog group, accused the agency of reporting meaningless statistics to mask a poor performance. ``Those are phony numbers,'' said Clarence Ditlow, the center's executive director. ``What they're doing is creating a smoke screen to conceal from the public that they're not enforcing the mandatory recall law.'' The center repeatedly has complained that under the Reagan Administration, the agency abandoned investigations that should have produced recalls. The agency said it pursued recalls when needed but discontinued probes when it was plain there was no widespread safety problem. The agency should not boast of influencing the highest percentage of recalls ever when the number of recalls was well below those of the late 1970s, Ditlow said. Jeffrey Miller, deputy administrator of the National Highway Transportation Safety Administration, acknowledged that recalls rose in the late 1970s and fell in the early 1980s, but said both trends resulted largely from tire problems that were corrected. There was a steady upward trend in recalls in the late 1980s, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Commander Finds Solution To Crime: Coups
DOC.TEXT: The national police commander said today that coup attempts are an effective but unpalatable solution to Manila's crime problem. Maj. Gen. Ramon Montano said car thefts declined from seven a day to 1.5 per day after military mutineers launched a nine-day coup attempt Dec. 1. ``Frankly, crime went down last December,'' Montano told radio station DZRH. But he added, ``I don't like to propose the coup as a way of bringing down (crime). '' Montano did not explain how crime was reduced during the coup, in which 113 people were killed. Fighting was limited to a few scattered areas of this city of nearly 8 million people, but a state of emergency gave police more search-and-seizure authority.

DOC.HEAD: Countdown Underway for Monday Space Shuttle Launch
DOC.TEXT: The countdown was under way today for launching the space shuttle Columbia on a 10-day mission to deploy one satellite and rescue another. The clock began ticking at 4 p.m. Thursday when NASA test director Jim McKnight issued the traditional call to stations at the launch pad and in the control center. Liftoff is scheduled at 8:10 a.m. Monday for the first of a record 10 shuttle flights planned in 1990. Columbia's five astronauts were to fly to Cape Canaveral late today from their training base in Houston to make final launch preparations. The commander is Dan Brandenstein. The other crew members are pilot Jim Wetherbee and mission specialists Bonnie Dunbar, Marsha Ivins and David Low. Brandenstein and Dunbar have made shuttle flights, while the others will be on their first trip. Once in space they are to deploy a Navy communications satellite and track down and retrieve a 21,400-pound science laboratory the size of a small bus before it falls back to Earth. The laboratory, which has been orbiting nearly six years, will be returned to Earth for a study of its 57 experiments and to determine what has happened to it during long exposure to space. Liftoff had been scheduled to take place before Christmas, but problems with the launch pad, which recently underwent a $50 million overhaul, forced a postponment. Fourteen hours of ``hold time'' were added to the countdown to allow NASA to stop and deal with any problems with launch pad 39A, which has not been used in four years.

DOC.HEAD: Two Candidates Announce for Massachusetts Gubernatorial Race
DOC.TEXT: Two candidates who ran against each other in 1978 for state attorney general again are vying for the same office _ this time, for governor. Democrat Francis X. Bellotti and Republican William Weld made separate announcements Thursday with both taking swipes at Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, the Democratic governor who is not seeking re-election, and with both positioning themselves as outsiders who could solve the state's fiscal problems. Bellotti, 66, served 12 years as attorney general before stepping down in 1986. He was elected lieutenant governor in 1962 and ran for governor unsucessfully in 1964. Weld, 44, went on to become U.S. attorney for Massachusetts and assistant U.S. attorney general after his defeat by Bellotti. Both men said they would offer voters a change from the Dukakis style; Bellotti, in particular, said he would take back the state from ``technocrats and team players.'' ``Massachusetts has become like the auto industry of a generation gone by. We cannot solve our problems by adding chrome fins and more fuel to an already unwieldy machine,'' Bellotti said. He said the most important issue facing the next governor will be to turn around a state economy ``clearly in a decline.'' Bellotti has opposed new taxes, but has not gone as far as Weld, who took a no-new-taxes pledge after delivering his announcement speech. ``Absolutely. Four years, no new taxes,'' Weld said when asked if he would oppose any tax increases as governor. While outlining the serious fiscal problems he said the state must face, Weld said the state still has its greatest economic strenth, a well-educated work force. ``The same brainpower, energy and determination that made us the center of the high-tech revolution can also place us at the center of the global economic revolution that lies ahead in the '90s,'' Weld said. Bellotti faces Lt. Gov. Evelyn Murphy and House Taxation Committee Chairman John Flood of Canton in the Democratic primary election. In addition, Boston University President John Silber is gearing up to run and Boston Mayor Raymond Flynn has not ruled out a bid. Weld faces House Minority Leader Steven Pierce of Westfield, former Congressman Paul Cronin and former Metropolitan District Commissioner Guy Carbone in te GOP race.

DOC.HEAD: On The Light Side
DOC.TEXT: A Collin County justice of the peace who faces a challenge in the Republican primary from a teen-ager hopes to give the youngster a lesson in politics. ``I do question whether he has the experience necessary to do the job,'' the 49-year-old James Murrell said of challenger John Payton. ``It's not something you gain from sitting down and reading a book.'' Payton filed Tuesday to run against Murrell in the March 13 GOP primary. The senior at Plano East High School will turn 18 before the contest. He said his high school law classes and work on the debate team and student government will prepare him for the job. ``My main goal is to be a politician,'' Payton said. ``That's what I've always wanted to be. I know the basics of the law. I'll gain experience through dealing with the community.'' His parents gave him the necessary $300 filing fee after he failed to get enough petition signatures over Christmas break to waive the fee. ``We've had several people call offering help and support for John,'' said his mother, Lorri Payton. ``John has always been mature and responsible and he's always set his goals high. I'm not surprised by his decision (to run).'' Payton is following his father's footsteps. At age 18, Stan Payton ran unsuccessfully for city clerk in Clovis, Calif., losing by fewer than 100 votes.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``We're not going to open cases of champagne. We'll take it one glass at a time.'' _ Tom Cash, head of the Drug Enforcement Administration in Miami, maintaining that the capture of Manuel Noriega was only one benchmark in the nation's drug war.

``The whole case did the entire city an injustice. I've been on this Earth 50 years, and I've read a lot of suspense stories, but I've not heard anything as bizarre and troubling as this.'' _ Boston Mayor Raymond Flynn, upon learning that Charles Stuart, the husband who reported that a black man robbed and shot him and killed his pregnant wife, committed suicide after his brother implicated him in the crime.

``I know I'm fat. I can tell you how I know I'm fat. I see myself in the mirror, naked. Horrible.'' _ Ed Koch, ex-New York City mayor who, four days out of office, signed on as a pitchman for a weight-loss powder to drop some of the 44 pounds he gained during his 12 years in power.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Consolidating for Elections, Calls for Joint Newspaper
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 3 grafs at end with opposition planning own newspaper; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Six main pro-democracy groups said they are forming a coalition for elections in May, but the groups are divided over economic and foreign policy issues that will be central to the campaign. Also Thursday, a parliamentary commission investigating corruption charges against ousted Communist officials reported that doctors were checking Erich Honecker to determine if the country's disgraced former leader could be imprisoned. Honecker, 77, suffers from complications from gall bladder surgery last August. He will have to be moved from the exclusive residential compound where he was under house arrest after his ouster on Oct. 18 because the complex is being converted to a facility for the handicapped. ADN, the official news agency, said the police cordon around Honecker's home had been lifted weeks ago and that the government was looking for a suitable place to move him while the corruption investigation continues. The government also said it wants to revive some intelligence activities following last month's decision to disband the state security agency. Pro-democracy opposition forces have demanded that no secret police activities be carried out until a new government is seated after the May 6 elections. In announcing the formation of a pro-democracy coalition, Social Democratic Party leader Steffen Reiche said a united front against the Communists was needed because reform groups were being wrongly cast as sympathetic with rightist causes. Some of the opposition groups have shown more interest than the Communists in joining in a confederation with West Germany, although most have carefully avoided discussion of formal reunification. The new coalition, called Election Alliance 90, includes New Forum, Social Democratic Party, Democratic Awakening, Democracy Now, the Initiative for Peace and Human Rights and the United Left. Detlef Poge of New Forum, the largest opposition group, conceded that the groups are so divided on how the economy should be restored that he doubted they could agree on a single position to push in the elections. ``Everyone is so preoccupied with political problems that the economic crisis is being ignored, and that's dangerous,'' Poge told The Associated Press. As the opposition stumbles, the Communists' advantage of 40 years in power and strong political organization becomes more apparent. The Communists still draw more voter support than any other single political party, and they have been stirring voter concern over the issue of a rightist resurgence. The Communists were stripped of their constitutional mandate to rule on Dec. 1, reducing them to the status of other political forces and transferring the leadership role to the premier instead of the party chief. Unlike the reform movement in neighboring Czechoslovakia, East German activists are disorganized, and in some cases at odds with their own members. More than a dozen groups representing social interests from the environment to women's issues are taking part in weekly negotiations with the Communists and other established political parties to draft reforms and advise the interim government. But the talks have been mired in bureaucratic infighting from their Dec. 7 start. Leaders of the Democracy Now group have advocated a gradual reunification with West Germany, while New Forum and the Social Democrats contend East German must remain a sovereign nation. The opposition forces also disagree about how much Western investment should be permitted to ease the nation's economic crisis. Another divisive issue is whether East Germany should rely on nuclear energy instead of the polluting brown coal that fires much of the nation's industry. New Forum suffers a rift within its membership, with one breakaway branch planning to form a political party on Jan. 27; the main group rejects formal organization as a political force. New Forum on Thursday proposed that reform supporters start an independent newspaper and begin publishing weekly by the end of the month. ADN said printing facilities, editorial offices and money for operating the newspaper would have to be raised through donations. Nine leading reform activists issued an appeal for support. Theu promised the weekly, to be called The Others, would address an array of political and economic issues.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Offers Plan To Revive Talks With Iran, Warns Israel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 12 grafs of quotes, details and background; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: President Saddam Hussein today proposed a three-point plan for reviving stalled peace negotiations with Iran, including direct meetings and an unconditional release of ailing and disabled prisoners. Saddam also praised his country's advanced arms industry and warned Israel against attacking Iraqi scientific or military installations after the recent launch of long-range missiles and a rocket reportedly capable of putting a satellite in space. The Iraqi president spoke in a 30-minute address aired live by radio and television to mark the 69th anniversary of the creation of the Iraqi Army. ``We are seeking to open a new door for a dignified peace with Iran,'' he said. Fighting in the eight-year Iran-Iraq war was halted by a cease-fire that went into effect Aug. 20, 1988. U.S. and European military analysts have estimated that 1 million people were killed and 1.7 million wounded, two-thirds of them Iranians. The war grew out of border skirmishes between Iran and Iraq after the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini took power in Iran in 1979. But Iran and Iraq had been in dispute for years over the 120-mile Shatt-al-Arab waterway, the confluence of the Tigris and Euphrates Rivers that flows into the Persian Gulf and forms the southern boundary between the two countries. To revive the peace talks, Saddam suggested that ``direct meetings between representatives of both leaderships be held alternately in Tehran and Baghdad under the auspices of the secretariat-general of the United nations. ``The direct dialogue will aim at reaching a common understanding of the clauses of (U.N. Security Council) Resolution 598 and fix a timetable for its implementation ... provided that the talks are completed within a period not exceeding three months.'' The Security Council adopted the resolution in July 1987. A year later, both countries agreed to it and stopped the fighting. But peace talks launched under U.N. sponsorship after the truce were quickly deadlocked. Tehran refused to discuss a settlement before Iraq withdraw from lands it occupied before the cease-fire, and Baghdad insisted on working out a new border demarcation accord that gives it total sovereignty over Shatt-Al-Arab waterway. Under a pre-war accord, the border between the two countries ran down the middle of the waterway, which forms Iraq's sole outlet to the gulf. Iran claims Iraq holds 1,065 square miles of its territory. But U.N. experts say the Iraqis occupy only 260 square miles. As a second step toward renewing the peace talks, Saddam proposed ``an immediate exchange of all wounded and sick prisoners of war under the supervision of the International Committee of the Red Cross.'' That, he said, would be followed by the release of the longest-held POWs, mainly those captured in the early stages of the war, which broke out in September 1980. He also called for registering thousands of prisoners who have not been included in lists provided to the Red Cross. The Red Cross has registered 50,182 prisoners held by Iran and 19,284 in Iraqi camps. But U.N. officials and diplomats say both sides together hold at least 100,000 POWs. The Red Cross mediated an agreement to repatriate the ailing and crippled POWs immediately after the cease-fire. But the accord broke down after the release of only 400 prisoners with Iran and Iraq accusing each other of falsifying the number of captives who were seeking asylum. The Red Cross estimates 1,000 ailing or disabled POWs are still held by both sides.

DOC.HEAD: Yellowstone Officials Warn Visitors To Stay Away From Coyotes
DOC.TEXT: Yellowstone National Park officials are warning visitors to keep their distance from coyotes in the park following the attack of a skier by one of the animals. Park rangers have been searching for the coyote that may have attacked Brian Dean, 27, on Wednesday, sending him to a Montana hospital where doctors were deciding whether to begin rabies treatments on the man. Dean, an employee of the park's concessionaire, was attacked while he was cross-country skiing alone near the Biscuit Basin. Park spokeswoman Joan Anzelmo said the Oak Lawn, Ill., man spotted the animal while coming down a hill, but had no chance to stop or go around it. The coyote then knocked Dean to the ground and attacked him while Dean beat the animal with one of his skis. Dean suffered lacerations and puncture wounds to his head, neck and arms. He was able to ski to a nearby road where a snowmobiler gave him a ride to Old Faithful. From there, he was taken to West Yellowstone, Mont. He was reported in good condition at Deaconess Hospital in Bozeman, Mont. The attack, the most severe in the park involving a coyote since at least the early 1970s, was one of several recent incidents in which coyotes acted bold or aggressive toward humans, Anzelmo said. ``The message is clearly please, don't approach the wildlife, don't feed the wildlife and be especially cautious around coyotes you may happen to see,'' she said. ``The extent of this attack is extremely rare. But when coyotes become habituated to people, they will get bold.'' A week ago a mother used a ski pole to fend off a coyote that charged her young son near Biscuit Basin, and in another incident one of the animals jumped over the lap of a woman sitting on a bench near the Old Faithful geyser, said Anzelmo. Officials believe the animals have become used to humans because of visitors who have been giving the coyotes handouts, she added. ``They become habituated to people and conditioned to handouts,'' she said. ``They expect handouts and get bolder and bolder. Most of the time, you can scare them away. But some animals at Old Faithful can get quite bold.'' She added that reports of ``beggar coyotes'' have been common in the park in past years and officials often heard reports of the animals approaching or running into people.

DOC.HEAD: Reports: Man Confesses to Serial Slayings; Leads Police to Bodies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: News conference scheduled at 11:30 a.m.
DOC.TEXT: Police today were questioning a man in the slayings of 14 women and the disappearances of two others since 1988, according to news reports. The man, who was reportedly convicted in 1972 in the strangulation deaths of two children, confessed to 10 of the killings, television station WOKR reported. But investigators would not confirm they had a suspect, saying only that they would release information on a breakthrough in the case at a news conference today at state police headquarters in Canandaigua, about 25 miles southeast of Rochester. Police said late Thursday that no charges had been filed, but the Rochester Democrat & Chronicle quoted an unidentified police source as saying, ``Through his statements he had knowledge that only the killer could have.'' Area newspapers and television stations reported that a 45-year-old food service worker told authorities where they could find the bodies of the two missing women. By midnight, officials had found one of those bodies, in West Creek in the town of Clarkson, but had not located the second, according to the Democrat & Chronicle. The Post-Standard of Syracuse reported that the suspect would be charged and arraigned on murder charges today in at least eight of the deaths. The suspect pleaded guilty in 1972 in Watertown to the strangulation slayings of a 8-year-old Rochester girl and a 10-year-old Watertown boy, the Democrat & Chronicle said. The girl, who was visiting the boy in Watertown, also had been sexually assaulted. The man was sentenced to 25 years in prison in October 1972 and paroled in 1987, according to reports. He had been denied parole eight times. According to reports, he was moved from Binghamton and two towns in Delaware County after residents became upset that he had settled in their communities. The suspect was found Wednesday about 15 miles west of Rochester where police were searching for a missing woman, WOKR said. He was questioned and released. Later that day, searchers found the remains of June Cicero, 34, frozen in a creek in Ogden. State police Sgt. Paul Sucher said Cicero was involved in prostitution. On Thursday, the man again was taken into custody for questioning and searchers found another body, believed to be that of a female, in the town of Sweden. About 60 state troopers, forest rangers from the state Department of Environmental Conservation, and town of Ogden police searched the Monroe County towns of Ogden, Riga and Sweden for clues into the latest deaths. Most of the women, including Cicero, were involved in prostitution or drugs. Sgt. Paul Sucher of the state police said Cicero was also a prostitute. Besides the two bodies found this week, 12 other women have been found since March 1988. At least four of the victims were strangled, one was shot, two were beaten to death and one was hit by a car while fleeing an attacker. Police have not determined the cause of the other victims.

DOC.HEAD: Storm from Southwest Hits Heartland; Northern States Warmer
DOC.TEXT: The storm that dumped heavy snow in the Southwest earlier this week churned into the central Plains today and mild Pacific air salved the Midwest and Northeast with warmer-than-usual temperatures. Thunderstorms rocked northeast Texas and southern Arkansas and pelted north-central Oklahoma with quarter-sized hail quarters before moving into Kansas today. Rain fell in much of Kansas and Missouri, the lower Mississippi Valley, eastern Texas, Alabama and northwest Florida on Thursday. Showers soaked western Washington state and snow blanketed some higher elevations in eastern Washington. Up to 5 inches of snow fell on parts of eastern Colorado and western Kansas Thursday evening. Rain changed to snow overnight across parts of Oklahoma, Kansas and Missouri. A westerly flow of air should bring mild air to the Midwest for the weekend, extending the unseasonably warm temperatures with highs in the 30s and 40s and lows in the teens and 20s. The high of 39 degrees at Marquette, Mich., on Thursday broke the previous record high for the date of 37 set in 1964 and tied in 1984. Several low pressure systems will continue their westerly flow across the northern Plains, spawning patchy clouds and some snow over the Dakotas, Minnesota and Wisconsin through tonight. A trough of low pressure stretched from the northern Rockies into the central Plains today. Weak high pressure was to the east over Minnesota and Wisconsin. More snow was predicted today for Michigan's Upper and northern Lower Peninsulas, with lows from 10 to the 20s. By Saturday, cloudy to partly sunny skies are expected statewide with highs from the mid teens to lower 30s. The changing weather is wrecking the roads, said John Joy, spokesman for the Oakland County Road Commission. ``We're getting potholes big enough to swallow Volkswagens,'' he said. ``The concrete is more resilient and there's a heaving of the asphalt.'' Dry weather prevailed across the rest of the nation, with sunny skies in the Southwest. Thursday's high for the nation was 84 degrees at Kingsville, Texas. DOC.HEAD: Tremors Cause Temporary Halt At Atomic Power Plant
DOC.TEXT: Two moderate quakes today struck a northwestern area where the country's only nuclear power plant is located, interrupting operations for several hours, the Tanjug news agency reported. The quakes near the city of Krsko occurred shortly after 1 a.m. and measured 2.7 and 2.3 on the Richter scale. There were no immediate reports of damage. It was the third series of tremors in the area of Krsko, west of Zagreb, Yugoslavia's second-largest city, in the past 10 days.

DOC.HEAD: First Vietnamese Re-education Camp Inmates Head for United States
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf `A total...' to UPDATE with all 156 inmates arriving; pickup 3rd graf, `Their arrival...'
DOC.TEXT: After many years of internment and waiting, the first group of former Vietnamese ``re-education camp'' inmates allowed to resettle in the United States arrived in the Thai capital today. A total of 156 inmates and their families arrived on morning and afternoon charter flights from Ho Chi Minh City, a U.S. Embassy spokesman said. Many will go to California after a week in a Thai immigration facility. Their arrival began the first major resettlement of the former inmates, some of whom were interned for more than a decade because they served the U.S.-backed South Vietnam government that Communist forces toppled in April 1975. ``I cannot say how happy I am after all these years,'' said Nguyen Cao Son, who taught at a South Vietnam military academy during the war. He said he was held for nearly three years of re-education then jailed for three years for trying to flee the country by boat in the late 1970s. ``I have come to the free world,'' said Nguyen Thuong Hiep, who sat with his wife and two children at Bangkok airport. ``Everyone loves their country, but our country suffers.'' Ho Van Phuoc, a former army helicopter pilot, said he saw about 25 people shot for trying to flee one of the camps, and many others died of disease. Two daughters of one former inmate wore white lace dresses and red ribbons in their hair to celebrate the occasion. But Nguyen Hoang Bich Van, the 18-year-old daughter of one former inmate, was not as happy. She left behind a boyfriend and other friends. Hundreds of thousands of people were put into camps for manual labor and political study because of their ties with the former government. Vietnam has released large numbers of people from the camps in recent years and Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach said in June that only about 120 people remained in custody. Like others, Nguyen Cao Son said he hoped for democratic changes in Vietnam that would allow him to return home one day. He said there were a few demonstrations there last year, and that he hoped the government would accommodate the people's wishes. ``We don't want a situation like that in Romania to happen in Vietnam,'' he said. Nearly 2,000 former inmates and their families will leave Vietnam by the end of March, said Richard Kocher, head of the office in Thailand of the International Organization for Migration. Officials had no overall figure on the number of former prisoners to be resettled under an agreement reached last July. The U.S. negotiator, senior State Department official Robert L. Funseth, said then that it would help heal ``the last big wound remaining from the war.'' Kocher said U.S. officials began interviewing the former detainees and conducting medical examinations in late October. The United States has resettled hundreds of thousands of Vietnamese since the war, but political bickering and other problems barred progress on the former re-education inmates. A U.S. source in Bangkok has said Washington estimated there were about 100,000 Vietnamese with re-education connections among the 600,000 who have applied to emigrate to the United States. The Vietnamese government estimated former inmates and their families total 550,000 people, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Precede: RABAT, Morocco
Three Countries Deny Entry To Stricken Iranian Tanker
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Portugal turning ship away. Pickup 5th graf `There has...'; EDITS thereafter to TRIM, CHANGES byline.
DOC.TEXT: A crippled Iranian tanker that spilled millions of gallons of oil off the Moroccan coast was turned away today by Portugal. Iran said the 100-square-mile spill occurred when the tanker, the Khark 5, exploded last month after one of its storage tanks was damaged in a storm. There has been no leakage from the tanker's two ruptured storage tanks since Monday, according to the Dutch salvage company Smit Tak. The 283,632-ton ship's original cargo was 72 million gallons of crude oil. But nearby countries were turning the ship away from ports where it could transfer its remaining cargo of crude to a second vessel. A Portuguese navy patrol boat was escorting the Khark 5 away from the Portuguese island of Madeira, north of the Canaries, after the tanker entered its territorial waters there, the national news agency Lusa said today. Morocco also has refused the tanker safe haven, and the Spanish Merchant Marine denied a request by the ship's owners to tow the 1,837-foot vessel to calm waters off the southern coast of Tenerife in the Canary Islands, a government official said. Smit Tak, which is commanding the three tugs towing the Khark 5, said an empty National Iranian Oil Co. tanker, the Shir Khooh, was headed to meet the Khark 5. If the Khark 5 is unable to go to a nearby island, Smit Tak said it planned to tow the tanker to the Cape Verde archipelago, through more than 1,200 miles of open seas, south of the ship's current position. The country is a former Portuguese colony off the West African coast. The tanker was 400 miles north of Las Palmas, in the Canary Islands, on Dec. 19 when an explosion ripped open its hull, creating an oil slick that crept toward the Moroccan coastline. Oil from the tanker could still reach the Moroccan coast, but the 19 million-gallon spill has dissipated and no longer poses the major environmental threat it had in recent days, experts said Thursday. They said more than 90 percent of the spill had either evaporated, dissolved in the sea, broken up in high waves or been dispersed by chemicals sprayed on the water to fight the slick. Darko Domovic, a technical expert with the center, said only remnants of oil could wash ashore over the next two months. ``There is very, very little oil left on the sea surface,'' he said. ``It would only be a question of normal cleanup with buckets and spades.'' Hundreds of sailors laid floating barriers to stop the oil's advance toward the Moroccan oyster farming town of Oualidyia, where the leading edge of the oil was 20 miles off the coast Thursday. Iranian Oil Minister Gholamreza Aqazadeh said a storm ripped a hole in one of the tanker's storage tanks, causing the explosion that started the leak. Aqazadeh said reports of environmental damage caused by the spill were exaggerated and that the ship met all safety specifications. The vessel, built in 1975, was damaged at least three times in Iraqi air strikes in the Persian Gulf during the Iran-Iraq war. The normal life span of a tanker of its size is 15 to 20 years.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Release Three Jailed Students
DOC.TEXT: The government has quietly released three Beijing college students jailed for taking part in the spring democracy movement, and Chinese sources said today that other activists also have been released recently. However, they said the releases do not indicate a softening of Chinese leaders' opposition to democratic reform. They said additional soldiers were brought into Beijing after the Romanian revolution last month prompted protest attempts here and illegal posters at several Beijing campuses. Most soldiers are inside walled compounds in the city and military bases in the suburbs, and the increased presence could not be detected. It is widely believed, however, that troops and police have been on alert for the past two weeks, with all leaves canceled, and that plans to lift martial law were called off. Martial law was imposed in Beijing in May during massive pro-democracy protests that were crushed by the army June 3-4. College students said three students from the Beijing College of Aeronautics who were arrested during the summer returned to their dormitories Thursday night. They were pale from their incarceration but said they had been treated well in jail, fellow students said. The school refused to say if the three would be allowed to return to class. Other sources said some older intellectuals who supported the protests also have been released in the past few weeks, but no figures were available. None of those released was prominent in the protests. A school official at the Beijing College of Aeronautics was quoted as telling students there that ``some students not only at this school but seven others'' wanted to demonstrate in support of the Romanian rebellion, which led to the ouster of Stalinist leader Nicolae Ceausescu. The official warned the Chinese students not to protest, saying it would affect their lives. More than 100 students at the aeronautics college tried last week to bicycle in a group off campus, without any posters, in a silent show of support for Romania's uprising, but they were stopped at the gate, sources there said. Similar efforts also were reported previously at two other schools, but the official's comments were the first indication that protest efforts were so widespread. One source said security forces have been authorized to shoot if necessary to stop students from marching off campuses. Four illegal protest posters also were reported at Beijing University, Beijing Normal University and Qinghua University during the Romanian street fighting. There have been scattered unofficial reports of worker unrest in Beijing, Shanghai and Chifeng in Inner Mongolia. However, authorities refuse to answer questions about unrest or protests, creating a climate in which rumors flourish and confirmation is almost impossible to obtain. Under martial law regulations, all questions and requests for interviews must be submitted to the Beijing City Foreign Affairs Office, which generally does not respond.

DOC.HEAD: Vatican Ambassador Smoothed Way for Noriega Surrender
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after 5th pvs, `He needed...' to ADD with officials saying Laboa offered ultimatum, Thursday noon deadline for Noriega to leave embassy; picks up 6th pvs, `It was...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: He would wake up before dawn, put on baggy shorts and do calisthenics on the patio. Later, he would don a white robe and a crucifix and try to persuade Manuel Antonio Noriega to get out of his house. As the Vatican's ambassador in Panama, Monsignor Sebastian Laboa became the reluctant host to the fugitive military dictator on Christmas Eve, four days after 26,000 U.S. troops descended on Panama City to topple Noriega. For 10 days, the papal mission was a building under siege, surrounded by barbed wire, soldiers in battle array, tanks and helicopters. The 67-year-old Laboa _ short, a bit plump, his gray hair receding _ is both a priest and a lawyer and is considered savvy, open and street smart. He needed all those qualities in the stalemate that followed. In the end, embassy officials told Noriega that if he didn't give up, the Panamanian government would be invited in to take him out, said the Rev. Javier Villanueva, assistant to the papal nunio. A senior Bush administration official said Laboa gave Noriega a noon Thursday deadline to get out. Noriega walked out of the embassy Wednesday night, surrendered to U.S. forces and was flown to Florida to face federal drug-trafficking charges. It was not the first time Laboa found himself at the center of a Panamanian political firestorm. He sheltered Guillermo Endara after a coup attempt failed to overthrow Noriega in October. Endara led the opposition to Noriega and now is president. Laboa also mediated between the Basque separatist organization ETA and the Spanish government of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez. Besides Noriega and a handful of his henchmen, four ETA members sought refuge at the embassy. Laboa said little publicly as he labored through sticky negotiations with U.S. military officials, who made their headquarters at the St. Agustin church school across from the Vatican mission. The papal nuncio was their exclusive conduit to Noriega and when the former dictator surrendered Wednesday night, Laboa was given most of the credit. ``Father Laboa was the most instrumental person in making this happen,'' said Maj. Gen. Marc Cisneros, commander of U.S. Army South. Noriega did not find life comfortable inside the two-story compound. He slept in a small room with a submachine gun under his bed. Just in case Noriega got ideas, Laboa told the troops outside they could storm the mission if the former strongman took hostages. Laboa kept Noriega in strict isolation, forbade the embassy staff to talk with him, let Noriega's faulty television set stay on the blink and refused to feed him vegetarian meals. Noriega does not eat meat. On New Year's Eve, the priest served Noriega pasta, one of Laboa's favorite foods. Born in the northern Basque town of San Juan Guipuzcoa in Spain, Laboa became a priest at the age of 26 and a lawyer in Italy six years later. He became Pope John Paul II's representative in Panama in 1982. He was visiting Salamanca in Spain when the U.S. troops invaded and hurried back to Panama. Noriega wasn't the only one Laboa kept under control. He also had to deal with hundreds of U.S. soldiers who ringed the embassy around the clock. The soldiers set up an outdoor system with four powerful speakers and blasted the building with rock, heavy metal, rap, and country music. Laboa was not amused. Word went out that ``steps'' would be taken if the racket didn't stop. It did. During the first confusing days of Noriega's sanctuary, troops searched Laboa's car on at least one occasion and he was detained while soldiers rummaged in the car for weapons and ``non-diplomatic personnel'' _ Noriega, they hoped. From a nearby hotel hundreds of reporters and photographers with zoom and special night lenses kept vigil. At dawn, Laboa would emerge wearing a sweatshirt bearing with the word ``Gago,'' a local supermarket. He would bend, stretch and walk at a fast pace on the embassy's palm-shrouded patio. In the afternoon, he darted in and out of the black iron embassy gates in a long white robe, spending hours with U.S. officials. In the end, Laboa's patience wore thin. And he was losing some of his popularity. Hours before Noriega's surrender, 20,000 demonstrators marched to the embassy demanding the unwanted guest be kicked out. ``We respect the Catholic Church,'' read one sign. ``But excuse us, we don't respect you, Monsignor Laboa.'' Vatican embassy officials said Laboa told Noriega bluntly that the building's diplomatic immunity would be lifted at some point. Gen. Maxwell Thurman, commander of the Southern Command in charge of the Panama invasion, said the United States owed Laboa special thanks. He said the priest showed ``extraordinary competence and statesmanlike conduct.''

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Official: Entertainment Industry Must Change Sex Portrayals.
DOC.TEXT: The entertainment industry should portray sex responsibly, according to a recommendation being considered by a national commission studying the battle against AIDS. ``If our (TV and movie) heroes can't say or use the `condom' word, I think our education efforts are doomed to failure,'' said James Allen, director of the AIDS program office of the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. Allen made his comments Thursday before a working group of the National Commission on AIDS. The three-member working group, chaired by Ramsey County Commissioner Diane Ahrens, is a subcommittee of the 15-member national commission created by Congress to advise lawmakers and President Bush on the development of coordinated public policy on AIDS. ``I don't care if we get a vaccine or a cure, it's never going to be as effective as not becoming infected with the AIDS virus,'' Allen told the group. The commission, expected to meet again today to work on recommendations based on Thursday's session, heard testimony all day from experts representing federal, state and local government agencies around the country. ``Leadership is crucial at every level,'' said Larry Kessler, commission member and head of the Boston AIDS Action Committee. ``Leadership means stepping outside one's agenda and working for the common good.'' The commission heard testimony Thursday about the increasing number of AIDS patients, many of whom lack health insurance. State and local governments are forced to scramble for funds to take care of them. The subcommittee also discussed how politicians need to become more involved in raising the awareness of the risk of transmission of the disease.

DOC.HEAD: Station Staff Allegedly Fled Rail Disaster; 307 Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE death toll, Bhutto visits hospitals, more on possible sabotage. TRIMS. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Police issued arrest warrants for three train employees accused of fleeing Pakistan's worst rail disaster, which officials said today left at least 307 people dead and 340 injured. Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto called it a ``national tragedy'' as she toured hospitals in the nearby city of Sukkur. ``The possibility of sabotage cannot be ruled out,'' she told reporters. Ms. Bhutto said she ordered two investigations _ one judicial and one by Pakistan Railways. Railway spokesmen said an improperly set switch apparently sent a loaded, express passenger train crashing into a parked freight train early Thursday just north of Sangi. Three of the green-and-yellow passenger cars were crushed as they piled together, and three more were heavily damaged. Pakistan's minister for railways, Zafar Leghari, said during a visit to the scene of the wreck that sabotage or conspiracy were possible causes. He said he based his suspicion on the disappearance of the Sangi station manager and two switchmen. Army troops cordoned off the maze of twisted and splintered steel as about 1,000 rescue workers spent a second day cutting through crushed passenger cars in search of more bodies and survivors. Dozens of bodied lay wrapped in sheets and blankets under an outdoor tent in Sukkur's Civil Hospital. Local people, some bringing tea and sweets, pitched in to help care for the hundreds of injured. Casualty counts continued to fluctuate, but rescue officials said at least 307 bodies had been recovered from the wreckage by this afternoon and that about 340 injured were accounted for in hospitals. Dr. Gulzar Ahmad Sheikh, civil surgeon of Sukkur district, estimated the number of people treated since the accident at around 700. He said many victims were treated and released at first aid stations. Railway officials said there appeared to be more bodies trapped in the first three passenger cars, which were crushed together in the impact. Officials said many survivors removed dead relatives for immediate burial and dozens of injured were treated and released from first-aid stations. Ms. Bhutto canceled today's birthday observances for her late father, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, who was overthrown in a 1977 military coup and hanged in 1979. Police were questioning the engineer of the passenger train, identified as Payra Masih, who was found alive in the driver's seat of the overturned locomotive. Railway officials said he tried to brake the train to avert the crash. His fireman in the cab was killed. Muktar Ahmad Abassi, regional traffic officer for Pakistan Railways at Sukkur, said the passenger train Zakaria Bahauddin, named after a Moslem saint, was traveling south overnight on a 500-mile run from Multan to Karachi with considerably more passengers than its 1,408-seat capacity. When it approached Sangi, which it was supposed to bypass, an improperly set switch threw it onto a siding where an empty, 67-car freight train stood, he said. The passenger train crashed into it with a speed of at least 35 mph, Abassi said, crushing and derailing cars. Pakistan's previous worst rail disaster occurred more than 30 years ago and killed about 200 people.

DOC.HEAD: Suspected Crack Dealer Slain, Month After Younger Brother Kidnapped
DOC.TEXT: The murder of a reputed crack dealer apparently was linked to the kidnapping of his 12-year-old brother, whose severed finger accompanied a ransom demand to the family, a published report said. Police investigators believe Richard Porter, 25, may have been negotiating with kidnappers for the release of his younger brother Wednesday night before he was killed, according to today's Daily News. Porter was found dead, shot several times, in the Bronx early Thursday, said Sgt. Mary Wrensen, a police department spokeswoman. His brother, William, was abducted on his way to school Dec. 5 and was still missing, detectives told the News. The family received a hysterical taped message the next day from the boy, along with his severed right index finger and two of his rings, the paper said. ``They cutted my finger off ... They said if you don't do as they say, they are going to cut my hand off,'' a terrified William said on the tape, according to the News. ``Please help ... I love you, Mommy.'' In a series of notes and phone calls that ended on Dec. 10, the kidnappers first demanded $500,000, then $350,000 for the boy's return, the News said. Detectives told the News that the elder brother had refused to cooperate with police in the investigation and may have been negotiating for the boy's release on his own. ``It seems robbery was not the motive, as identification and property were found on him,'' Wrensen said. ``Apparently he was dumped there.'' Police refused to comment on the kidnapping case so as not to jeopardize William's safety. The last contact that the family had with the kidnappers was a note they received on Dec. 10. ``We still want the money. The child is in pain and he needs medical attention,'' the note said. Richard Porter was a local drug distributor who controlled several street sellers, the News said.

DOC.HEAD: South Africa Hopeful of Expanding Ties With Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Pik Botha, back from his first trip to Eastern Europe, said today his government hopes to establish diplomatic relations with Hungary and possibly other long-hostile Warsaw Pact countries. Botha also said his government sought to attract Eastern Europeans to South Africa to ease a manpower shortage in skilled jobs. Anti-apartheid groups have denounced the recruitment campaign, saying the government should be training blacks rather than wooing white immigrants. In Budapest, Botha met Thursday with Hungarian Foreign Minister Guyla Horn. Hungary's national MTI news agency reported afterward: ``Both sides expressed their intention to gradually establish official relations.'' The African National Congress, which for decades has received Soviet bloc backing for its guerrilla campaign against white-minority rule, accused Hungary of betraying South Africa's black majority and forming ``a racist partnership with apartheid.'' However, Botha told reporters before leaving Budapest that ``no agreements were concluded'' with Hungary. And Horn reminded Botha that Hungary ``opposes any kind of racial, national or ethnic discrimination, and condemns all manifestations of apartheid,'' MTI said. At a news conference today at Johannesburg's airport, Botha said the two countries would investigate possible cooperation in trade, industrial development and tourism. He said South Africans could now travel to Hungary ``without any problem.'' Asked about the prospect of formal ties with other Eastern European countries, Botha replied: ``There is already contact, and we are talking.'' Before Eastern Europe's recent political upheavals, Warsaw Pact nations were aligned closely with most Third World countries in vehement opposition to South Africa's white-controlled government. This alliance advocated isolation of South Africa as a means of forcing an end to its racial segregation policies and bringing about black-majority rule.
