Hungary was one of the first East bloc countries to accept reform. In October, its ruling Communist Party was disbanded in favor of a party that swore allegiance to democratic ideals. On March 25, Hungary is scheduled to hold its first multiparty elections since 1948. Alfred Nzo, secretary-general of the African National Congress, said Hungary's decision to receive Botha demonstrated ``bad faith and a cynical disregard for international agreements.'' ``Only 10 days ago, representatives of the Hungarian government assured the ANC that they have no contact with the apartheid regime,'' he said, accusing the Hungarians of trying to ``betray the majority of the people of South Africa by forming a racist partnership with apartheid.'' ``Hungary cannot expect to maintain normal relations with the peoples of Africa while it befriends the enemy of our continent,'' he said. Botha said he and Horn discussed the possibility of a gradually broadening relationship that would include ``interest offices, consular offices and eventually embassies.'' ``But this will depend on what happens in South Africa and Hungary over the next few months,'' he said. Botha's two-day stay was the first known visit by a senior South African official to a Warsaw Pact country. While there, he said his government is committed to forging a new constitution that would end white domination. MTI said Hungary ``is prepared to hold dialogue ... with South Africa, parallel to maintaining its position'' against apartheid. The state-run South African Broadcasting Corp., in a commentary today on Botha's trip, said: ``The hostility shown by the United States Congress and others (through sanctions) makes it imperative that new friendships and partnerships be formed.'' It suggested the East bloc might seek to tap South Africans' mining expertise. ``There is real hope that South Africa is poised to start breaking out of her international isolation,'' the network said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Commits Suicide After Brother Implicates Him in Pregnant Wife's Death
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf, `Police said...' to add prosecutors saying no evidence of insurance motive or drug involvement. SUBS 23rd graf, `He stepped...' with 2 grafs to add comment from brother's lawyer. CORRECTS to Stuart sted Stewart in grafs 5 and 25 pvs.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BX2
DOC.TEXT: The story behind a grim inner-city shooting that stirred racial fears turned out to be a lie as the storyteller committed suicide after his brother implicated him, authorities said. The body of Charles Stuart, who became a sympathetic figure as the suburban victim of a Boston shooting that killed his pregnant wife and left him wounded, was pulled from the Boston Harbor. Stuart's tale to police was that he and his 30-year-old wife, Carol, were robbed and shot by a black man after they left a childbirth class Oct. 23. Stuart, a fur store manager, also reportedly identified a black man in a police lineup as the killer. The story, Suffolk County District Attorney Newman Flanagan said, ``is not true.'' Mrs. Stuart, a lawyer, died hours after the shooting. The Stuarts' son, delivered by Caesarean section, died 17 days later. Hospitalized at the time his wife was buried, a letter from Stuart was read at the funeral. ``Now you sleep away from me,'' he wrote. ``I'll never know the feeling of your hand in mine, but I will always feel you. I miss you, and I love you.'' Gov. Michael Dukakis and Mayor Raymond Flynn were among those who attended the funeral. Flynn had called Stuart a hero for directing police to his wife by their car phone despite being wounded himself. ``The whole case did the entire city an injustice,'' Flynn said Thursday. ``I've been on this Earth 50 years, and I've read a lot of suspense stories, but I've not heard anything as bizarre and troubling as this.'' Blacks also reacted angrily _ because the story touched the worst fears among white America about black inner-city violence when it exploded in headlines and on news reports nationwide. ``Black people in particular have to look at it and wonder what hope we have for justice in a country that took this man's lie and made him and his family a symbol of national mourning,'' said Chuck Turner, director of the Center for Community Action of the Episcopal City Mission in Boston's largely black Roxbury section. Authorities were theorizing that Stuart's motive in the slaying was to collect life insurance policies taken out on his wife, The Boston Globe and Boston Herald reported today. Both newspapers quoted unidentified sources. Stuart recently collected $83,000 from a $100,000 policy on his wife, the Globe reported, citing a source within an unidentified insurance company. The newspaper said the policies on his wife totaled at least $500,000. Police said there were reports that Charles Stuart had tested positive for cocaine after the shooting, the Herald reported today. Prosecutors who spoke on the record said there was no evidence of an insurance motive or drug involvement. Stuart, 29, jumped off the 300-foot Tobin Bridge hours after his brother's disclosures to authorities. He left a suicide note in his car. Flanagan said the case remained active, but he refused to disclose details or the contents of the suicide note. ``Basically, it's fair to say, he could not handle the allegations or statements made about him,'' the prosecutor said. Flanagan said he ordered police to arrest Stuart in his wife's killing. But police could not find him late Wednesday or early Thursday. Officials said Stuart apparently knew he was a suspect, but they did not say how he knew. A black man, William Bennett, had been identified in news accounts as a suspect. He was never charged in the Stuart case, and the prosecutor has now cleared him. Bennett said that was not enough. ``My life and my family's lives have been ruined and no one is willing to take responsibility,'' he said. Stuart's 23-year-old brother, Matthew, a paint factory employee who was a pallbearer at Mrs. Stuart's funeral, had long suspected that his brother's account of the shooting was false, according to his attorney, John Perenyi. He stepped forward with his fears on Wednesday because he was afraid an innocent man might be charged, Perenyi said, adding that his client offered no explanation for why his brother might have committed the crime. ``He was really at a loss to give me a motive,'' he said. ``He didn't think his brother was into gambling, drinking or other women.'' On the night of the shooting, Matthew Stuart said his brother had asked him to meet him near the hospital where the Stuarts had attended the childbirth class, according to Perenyi. Matthew Stuart said his brother told him he would pass a bag to him through the car window. He said he took the bag, which included a nickel-plated snubnosed revolver, according to Perenyi. The lawyer said Matthew Stuart did not see Mrs. Stuart in the front seat. A search Thursday of the Pines River in Stuart's hometown of Revere turned up evidence mentioned by Matthew Stuart, including a Gucci bag, wallet, makeup and other personal belongings of Mrs. Stuart. The gun was not found.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa Donates Nobel Prize Money to National Fund
DOC.TEXT: Solidarity leader Lech Walesa has donated the $200,000 he received for winning the Nobel Peace Prize to a fund created to rebuild the country. Walesa made the announcement in a statement released at the Solidarity trade union headquarters in Gdansk on Thursday. ``The Nobel Prize I received in 1983 was at the same time a prize for the whole movement of reforms called Solidarity. The desire to give the prize money for a most worthy purpose held me back against a hasty decision,'' Walesa said. ``Today, the fact that Solidarity has taken over responsibility for the country in such a difficult period for society makes me donate the sum of $200,000 to the National Gift Fund,'' he said. Reviving a pre-war tradition of appealing to the nation for help, the National Assembly approved the creation of a National Gift Fund in early December. People may donate anything from cash to jewelry to the fund, which will be used to help the country and citizens who face financial problems as the country moves toward a market-oriented economy. Last year was one of triumph for Solidarity, the independent trade union movement founded more than nine years ago in Gdansk. Solidarity swept to victory in prarliamentary elections in June. Walesa's adviser, Tadeusz Mazowiecki, was elected in August to be the East bloc's first non-Communist prime minister. Despite its political victories, the Solidarity-led government faces a major challenge in introducing market-oriented economic reforms that are almost sure to leave Poles worse off in the short run.

DOC.HEAD: Ethnic Protests Break Out in Five Bulgarian Cities
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 12th pvs, `About 320,000...' to ADD background. Pickup 13th pvs, `Zhivkov was...'
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Bulgaria's majority Slavs walked off their jobs today in at least five cities to protest a new policy restoring Moslem names and religious rights to ethnic Turks. Bulgarian radio said the protests paralyzed the southern city of Kardzhali and caused disruptions in the other cities, Bulgarian radio reported. The radio said thousands of workers from all enterprises went on strike in Kardzhali, and public transportation was halted. Strikes and mass protests also took place today in Plovdiv, Bulgaria's second largest city, as well as in the northern cities of Ruse, Razgrad and Silistra. The report described the situation as particularly tense in Kardzhali, in which nearly half of the 50,000 residents are ethnic Turks. Petar Mladenov, the Communist Party chief and president, was expected to arrive in Kardzhali to assess the nationalistic protests. The Bulgarian Communist leadership adopted a policy on Dec. 29 that allows Bulgarian Turks to use their Moslem names. The policy reversed measures in effect under the ousted hard-line Communist leader Todor Zhivkov in which Moslems were given Slav names and their religious rites were restricted. Addressing thousands of demonstrators in Plovdiv, Pantalei Pachov, a member of the Politburo and the city's first party secretary, said the Central Committee decision allowing free choice of names had been ``premature,'' assured the protesters that the measure would be reconsidered. ``The Turkish-speaking citizens demand their own schools, they do not raise Bulgarian flags at their demonstrations. They have rejected our stretched-out hand,'' Pachov said. Thousands of people demonstrated in front of Parliament in Sofia on Thursday, demanding a national referendum on the ethnic question. Protests also took place in Kardzhali and several other cities. Bulgarian newspapers today carried a joint statement issued by the ruling Communist Party and the opposition expressing ``full support'' for the Dec. 29 decision regarding ethnic rights. The state news agency BTA reported spokesmen for the Communist Party and the democratic opposition as rejecting a proposed referendum on the ethnic decision, saying: ``The validity of human rights in Bulgaria cannot be submitted to any referendum.'' About 320,000 Turks fled this summer when Zhivkov permitted them to get passports. Nearly all of them complained about persecution and the denial of essential religious and ethnic rights. The exodus ended when Turkey, unable to take more immigrants, closed their borders. About 1.5 million of Bulgaria's 9 million people are Moslem. Nationalists have doubted the loyalties of the Bulgarian Turks since Bulgaria declared independence from the Ottoman Empire, which had ruled it for 500 years. Zhivkov was ousted Nov. 10 amid a wave of democratic reforms that have swept Eastern Europe. Mladenov, considered more moderate, took over and promised free elections and dismantled secret police units. Parliament is expected to pave the way for a pluralistic political system Jan. 15 when it votes on removing a constitutional clause guaranteeing the Communist Party's hold on power Bulgaria.

DOC.HEAD: Vatican Embassy Told Noriega Diplomatic Immunity Would Be Lifted
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 5 grafs for grafs 15-18 pvs, `Cisneros said...' to UPDATE with report Noriega cried on plane, regretted decision. Pickup 19th pvs, `A top...'
DOC.TEXT: The Vatican embassy pressured Manuel Noriega to surrender to U.S. troops by threatening to ask Panamanian authorities to come in after the ``highly dangerous criminal,'' a spokesman said. ``We would have lifted the diplomatic immunity,'' said the Rev. Javier Villanueva, assisant to the papal nuncio. He made the disclosure Thursday as Panamanians assessed the cost of the two-year struggle over Noriega's ouster, which was completed Wednesday when he left the Vatican embassy and was whisked off by U.S. troops to Florida to face federal drug-trafficking charges. Noriega's arrest led to festive street celebrations, but Panamanians must now face an economy battered in large part by the invasion and by U.S. sanctions aimed at toppling Noriega. Maj. Gen. Marc Cisneros, commander of U.S. Army South, said there was no remaining fighting or guerrilla activity on Thursday. ``The whole country is pretty well pacified,'' Cisneros said. He said all 16,000 members of Noriega's Defense Forces had been accounted for, but he did not say where they were. Villanueva said embassy officials didn't give Noriega a deadline to leave, but made his choices clear. ``If he would not have given himself up, the Panamanian government, not the U.S. government, would have been invited to send in forces to take him out,'' Villanueva said in a telephone interview. In Washington, however, a senior Bush adminstration official said the papal nuncio, Monsignor Sebastian Laboa, gave Noriega a Thursday noon deadline to get out, ``meaning he would no longer be a welcome guest.'' U.S. troops had ringed the mission since Noriega took refuge there on Christmas Eve, four days after the American invasion crushed his military regime and installed a civilian government. Cisneros said Noriega kept a machine gun under his bed during his entire 10-day stay at the mission, which would have made it difficult for embassy staff to remove him forcibly. Villanueva said the lifting of diplomatic immunity would not have been considered if Noriega had been a political prisoner. ``But this man is a highly dangerous criminal,'' he said. Noriega claimed he was a political prisoner in refusing to enter a plea to drug-trafficking charges in Miami. The judge entered an innocent plea for him and he was held without bond. Cisneros said Noriega showed no emotion when he left the Vatican mission. ``When he walked out of the nunciatura, he was normal. In other words, he wasn't strutting or ... defeated. He was just walking expressionless,'' he said. Today's editions of the Washington Times said that once he was aboard the Florida-bound military transport plane, Noriega began to cry and told U.S. drug agents he had ``really put my foot in it this time.'' ``He carried a Bible in one hand and three Catholic rosaries in another when they brought him to the plane,'' the Times quoted a source familiar with the flight as saying. ``He was very depressed, although tranquil. One agent read him sriptures from the Bible in Spanish during the flight.'' The source, who was not identified, said Noriega told the agents he had chosen to surrender but now believed he may have made a mistake. A top Noriega adviser and head of his secret police, Lt. Col. Nivaldo Madrinan, walked out of the mission on Thursday and surrendered to U.S. troops. The new government of President Guillermo Endara preferred to have Noriega go directly into U.S. hands. Endara has said Panama has no prison secure enough to hold him and the judicial system was inadequate to prosecute him. Also, several Panamanian officials have said there was no law that would allow his extradition. Endara said his government's priorities are: _ Reconstruction of Chorrillo, the low-income neighborhood around the Defense Forces headquarters that was destroyed in the U.S. invasion. _ Organization of a security force. _ To ``make sure the military occupation is as brief as possible.'' _ Reconstruction of the economy, ``which has suffered so much.'' Panama's economy once flourished on international banking and trade, but it skidded to a near-halt after the United States began imposing sanctions nearly two years ago to press for Noriega's ouster as chief of the Defense Forces.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS by deleting reference to 1986 in Edgerton obit. CORRECTS to Vallecchi sted Vallechi; no separates moved for the PMs cycle. Brainard also moved on the financial wire.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BX1
DOC.TEXT: Harold ``Doc'' Edgerton, a pioneer in strobe and underwater photography and a professor emeritus at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, died Thursday of a heart attack. He was 86. Edgerton's revolutionary work in the use of strobe lights captured images long hidden to the naked eye. Edgerton's strobe lamps enabled the Allies to track enemy movements at night during World War II. His strobes were used to photograph the first atomic tests. His work in sonar helped locate underwater wrecks. Undersea explorer Jacques Cousteau collaborated with Edgerton in locating the British Army ship, the HMS Britannia. His Edgerton-Benthos underwater camera was used to photograph the Titanic. He was awarded a national medal of technology by President Reagan in 1988.

Alberto Lleras Camargo, whose career as a political leader, journalist and diplomat spanned 50 years, died Thursday of lung cancer. He was 83. Lleras Camargo, a member of the ruling Liberal Party, began his career in the 1930s as a reporter for Bogota's El Liberal and as a orrespondent for the Buenos Aires daily La Prensa. He gained influence with Liberal Party leaders, was named interior minister by President Alfonso Lopez Pumarejo, then succeeded Lopez when he resigned in a political crisis in 1945. In 1947, he was chosen as director of the Panamerican Union, which became the Organization of American States one year later. Lleras Camargo became the first secretary-general of the OAS. He also founded the Colombian weekly magazine Semana.

Enrico Vallecchi, a book and magazine publisher, died Thursday. He was 87. Vallecchi took charge of the family publishing company after World War II from his father, Attilio, who founded it. The firm published some of the most prominent Italian writers of the 1930s and 1940s, such as Curzio Malaparte, Aldo Palazzeschi and Vasco Pratolini. Vallecchi was forced to sell the company in the early 1960s and went on to found a new one and successfully publish magazines on hunting, fishing, horseback riding and other outdoor activities, which he loved.

Gerhard Schroeder, former foreign minister and a co-founder of the country's conservative Christian Democratic Union, died Monday of heart and kidney complications. He was 79. In 1949, Schroeder was voted into the first West German parliament as a deputy from the Duesseldorf district of Mettmann. From 1953 to 1961, Schroeder served as interior minister under West Germany's first chancellor, Konrad Adenauer. Schroeder, a strong supporter of close ties with the United States, was awarded an honorary doctorate by the University of Maryland in 1959. In 1961, he became foreign minister under Adenauer, a post he kept when Ludwig Erhard took over as chancellor in 1963. When the ``great coalition'' of Christian Democrats and the leftist Social Democratic Party formed a new government in 1966, Schroeder was appointed defense minister. He remained a member of parliament until his retirement in 1980.

Vladimir Ussachevsky, a Columbia University professor who collaborated in the first electronic works performed in the United States, died Thursday of a brain tumor. He was 78. Ussachevsky, who taught at Columbia from 1947 until his retirement in 1980, started experimenting with electronic music in 1951. On May 9, 1954, a work he composed for tape recorder was performed in the first demonstration of electronic music in the country. In 1959 he helped establish the first music center devoted entirely to composition and research of electronic music, the Columbia University Electronic Music Center.

Loretta Bechtel Landrieu, the mother of former New Orleans Mayor Moon Landrieu, a former U.S. secretary of Housing and Urban Development, died Thursday at her New Orleans home of natural causes. She was 86. Mrs. Landrieu, whose grandchildren include Louisiana Treasurer Mary Landrieu and state Rep. Mitch Landrieu, was a real estate broker, and in 1963 was elected president of the New Orleans Council of Women Realtors.

Alfred M. Watson, bishop of the 13-county Roman Catholic Diocese of Erie, died Thursday at age 82. Watson was named auxiliary bishop of the diocese in 1965 and bishop four years later. He had been credited with overseeing the construction of new churches and nurturing the development of parish programs.

Ernest T. Brainard, who was called the nation's oldest active stockbroker by former President Reagan, died Wednesday at age 99. Brainard began work as a stockbroker after World War I. He started a brokerage, Brainard & Judd, after a satisfied client provided him with $100,000 seed money. Brainard spent most of his career there until the firm was liquidated in 1975, when he joined Coburn & Meredith. Brainard boasted of helping clients through both the 1929 and 1987 stock market crashes. He would have celebrated his 100th birthday Jan. 27. He received a congratulatory letter from Reagan on his 95th birthday.

DOC.HEAD: Increased Crash Protection Proposed For Vans, Light Trucks
DOC.TEXT: Light trucks and vans would have the same crash protection devices as those required for passenger cars under a proposed federal regulation. ``The installation of air bags or automatic safety belts in the front seat of these vehicles could save as many as 2,000 lives a year,'' said Jerry R. Curry, administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. The agency said Thursday that it would phase in the new requirement over three years as it did with the rule on crash protection for cars. Under the regulation, 20 percent of the vans, light trucks, multipurpose passenger vehicles and small buses manufactured in the 1994 model year would be required to provide the bags or automatic safety belts. The safety features would be required on 50 percent of the 1995 model vehicles and on all of those manufactured in 1996. Under the rule, vehicles that offer a driver's side air bag could have a manual safety belt on the passenger side and still comply with the agency's standard through the 1997 model year. But manufacturers that don't provide a driver's side air bag would have to install automatic belts for the driver and on the front-seat passenger side. ``We are encouraging air bags as the technology of choice because air bags in combination with existing lap and shoulder belts offer the best protection available,'' Curry said. All new passenger cars sold in the United States now must have air bags or automatic belts. ``They are saving thousands of lives and preventing tens of thousands of serious injuries each year,'' Curry said. ``The same protection should be given to those who choose to buy today's popular minivans and light trucks.'' Deaths and injuries to light truck riders increased from 6,500 in 1984 to 8,300 in 1988, he said. Number of the vehicles sold also have increased. The agency's move drew praise from Sen. Jack Danforth, R-Mo., ranking Republican on the Senate Commerce Committee and a longtime air bag proponent. ``Air bag technology has been around since the early 1960s, but only this year did we see large numbers of cars with air bags,'' Danforth said. ``We should not go through another long struggle to get air bags into the vehicles now used frequently by families.'' The rule would apply to all vans, trucks, buses and multipurpose vehicles with a gross vehicle weight rating of 8,500 pounds and an unloaded vehicle weight of 5,500 pounds or less. Included would be motor homes, convertibles, open-body-type vehicles, walk-in van-type trucks and vehicles carrying chassis-mounted campers. Also under the rule, light trucks and passenger cars with only two seating positions would have to be equipped to support a child safety seat on the passenger side. The announcement opens a 60-day period for public comment on the proposed rule. Afterward, the agency will write a final version and set a date for implementing it.

DOC.HEAD: Census: One-Third of States' Revenues Spent on Education
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, That spending, to delete extraneous word `marked'.
DOC.TEXT: State governments are keeping up a decade-long trend of substantially increasing spending on education, the Census Bureau says. States spent nearly $160 billion, or 33 percent of their revenues, on education in 1988, the bureau reported Thursday. Most of the money went to local governments or higher education institutions, the report said. That spending was 6.4 percent more than what the states gave to education in 1987, the report said. Since 1978, states' education spending has increased at an average annual rate of 8.6 percent, the bureau said, while overall state spending has increased by an average of 9.1 percent. Healthy education increases are probably due, in part, to a trend by states to funnel funds to education reforms, said Education Department budget chief Charlie Kolb. ``There's been a sense for the last seven or eight years that we're not doing as well as we could have,'' Kolb said. ``We're outspending the rest of the world but we're not outperforming.'' Kolb said education spending at all levels _ federal, state and local _ increased from $331 billion in fiscal 1989 to $353 billion in fiscal 1990. The Census Bureau's report said about 17 percent, or $84 billion, of state funds in 1988 went toward public welfare programs, a 7.4 percent increase over the previous year. Private vendors received $44 billion for services they provided to the needy while direct cash payments to welfare recipients totaled $11 billion, the report said. Big-ticket expenditures by states included $44 billion on insurance funds such as workers compensation, $41 billion on highways and $35 billion on health and hospitals. In all, states spent $485 billion on programs while revenues climbed 4.8 percent to $542 billion. Taxes accounted for $264 billion, or 49 percent of all revenue, while federal payments totaled $100 billion, or 18 percent. Per capita revenue for all state governments averaged $2,209, down slightly from the previous year. Alaska was highest at $10,671, followed by Wyoming with $3,531. The lowest were Texas, at $1,583, and Florida, at $1,570. More than half of all revenues were collected by just nine states, the report said. Those states, followed with the amounts in billions, are: California, $73.2; New York, $57.3; Ohio, $25.6; Texas, $26.7; Pennsylvania, $23.8; Michigan, $21.5; New Jersey, $21; Illinois, $20.5; and Florida, $19.4.

DOC.HEAD: Orders Jump to Second Highest Level
DOC.TEXT: Orders to U.S. factories for manufactured goods rose 2.4 percent in November, pumped up by durable goods to the second highest level ever, the government reported today. The Commerce Department said orders for both durable and non-durable manufactured goods totaled a seasonally adjusted $239.7 billion after edging down 0.1 percent in October. It was the highest level of orders since a record $239.9 billion were posted last April and the fastest rate of increase since a 2.8 percent advance in August. The department said all of the November improvement was in orders for durable goods _ big-ticket items expected to last more than three years. All of the major durable categories recorded increased sales. The report was one of several recently portraying a mixed picture of the extent of sluggishness in the economy, particularly in housing and the durable-goods manufacturing sector. Improvements have been reported in November, for instance, in sales of new and existing houses and of durable goods, and industrial production advanced 0.1 percent. But the Labor Department reported today that the manufacturing sector lost 25,000 jobs in December, bringing job losses in this area to 195,000 since last March. Today's reports follow falling interest rates, which the Federal Reserve had earlier boosted to slow the economy and restrain inflation. As inflation moderated and concerns grew that the economy might fall into a recession, the central bank has gradually eased its grip on credit. Many analysts continue to express concern over the economy, however, and want the Fed to permit interest rates to fall further to stimulate economic activity. In addition to new orders, the Commerce Department said shipments of manufactured goods rose 0.5 percent to $233.1 billion, while inventories rose 0.3 percent to $373.0 billion. If inventories increase without a corresponding gain in new orders, it could signal production cutbacks in the future as factories attempt to get rid of goods on shelves and backlots. Orders for durable goods gained 4.8 percent to $130.2 billion. Transportation equipment increased 10.6 percent to $36.7 billion. This included increases of $2.6 billion for aircraft and $1.5 billion for automobiles. Excluding the transportation sector, orders would have posted only a 1.1 percent gain. Electrical machinery orders were up 7.7 percent to $21.7 billion, while non-electrical machinery gained 5.7 percent to $22.7 billion. Primary metals advanced 2.2 percent to $11.3 billion. Orders for non-durable goods declined 0.3 percent to $109.5 billion. Defense orders fell 10 percent to $16.9 billion. Excluding this category, orders would have risen 1.8 percent. In the key category of non-defense capital goods, a barometer of business investment plans, orders jumped 7.7 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Held Under Tight Security Following Arraignment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 7th graf, `Defense attorney...' to UPDATE with drug agents saying Noriega wept, read Bible on flight to U.S. Picks up 8th graf, `If convicted....
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MH2; MH11 of Jan. 4
DOC.TEXT: Manuel Noriega's tumble from dictator to defendant ended in the tight security of a U.S. courtroom as the once-fiery Panamanian ruler quietly faced a federal judge. In a soft voice, a humbled Noriega answered U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler's initial inquiries. But he declined to reply to drug trafficking charges at the brief hearing Thursday, less than a month after saying he would never surrender to the United States. The judge entered an innocent plea for Noriega, who appeared in court in a Panamanian Defense Force uniform. Noriega, federal prisoner No. 41586, was being held early today in an undisclosed Miami-area location, his attorneys said. Defense attorneys say it could be nine months before they can go to trial on charges that Noriega took $4.6 million in bribes from Colombia's Medellin drug cartel to turn his nation into a way station for the cocaine trade. U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen said he thought the trial would take only two months; defense attorneys said it could go on for six months. Defense attorney Frank Rubino said Noriega ``appeared to be strong. He appeared to be confident. We went over the facts. ... He was extremely confident in assisting us.'' U.S. drug agents who accompanied Noriega on his flight from Panama to Miami gave a markedly different description, saying he was in tears aboard the transport plane and regretted leaving the papal nunciature, The Washington Times reported today. ``I really put my foot in it this time,'' Noriega was quoted as saying. ``I should not have left the nunciature.'' A source familiar with the flight said Noriega carried a Bible in one hand and three rosaries in another when he was brought to the plane. ``He was very depressed, although tranquil. One agent read him scriptures from the Bible in Spanish during the flight,'' the unidentified source told the newspaper. If convicted of all charges, Noriega, 51, could be sentenced to 145 years in prison and fined $1.1 million. Rubino said he planned to file motions to dismiss the case, claiming the charges are politically motivated and questioning the methods used late Wednesday to remove Noriega from the Vatican Embassy in Panama City, where he was sheltered in a room for 10 days under diplomatic protection. ``General Noriega refuses to submit to the jurisdiction of this court ... because he is a political prisoner brought to this country illegally,'' Rubino told Hoeveler. Other defense claims will say the U.S. invasion violated Panama's sovereignty and international treaties, and that Noriega is a chief of state and subject to immunity, Rubino said. But last year, Hoeveler ruled that the United States has jurisdiction in the case because the State Department never recognized Noriega's political legitimacy. Rubino said the Panamanian general surrendered following statements that Panama would revoke the diplomatic status of the papal nuncio, and because the embassy was surrounded by angry crowds and U.S. soldiers. Vatican officials, however, said Noriega left voluntarily. In Washington, a senior Bush administration official said the Vatican planned to order Noriega to leave by noon Thursday. Rubino said he will likely request a bond hearing within 30 days. The judge ordered Noriega held without bond. Tom Cash, head of the Drug Enforcement Administration in Miami, said Noriega's capture was only one benchmark in the nation's drug war. ``We're not going to open cases of champagne. We'll take it one glass at a time,'' he said. Noriega walked into the downtown courtroom without handcuffs or shackles. Each time Hoeveler asked a question, he rose and removed his headphones used for translation. He answered softly in Spanish and stared at the judge, showing no emotion. Noriega and 15 others were indicted in February 1988 by a federal grand jury in Miami. Noriega also faces charges in Tampa. Bush administration sources said Noriega was assured he would not be tried under a statute that carries the death penalty for drug-related killings. Five other defendants in the indictment have appeared in court in Miami. Noriega's whereabouts today were a losely guarded secret. ``We will only say that he is in a secure facility,'' said Justice Department spokesman Daniel Eramian in Washington. Although officials refused to divulge details of security measures, they acknowleged precautions were stepped up. ``The security taken is in line for such a high-visibility defendant,'' said U.S. Marshals agent Darrell William. Noriega landed early Thursday at Homestead Air Force Base south of Miami and immediately was taken to a basement holding cell at the federal courthouse. Outside, Panamanian exiles celebrated Noriega's capture and scuffled briefly with a protester opposing the U.S. invasion. Two airplanes flew overhead with banners saying ``Bye Bye, Tony'' and ``Rent This Ad When Fidel Falls,'' showing Cuban-American solidarity with Panamanians. Among the witnesses expected to testify against Noriega are Jose Blandon, the former Panamanian consul in New York, and several co-defendants. ``The informants will fall like pineapples from a tree now that Noriega is in custody,'' said Richard Sharpstein, attorney for co-defendant Brian Alden Davidow.

DOC.HEAD: Female Cabinet Minister Drops Challenge to Sumo Tradition
DOC.NOTE: Eds: One name only for Futagoyama
DOC.TEXT: Tradition won over women's rights today, as Japan's chief government spokeswoman abandoned her challenge to an ancient taboo that bans women from entering the sumo ring. The battle began in December, when Chief Cabinet Secretary Mayumi Moriyama informed the Japan Sumo Association that she intended to present the Prime Minister's Cup to the winner of the New Year Grand Sumo Tournament from inside the ring. The Prime Minister's Cup since 1978 has been presented by the deputy chief Cabinet secretary to the winner of the annual 15-day New Year's tournament, which begins Sunday. But Mrs. Moriyama, who last year became the first woman to hold the important Cabinet post, asked to present the award herself to challenge a tradition that forbids women from entering the ring, a raised mound of clay about 14 feet in diameter. ``What Mrs. Moriyama meant to do was to raise the issue to improve women's social position,'' the deputy Cabinet secretary, Nobuo Ishihara, told reporters Friday. But after sumo officials stated their opposition, she decided not to push the issue further, Ishihara said. Futagoyama, the chairman of the sumo association, told reporters today that ``I don't know how things will change in the future, but I appreciate (her) understanding.'' On Thursday, the former wrestler had said the ring ``is sacred and we must preserve our traditions.'' It was not until 1778 that women were allowed to watch bouts _ but only on the final day of tournaments. A century later, women were allowed to watch throughout tournaments, but not permitted to go up on the ring, a tradition which remains the same to this day, even though the 2,000-year-old sport has gained many female fans. At Ryogoku national gymnasium in Tokyo, which opened in 1909, women were banned from the first five rows around the ring until after World War II, said Lora Sharnoff in her recently published book, ``Grand Sumo.'' ``Although her challenge didn't work this time, things have changed, and I believe they will also change in the future,'' said Ryoichi Maki, a secretary to Mrs. Moriyama. ``Sumo symbolizes the male-dominated structure of our society,'' said Yoko Morosawa, a researcher on women's issues. ``I'm glad Mrs. Moriyama did this. Although she won't be able to climb into the ring, her action definitely contributed to making more people realize the problem.''

DOC.HEAD: N.J.-Pa. Hospitals Asked to Cancel Elective Surgery Due to Blood Shortage
DOC.TEXT: The regional American Red Cross is asking hospitals in southeastern Pennsylvania and southern New Jersey to cancel all elective surgery because of a critically low supply of blood. The request was to go to 93 hospitals in the region, said Susan Snyder, a spokeswoman for the Penn-Jersey region of American Red Cross Blood Services. The hospitals ``will all be advised that we can't support elective surgeries,'' she said Thursday. In Georgia, four Atlanta-area hospitals also canceled elective surgeries because of low blood supplies. Elective surgery includes operations that may be necessary to a patient's health but not those needed to save a life. Ms. Snyder said surgeries have been canceled previously because of blood shortages, ``but there haven't been cancellations this severe, such extensive and planned cancellation of elective surgery in at least 10 years.'' The request came on the second day of an emergency appeal for blood donors as the Red Cross said it fell 4,500 units short during December and had virtually no blood available of types O negative and B negative. Donation levels typically drop during the holiday season, but they were reduced even further when the unusually cold December kept people from going to donation centers, the Red Cross said. The Red Cross, which provides 94 percent of the blood used in the 93 hospitals, needs about 1,750 donors a day and was down to about 1,000 last month. Donors increased to 1,347 Wednesday and more callers were seeking information Thursday, the Red Cross said. ``The initial response we are seeing is very gratifying,'' said Dr. William C. Sherwood, director of the Penn-Jersey region. In Atlanta, surgeries were delayed for a pregnant woman needing abdominal surgery, a man awaiting open-heart surgery, a patient waiting for a liver transplant, and a patient with a bleeding ulcer, Anne Willcox, a Red Cross representative, said Thursday. After an appeal for donations, about 1,300 people donated blood Wednesday, Red Cross officials said, but that response was not matched Thursday. The Red Cross normally needs 900 units of blood a day to meet the demands of the more than 100 hospitals in the 82-county Atlanta region, but donations dropped as low as 300 units a day over the holidays, said Beth V. Greenberg, administrative director of Red Cross Donor Services.

DOC.HEAD: Four Killed in Shiite Battles; President Planning Move to West Beirut
DOC.TEXT: Rival Shiite Moslem militias battled with machine guns, mortars and rocket-propelled grenades today in south Lebanon, killing four people and wounding 12, including three PLO guerrillas sent in to quell the violence, police said. President Elias Hrawi, meanwhile, planned to set up his office and residence in a west Beirut building to avoid the risks of commuting in the Moslem area, where his predecessor was killed by a car bomb. Fighters of the Syrian-backed Amal and pro-Iranian Hezbollah militias fought in south Lebanon's Apple Province as they continued their more than 2-year-old war for mastery of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites. A police spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity in line with regulations, said the wounded Palestinians were caught in cross-fire as Amal repulsed two thrusts by Hezbollah fighters in the village of Kfar Hatta. The Palestinians, from the mainline Fatah faction of the PLO, are based between the Amal-held Kfar Hatta and the neighboring village of Kfar Milki, which is controlled by Hezbollah. They were part of a 300-member force deployed over the weekend to quell the militia fighting, the police spokesman said. The casualties today raised the overall toll to 77 killed and 275 wounded since the latest militia fighting began Dec. 23. Hrawi had been staying at an army barracks in east Lebanon's Bekaa valley since his election Nov. 24. The police spokesman said he was expected to move to west Beirut as soon as security arrangements were made. Hrawi planned to set up a residence and office in a seaside apartment building where his predeccesor, Rene Mouawad, lived. Mouawad's office was a 10-minute drive away, and he was killed by a car bomb Nov. 22 as he drove home from the office. ``The president will not leave the building unless on foreign trips,'' a government sources said of Hrawi. He spoke on condition of anonymity. ``We want to avoid risks.'' The presidential palace in Beirut's suburb of Baabda is the traditional seat of a head of state, but the Christian leader, Gen. Michel Aoun, refuses to leave the compound. Aoun rejected Hrawi's election, which came about as a result of an Arab League-sponsored plan aimed at ending 14 years of civil war. Aoun opposed the plan because it did not include a deadline for the withdrawal of Syria's 40,000 troops from Lebanon, and he denounced Hrawi as a Syrian puppet. Hrawi dismissed Aoun as the army leader, but Aoun continues to command 20,000 loyal troops controlling Lebanon's Christian enclave. France said today it had received a request from Lebanese Prime Minister Selim Hoss to freeze all French bank accounts belonging to Aoun. A French Foreign Ministry spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity, refused to discuss what the government might do in response. The French satirical and investigative weekly Le Canard Enchaine published a reproduction of a bank statement showing two accounts in Aoun's name at the Banque Nationale de Paris, one with $500,000 and the other with $14.7 million. In a radio interview Thursday, Aoun said the money came from donations by Lebanese supporters and was used to support his military effort. Syria's chief ally in Lebanon, Druse warlord Walid Jumblatt, alleged in an interview published today in Lebanon that PLO chief Yasser Arafat donated the money in hopes of regaining the PLO's foothold in Beirut. The PLO was driven out of Beirut during Israel's 1982 invasion of Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Lights Fail at Small Detroit Airport As Plane Prepares to Land
DOC.TEXT: A worn-out cable caused a blackout at City Airport, forcing officials to close the airport and divert at least two flights to the much-larger Detroit Metropolitan Airport. One of the planes, Southwest Flight 993 from Chicago, banked away from its landing when the runway and other lights flickered out about 10:45 p.m. Thursday, said passenger Bruce Babiarz. The airport temporarily had no radio, no communications and no navigational equipment, Federal Aviation Administration spokeswoman Martha Vercammen said. Generators were started up for the control tower but didn't have enough power to light the runway, forcing the airport to shut down until daylight, said George Cascos, deputy superintendent of the city Public Lighting Department. He said 300 feet of underground cable were being replaced today and that the lights were expected to be working again this afternoon. Babiarz said the pilot came on the intercom and said, ``I suppose you're all wondering why we didn't land.'' The plane circled for about 15 minutes. The pilot then announced that the airport was having major power problems and the flight would land at Metropolitan airport, about 30 miles southwest. Later, Southwest Flight 506 from Chicago, scheduled to arrive at 11:45 p.m., was also diverted to Detroit Metro. Both planes landed without incident and passengers were bused to City Airport.

DOC.HEAD: Mother Gets Six Months in Jail on Daughter's Drug Tip
DOC.TEXT: A woman turned in by her 8-year-old daughter was sentenced to six months in jail for possessing cocaine for sale. Superior Court Judge Kathryne Stoltz on Thursday also sentenced Carmen Garcia to three years of probation. After attending a drug-education program, Garcia's daughter, whose name was withheld, brought a suspicious bag of white powder to her teacher at her North Hollywood elementary school, police said. A laboratory test determined the powder was cocaine and police got a search warrant for Garcia's home that afternoon. Police arrested Garcia, 31, in October after they searched her home and discovered 14 other packets of cocaine. The girl was sent to live with her father at a separate home.

DOC.HEAD: Paper Quashed by Noriega Plans to Resume Publication
With PM-Noriega, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The forecful editorial voice of Panama's La Prensa newspaper will be heard again Sunday for the first time in nearly two years if its exiled publisher can ``patch it together'' in time. ``We are running around like chickens with our heads cut off buying computer parts and so forth and hoping to get our first edition out on the streets by Sunday morning,'' Roberto Eisenmann Jr. said Thursday. Eisenmann, who has worked as a Miami bank executive while in exile, planned to travel to Panama City today in the absence of ousted leader Gen. Manuel Noriega. Pro-Noriega forces repeatedly shut down the presses of Panama's leading independent newspaper, the last time in February 1988. After receiving a dire report on conditions at the newspaper office, Eisenmann said, ``I don't know how we're going to do it with 95 percent destruction, but we're going to do it.'' Staff members returned to the newspaper plant on Christmas Day for the first time since the closure. ``The team came together immediately, and everybody's been working around the clock cannibalizing all the equipment to make one computer out of three,'' he said. ``We're going to patch it together with Band-Aids and be on the streets.'' Eisenmann, whose voice had been a thorn in the side of Noriega, said he had ``absolutely no problem'' with U.S. prosecution of Noriega on drug charges. ``Panama at this point has no capability. The judiciary system is not yet organized,'' he said. ``There isn't even a secure jail in the country at this point.'' The publisher said he expected Noriega to be returned to Panama for prosecution on human-rights abuses after the U.S. trial. Meanwhile, Eisenmann's time was occupied with ordering computer parts and preparing to fly home. ``When you're in exile, you live for the return,'' he said. ``Everybody that I know is packing bags and getting ready to go back.''

DOC.HEAD: Japan Considering Aid Package, Envoy Says
DOC.TEXT: The Japanese government is considering an aid package to help Panama recover from the ravages caused by the U.S. military invasion, Japan's ambassador said in a meeting with Vice President Dan Quayle today. Quayle, at the start of the meeting with Ambassador Ryohei Murata, also announced that Japan has decided to formally recognize the U.S.-installed government of Guillermo Endara in Panama. Japan joins a handful of other nations that officially recognized the new government in the wake of the U.S. invasion that drove dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega from power last month. Bush administration officials have said they would like Japan and other nations to help boost Panama's economy and provide aid to compensate for the invasion-related destruction as well as the economic damage resulting from U.S. economic sanctions against the Noriega regime. Asked if Japan would provide such aid, Murata said he planned to ``discuss some of those things'' in the meeting with Quayle. Estimates range as high as $2 billion in damage to Panama's economy from the invasion. Entire neighborhoods were destroyed by bombing and fighting, and the central business district suffered heavy damage and looting. When the United States was exerting pressure on its friends around the world to break with Noriega in 1988, Japan was slow to respond, making its action now significant for the administration. Asked if Japan supported President Bush's decision to invade Panama, Murata declined to answer directly. ``We understand the background against which the U.S. decided to take that action,'' he said. Quayle said he hoped Japan's early recognition of the Endara government would encourage other nations to follow suit. ``This is another positive development in the Endara government establishing its credibility, not just in this hemisphere but around the world,'' Quayle said.

DOC.HEAD: Strikers Not Ready To Celebrate Yet
DOC.TEXT: Striking coal miners say they are eager to end a nine-month strike but won't decide about getting back to work until they get their hands on the tentative contract. ``We're not popping the champagne corks yet,'' Everett Street said Thursday at a United Mine Workers camp in Logan County. The union and Pittston Coal Group officials on Monday announced an agreement that would end a strike that has idled the company since April 5. Street said he needs to get a close look at the proposed pact. ``We don't have a contract yet and we aren't going back until we have one,'' he said. ``We vote next week to ratify it. If it passes, we go back. If it doesn't, we'll stay out here for another nine months.'' Copies of the contract have yet to be distributed to the 1,700 Pittston employees who struck in West Virginia, Virginia and Kentucky, and on Thursday the document still was being drafted. Miners waiting at Camp Solidarity II southwest of Logan were told to expect copies on Monday, said a UMW District 17 spokeswoman who declined identification. ``More and more people are just hanging around the camp, sitting and waiting,'' said Roger Nelson, an unemployed coal miner who helps run the camp. ``There are about 40, 45, 50 people here _ more than on an average day,'' he said Thursday. ``They're discussing it, and they're all optimistic about getting back to work.'' Neither the union nor Pittston has released details of the contract proposal. But neither side is denying published accounts that say Pittston and the UMW would pay into a separate trust fund for pensioners and that health benefits for retirees would be paid at 100 percent, except for some doctor visits and prescription drugs. The agreement also is contingent upon $65 million in fines against the union for strike violence being dropped. National Labor Relations Board charges against both sides also would be dropped. ``As of yet we don't have a schedule for ratification,'' UMW spokeswoman Kirsti Smith said Thursday. ``We still have to get hold of the trustees and courts and NLRB. As soon as we have a schedule we'll make it public.'' At Pittston operations in Virginia, replacement employees continued at work pending ratification. Company spokeswoman Susan Copeland said Thursday it wasn't clear what would happen to the replacement workers when, or if, the union miners return. The use of replacement workers led to violence, and at one point more than 46,000 miners in 10 states staged a wildcat sympathy strike fearing a Pittston victory would encourage other companies to fight the union.

DOC.HEAD: Liberian Fighting Said to Destroy Two Towns
DOC.TEXT: Fighting between Liberian forces and rebels opposed to President Samuel K. Doe has destroyed two towns in northeastern Liberia and sent thousands fleeing across the border, Western diplomats said today. The fighting began nearly two weeks ago in eastern Nimba County, where Doe said two groups of rebels entered Dec. 24 from neighboring Ivory Coast. One of the groups killed a police sergeant at the border town of Butuo before government forces ``arrested the situation,'' while the other group reached the capital, Monrovia, but abandoned their weapons and surrendered, Doe said Tuesday. A Western diplomat contacted by telephone in Monrovia said today he understood most of the dissidents had been killed, captured or fled. Diplomats, who refused to be identified, said it was difficult to determine the exact number of Liberians fleeing the hostilities because the border area is heavily forested and communications are poor. ``People are trying to get out of the contested area,'' one said. ``The number, however, is anyone's guess.'' Emmanuel Bowier, Liberia's information minister, refused to discuss the situation when contacted today by The Associated Press. Doe said Thursday that the situation in Nimba County was returning to normal and invited journalists to visit the area, but ``at their own risk as military operations were continuing.'' The Liberian News Agency reported today that Doe himself was going to the area, which is under a dusk-to-dawn curfew. The diplomats said it could take awhile for the government to dislodge all the dissidents in the sparsely populated region 100 miles northeast of Monrovia. One diplomat said the towns of Kahntle and Butuo were destroyed in the fighting. Justice Minister Jenkin Scott said Tuesday the invaders numbered 96 and they had been trained in Burkina Faso and Libya. Ivory Coast repeatedly has denied Liberia's charges it harbors Doe's opponents. Burkina Faso also denied any role in the invasion. The dissidents are led by Charles Taylor, a former civil servant in Doe's government. They call themselves the National Patriotic Front and appear to have no connection with Liberia's opposition parties, said a diplomat. Doe is a former sergeant major in Liberia's army. He came to power in a bloody coup in April 1980 in which President William Tolbert, a descendant of freed American slaves, and most of his political allies were killed. Doe himself has withstood several alleged plots.

DOC.HEAD: Feds Charge Reputed Mobster With Supervising `Joint Venture' Drug Conspiracy
DOC.TEXT: A reputed member of the Gambino crime family has been accused of supervising a ``joint venture'' of American and Italian organized crime groups to import heroin into the United States. An indictment unsealed Thursday charges John Gambino with conspiracy to import and distribute heroin and cocaine from 1978 to 1988, distribution of heroin and racketeering. He was arrested outside his home Wednesday and a bail hearing was scheduled today. Gambino was added as a defendant in a pending federal indictment that had already charged his brother, Giuseppe, and 14 other men. The other defendants, first charged in December 1988, are scheduled for trial in April. The Pennsylvania Crime Commission says Gambino is a cousin of Carlo Gambino, the nation's top Mafia boss at the time of his death in 1976. Authorities say the Gambino crime family is now headed by John Gotti. FBI spokesman Joseph Valiquette said the suspect was the same John Gambino who was described in 1983 as a captain in the Gambino crime family's southern New Jersey unit. A New Jersey state police report on organized crime said Gambino was involved ``in heroin trafficking and was recently (February 1982) indicted in Italy on counts of conspiracy to import drugs into Italy, manufacture heroin and import it into the United States.'' The Pennsylvania Crime Commission has reported that he was deported in 1958 as an illegal alien, but returned to the United States, married a cousin, and settled in New York. The indictment said John Gambino, identified as Giovanni in the indictment, and his brother were in charge of a Gambino family crew that operated out of a cafe in Brooklyn. ``Since at least 1978, the Sicilian and American branches of the Mafia conducted a joint venture to import multiple kilogram quantities of heroin into the United States through Giovanni Gambino and his subordinates in New York,'' the indictment said. As an example, the indictment said Gambino and his crew allegedly received more than 500 kilograms _ 1,100 pounds _ of heroin from the Sicilian Mafia between late 1978 and mid-1979. Gambino's attorney, Robert Ellis, opposed his client's detention, saying he had serious health problems that date back to a stroke in 1985 and open heart surgery in 1987. Ellis said Gambino works in the construction industry. If convicted of the charges, Gambino could be sentenced to life in prison and fined millions of dollars. According to the Pennsylvania Crime Commission, Gambino was one of several cousins of Carlo Gambino who moved in 1972 to southern New Jersey, where they established restaurants that allegedly were used as fronts for drug dealing. A younger brother, Rosario Gambino, of Cherry Hill, N.J., was convicted in 1984 of heading a $200 million-a-year heroin ring and is serving a 45-year sentence.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Assad To Punish Jibril If Involved In Plane Bombing
DOC.TEXT: Syrian President Hafez Assad promised to punish a breakaway Palestinian leader if Washington provides proof that he was involved in the December 1988 bombing of the Pan Am Flight 103, a newspaper reported today. The Kuwaiti daily Al-Qabas said the pledge was made in a letter Assad recently sent to President Bush in reply to a message on three regional problems _ terrorism, Lebanon and the Arab-Israeli conflict. The report quoted unidentified ``informed sources'' in the Syrian capital, Damascus, as saying Assad reiterated in the message that his country rejects ``all forms of terrorism.'' A bomb concealed in a radio-cassette player exploded on the New York-bound plane over Lockerbie, Scotland on Dec. 21, 1988, killing all 259 people on board and 11 people on the ground. The bomber has not been identified, but suspicion has falled on the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, led by Ahmed Jibril, a former Syrian army captain. Jibril's group has been blamed for a series of terrorist attacks since it broke away from the mainstream Palestinian faction, Fatah, which is led by Palestine Liberation Organization chief Yasser Arafat. According to Al-Qabas, Bush told Assad: ``Washington has evidence that the operation was planned in Syria and that some of those who carried it out came from Syrian territory.'' The report said Bush asked Assad to help arrest the terrorists so they can be tried in the United States. Al-Qabas said: ``Damascus asked Washington to send the evidence that proves Jibril's involvement, expressing readiness to punish all those who turn out to be guilty.''

DOC.HEAD: Survivor of Boat Accident Recalls Deaths of Other Boaters
DOC.TEXT: The lone U.S. survivor of a chartered scuba diving boat that sank in chilly Gulf of California waters says a wetsuit helped save his life as others clutching the same piece of wreckage lost their grip. ``I saw them die,'' Opha Watson said in an interview published today in the Los Angeles Times. ``It took hours, but they had to give up. The cold water just saps your energy. Without my wetsuit, I wouldn't be here today.'' ``Honestly, I began to believe that I wouldn't make it through the night,'' said Watson, a 62-year-old retired engineer, speaking from his Tucson, Ariz., home on Thursday. He was one of two men who survived the wreck of the Santa Barbara, a converted 68-foot fishing boat on a scuba diving expedition. Fourteen others are still missing after the ship went down early New Year's Day in the Gulf of California, about 25 miles west of the Mexican port of Guaymas. The Silent Experience Scuba Center and Caiman Expeditions, both of Tucson, arranged the charter. The other survivor, Vicente Gonzalez Mancilla, a 25-year-old Mexican machinist boat crew member, moved in the chilly waters for some 35 hours with only a life preserver and some plastic covering he used for flotation and warmth. ``I never stopped moving,'' Gonzalez said Thursday from the Social Security Hospital in Santa Rosalia, the Baja California town where he was taken after a passing ferry boat rescued him Tuesday afternoon. Watson was picked up by the private rescue craft Sala del Mar just before dusk Tuesday. Still missing are 10 U.S. citizens, seven from Arizona and three from California, along with four Mexican crew men. As gulf weather conditions worsened Thursday, U.S. and Mexican officials suspended their search, saying there was little hope of finding survivors. The shipwreck occurred about 3:15 a.m. Monday when extremely high seas created several huge waves that swamped the vessel, the survivors said. The boat sank within minutes, before lifeboats could be launched.

DOC.HEAD: Cancer Prize Goes to Former Head of Cancer Institute, Harvard Scientist
DOC.TEXT: The $100,000 Hammer Prize for cancer research will be awarded to Dr. Vincent T. DeVita Jr., former director of the National Cancer Institute, and Dr. Emil Frei III of Harvard University. The recipients of the 1989 prize were announced Thursday by Armand Hammer, chairman and chief executive officer of Occidental Petroleum Corp. ``Very many cancer victims, and especially children, owe their recovery from leukemia and Hodgkin's disease to these dedicated scientists, who continue to make important contributions to new and improved cancer therapy,'' Occidental said in a statement. DeVita, now physician-in-chief at New York's Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, served as director of the government's cancer research agency from 1980 to 1988. Frei directs Harvard's Dana-Farber Cancer Institute. Hammer, a longtime patron of cancer research, said DeVita was getting the award for pioneering work in developing combinations of chemotherapy drugs to safely treat and cure cancer, particularly Hodgkin's disease. Frei was cited for developing combinations for chemotherapy drugs to treat leukemia, and for helping show how such drug combinations work. While the scientists faced initial skepticism about the effectiveness of combinations of chemotherapy drugs to treat cancer, ``they persevered to the ultimate benefit of the patients they treated,'' the Occidental statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-war Activist Wooed for U.S. House Seat
DOC.TEXT: Ron Kovic, the real-life Vietnam veteran and anti-war activist portrayed in the movie ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' is being recruited to run for Congress against conservative Rep. Robert K. Dornan. Kovic, 43, whose autobiography was made into the Tom Cruise film directed by Oliver Stone, is being wooed by the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, the Los Angeles Times reported Friday. ``We met with Mr. Kovic. We encouraged him to run,'' said Howard M. Schloss, a spokesman for the committee. Kovic declined to return telephone calls seeking comment, but a longtime friend, political consultant Sid Galanty, said Kovic was intrigued by the committee's interest. ``I think he was very taken by the fact that some of the most powerful men in the Democratic leadership in the country would want to meet him and convince him to run for office,'' said Galanty. The Republican Dornan, 56, said he would welcome a challenge from Kovic for his seat representing affluent, conservative Orange County. ``Kovic is going to have to defend the Hollywood far left,'' Dornan said. ``If he thinks he's going to recruit Oliver Stone and Top-Gun-turned-top-malcontent Tom Cruise, and bring the whole Jane Fonda team down here to Orange County, I welcome it. Let's go.'' Though representing both ends of the political spectrum, Kovic and Dornan both have a flair for attracting attention. Kovic, paralyzed from the chest down by a Vietnam war wound, became a key leader of the anti-war movement after his return home. Dornan, nicknamed ``B-1 Bob'' for his strong support of military projects, is a staunch and blunt-spoken foe of abortion and homosexual rights. The pair also have something in common, according to Dornan. During the 1972 Republican National Convention in Miami, Dornan _ then a television producer _ let in Kovic and another disabled veteran. The two veterans briefly disrupted the proceedings. ``I personally wheeled him in,'' Dornan said. ``Against my better judgment, but he promised he'd be polite.'' Kovic also appeared three times on a local talk show Dornan was host of from 1970 to 1973, the lawmaker said.

DOC.HEAD: Priest Asked To Resign Because He Enforced Dress Code
DOC.TEXT: A Roman Catholic priest who denied communion to worshippers who violated his dress code has been asked to leave his Dayton parish, a spokeswoman for the archdiocese of Cincinnati said today. She would not confirm a published report that the Rev. Roger Griese had been removed from Sacred Heart Church in Dayton _ an action he could appeal to the Vatican. The Cincinnati Enquirer reported that Archbishop Daniel Pilarczyk ordered Griese to give up his post effective Wednesday. ``He has been asked to leave,'' spokeswoman Rita Reilly said today. Ms. Reilly would not comment further. The Rev. Daniel Conlon, chancellor of the archdiocese, declined to comment. A woman answering the door at Sacred Heart Rectory said Griese was not in and that she didn't know when he would be back. Messages left for Griese were not immediately returned. However, Griese told the Dayton Daily News early today: ``I haven't lost anything.'' He did not elaborate. The 73-year-old priest criticized Pilarczyk from the pulpit during Mass on Sept. 17, after Pilarczyk instructed him to ease enforcement of a church dress code banning shorts, miniskirts, sun dresses and jeans. Griese had twice denied communion to a man who went to church dressed in shorts. Griese, who has been pastor of Sacred Heart for 21 years, will remain a priest in good standing, Pilarczyk said in a letter quoted by the Enquirer. The church's mandatory retirement age is 75. A letter is to be read Sunday to Sacred Heart parishioners, announcing Griese's departure and the appointment of a new pastor, the Enquirer reported.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Postpones Meetings to Concentrate on Soviet Unrest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 3rd pvs, ``The reports...'' to UPDATE with reaction on Wall Street. Pickup 4th pvs, ``The reaction...''
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has put off appointments with foreign visitors for the time being to deal with domestic unrest and a political crisis in Lithuania, a source said today. ``It's right,'' said one senior Communist Party official when asked about news reports that Gorbachev had postponed planned meetings with Britain's opposition leader and other foreign dignataries. ``We have many problems right now.'' The reports sent share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange into their worst plunge since Oct. 16. In New York, stock prices declined slightly in an atmosphere of uneasiness over the economic outlook and political developments in the Soviet Union. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down about 17 points at its early-morning low, was off .43 at 2,795.65 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. The reaction demonstrated how closely Gorbachev is linked by many in the West to the success of the economic and political reforms and reductions in East-West tensions he has pursued since becoming Kremlin leader in March 1985. The party official, speaking on condition of anonymity, cited disturbances along the Iranian border and the Lithuanian Communist Party's decision to break away from the ruling national party headed by Gorbachev. Soviet Azerbaijanis have tried for four days to force open the frontier and reunite with their ethnic brethren in Iran, tearing down guard towers and prompting the KGB to reinforce security along the frontier. A protest organizer said Thursday the demonstrators were in retreat. Gorbachev met for more than five hours Thursday with Lithuanian party leaders, who said afterward he failed to sway them from their decision to split from the 20 million-member ruling party and pursue local independence. The policy-making Central Committee of the national party has directed Gorbachev to go to Lithuania to try to mend the split. The No. 2 party leader in Lithuania, Vladimir Beriozov, said the visit would begin Wednesday and last through Friday. Meanwhile, the Estonian Communist Party threw its support to the Lithuanians in the dispute with Moscow, local journalist Tarmu Tammerk said today. The Estonian party's Central Committee meeting on Thursday also set March 23 for its own full congress, which is expected to vote on a similar proposal to split from the Soviet party, he said. The Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman, Gennady I. Gerasimov, would neither confirm nor deny the report that Gorbachev was putting aside foreign questions to concentrate on the domestic situation. Asked about a report from London that the Soviet Ambassador to Britain, Leonid Zamyatin, had told Labor Party leader Neil Kinnock that Gorbachev was postponing a meeting with Kinnock and all contacts with foreign politicians this month, Gerasimov replied: ``Has this meeting been planned? Let The Associated Press compose its own commentary. For me this is all clear. Let them comment on that as they wish.'' A spokesman for Britain's opposition Labor Party said Zamyatin delivered a personal message from Gorbachev to Kinnock, who had been scheduled to visit Moscow for talks on Jan. 16. The message said the meeting had to be postponed because ``political events in the Soviet Union'' required Gorbachev's ``personal attention and participation,'' the Labor spokesman said. The spokesman, who in accordance with British practice declined to be named, said Gorbachev's message stated that the Soviet leader was ``postponing contact with foreign politicians scheduled for January.'' Gorbachev's calendar is rarely made public, and foreign visitors sometimes come to Moscow expecting to gain an audience with him but failing to do so. Whenever he disappears from the public eye, speculation about his activities and even his health becomes rife. The Kremlin leader was last seen on state-run television delivering a taped New Year's Eve address to the nation Dec. 31. Moscow-based official media did not report on his closed-door meeting Thursday with the Lithuanians. News of Gorbachev's plans to cancel appointments with visitors sent the Tokyo Stock Exchange's 225-issue Nikkei average into a tailspin. The leading market indicator closed down 438.12 points, or 1.1 percent, from Wednesday. It was the largest single-day loss on the exchange since a 647-point plunge on Oct. 16. ``To Japan, the worst thing that could happen to the world scenario would be for Gorbachev to drop from sight,'' said Chris Schreiber, an investment analyst with New Japan Securities. Gorbachev is regarded in Japan as the key to global stability, he said. The president's efforts to reform Soviet society and politics have created troubles at home, however. More than 300 people have died nationwide in ethnic unrest in two years. And in an atmosphere of growing restiveness among the Soviet Union's many ethnic groups, the Dec. 21 vote by a congress of Lithuanian Communists to break with Moscow could trigger a stampede from central party control elsewhere. Beriozov, the Lithuanian party leader, reported after the meeting with Gorbachev that the president said he would not interfere. ``We determined our positions, from which we will not be moved,'' Romualdas Ozolas, a member of the Lithuanian party's 19-member ruling bureau, told state-run TV in Vilnius, the republic's capital. Previously, Gorbachev opposed the Lithuanian decision to split from the national party. But he and other officials have also indicated the Kremlin would not use force to keep the secessionist Baltic republics in line. Lithuania's actions ran counter to more than seven decades of recognized local party subservience to the Kremlin. The Soviet party's 250-member Central Committee, which sets policy and can change the party's leader _ now Gorbachev _ reportedly includes members who advocate taking strong measures against the separatists.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't to Fire 126,000 Employees
DOC.TEXT: The government will fire about 126,000 of its employees this month in a bid to weed out unqualified civil service workers who got their jobs through political patronage, an official said Friday. The affected employees hold temporary positions they received through the intercession of politicians, said Patricia Santo Tomas, head of the Civil Service Commission. ``I would like to think that the 126,000 are people who not qualified,'' Santo Tomas said. ``They represent the patronage factor. We're trying to do away with political patronage.'' Not included are those employees without civil service eligibility but who have served for 10 years or more, she said. The government is the country's biggest employer, with about 1.6 million workers.

DOC.HEAD: Policeman Reports Partner Shoplifting Two-Cent Candy
DOC.TEXT: A policeman with a sweet tooth was turned in by his partner for shoplifting a two-cent piece of candy, but the state refused to prosecute the case, it was reported Friday. The two officers went into a closed candy store in November to investigate a burglar alarm, which turned out to be faulty, the TT news agency said. On the way out, one officer took a piece of candy, and was charged with shoplifting by his partner, TT said. Prosecutor Krister Waern said the charge was dropped because the candy store owner previously had offered treats to police when they came to his shop late at night to turn off false alarms, TT reported. Other police in Skovde, in south-central Sweden, agreed the officer was wrong to take the candy but said his partner should not have reported him. The officer was not identified, in keeping with Swedish law.

DOC.HEAD: Rebel Tribesmen Hijack 22 Elephants in Chittagong Hills
DOC.TEXT: Rebel tribesmen hijacked 22 government-owned elephants in the Chittagong hills, it was reported Friday. The elephants, which were trained to carry lumber, vanished along with their drivers last week in the Bagachari forest, 135 miles southeast of Dhaka, the United News of Bangladesh reported. The forest is in the Rangamati district, part of the Chittagong Hill Tracts where rebel tribesmen have been waging a bush war against the government since 1976. Government troops were searching the forests for the missing elephants and men, whose fate was not known, the news agency said. The elephants belonged to the government's Bangladesh Forest Industries Development Corp. Rebels from the Chakma and other tribes seek autonomy for the hill region, which is rich in timber and natural gas and lies along the Burmese and Indian borders. More than 4,000 people have died in the 14-year-old guerrilla war. An estimated 30,000 tribespeople have fled to India to escape the fighting.

DOC.HEAD: Dozens Killed in Uganda Bus Crash
DOC.TEXT: A bus traveling at high speed struck a tractor-trailer northwest of Kampala on Friday, killing more than 30 people and injuring 11, police said. Police did not know how many people were on the government-owned Uganda Transportation Company bus, which legally can carry 59, although sources said it was packed with people who were returning to the capital from villages where they spent the recent holidays. Police spokesman Oballell Omoding said 22 people were dead at the scene, which was 18 miles northwest of Kampala, and eight others died en route to the hospital; 11 were in serious condition at the government's main hospital; 15 people were unhurt. Omoding said he believed there were more dead in the wreckage. The bus driver was killed in the accident, but the truck driver survived and fled before police arrived, Omoding said.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Could Interfere With Space Shuttle Launch
DOC.TEXT: Meteorologists issued a gloomy weather forecast Friday that could interfere with the launch of the space shuttle Columbia on a 10-day satellite rescue mission. ``Other than the weather, we're looking good,'' NASA test director Ron Phelps told reporters. He said only a 40 percent chance of favorable weather was predicted for launch time Monday because a rain front was expected to move into central Florida on Saturday and linger for a while. Phelps said the countdown, which started Thursday, was ``real smooth, and we're not tracking any major problems at the launch pad.'' The main task Friday was loading liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen for Columbia's electricity-producing fuel cells. Liftoff is scheduled for 8:10 a.m. Monday for the first of a record 10 space shuttle missions scheduled in 1990. The crew is to deploy a Navy communications satellite and then track down and retrieve a 21,400-pound science laboratory the size of a small bus before it falls back to Earth. The laboratory, which has been orbiting nearly six years, will be returned to Earth for a study of its 57 experiments to determine the effects of long exposure to the radiation and vacuum of space. Trackers estimate that the lab would re-enter the atmosphere on Feb. 28 if not retrieved before then. Liftoff had been scheduled before Christmas, but problems with the launch pad, which recently underwent a $50 million overhaul, forced a postponment. The mission's commander is Dan Brandenstein. The other crew members are pilot Jim Wetherbee and mission specialists Bonnie Dunbar, Marsha Ivins and David Low. Brandenstein and Dunbar have made shuttle flights, while the others will be on their first trip.

DOC.HEAD: Immigrants May Be Forced to Leave Because They're Christians
DOC.TEXT: Nineteen members of a Soviet family who immigrated to Israel this week may have to find another place to live after disclosing that they are not Jews but members of a Christian sect. Pyotr and Alexandra Trofimov arrived in Israel with 17 children and grandchildren on Dec. 31 after emigrating from the Crimean city of Simferopol. Like Jewish immigrants to Israel, the Trofimovs were granted automatic citizenship and given certificates entitling each family member to $175 and extensive housing and education benefits. They were housed in three modern apartments in the port city of Haifa. The government apparently learned through news reports later that the family is not Jewish but Pentecostal, a fundamentalist Christian sect. Pyotr Trofimov, 63, said that Pentecostals are persecuted in the Soviet Union. ``We did not feel ourselves morally free because we are Christian believers,'' he said in an interview. ``My apartment was searched several times and there have been a number of arrests'' of fellow believers, he said. He added his children had employment problems because of their religion.
