A spokeswoman for Israel's Interior Ministry said Friday the family members would be called in and may ``have to find another place in the world to live.'' The Soviet Union does not take back citizens who have emigrated. Pyotr said the family came to Israel on an invitation through a daughter who earlier left for the United States. Some Christians are known to use invitations from Israel to escape to other countries. ``They took our visas and questioned us in small immigration offices and as they were talking to the first son, he told them we are Christians and believers,'' Pyotr said. But Tova Elinson, the spokeswoman for the Interior Ministry, which is responsible for issuing citizenship and visa permits, said the Trofimovs may have misrepresented themselves as Jews. She said they would not have been given citizenship if officials had known they were not Jews. ``It happens that a clerk may make a mistake on one person, but not 20!'' she said. The family may receive three-month tourist visas and temporary work permits, during which time they must find another place to live, Ms. Elinson said. Dov Kehat, director-general of the Interior Ministry, said the family may apply for Israeli citizenship, but it is rarely granted to non-Jews. In the early 1980s, Israel accepted several dozen Vietnamese ``boat people'' as residents. Nearly 12,000 Jews immigrated to Israel from the Soviet Union in 1989, a six-fold increase from 1988, and officials predict 30,000 to 50,000 will arrive in 1990. Asked if they would consider converting to Judaism, Alexandra Trofimov, 65, said she knew nothing about the religion but wanted to learn Hebrew and stay in Israel. ``We hope to get work here,'' she said on Israel radio. Pyotr Trofimov said he and his wife were manual laborers and that their children and grandchildren included computer programmers, drivers and photographers.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Tones Down Anti-Noriega Rhetoric Pending Drug Trial
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration, after months of condemning Panama's Manuel Antonio Noriega as a ``thug'' and a criminal, is toning down its rhetoric to avoid prejudicing the deposed dictator's drug-trafficking trial. Meanwhile, a Pentagon spokesman said today that an additional 900 American troops have returned to the United States, raising the total of servicemen who have left Panama since the Dec. 20 invasion to 2,900. The remaining forces in the country stood at 24,500, including the approximately 12,000 troops who were stationed in Panama before the invasion. The return of the 900 troops was due to the availability of transport aircraft and the release of ``individuals ... from their mission,'' said the spokesman, Lt. Col. Keith Schneider. There were no details on the return of specific units. The Defense Department also released revised figures on the number of Panamanians detained since the invasion. The original total of 5,600 was revised to 4,230. During the more than two-week period of the U.S. presence, 3,555 of the 4,230 detainees have been released. An administration official disclosed Thursday that Noriega surrendered to the U.S. military in Panama City only after the Vatican embassy gave him a deadline to leave. As defense officials were replacing U.S. combat troops in Panama with rebuilding forces, a senior official said Noriega's longtime CIA ties have been reviewed and that any potentially damaging disclosures Noriega might use in his trial defense will be ``manageable.'' President Bush kept a low profile on the day after he announced Noriega's Wednesday night surrender to U.S. forces in Panama. Only days earlier, he had called Noriega a ``thug.'' Bush telephoned Pope John Paul II to thank him for any efforts in persuading Noriega to leave the Vatican Embassy in Panama City and surrender, said the president's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater. Fitzwater was low-key in describing Noriega's surrender and flight to Florida. He declined to answer questions about prospects for Noriega's prosecution, saying, ``We feel the court system can handle this case based on the evidence that is presented and the indictments.'' Fitzwater's comments, and the later briefing by the senior official who spoke on condition of anonymity, contrasted with the inflammatory words the administration has used for months to describe Noriega. Bush himself set that tone, accusing Noriega of corruption, intimidation, coercion and fraud and calling him ``an outlaw in the world community.'' But with Noriega in custody in Miami, the focus shifted Thursday to the judicial system and his arraignment on charges of accepting a $4.6 million bribe from Colombian drug lords, and related crimes. Toning down the rhetoric now is ``a common-sense'' approach officials decided to honor, said one administration official. Fitzwater said Bush and his aides would be ``very careful in the days ahead not to offer any comments on the case that might prejudice it in any way.'' Fitzwater acknowledged the 1991 budget includes no aid money to repair invasion-related damage to Panama. Estimates range to more than $2 billion in losses due to bomb and combat damage, looting losses and the longer-range losses left by U.S. economic sanctions against the Noriega regime. ``Undoubtedly there will be some international funds, some bank loans and that sort of thing that would be involved, and at this point we just can't say how any aid might be financed,'' Fitzwater said. As Bush dispatched Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, to Panama on Thursday to arrange troop withdrawals, several Democratic members of Congress called for a quick pullout. Meanwhile, the senior official who spoke anonymously gave reporters new details about Noriega's surrender. Bush had stressed that the leader surrendered voluntarily, but the official said the Vatican gave Noriega a noon Thursday deadline to leave the embassy. ``The papal nuncio had said that his asylum or what have you would expire by noon today, meaning he (Noriega) would no longer be a welcome guest,'' the official said. In Panama City, Rev. Javier Villanueva, assistant to the papal nuncio, said it was made clear to Noriega that if he had not given himself up, ``the Panamanian government, not the U.S. government, would have been invited to send in forces to take him out.'' However, he said Noriega was not given a specific deadline. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said a Noriega bodyguard overheard two U.S. servicemen discussing the invasion of Panama hours before it occurred. It was unclear, however, whether the guard relayed that information to Noriega, Williams said. A U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration official said Noriega might eventually be returned to Panama for trial on other charges, including murder. That could happen after his U.S. trial, said David Westrate, assistant DEA administrator. Panamanian Vice President Guillermo Ford earlier said Noriega would be returned to Panama for trial on a long list of charges after his U.S. trial ends.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Suggests Peace Talks With Iran, Resuming Air Links
DOC.TEXT: President Saddam Hussein on Friday proposed resuming peace talks with Iran that have been stalled more than a year, and he suggested the long-hostile nations re-establish air links. ``We are seeking to open a new door for a dignified peace with Iran,'' Saddam said in a speech marking the 69th anniversary of the founding of the Iraqi army. He hailed advances by the Iraqi arms industry, including the recent launching of long-range missiles and of a rocket reportedly capable of putting a satellite in space. Saddam suggested that direct meetings between representatives of Iran and Iraq be held alternately in Tehran and Baghdad under the auspices of the U.N. secretary-general. Fighting in the eight-year Iran-Iraq war ended Aug. 20, 1988, when both sides accepted a cease-fire based on U.N. Security Council Resolution 598. Peace talks stalled immediately over interpretation of the terms of the resolution and priority in implementing its various clauses. Saddam said his proposed dialogue ``will aim at reaching a common understanding of the clauses of Resolution 598 and fix a timetable for its implementation ... provided that the talks are completed within a period not exceeding three months.'' There was no immediate response from Iran. Iran has insisted that resumption of talks be preceded by the withdrawal of Iraqi troops from 1,065 square miles of Iranian territory it claims are still under occupation. Iraq, meanwhile, wants Iran to accept a new border giving Iraq total control of the Shatt-al-Arab waterway. Under a 1975 accord, the border was drawn down the middle of the waterway, which is Iraq's main outlet to the sea. Saddam proposed an immediate exchange of all wounded and sick prisoners of war as the first step in reviving negotiations. That would be followed by the release of the longest-held POWs, mainly those captured in the early stages of the war, he said. He also called for registering thousands of prisoners who have not been included in lists provided to the Red Cross. The agency has registered 50,182 prisoners held by Iran and 19,284 by Iraq, but U.N. officials and diplomats say there are at least 100,000 POWs held by both sides. The Red Cross mediated an agreement to repatriate ailing and crippled POWs immediately after the cease-fire. The agreement collapsed after the release of only 400 prisoners as the sides accused each other of falsifying the number of captives. The president said establishing air links between Iran and Iraq would ``secure an atmosphere of peace and security among the people of Iran and Iraq.'' Air links between the countries were cut off shortly before the war broke out in September 1980. Dealing with the advances in Iraq's arms industry, Saddam attacked the United States for expressing concern over new Iraqi missiles without saying anything about Israel's nuclear capability. Iraq announced last month it had launched a 48-ton three-stage rocket capable of placing a satellite in space. It also said it had test-fired two surface-to-surface missiles with a range of 1,243 miles, long enough to reach Israel. Washington confirmed the test-firings. Israel complained the Iraqi advances, coupled with its stockpiling of chemical weapons and reported efforts to acquire a nuclear capability, posed a serious threat. Citing a similar excuse in 1981, Israel launched a long-range air raid that destroyed a French-built nuclear reactor near Baghdad. Saddam said Iraq will ``retaliate firmly and with precision to any attempt by the Zionist entity (Israel) to strike at Iraq's scientific or military installations.'' ``If Israel undertakes any aggression, the United States will not be able to absolve itself from the responsibility of encouraging such an act,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Traffickers Kidnap at Least 20 in War Against Government
DOC.TEXT: Drug traffickers in Medellin have abducted at least 20 people, including members of Colombia's richest families, as part of their terrorist war against the government, police said Friday. Most of the victims were kidnapped in the last two months in Medellin, the center of the country's cocaine trade, said a police spokesman in Medellin. The spokesman, reached by telephone, refused to identify himself. A statement sent by the Medellin cartel said traffickers had ordered the ``leaders of working-class neighborhoods to take members of the traditional oligarchy hostage.'' Half of the ransom paid by family members for the release of the hostages will be used to finance the war against the government of President Virgilio Barco, said the communique, published Friday in local newspapers. The cartel said it would use the other half of the money to finance the construction of housing for the needy. The communique did not mention the amount of ransom demanded by traffickers. The cartel offered no explanation as to why it would need money at a time when its reputed leader, Pablo Escobar, has a personal fortune estimated at $2 billion. Government officials have suggested that Escobar's cocaine smuggling business has been hurt by the government's war on drugs but it appeared the wave of kidnappings was the Medellin cartel's latest attempt to pressure the government into abandoning its war on drugs. Barco launched the offensive in August after traffickers killed Sen. Luis Carlos Galan, a leading presidential candidate. Authorities have confiscated hundreds of properties allegedly belonging to the traffickers, extradited 11 drug suspects to the United States and killed one leader of the Medellin cartel, Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, in a gunfight. Traffickers have responded with a wave of bombings and assassinations that have left 261 people dead and more than 1,200 injured. In the last few days, Medellin authorities have distributed handbills offering $450,000 reward for information leading to Escobar's capture. ``Yesterday it was Rodriguez Gacha; tommorow it will be Pablo Escobar,'' the handbills read. A spokeswoman for the investigative unit of the national police said that evidence indicates that Escobar ordered the Dec. 20 kidnapping of the son of Barco's closest adviser. A group of men apparently working for Escobar forced Alvaro Diego Montoya into a car as he was walking out of the northern Bogota offices of his financial services firm. The victim is the son of German Montoya, Barco's secretary-general. A senior government official, asking not to be identified, said anonymous callers to the president's office announced that Montoya would be held until Barco agreed to negotiate with traffickers. In Friday's communique, traffickers reiterated their willingness to talk but added they would never surrender to the government. ``We will not drop the flag, but will redouble our fight to surprise an imperialistic and unpatriotic government that has seen fit to declare itself victorious,'' the communique said. Barco's government has refused negotiation.

DOC.HEAD: Delta Says Trans-Atlantic Flights Threatened
DOC.TEXT: Delta Air Lines is beefing up security following a threat against the airline's trans-Atlantic flights, even though airline officials say they think it is a hoax. Delta spokesman Jim Lundy said Thursday the ``general threat'' did not name a particular flight, city or day. He would not discuss the nature of the threat or say when it was received. ``We really do believe it's a hoax, but we can't treat it that way,'' said Neil Monroe, another Delta spokesman. Federal Aviation Administration spokesman Richard Stafford said the agency was aware of the situation but refused to say what action, if any, was being taken. Delta's trans-Atlantic operations include flights to and from Germany, Ireland, England and France. Lundy said passengers were being notified of the threat upon check-in and were given the option of canceling or delaying their trips. Delta officials said Thursday evening that roughly only 20 to 30 of 700 ticket holders on its four international flights scheduled out of Atlanta during the night had switched airlines. Lundy said the intensified security would remain in effect until officials are sure the threat has ended or it is confirmed as a hoax. Last week, Northwest Airlines received a bomb threat against its flight from Paris to Detroit. After passengers were told they could cancel their tickets, a Northwest DC-10, which can carry 284 passengers, made a safe flight Saturday carrying 28 passengers and 14 crew members. ``There has been so much attention on the Northwest situation, it generates additional activity,'' Monroe said.

DOC.HEAD: Nebraska Supreme Court Defines Recklessness
DOC.TEXT: People who play contact sports can be held liable for the injuries they inflict on others if their conduct is willful or recklessly disregards others' safety, the state Supreme Court said today. The high court used a case stemming from a ``pickup'' basketball game in Omaha to spell out when people who participate in contact sports can be held responsible for injuries they cause to others. The judges also provided a definition of ``reckless'' behavior. The case involved a suit brought by Joseph Dotzler against Bruce Tuttle. Dotzler suffered two fractured wrists in 1984 when Tuttle allegedly pushed him during a basketball game at an Omaha YMCA. A jury decided the case in favor of Tuttle. The Supreme Court reversed that decision and ordered a new trial, saying District Judge Theordore L. Carlson didn't properly instruct the jury. The trial court shouldn't have allowed the issue of contributory negligence _ whether Dotzler's conduct was partly responsible for his own injuries _ to be considered, the Supreme Court said. Dotzler testified that he was standing still when he was allegedly pushed by Tuttle. Tuttle said he wasn't particularly aware of Dotzler's position on the basketball court. ``That was all of the evidence in the record and it was not sufficient to permit a finding by the jury of absence of lookout or lack of control'' on Dotzler's part, Chief Justice William Hastings wrote. ``Jury instructions should be confined to the issues found in the pleadings and which find support in the evidence,'' the opinion said. Judge C. Thomas White did not participate in the 6-0 decision. The judges said the case raised the issue of what constitutes ``recklessness'' under Nebraska law, and what standard of liability applies to someone who injures another during a contact sport. The judges held that ``a participant in a game involving a contact sport such as basketball is liable for injuries ... only if his or her conduct is such that it is either willful or with a reckless disregard for the safety of the other player, but is not liable for ordinary negligence.'' The high court defined recklessness in part as ``the disregard for or indifference to the safety of another or for the consequences of one's act.'' ``Recklessness differs from intentional wrongdoing in that while the act must be intended by the actor in order to be considered reckless, the actor does not intend to cause the harm which results from the act,'' the court wrote.

DOC.HEAD: Chief of Detroit District Court Kills Self, Police Say
DOC.TEXT: Longworth D. Quinn, chief judge of Detroit's 36th District Court and son of the longtime editor and publisher of the Michigan Chronicle, has died at age 46, apparently a suicide, police say. Quinn was found dead Thursday by his mother, Dorothy Quinn, at her home, police said. He had been shot once in the head. Inspector Gerald Stewart, who said Quinn apparently killed himself, said a will and other personal papers were stacked neatly together on a nearby dresser. Police said Quinn left a note but they declined to reveal its contents. A friend, the Rev. Dan Aldridge, said Quinn was despondent over the deaths of his father, Longworth M. Quinn, last year and of a girlfriend who jumped to her death from an apartment building in 1984. The elder Quinn ran the Michigan Chronicle, a weekly newspaper serving the black community, for many years. Quinn was elected to the district court in 1981 and was chosen chief judge by his colleagues in May. In addition to his mother, he is survived by two sisters. There was no immediate word of funeral arrangements.

DOC.HEAD: Three Months in Jail for Hit-Run Driving
DOC.TEXT: A man convicted of hit-and-run driving in the traffic accident that killed childhood kidnap victim Steven Stayner has been sentenced to 90 days in jail. Antonio Loera, 28, who had pleaded no contest, also was placed on probation for one year Thursday by Merced County Superior Court Judge George C. Barrett. His driver's license is automatically suspended for one year. Stayner's motorcycle slammed into Loera's car on a rain-slickened road. District Attorney Frank Dougherty said he agreed to the plea bargain because investigators found that the carburetor in Loera's car was defective and made the car stall. Dougherty said that prevented him from proving that Loera violated the right-of-way, so he dropped a vehicular manslaughter count. Stayner disappeared at the age of 7 while walking home from school in Merced in December 1972. In March 1980, Stayner turned up at the police station in Ukiah, about 200 miles north of Merced, with a 5-year-old boy who had been abducted from that area a few days earlier. Kenneth Parnell, a drifter, was sent to prison for kidnapping both youths but now is free on parole. Stayner returned to his parents in Merced, completed high school and was married in 1985. He and his wife had two children, aged 2 and 3. He was 24 when he died.

DOC.HEAD: Airlines Say `Die Hard II' Endorses Terrorism, Protest Stapleton Filming
DOC.TEXT: Airline officials are angry that portions of Bruce Willis' ``Die Hard II,'' will be shot at Stapleton International Airport, contending that the film ``is an endorsement of terrorism.'' ``It involves terrorism, violence against airports, destruction of an aircraft and a crash,'' Jack Ekey, general manager of United Airlines' Denver operations, said Thursday. ``As a matter or principle, we don't believe that kind of thing represents either airports or airlines in a way which we see ourselves or want the public to see us,'' he said. Twentieth Century-Fox plans to start shooting the film at Stapleton and in Weld County Jan. 15. Representatives of all airlines that use Stapleton lodged a complaint last week with airport officials. Greg Lazzaro, location manager of the film, said the airlines' position is ``total, unadulterated bull'' and ``preposterous and stupid.'' Ekey said the film script, which has not been shown to the airlines, is the story of a police officer's battle against terrorists who try to take over Dulles International Airport in suburban Washington. The plot of the sequel to ``Die Hard'' is heavy on wisecracks and liberal in the use of automatic weapons and plastic explosives in the abuse of private property, he said. ``To say it's an airport-bashing movie is unfair,'' Lazzaro said. ``It's not a movie about airlines; it's a movie about a New York cop who's in a cartoon.'' In response to the protests, Stapleton officials placed added restrictions on the filmmakers, including prohibiting the filming of real airline logos and aircraft. ``It really paints a bad picture of aviation and of all people who work at airports,'' said George Doughty, Denver aviation director. ``I don't like it either, but our position is that it's going to be filmed somewhere and there are some major benefits to letting it be filmed here.''

DOC.HEAD: Minimum Hard-Currency Exchange Rule Dropped for Foreigners
DOC.TEXT: The warming trend between East and West has had a positive side-effect for foreigners, with visitors no longer required to hand over a minimum of $14 for each day of their stay in East Germany Under an aid agreement with Bonn, East Germany has ended its age-old ``Zwangsumtausch,'' or the ``forced exchange'' that aimed to increase the socialist state's hard-currency coffers. Officials from the two nations announced in December that West Germans would no longer be required to make the minimum conversion after Jan. 1. The extension of the benefit to other foreigners has come as a surprise. ``We've heard that was the case, but we have nothing official on it yet,'' U.S. Embassy spokesman Jaroslav Verner commented when asked if U.S. authorities had been informed of the change. Tourists from the United States, France, Great Britain and other nations required to enter East Germany through Checkpoint Charlie have found empty money exchange booths at that border crossing. No public announcement of the policy change has been made, but East German officials confirmed Friday that all visitors can enter free of charge. Franz Koeckerbauer, spokesman for the Finance Ministry, said border authorities stopped demanding the exchange minimum on Dec. 23 when the Berlin Wall, which was built in 1961, was opened at the historic Brandenburg Gate. Hundreds of thousands poured through the new opening in the wall to make the towering gate accessible to pedestrians from East and West Berlin. East Germany's ADN news agency reported that 3.7 million people passed between East and West Berlin over the New Year's holiday weekend, although it did not indicate if that figure included an estimate of the thousands who simply scaled the graffiti-splattered wall rather than using designated border crossings. Bernd Schroeter, a spokesman for East Germany's state bank, said the decision to suspend minimum currency exchange requirements for all visitors was connected with the agreement reached with West Germany in early December. Under the deal agreed to by Communist Premier Hans Modrow and Rudolf Seiters, the chief of staff for Chancellor Helmut Kohl, Bonn is financing a special hard-currency fund for East Germans in exchange for ending the conversion minimum for West Germans. Schroeter said the West German measures compensating East Germany for the lost revenue extended to the entire fund, not just the revenue from West Germans. Western diplomats estimate that East Germany earned between $294 million and $441 million annually from forced conversion. Schroeter said he could not estimate what percentage of the total came from foreigners other than West Germans. Visitors are forbidden to take East German marks with them when they leave the country, so in the past much of the currency was left behind with friends or relatives, or squandered at overpriced restaurants. Under the new currency exchange rules, foreigners can change their hard currencies at a rate that gives them three times as many East German marks as under the old system _ but only if they want to.

DOC.HEAD: Two AIDS-Related Viruses Common Among Drug Users, Female Prostitutes
DOC.TEXT: Two distant cousins of the AIDS virus that usually are carried by drug users are also fairly common among female prostitutes, say researchers who interviewed and tested more than 1,300 prostitutes. The study released Thursday, done by researchers at the federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta, expands the groups considered at risk for the viruses and further underscores the importance of public-health efforts to prevent their spread, said Irvin Chen, an outside expert who also has done research on the viruses. The viruses, called HTLV-I and HTLV-II, are transmitted much like the AIDS virus: through shared hypodermic needles, sexual intercourse and from infected mothers to their babies. HTLV-I has been linked to a type of leukemia and a serious neurological disorder. As many as 5 percent of those who test positive for the virus eventually contract leukemia, the CDC researchers said. The second virus, HTLV-II, has not been clearly associated with disease. It is, however, so closely related to HTLV-I that tests sophisticated enough to differentiate between the two are not yet available, the researchers said. For that reason, researchers used a test for both viruses on the 1,305 prostitutes examined between 1986 and 1988. The women all were older than 18 and had had a median of 2,900 sexual encounters. Of those tested, 6.7 percent were found positive for the viruses, said Dr. Rima Khabbaz, lead researcher of the study reported in Friday's Journal of the American Medical Association. While the single most important risk factor for carrying the virus was drug abuse, 2.4 percent of the women who reported no history of intravenous drug abuse and had no needle marks also tested positive, according to the study. ``It's clear that both of these viruses are found in intravenous drug abusers in this country,'' said Chen, a researcher at the University of California-Los Angeles who specializes in the viruses. ``It's interesting that they're finding it in another group _ among female prostitutes. It just extends the range of the viruses.'' The researchers studied women in Atlanta; Miami; Los Angeles; San Francisco; southern Nevada; Colorado Springs, Colo.; Newark, N.J.; and four other New Jersey cities. Prostitutes in Newark were most likely to carry the viruses, with 25.4 percent testing positive, while none of the prostitutes tested in southern Nevada was found to carry the viruses. Khabbaz and Chen agreed that the findings carry important public-health implications. ``It's clear now that all of these viruses ... are transmitted in the same way,'' Chen said. ``In the public-health point of view, anything that can be done to prevent the spread of these viruses is essential.'' ``Control measures, such as the use of condoms to prevent other sexually transmitted diseases ... should be encouraged,'' Khabbaz and her colleagues wrote. ``Finally, control measures aimed at (intravenous) drug use and the sharing of needles and other blood-contaminated injection paraphernalia are urgently needed.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Precede KIRTLAND, Ohio
Thirteen Charged After Discovery of Five Bodies Buried at Ohio Farm
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates throughout with identification of victims, 13 defendants and details. No pickup. Changes byline.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos CD1, KX3
DOC.TEXT: Thirteen people have been charged with murder or conspiracy after five family members were found buried at an Ohio farm rented by the leader of a religious splinter group, federal authorities said today. Five of those charged were arrested late Thursday and early today in Kansas City and nearby Independence, said George Rodriguez of the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms in Kansas City. ``Two of those arrested have confessed to their participation in the mass murders,'' Rodriguez said at a news conference. He said authorities have a motive but would not release it. The Cleveland Plain Dealer, quoting police sources the newspaper did not name, said the five may have been killed as part of a religious sacrifice. Rodriguez said federal authorities would not comment on that report for fear of prejudicing juries. He said it was accurate to characterize Lundgren as the leader of a cult. The bodies of the Dennis Avery family were found Wednesday night and Thursday at a Kirtland, Ohio, farm. Rodriguez said they were members of a splinter religious group led by Jeffrey Lundgren, a former lay minister of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, which is headquartered in Independence. The dead were identified tentatively as Dennis Avery, 49; his wife, Cheryl, 42; and their three daughters, Trina, 13; Rebecca, 9; and Karen, 5. Rodriguez said the family, originally from Independence, apparently had lived off and on at Lundgren's farm in Ohio and were killed around April 16-18. Lundgren, 39, and his wife, Alice, 38, were among those charged and were being sought today. Lundren was charged with five counts of aggravated murder. His wife was charged with five counts of conspiracy to commit aggravated murder. Authorities were led to the bodies on farm about 25 miles northeast of Cleveland by an anonymous tip, said Kirtland Fire Chief Richard Martincic. The Plain Dealer quoted a police source as saying cult members had to perform the sacrifice before traveling west ``where they would be cleansed and could search for a `golden sword,''' which was not further characterized. A Kirtland police spokesman said officers who had worked on the investigation almost non-stop for 48 hours were resting early today and were unavailable for comment on the report of human sacrifice. Authorities would not say how the five died. Authorities sent the bodies to Cleveland for autopsies. A neighbor of the commune in Ohio said the group appeared to leave the area last April. Deputy Sheriff Rick Ring of Johnson County, Mo., said Lundgren and a group of people had been living in a barn near Chilhowee, a rural area about 45 miles southeast of Kansas City, and were last seen in the area in late October or early November. Rodriguez said it was not known whether Lundgren was in the Kansas City area, but authorities were in contact with his wife's parents in the area. The group led by Lundgren apparently disbanded late in December after members became disgruntled, Rodriguez said. Rodriguez said the group following Lundgren consisted of 29 men, women and children, but some members, including the Avery family, came and went. Ron Luff, 29, of Independence was arrested and charged with murder. Those arrested and charged with five counts each of conspiracy to commit aggravated murder were identified as Susan Luff, 31, of Springfield, and Dennis Patrick, 35, Tonya Patrick, 33, and Debbie Olivarez, 37, all of Independence. Those charged with murder but not in custody this morning were Richard Brand, 26, of Independence, Damon Lundgren, 19, no hometown given, and Gregory Winship, 29, of Euclid, Ohio. Kathryn Johnson, 36, of Holden was charged with conspiracy to commit aggravated murder but not yet arrested. The names of two others charged in the case were not released. Rodriguez said he expected more arrests later today. Those being held will be extradited to Ohio to face the state charges, he said. Lundgren left the church after his ministry credentials were revoked and formed his own religious group, said Dale Luffman, president of the northeast Ohio chapter of the Reorganized Church. Luffman would not describe the practices of Lundgren's group or why Lundgren lost his credentials. Another family and other individuals shared a house with Lundgren, his wife and children. The group of up to 10 people living at the house had been under investigation for more than a year for alleged civil rights violations, according to Kirtland Police Chief Dennis Yarborough, who declined to specify the alleged violations. Grant McMurray, world church secretary at the Reorganized Church's headquarters in Independence, Mo., said Lundgren's lay minister's credentials were revoked when his beliefs strayed too far from the church. McMurray said his church has about 250,000 members worldwide. He said it is not affiliated with the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, based in Salt Lake City, although both groups base their beliefs on the Book of Mormon and the Bible. Kirtland is an important site in the history of the church founded by Joseph Smith, Luffman said. Smith built a temple there in 1836, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Residents Angered by Stuart Shooting Development
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with activists' news conferences, picking up 7th graf pvs, `Police said...'.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Double Shooting, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Revelations that the suspect in a pregnant woman's killing was her husband, not an inner-city mugger as reported, stirred angry demands for amends from residents of the neighborhood where the slaying occurred. ``We're looking for an apology and we want it to go nationwide,'' cried Adline Stallings, who lives in the city's Mission Hill area. The mostly black neighborhood became the backdrop for the sensational case of Carol and Charles Stuart, middle-class, white suburban professionals, in what was cast as a fatal encounter with inner-city violence. Stuart, 29, told police that a mugger had fatally shot his 30-year-old wife in the head and shot him in the abdomen after they left a childbirth class at a hospital the night of Oct. 23. The story touched the worst fears among white America of black inner-city violence when it exploded in headlines and on news reports nationwide. At the first of two news conferences today to express concern over the case, Sadiki Kambon, director of thee Black Community Information Center in Roxbury, called on the mayor to fire police Commissioner Francis Roache. He accused the police of arresting a black man in the case ``because of his skin color and the Boston police's need for a victim to satisfy the hunger of white racism in Boston and America.'' Kambon cited allegedly abusive behavior by police in searches of black residents of the Mission Hill area during the investigation. ``I demand an apology from the mayor of Boston not just to Mission Hill, but to every black person in the city of Boston who was traumatized and victimized by political hysteria,'' said Louis Elisa, president of the NCAAP Boston chapter. ``Every white person was looking at members of the black community as a possible killer.'' Police said Stuart committed suicide Thursday morning by jumping off a Boston bridge after apparently learning that police were about to arrest him for the slayings of his wife and infant son, Christopher. The baby was born prematurely after the shooting and died 17 days later. Stuart claimed a black man was the assailant and police descended on the area, going house to house seeking anyone who fit the description he provided. ``It wasn't fair,'' said Stallings, a member of the Mission Main Task Force board of directors. The slant of the publicity, Ms. Stallings said, was ``as if we, the people who live here in this development, were involved in a crime.'' But words alone might not satisfy people like Sara Flint-Elsey, executive director of Tenants United for Public Housing Progress, a group representing the 60,000 public housing tenants in Boston. ``I got phone calls from relatives as far away as California. They said `What is going on in Boston? It's really pathetic,'' Ms. Flint-Elsey said. Ms. Flint-Elsey, who is black and lives in the largely black Roxbury section of Boston, said publicity around the Stuart case inflamed racial tensions not felt since the school busing crisis a decade ago. ``I felt this city was ready to explode on the implications that a black man had done this to a white woman,'' Ms. Flint-Elsey said. Mission Hill, where rescuers found the Stuarts, is part of the city already under siege from violence police blame largely on drugs and gang warfare. City Councilor Bruce Bolling, a black whose district includes part of Mission Hill, said the struggle of the poorer neighborhoods was irrevocably damaged by the way the story was presented and spread. ``It has left permanent shame on Boston's black community and has had a chilling effect on development,'' Bolling charged Thursday. ``This case has stirred the racial fears, not only in Boston, but nationally in neighborhoods in urban America,'' Bolling said ``A whole race of people have been maligned.'' In addtition to the reaction by blacks, residents throughout Boston and its suburbs were stunned and confused by the news. ``I would say the whole town is shocked. They were portrayed as a model couple,'' said Wally Arsenault, a restaurant manager in Reading, 15 miles north of Boston where the Stuarts lived.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Send `Fan Mail' to Romanian Embassy
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: ``Salute the heroic, fearless Romanian people,'' reads one postcard mailed to the Romanian Embassy in Beijing. It is signed, ``a Chinese.'' ``The dictator is ousted, welcome a new era,'' begins another, signed ``a Chinese citizen.'' The embassy has received several dozen messages of congratulations from official Chinese institutes, workers and even a soldier in the two weeks since Romanian citizens rose up against hard-line Communist leader Nicolae Ceausescu. ``All expressed solidarity with the Romanian people and satisfaction with what happened in our country, but said nothing about their own problems,'' a Romanian diplomat said Friday, speaking on condition of anonymity. Many Chinese were elated because the Romanian rebels defeated an armed attack of the kind that China's hard-line leaders mounted to crush Chinese pro-democracy protesters on June 3-4. Ceausescu applauded China's crackdown. The diplomat was amazed that Chinese mail workers delivered the postcards with daring references to ``the reactionary ruler'' and ``the dictator.'' ``They must have seen the messages, they are open,'' he said. The postcards were anonymous, but one letter came from workers at the No. 2 Automobile Factory in central China, a leading state-owned facility, and two Chinese who telephoned from Beijing factories said they spoke for their co-workers. Even a unit of the government-run Chinese Academy of Social Sciences and several other state institutions sent signed letters, the diplomat said _ before Chinese Premier Li Peng and President Yang Shangkun recognized the new Romanian government Dec. 27. ``Everyone expressed concern, everyone was very warm _ even warmer than before,'' said a second diplomat. ``It was very touching.'' The embassy itself, which has just seven diplomats, held a meeting on Dec. 23, while fighting still raged between pro- and anti-Ceausescu forces, and decided to support the rebels. They hauled down their Romanian flag and raised one without the hated Communist Party emblem. Someone stitched together swatches of red, blue and yellow silk to make a tiny new flag for the ambassador's car. More than a dozen portraits of Ceausescu were taken down from embassy walls, leaving empty hooks and faint white outlines. ``We were so happy, we were all so relieved,'' the second diplomat said. The diplomats said that like the Chinese, they received information about the fighting in Romania mainly from foreign news reports. But many Chinese, assuming the embassy had up-to-date information, called and asked for the latest news. ``They told us they were listening to the Voice of America and British Broadcasting Corp. _ they said they were keeping their radios on, just like in June,'' one said. China's government-controlled media said nothing about the Romanian uprising for several days, and then gave only sketchy reports without explaining its motives. Nonetheless, the news spread rapidly, and posters mocking Ceausescu and Chinese leaders went up quickly at three Beijing colleges. Students at seven colleges gathered on campus in silent protests or made plans to do so but were stopped. The Chinese government responded by canceling plans to lift 7-month-old martial law in Beijing, and instead putting the army and police on alert, according to unofficial sources. The diplomats said no Chinese have come in person to the embassy to offer congratulations. Contacts with the Chinese government have continued normally, they said. From the Chinese Communist Party, however, there has been only silence.

DOC.HEAD: Nissan Begins Affirmative Action Program
DOC.TEXT: Nissan Motor Corp., which paid more than $600,000 last year to settle federal sex and racial bias complaints, is launching an affirmative action program, the company said. President Kazutoshi Hagiwara told Nissan Motor's 2,300 employees nationwide in a Jan. 2 letter that the goal of the plan at the company's Carson headquarters and 11 regional sales and distribution offices was to improve the company's ``overall utilization of minorities and females and their distribution throughout the company.'' In February, Nissan agreed to pay $605,000 and promote dozens of women, blacks, Hispanics and older workers to settle a 4{-year federal investigation of employment discrimination by the automaker. The new affirmative action program is voluntary and not part of Nissan's agreement with the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, said John T. Weakly, director of human resources and administration at Nissan's Carson headquarters.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Suspect Charged in Rochester Serial Slayings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with more police statements, possibly 17 victims, other details. Picks up 7th graf, `The Syracuse...' SUBS 14th graf, `The suspect...' and deletes last graf to conform.
DOC.TEXT: A man paroled in 1987 in the killing of an 8-year-old girl was arraigned today on charges of murdering eight of the women involved in serial slayings in the Rochester area since March 1988. Arthur Shawcross, 44, a food service worker, pleaded innocent to eight murder counts before Rochester City Judge John Manning Regan and was sent to the Monroe County Jail without bail. State Police Superintendent Thomas Constantine said in Albany that charges will be brought against Shawcross in at least three more Rochester murders and that he is a suspect in other deaths. The bodies of at least 14 slain women have been found in the area in the past 22 months. Deputy Rochester Police Chief Terrence Rickard said there may have been as many as 17 serial victims and that Shawcross may have told authorities where to find three bodies, not two, as earlier reported. The Rochester Democrat & Chronicle newspaper said one body was recovered late Thursday in Clarkson. Rochester Police Chief Gordon Urlacher said today that police think he was responsible for 11 of the murders. ``We've said all along that we don't believe all these cases were related, and that's the way it turned out,'' Constantine said. According to police, Shawcross was arrested Wednesday after officers in a police helicopter saw a car speeding away from the culvert where a woman's body was found in Sweden, about 12 miles west of Rochester. ``The person derives some type of satisfaction from the murder and it's very possible that they go back and look at the results,'' Constantine said. The Syracuse Post-Standard quoted sources as saying the suspect told police several women were killed for mocking him when he was unable to engage in sex; another was killed when she broke the gear shift knob in his girlfriend's car; another because he thought she lied about being a virgin; and yet another because she pushed him into he Genesee River while they were swimming. According to the state Department of Correctional Services, Shawcross served 15 years of a 25-year sentence after a 1972 first-degree manslaughter conviction in Watertown, N.Y. Shawcross was convicted of killing Karen Ann Hill, 8, of Rochester, who was strangled and sexually molested while visiting Watertown. Shawcross also confessed to strangling 10-year-old John Blake, of Watertown, according to retired Watertown Police Detective Charles Kubinski, who interrogated Shawcross about the killings. Shawcross was paroled from Green Haven state prison in June 1987 and appeared to be adapting well to life outside prison, Edward Elwin, executive director of the state Division of Parole, said today. ``Superficially, he was making a good adjustment,'' Elwin said. Shawcross had tried to settle in Delhi, in rural Delaware County, following his parole, but was moved by parole officials to Rochester after about two weeks when residents complained about his presence. Investigators first questioned Shawcross Wednesday while they were searching for a missing woman west of Rochester, according to news reports. Searchers found one woman's body in the area Wednesday afternoon and a second woman's body Thursday. When the suspect was brought in again for questioning Thursday, he confessed to 10 of the killings, according to Rochester television station WOKR, which quoted unidentified police sources. About 60 state troopers, forest rangers from the state Department of Environmental Conservation and town of Ogden police searched the Monroe County towns of Ogden, Riga and Sweden for clues into the latest deaths. Most of the women, including June Cicero, 34, of Rochester, whose body was found frozen in a creek Wednesday in Ogden, were involved in prostitution or drugs, police said. The first body found Thursday, believed to be that of a female, was discovered at about 8:15 a.m. in Sweden by a local resident, according to Capt. David L. Christler of the state police. Police were unable to immediately identify that body. Investigators began looking in the Northampton Park area Sunday after a park worker found a pair of pants and boots in the snow. Inside the pants was a Social Security card belonging to Felicia Stephens, 20, who was last seen by her boyfriend, Raymond Pendergrass, in Rochester on Dec. 26, police said. The park is about 13 miles west of Rochester.

DOC.HEAD: Former FDA Chemist Sentenced to 30 Days in Drug Probe
DOC.TEXT: A former chemist for the Food and Drug Administration was sentenced Friday to 30 days in prison for taking $4,300 in bribes to influence the government's approval of generic drugs made by two companies. U.S. District Judge John Hargrove sentenced David Brancato to three, two-year prison terms, but suspended all but 30 days. Brancoto was also fined $3,000, ordered to serve 500 hours of community service and put on probation for three years. He was accused of accepting bribes from Ashok Patel, former senior vice president of Par Pharmaceuticals of Spring Valley, N.Y., and Dilip Shah, former president of Quad Pharmaceuticals of Indianapolis. Patel and Shah were convicted earlier. Prosecutors said Brancato, who worked in the FDA's Rockville office, took the money in exchange for favorable FDA treatment of applications for approval of generic drugs produced by the companies. Generic drugs are the chemical equivalents of brand-name drugs whose exclusive marketing patents have expired. The rush by generic drug companies to win FDA approval for their cheaper products has created a lucrative market susceptible to corruption, investigators say. In all, the generic drug probe has resulted in guilty pleas from three officials of generic drug companies, three FDA chemists and two pharmaceutical companies. Brancato, who pleaded guilty earlier to three counts of receiving illegal gratuities, actually took $16,000 in bribes from four drug manufacturers, said prosecutor Gary Jordan. Brancato was charged only with taking $4,300 in bribes.

DOC.HEAD: Retired Erie Roman Catholic Bishop Dies
DOC.TEXT: Alfred M. Watson, former bishop of the 13-county Roman Catholic Diocese of Erie, has died. He was 82. Watson, a priest for 56 years, died Thursday at his home, the diocese said. It did not disclose the nature of his final illness, but Watson had been in poor health since breaking his hip nine years ago. Watson was named auxiliary bishop of the diocese in 1965 and bishop four years later. He had been credited with overseeing construction of new churches and helping develop parish programs. He retired in 1982. Watson is survived by three nephews and a niece.

DOC.HEAD: Argentine Gets Probation for Computer Shipment
DOC.TEXT: An Argentine was placed on probation for two years Friday for conspiring to export a IBM computer system valued at $500,000 in violation of export control laws. Jorge Stein, 34, of Buenos Aires was charged in October 1989 with attempting to export the computer system to Bulgaria after shipping it through France. The federal complaint charged that Stein indicated to an informant that he would apply for a Commerce Department export license using a fictitious name and address in Paris, but that the destination of the equipment would be Bulgaria. Stein pleaded guilty to the conspiracy charge. A Miami company, Dinorall Corp., which also entered a guilty plea in the case, was fined $20,000.

DOC.HEAD: Burgeoning Democracies Put Squeeze on U.S. Foreign Aid Funds
DOC.TEXT: Bush administration policymakers, faced with a foreign aid squeeze because of the need to reward emerging democracies in Panama and Eastern Europe, are looking primarily to the Pentagon budget for possible relief, say congressional and private sources. One growing school of thought argues that changes in the world's security balance now mean that U.S. interests abroad are better maintained by diplomacy than by threat of force, and that at least a small amount of the military money saved through arms treaties and lessened tensions should go for foreign aid. Others in the administration and on Capitol Hill are talking about nicking the largest current aid recipients _ countries such as Israel, Egypt, Pakistan, Turkey and Greece _ to pay for assistance to the new democracies. That option, however, is seen as more politically difficult and therefore less likely than others. The administration this week sent a delegation to Panama to evaluate the need for U.S. assistance in reviving a once-robust economy crippled by American trade sanctions. Early estimates of needed aid are running upwards of $1 billion over several years. Bush also has pledged that Eastern European countries that adopt democracy and reform their economies can expect help of the sort that Congress voted last year for Poland and Hungary, which together are getting $840 million over the next three years. But the new aid will have to be found in a foreign assistance budget that already is strained beyond its limits, leaving some friendly countries to do without. About a dozen nations that normally could expect some U.S. economic aid this year will end up with nothing, said Mark Edelman, acting administrator of the State Department's Agency for International Development. ``We have a hell of a problem, and it's getting tighter and tighter and tighter,'' Edelman said in an interview. Of the $14.6 billion in this year's foreign aid package, Israel has received $3 billion and Egypt $2.1 billion. Those two, along with Pakistan, Greece and Turkey, get the lion's share of U.S. economic and military aid and are protected by congressional earmarks. What's left is parceled out in far smaller amounts to several dozen other countries. As the year wears on and Congress begins deliberations on a 1991 aid bill, matters are bound to get worse, officials say. Foreign aid is among the least popular programs on Capitol Hill, meaning the growing U.S. commitments must somehow be shoehorned into a budget that will remain essentially unchanged. ``We only have so much,'' said Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan. ``It may not be possible for some countries to do quite as well'' as they have in the past. ``The American people understand that we are going to have to help in countries like Romania and Czechoslovakia.'' ``There's a bottom line: If you want to do more here, you've got to do less there,'' said Edelman. ``There is going to be a squeeze,'' predicted William Hellert, an analyst with the Overseas Development Council, a Washington-based advocacy group for development in poorer countries. He noted that not only are Panama and Eastern Europe likely to expect new aid from the United States, but other countries may make claims as well: Namibia, which is gaining its independence from South Africa; and Mozambique and Angola, where settlements of civil wars are hoped for. In addition, the United States is faced with taking care of late payments to the U.N. peacekeeping force, money that comes out of the foreign aid bill, and with new payments to the International Development Association, an arm of the World Bank. Additional money will be needed to cope with increased flows of refugees around the world. As new and more politically popular recipients line up at the aid window, some of the world's most needy countries fear they will get pushed even further back in the queue. Noted Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., a senior Foreign Affairs Committee member, ``We've been squeezing Africa for about as long as you can squeeze it.'' Throughout Latin America, the growing scarcity of U.S. aid is a top concern. ``They have just gone through a lost decade as far as development is concerned,'' said Hellert. ``Are they going to go through another one?''

DOC.HEAD: Factory Orders Near Record High
With AM-Unemployment, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Orders to U.S. factories for manufactured goods reached their second highest level in November, the government said Friday in a report that analysts saw as further evidence the longest peacetime economic expansion is continuing. ``This confirms our expectations that the economy won't drop into a recession,'' said Thomas Runiewicz, an economist with the WEFA Group, a Bala Cynwyd, Pa., forecasting organization. ``We're going to see a slowdown, but no recession.'' ``It pretty much conclusively demonstrates that we're not heading into a recession,'' agreed Gordon Richards, economic policy director for the National Association of Manufacturers. The Commerce Department said orders for both durable and non-durable manufactured goods jumped 2.4 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $239.7 billion, after edging down 0.1 percent in October. They had gained 1 percent in September. It was the highest level of orders since a record $239.9 billion was posted in April and the fastest rate of increase since a 2.8 percent advance in August. The report was a bright spot in what has become a mixed picture of the manufacturing economy. The Labor Department reported Friday that the manufacturing sector lost another 25,000 jobs in December, raising to 195,000 the number of factory jobs lost since March. However, orders for durable goods _ where much of the manufacturing weakness has been concentrated _ posted a 4.8 percent increase, to $130.2 billion, after a slip of 0.8 percent in October. Increases were widespread within all the major categories. Runiewicz said that portends good news because factory orders are a leading indicator and thus suggest future economic growth. Transportation orders jumped 10.6 percent, to $36.7 billion, after a 1.9 percent gain in October. While aircraft orders totaled $2.6 billion, or 62 percent of the advance, the slumping auto industry posted a $1.5 billion gain. Excluding the transportation category, orders would have risen 1.1 percent. Other major durable goods categories recording gains included electrical machinery, up 7.7 percent, most of it in defense communication equipment; non-electrical machinery including computers and a wide variety of industrial equipment, up 5.7 percent; and primary metals, up 2.2 percent. On the other hand, orders for non-durable goods that had been the mainstay of the economy in recent months dropped 0.3 percent, to $109.5 billion, after rising 0.6 percent in October. Richards described the turnaround as a statistical correction. ``It's pretty typical of economic statistics that when you see deviations in one direction, chances are it's going to be a fallback in the other direction at some point,'' he said. Defense orders rose 16.9 percent, to $11.2 billion, after falling 10 percent in October. Excluding defense, orders would have risen 1.8 percent. Analysts agreed that non-defense capital goods orders were another positive in the November report because they are a barometer of business investment plans. They were up 7.7 percent after a 1.8 percent gain in October.

DOC.HEAD: With US-Panama
DOC.TEXT: Here is the transcript of President Bush's news conference Friday: President Bush: Well, this morning I met with the attorney general, Dick Thornburgh, to discuss the legal process related to the prosecution of General Noriega. We are committed to a fair trial and to providing all the protections guaranteed by the United States Constitution and laws. The attorney general assures me that our case is strong, our resolve is firm and our legal representations are sound. Our government is not seeking a deal with Noriega. Our policy remains that we have brought him to this country for prosecution. I will be ever mindful of this legal process in the days ahead and will not comment on any aspect of this prosecution or any matters that could even inadvertently affect the outcome of this case, and I'm going to ask others in this administration to do the same. Deputy Secretary of State Eagleburger and Deputy Secretary at Treasury Robson have just given me a report on the economic reconstruction efforts in Panama. The first action that the United States took after General Noriega was removed from power was to release some $400 million in money that was withheld by virtue of our economic sanctions, sanctions which are now being lifted. $140 million I believe is already in Panama. The revitalization of the Panamanian economy is a major priority in the months ahead as our efforts _ as are our efforts for humanitarian assistance. And I would say here, I've been very grateful for the medical supplies that have gone to Panama. I can report today that considerable progress has been made so far in returning Panama to a normal state of affairs. The new government has taken charge, and President Endara is working tirelessly to meet the needs of his people. Both Undersecretary Robson and Eagleburger were very high in their praise of Mr. Calderon, Mr. Ford and, of course, President Endara. They are discussing housing programs, business development, bank loans that will help spur economic growth. We are committed to be a part of that process. I want to assure all of the countries of Latin America that United States policy remains one of a friendly, supportive and respectful neighbor. We have worked hard and intensively to consult bilaterally and multilaterally with Latin America and we will continue to do that. I personally will be involved in that. At the Latin American summit in Costa Rica I pledged that we would work with the countries of this hemisphere to build a better life for its citizens. Our policy of cooperation is firm. Yesterday I had a lengthy discussion with Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez of Spain, who is so well respected in this hemisphere as well. And I share his deep personal interest in seeing that the countries of this hemisphere pull together on behalf of democracy and economic freedom. I know the yearnings of my fellow leaders in this hemisphere _ leaders in Latin America _ and I believe they will support the new government of Panama, and they will support the United States as we work together in this hemisphere. And I've asked the vice president, Dan Quayle, to visit a number of these Latin American countries within the next several weeks to personally deliver this message. I view this as very, very important diplomacy and I am determined not to neglect the democracies in this hemisphere. Some have felt that we were so infatuated with the change in Eastern Europe that we were in a process of neglecting this hemisphere, and that is not the case. And the Quayle trip, in my view, will help. I have been undertaking consultations directly with leaders since I've been president. I will resume that, as I said, and the vice president will be in a position to explain very clearly not only U.S. policy but our aspirations for Panama and indeed, for this entire hemisphere. So that's where we are, and I'll be glad to take a few questions.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Probe Into Reopening of 1964 Civil Rights Workers' Deaths Is Wrapping Up
DOC.TEXT: An investigation on whether to reopen the cases of three civil rights workers who were slain in rural Mississippi in 1964 is nearly complete, the state attorney general said. Attorney General Mike Moore declined, however, to discuss what the probe has concluded. State officials, encouraged by the NAACP and other groups, have sought to determine whether the case should be reopened. ``The inquiry is continuing,'' Moore said Thursday. ``We've made some pretty good progress.'' The state legal official said the first question to be answered would be whether the case could be retried and if that action would be in the best interests of Mississippians. On June 21, 1964, civil rights workers James Earl Chaney, 21, who was black, and Andrew Goodman, 20 and Michael Schwerner, 24, who were white, disappeared after they were released from the Neshoba County Jail in Philadelphia, Miss. They had been stopped for speeding after investigating the burning of a black church by the Ku Klux Klan. Their bodies were found 44 days later in a soggy earthen dam in rural Neshoba County. All three had been shot to death. The men's deaths were the basis of the 1988 film ``Mississippi Burning.'' A U.S. District Court jury convicted seven Ku Klux Klan members in 1967 of conspiring to deprive the workers of their civil rights. Their sentences on the federal charges ranged from three to 10 years in prison. None was indicted or tried for murder in state courts. Moore said the investigation by his office thus far reveals that some of the alibi witnesses for those who were tried in 1967 have died. That could allow defendants to raise a question of due process in the courts becase of the passage of time, he said. ``There's been a lot of research done,'' Moore said. ``We're working with the FBI.'' Moore had originally hoped to make an announcement by the end of 1989, but he said he now plans to release the investigation's findings sometime early this year.

DOC.HEAD: TV Gave the Impression He Was Indifferent to Casualties, Bush Says
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today that some Americans got the wrong impression that he ``didn't give a damn'' about U.S. losses in Panama because television had shown him in a ``frivolous'' mood while split-screen TV carried pictures of GIs' bodies being taken from a plane. At today's news conference, Bush took the unusual step of appealing to the television networks to give him warning when they use the split screen technique while he was conducting a news conference. He said if a competing news event were so urgent as to justify the use of that technique, he would stop the news conference. ``I could understand why the viewers were concerned about this,'' Bush said. ``They thought that their president at a solemn moment like that didn't give a damn. And I do, I do, I feel it so strongly.'' Toward the end of his Dec. 21 news conference, a relaxed Bush was seen on television bantering with reporters while, one by one, the flag-draped coffins of Americans killed in the Panama operation also were shown as they were carried from a just-arrived transport plane at Dover Air Force Base, Del. It was evident to viewers that Bush was unaware of the image that was going out to the country. The news conference was held in late afternoon just one day after the Panama operation started. In all, 23 American servicemen died during the U.S. intervention. ``I read a lot of mail after the last press conference and I had some calls because when I was speaking here in this room, juxtaposed against my frivilous comments at the time was some split-screen technique which showed the bodies of dead soldiers in caskets coming home,'' Bush said at the conclusion of today's session. ``I would respectfully request that if the urgency of the moment is such that that technique is going to be used, if I could be told about it, that we stop the proceedings. ``So please help me with this if you would ,'' Bush said, directing his appeal to the television networks. The Dec. 21 news conference ended with presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater telling reporters to stay in the room to receive Christmas presents. At the same time, honor guards in dress uniform were still solemnly carrying coffins from the plane.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: Juanita Pierson and Albert Johnson were just neighbors at the Oak Ridge Convalescent Center until the day he asked her if she'd like to watch the news on television with him. ``He pulled my wheelchair over to the door of his room,'' Pierson said. With a smile, she added: ``I can't say it's been just to the door since.'' They were married Tuesday after a five-month courtship. Pierson, 79, is a lifelong Richmond resident who was married for 50 years. Johnson, 82, has lived here since 1924 and was married for 52 years. Both are widowed, have five children and suffered strokes that confine them to wheelchairs. ``We decided we needed each other,'' he said. Janice Spainhour, assistant director of nursing services, said the staff has been watching the relationship grow. ``We knew there was a romance in the building and we all loved it,'' she said.

Tacky and glitzy or chic and ritzy, neon lights up a new exhibit here in a state that's been called the neon capital of the world with its blazing casino displays. ``There definitely was a time when neon was considered tacky, kind of low life. But now it's tres chic and it's everywhere,'' said Erik Lauritzen, curator of the Nevada Historical Society exhibit. ``People aren't just using it to advertise but they're using it in art, as decoration and in architecture,'' he said Friday. ``It's back in style. Look at just about any downtown area or shopping mall.'' The exhibit, which opens Jan. 19 at the Reno museum, includes seven neon signs and art works and 50 photographs of glowing displays, from the state's first neon sign documented in 1928 on a grocery store in northeastern Nevada's Elko to the modern hotel-casino extravaganzas several stories high. Neon signage has gone through several ``periods,'' according to Lauritzen. ``The first stage was from the early '30s to the early '50s when use of neon was very innovative,'' he said. ``Then the '50s to '70s when neon was becoming just a way to advertise and kind of got a bad rap. Then through the '70s and until now when neon is coming back as art and decoration.''

DOC.HEAD: More than 2,000 to Contest General Elections, Conservatives Strong
DOC.TEXT: Candidates for general elections in May include a popular pro-democracy leader now under house arrest and a phalanx of veterans from the party that wielded authoritarian power for 26 years. According to incomplete reports received Friday from the Election Commission, 2,066 candidates from 96 political parties and 70 independents will vie for 492 parliamentary seats. Although Burma's military rulers ordered house arrest for Aung San Suu Kyi, the charismatic pro-democracy leader has been allowed to file a nomination to run in a constituency in Rangoon, the capital. Ms. Suu Kyi, the daughter of independence hero Aung San, rose to prominence in the fall of 1988 as millions of Burmese rose up against a military-led government that suppressed political freedoms and ruined the country's economy during its 26-year rule. The uprising was crushed violently by the military, and a military council has ruled with martial law since then, but it promised elections in May 1990. No date has been set. Many Western diplomats in Rangoon and Bangkok doubt the polling will be fair and free, noting widespread arrests of political opponents and human rights abuses in the past year. The only party capable of fielding candidates in all 492 constituencies is the National Unity Party, which under another name was the sole political party in the country from 1962 until 1988. The party will field virtually all the prominent leaders of the former ruling party, the Burma Socialist Program Party. Perhaps the most popular of the six national parties is Ms. Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy. It built up a rapid base of support but has been weakened by the arrests of top-level members, including party chairman Tin Oo. He was sentenced to three years in prison last month for allegedly inciting arrest and attempting to divide the army. Similar accusations were made against Ms. Suu Kyi, but the military rulers have not taken legal action against her although she remains under house arrest in Rangoon. Others who filed nominations are popular leader Aung Gyi, of the Union Nationals Democracy Party, and Chit Maung, chairman of the largest leftist party, the Democratic Front for National Reconstruction. Burma's last multiparty elections were in 1960. The elected government of Prime Minister U Nu was overthrown in a 1962 coup led by Gen. Ne Win. Ne Win and the military crushed dissent and pursued rigid socialist policies that made resource-rich Burma one of the world's poorest nations. Those economic woes and repression fueled the nationwide protests in 1988 that forced the resignation of Ne Win and later his successor, Sein Lwin. Maung Maung took power Aug. 19 as the country's first civilian leader since 1962 and promised the elections.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: few questions.
DOC.TEXT: Q: Mr. President _ A: Is it Helen first? Q: You said that the government is not seeking any kind of a deal _ A: Yeah. Q: _ concerning Noriega. Does that mean that you are irrevocably ruling out any reducing of charges, increasing of charges? And also, since the indictment runs from '81 to '86 and you had many contacts, apparently, with Panama during that period, were you ever aware of any drug activities on the part of Noriega? A: On the first part of the question, there's no such plan. The man's entitled to do whatever is granted him under our law, so there isn't any such plan. Secondly, I have made some statements along in reply to your second question, so punch it in the computer, and I'll have nothing more to say about it. Because I do not want, even inadvertently, to prejudice this case. But it _ my actions are, in my view, totally unrelated. Yeah, Tom. Q: Mr. President, with General Noriega out of Panama and safely in custody in this country, it seems like you may have a difficult choice in deciding how to maintain order in Panama. Do you envision keeping a U.S. military peacekeeping force there beyond the usual contingent of 12,000 troops, or would you like to see the Panamanian Defense Forces reconstituted? A: One, I'd like to see their police forces, whatever emerges, reconstituted. Two, we will get our forces that went in out as soon as possible. Three, I will just say this because your question obviously understands this, but to those listeners out there, SOUTHCOM (Southern Command) has had a force there, and that force, under the treaty, will remain there. But the answer is, we want to get those additional augmented forces out as soon as possible. And we will. Q: Mr. President, I'd like to try to follow up a question you were asked when you were here last about secrecy and the two missions by General Scowcroft to China. As I'm sure you may be aware, Secretary of State Baker was asked about the first _ what we then thought was the first China mission on one of the weekend talk shows. He indicated that it was, indeed. It turned out to be the second. He has since acknowledged quite openly that his answer was false, and that he felt constrained to give that answer to protect the secrecy of the mission. And I wondered first, sir, whether you felt it was worth it for him to have to do that, and second, whether that sort of thing is acceptable in your administration. A: Well, let me simply say that some things will be conducted in secrecy. And I know you don't like it _ your business is to get everything out in the open, and my business is to conduct the foreign affairs of this country in the way I think I was elected to, and for the most part that'll be in the open. But this move into Panama was held in secrecy, and I think the American people understand that. My move to send people to China was controversial. Some think that the best way to make change for human rights in China is isolation: Don't talk to them; try to punish them by excommunication. I don't feel that way, and so I asked these people to go forward. And I don't think Jim Baker would ever deliberately mislead somebody. And so I will stand _ stand with him. Q: Well, he _ sir, I believe he indicated that he felt he had to do that, and that he knew what he was doing and he had to do it. And I just wondered how you feel about _ A: Well ask him about it. I support my secretary of state. Yeah, Lesley?
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: N.J. Prosecutor Fabricated Shooting Story, Official Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with attorney general's news conference. Picks up 5th graf, `Asbell held...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto TN2
DOC.TEXT: A prosecutor known for accompanying detectives on drug raids resigned after he was caught fabricating a story that two men tried to assassinate him, the state attorney general said today. Camden County Prosecutor Samuel Asbell, who shot out the windows of his car New Year's Day and presented it as evidence of an attack, has checked into a psychiatric facility, Attorney General Peter N. Perretti said. ``The event was staged by Prosecutor Asbell, apparently acting alone,'' Perretti said at a news conference. Asbell resigned Thursday night after he was confronted with details of a state police investigation, Perretti said. He said there is no evidence that Asbell's ``sudden and aberrational behavior'' has affected his work as prosecutor. Perretti said it appears several criminal laws were violated, but a decision on filing charges against Asbell would depend upon his psychiatric evaluation. Asbell held a news conference Tuesday to tell reporters he barely escaped death when two man chased him for about four miles through Camden's streets. When the gunmen opened fire, Asbell said, he fired a 12-gauge sawed-off shotgun and a handgun that he kept in his car, striking the passenger in the assailants' car. ``Thank God I'm alive,'' Asbell said. ``I guess it just wasn't my day or my time.'' Efforts to reach Asbell were unsuccessful today. His spokesman, George Kerns, said he was not expected in the office today. Asbell had said his car was ambushed by two men in a station wagon after he left his office about 5 p.m. Monday. He said he was in his office on New Year's Day to catch up on paperwork and collect his check after a vacation. He said the gunmen opened fire, and he was sprayed with glass from his windows but was not seriously injured. He said he believed the attack was drug-related. Camden, a rundown, mostly black city across the Delaware river from southern Philadelphia, has a high rate of drug-related crime. Word of Asbell's apparent fabrication came on the same day blacks in Boston were expressing outrage over news that inner-city violence and a black man were unjustly blamed for the shooting of a pregnant woman. The woman's husband, a well-off white businessman, became the murder suspect and committed suicide Thursday. New Jersey authorities said they were confounded by a lack of leads when they tried to investigate Asbell's story. No body was found and the alleged victim did not turned up at local hospitals. Asbell and his family were placed under 24-hour state police protection. At a Thursday news conference, Asbell stood by his story. ``I have met with the attorney general, and he made it explicitly clear to me that I am a victim ... of a violent crime. He very kindly said I have to get (in) my mind the fact that I am not a prosecutor in this matter, but I am a victim,'' Asbell said. Asbell, while in private practice, was shot in the chest in 1970 while representing a client whose property was put up for sheriff's sale. The bullet is still lodged in his chest. Perretti appointed Assistant Attorney General James F. Mulvihil as acting prosecutor in Camden County.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Prosecutor in Atlanta Resigns
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Attorney Robert L. Barr Jr., who prosecuted former U.S. Rep. Pat Swindall and other public officials, announced today he is resigning to become president of a conservative public-interest law firm. Barr, whose four-year term as federal prosecutor for the Northern District of Georgia would have expired next October, called a news conference to confirm reports that he is quitting to head the Atlanta-based Southeastern Legal Foundation Inc. He said his resignation, submitted to President Bush and Attorney General Dick Thornburgh during a visit to Washington this week, is effective Feb. 1. The 13-year-old business-oriented foundation, known for taking on conservative causes, was involved in a successful lawsuit against an Atlanta affirmative-action minority enterprise program earlier this year. The foundation also has filed reverse discrimination lawsuits. Barr, a former Cobb County Republican chairman, said he will be active in politics but would not say if he plans to run for political office. Barr, 41, was appointed federal prosecutor in 1986. During his tenure, Barr's office successfully prosecuted Swindall, R-Ga., for lying to a grand jury, and Fulton County Commissioners A. Reginald Eaves and Chuck Williams and DeKalb County Commissioner John Evans for extortion. Earlier this year, Barr's office won indictments against Fulton County Sheriff Richard Lankford on 27 counts of extortion and income tax evasion.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: Yeah, Lesley.
