DOC.TEXT: Q: You talk about your concern about prejudicing the case, but as you well know, you have called Noriega a ``thug'' and other people in the administration have gone further. A: Yeah. Q: You said he's poisoning our children. Haven't you already done that _ A: Well I don't _ I think I've heard all kinds of characterizations of him in the press _ columnists, even commentators _ presidents, members of the United States Congress. He is now in custody. The time for rhetoric is over. The time for answering hypothetical questions that might prejudice the trial is over. I would go back, Lesley, to help you on that, to Watergate where there were hearings _ hearings held, charges made over and over again, editorials written and voiced. And yet the people received a fair trial. So I am convinced that our system of justice is so fair that the person will _ will get a fair trial. But I can tell you from my standpoint, I am going to bend over backwards and not answer hypothetical questions or not do anything that might prejudice that. Yeah? Q: Can I have a follow-up please? On _ I want to actually follow up on Helen. On _- A: No, that's a separate question. (Laughter.) Q: But it's a follow-up. Reducing of charges. Are you saying that if he wants to go for that, he if wants to try to go for reducing of charges that we will entertain it? You said _ A: No, I'm not saying that. I'm saying he has a right to do what he wants, and then let the legal process determine how that should work out. Q: Then you're not ruling it out? A: Well I'm not ruling it in. Yeah? Q: Mr. President _ A: I'm just saying he's got his rights and he ought _ we ought not to stand up here and try to define narrowly what they are. (Calling on reporters.) Yeah, and then John and then we'll start moving into the back. Q: Mr. President, based on your opening remarks and your comments about the vice president's trip, it would indicate that you're concerned about relations with Latin America. Has the action that you've taken set it back? A: To some degree, I am concerned, because I am well aware of how our friends south of our border, including my friend, President Salinas (of Mexico), look at the use of American force anywhere. So I'm concerned about it. I think it's something that's correctable, because I think they know that I have tried a lot of consultation, that we have exhausted the remedies in this particular case of multilateral diplomacy. But given the history of the use of U.S. force, I would be remiss if I didn't face up to the problem that we must go forward diplomatically now to explain how this president looks at the protection of American life, that we acted, in our view, well within our rights, but that we will continue consultation. But, look, I feel strongly about the protection of American life, so we've got to get them to understand that this isn't a shift away from what some had termed ``excessively timid diplomacy.'' Q: What about _ Q: But Mr. President, wouldn't that indicate that actually you're _ we're continuing old American policies that have upset the people of Latin America? A: Well, to the degree _ if there is that perception, then it's up to me and the secretary. And in this instance, the vice president's trip takes on enormous importance to convince the people of the truth, and that is that we are not reverting to just, you know, a willful _ what's the word I'm groping for here? _ use of force that has no rationale. But when it comes to the protection of American life, please, our friends south of the border, understand that this president is going to protect it. I'll tell you one thing that's helped on this, to the degree there is a problem at all, and that is the way the Panamanian democracy is now starting to move forward. The certification of the three people who had been deprived of their right to hold office by the previous regime _ that's been of enormous help. And then I think the other thing is the reception, the public reception in Panama, for our action. It has been overwhelming, overwhelming.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Carhenge Exempted From Zoning Restrictions
DOC.TEXT: Carhenge, the junk car sculpture that spoofs England's prehistoric Stonehenge, has a better chance of survival because of a City Council vote. The tourist attraction was threatened because its creator never fully complied with a special use permit granted when he built it outside this northwestern Nebraska town in 1987, officials said. The City Council voted Thursday to exempt the 10.6-acre site from the city zoning boundaries. Councilman Mike Dafney said by adjusting the boundary, the city dissociates itself from Carhenge, built by James Reinders of Houston. ``It can get on with itself and try to survive by itself,'' he said. ``But the city has no liability I can see or anything else. We more or less are washing our hands with it as far as trying to regulate it.'' However, the City Planning Commission still has to approve the change. The sculpture consists of old car bodies arranged in a likeness of the famed Stonehenge in England. Reinders reportedly never fully complied with the permit, which included requirements for liability insurance, a paved access, an escrow account for maintenance and a parking area for visitors at Carhenge. A group called Friends of Carhenge has been working to bring the growing tourist attraction into compliance with the permit.

DOC.HEAD: Official Daily Explains Why China is Poor
DOC.TEXT: Socialism is not to blame for China's poverty, and the nation will eventually triumph over its capitalist rivals, the Communist Party daily newspaper said Friday. The lengthy commentary in the People's Daily came less than a month after a small group of university students, in a bold gesture of dissent, unfurled a banner in front of the state television station reading ``Motherland, why are you so poor?'' It is also part of a government propaganda campaign to convince the populace that China must stick to the socialist road, suppress political dissent and reject the reforms now sweeping East Europe. The Dec. 9 rally by Beijing University of Aeronautics students, the first in the capital since the military crushed the pro-democracy movement last spring, was not reported in the official press. But Chinese sources said 10 seniors were arrested, including three who were only indirectly involved in the demonstration. They said one Chinese reporter who tried to stop police from hitting the protesters was also detained. One source said a relative of one of the students was told he was taken to Qincheng, a high-security prison where student activists from the democracy movement are being held. The commentary, while not mentioning the protest, said many young people are asking: ``If the socialist system is superior, why is socialist China now so poor?'' It acknowledged that a per capita income of about $300 a year makes China one of the world's poor countries, with a rank below 100th in the world. But it attributed that to the nation's huge population of 1.1 billion, and noted that China ranks eighth in the world in gross national product and is one of the world's leading political, economic and military powers. It said the cost of goods is low, distribution of income is equitable, calorie intake approaches world averages, and the average lifespan is 69 years, compared to 63 in the world as a whole. The daily said it was unfair to compare China to Japan or Taiwan, saying the rapid postwar development of those capitalist economies shows the inferiority of socialism. Both Japan and Taiwan, it said, started with more solid economic bases and received substantial assistance from the United States. Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalists also carried off great quantities of gold when they fled to Taiwan in 1949, it said. The commentary said China's economy grew 9.4 percent a year from 1967 to 1984, compared with 4.9 percent for the world's developing countries, and that the gap with developed nations was shrinking. It also emphasized the moral superiority of socialism. Whatever happens, it said, quoting senior leader Deng Xiaoping, ``capitalism cannot cast off the super profits of the millionaires, cannot break away from exploitation and plunder, cannot shake off economic crises, cannot form a common ideal and morality and cannot avoid every type of extreme and serious crime, degeneracy and despair.'' China is backward, it concluded, but ``there will be the day when we approach, catch up with and surpass those developed capitalist countries. Time belongs to us, and the final victory belongs to us.''

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors, Defense Teams Have Changed
With AM-Noriega-Graymail, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Both the prosecution and defense teams have undergone major changes since the indictments of Panamanian Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega were handed up in Miami and Tampa. Richard Gregorie, who wrote the Feb. 4, 1988, Miami indictment, left the U.S. attorney's office last year. He expressed concern that he hasn't been asked for help from the current team, which has no one who played a major role in the case. Gregorie, a 17-year prosecutor now in private practice, says he left a very detailed memo about the Noriega case but has other files and ``some in my head ... I'd be happy to share. I'm more than happy to help the government in any way to make sure that the prosecution is successful.'' U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen declined to comment on Gregorie's statements. His executive assistant, Diane Cossin, said a seven-member prosecution team with a total of 40 years' experience would handle the complex case, in which Noriega is charged with allowing Panama to be used as a way station for cocaine, chemical and money shipments. She said there were no plans to bring in Gregorie, former U.S. Attorney Leon Kellner or Mark Schnapp, another assistant U.S. attorney who helped with the indictment, as consultants. Charles Senatore, another former assistant U.S. attorney now in private practice, said turnover makes it common for new prosecutors to take over cases. ``It's a problem that happens a lot because a small percentage of the people employed as assistant U.S. attorneys remain there their entire careers,'' Senatore said. ``There's certainly enough of a database remaining for the current team.'' Lehtinen and Myles Malman, an assistant U.S. attorney with experience in drug-related trials, are the lead prosecutors for now and represented the government at Noriega's court appearance Thursday. Then-President Reagan named Lehtinen on June 17, 1988, to replace Kellner, who left for private practice in Washington. He said Thursday he wouldn't comment on the Noriega case. In Tampa, where Noriega was indicted on drug bribery charges, Robert Genzman has become the U.S. attorney, succeeding Robert Merkle, who resigned after successfully prosecuting Colombian cocaine kingpin Carlos Lehder Rivas. Merkle lost a U.S. Senate bid in 1988 and is in private practice in Clearwater. Lehtinen, 43, is a former state senator with federal prosecution experience in Los Angeles and Miami. He has been a high-profile U.S. attorney, and last year raised eyebrows by suing state water managers for allegedly failing to protect the Everglades from polluted water flowing from Lake Okeechobee. That suit is pending. Lehtinen's wife, Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, won a special election last August for the U.S. House seat left vacant by Rep. Claude Pepper's death. She became the first Cuban-born U.S. representative. While Lehtinen hasn't tried a case in a decade, Malman has 15 years of prosecuting experience in New York and Miami. One of Noriega's original defense attorneys, nationally prominent lawyer Neal Sonnett, withdrew last week, citing conflicts with the other attorneys. Ray Takiff, another of Noreiga's Miami attorneys, asked this week to withdraw because of health problems. Noriega's remaining attorneys are Frank Rubino and Steven Kollin. Rubino, 44, is a former Secret Service agent, ex-private eye and a race car driver. Kollin, 41, was once a U.S. Treasury agent and worked in the Dade County state attorney's office. Both have experience in drug-related trials, but some Miami defense attorneys have said the complexity of Noriega's case and its high profile may bring other, better-known attorneys. Sonnett, president of the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers, didn't rule out returning to Noriega's defense. The attorneys didn't answer questions about how they're being paid. The United States has seized Noriega assets it has been able to identify.

DOC.HEAD: Albanian Envoy Denies Reports of Greek Deaths, Unrest
DOC.TEXT: The Albanian ambasador on Friday denied reports that four Greeks were tortured to death for trying to flee the isolated country, and he said the pro-democracy movement in Eastern Europe has not affected Albania. Ambassador Izedin Haidini showed a film that he said proved the four Greek Prassas brothers were alive, contrary to allegations of the Orthodox Church of Greece. However, no independent observer could verify that the four young men shown exchanging New Year's greetings were the brothers. A Greek Foreign Ministry official said Greek diplomats based in Tirana, the Albanian capital, were not permitted to leave the city to verify that the Prassas brothers were alive in their village of Pepel. Church officials have said the men were caught trying to flee Albania for neighboring Greece in October and were tortured to death. Albania is the last bastion of Stalinist Communism. The Orthodox Church claims the country's 400,000 ethnic Greeks are denied human rights, since they are banned from practicing their religion or speaking Greek in public. The government of Albania, which incorporated Greece's northern province of Northern Epirus in 1916, claims the Greek minority enjoys special treatment. Haidini denied that diplomats or tourists with valid visas were prevented from traveling throughout the heavily guarded country. Albania, sandwiched between Yugoslavia and Greece on the Adriatic Sea, is one of the most isolated countries in the world, with foreign visitors strictly limited and access to foreign broadcasts and books tightly controlled. The ambassador also said that no unrest had occurred in Albania as a result of the political upheaval that has toppled hard-line Communist regimes across the East bloc. A man who claims to be Albania's true ruler was quoted as saying Friday that leaflets calling for a revolution in Albania will be attached to balloons and dropped into the country. ``We will broadcast messages by radio and drop leaflets by balloon, something we have done before,'' said the man who calls himself King Leka I. His comments appeared in the Johannesburg newspaper Business Day. Leka is the son of self-syled King Zog I, who ruled Albania from 1925 to 1939. Leka, who lives in South Africa, was taken from his homeland when he was 3 days old and has never returned.

DOC.HEAD: One-Year Maximum Sentence Given in Slaying of Actress' Son
DOC.TEXT: A Tongan man was sentenced today to a year in prison, the maximum sentence for his conviction of misdemeanor homicide in the death of the black son of a Hollywood actress in a trial that sparked racial tension. John Leota also was ordered to pay restitution of more than $40,000 for the death of Malik Smith, the 18-year-old son of actress Beverly Todd and producer Kris Keiser. Third District Judge Homer Wilkinson's sentence was the maximum for the charge of negligent homicide. Leota, 19, also was sentenced to one year's probation and 150 hours of community service for an assault charge involving another man. ``I just want to express how sorry I am to the family.'' Leota said before sentencing. ``I know that what I did was wrong ... I didn't know it was going to happen.'' The emotionally charged sentencing hearing drew an outburst from Todd, when defense attorney Phil Hansen told Wilkinson she had ``pulled the plug'' on the life-saving machine that kept her son's body alive. ``That's a lie,'' Todd said, ``Why would he say that?'' She then wept. Keiser emphasized that life support equipment was not removed from Smith, of Los Angeles, until after two tests showed his son was brain-dead. On Thursday, members of the Polynesian community here charged that ``wealthy Hollywood blacks'' were trying to deny Leota justice. Entertainers such as Whoopi Goldberg and Jennifer Warren wrote letters to Wilkinson to protest the misdemeanor conviction of a defendant who was tried for second-degree murder. Smith was fatally injured when he struck his head after being punched by Leota at a West Valley disco March 20. Leota testified Smith had embarrassed him but he did not mean to kill him when he hit him once and kicked him in the face. Surrounded by about 20 members of the Polynesian community, attorneys Paul Schwenke, Filia Uipi and Victor Lawrence, a Samoan, Tongan and Hawaiian, respectively, blasted ``wealthy Hollywood blacks'' for ``trying to trample the civil rights of a John Leota.'' ``These black entertainers who live in one of the most violent areas of the world outside of Beirut _ L.A. County _ have the arrogance to point their wealthy fingers at Utah and scream about injustice,'' Schwenke said at a news conference Thursday. `We, the Polynesian community and citizens ofUtah, say to these celebrities, Utah is a law-abiding state. We demand you let the judicial process go forward. We do not want the legal process to be influenced in any way,'' he said. A letter to the editor by Goldberg said she would ``spread the word of the dangers that lurk in your beautiful state.'' Schwenke did not feel there were racial issues surrounding the crime, but that racial issues were generated by comments from the victim's family. Upon sentencing, Wilkinson ordered Leota incarcerated in Salt Lake County Jail.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: overwhelming, overwhelming.
DOC.TEXT: Q: On that, sir, Lee Atwater, the chairman of the RNC (Republican National Committee), says Panama is a political jackpot for you, and it will wipe out the disenchantment, for example, of the way you handled China. Without saying that's why you went into Panama, sending the troops in _ A: Thank you. (Laughter.) Q: Isn't _ is one effect of it that it is a political jackpot? A: Well, Jesse Jackson doesn't think so. He talked to my wife. And so, you know, there's differences of opinions on that, but this isn't _ I didn't do something for political reason. That's not the reason I did that. I did it to protect American lives. A president's called on to take certain actions. We're not going in to try to furbish a political image. That's ridiculous. Q: Having said that, though, have you now neutralized Democrats on foreign policy? Is this the last time (Senate Democratic leader) George Mitchell can ever accuse you of having a timid foreign policy? A: Knowing George, he'll find a reason, he'll find a way. And that's his job. I mean, look, we're going into an election year. But this _ I want to try, if I can, to separate the responsive end. He's been supportive of this. Let's give the man credit. Q: That's my point. A: But I don't think it's laid to rest, put off bounds, any criticism of the president by a Democratic opposition, if that's the question, no, absolutely not. Q: What about _ A: Yeah, Frank, and then _ Q: Mr. President? A: And then you're third. Go ahead. Q: Mr. President, do you anticipate that the combat troops, the bulk of the additional combat troops sent into Panama, will indeed be out by the end of this month, as some administration officials have said? And secondly and more broadly, do you now see an expanded role for the American military in small regional issues like this one, or more particularly, in the war against drugs, since there was a strong drug connection to this operation? A: No, I see no _ well, I see no parallel between the situation here, where American lives were at stake and you had an indicted person who'd usurped power and declared war against the United States. I don't think you can draw a parallel between that unique situation and then other countries. And what was the other part of it? Q: The bit about when you see America _ these additional combat troops able to come home, all of them? A: As soon as possible, and I've made clear to the secretary of defense, to the chairman of the Joint Chiefs, who is down in Panama right now, I believe, that this is what we should do. This is what they themselves want to do. Some U.S. forces that went in are already out. So, I would look for an early return. Q: General timeframe? A: Can't help you, but as soon as General Powell gets back, we'll have a more _ Dave? Q: What about the international law _ A: Is your name Dave? (Laughing.) Q: _ implications? A: Go ahead. Q: What about the international law implications? Is this something that you are also going to talk to the Latin American countries _ A: Absolutely. Q: _ (Off mike) _ a precedent? What is the explanation behind it? A: The right to protect American lives granted under the U.N. Charter, and we will protect lives of citizens and we will go forward with that. The State Department, as I understand it, has already spelled that out, but I think you raise a good point. Yes, we should make very clear why we acted and under what authority we acted as we did. David? Q: Mr. President, you just described Panama as a unique case, and I'd just like to ask you sort of a philosophical question. If the criteria you listed here _ protecting American lives, having exhausted all the other diplomatic options _ presented themselves again, should we look in a Bush presidency for more such deployments of military force, if your criteria were met? A: Well, yeah, if you can spell out what the criteria is and then if you can _ if you can _ if you can look to the future to see the situation surrounding it. I can't visualize another situation quite this unique. But let me just say, when American life is threatened we _ we were concerned in El Salvador, for example. A civilian hotel could well have been occupied by a guerrilla force that would have threatened the American use of _ threatened American life. That concerned me. And indeed we moved forces, not in some macho way, but to try to protect the lives of American citizens. But I think most people understood that. But I don't see _ David, I don't see another real parallel here looming on the horizon at all.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Assigned to Case Highly Rated
With AM-Noriega-Graymail, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The federal judge presiding over Panamanian Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's case is a soft-spoken, patient jurist rated one of the best by the attorneys who practice before him. U.S. District Judge William M. Hoeveler, 67, is known for giving attorneys time to argue all of their points. ``Lawyers want to be heard,'' he said in a 1983 interview. ``Usually, if they feel they've been allowed an opportunity to present their position, they'll leave thinking they got a fair shake.'' Facing a complicated case with the Noriega indictment, Hoeveler made clear Thursday in Noriega's arraignment that he doesn't want shortcuts. ``This is not a case I want to go by waivers,'' Hoeveler said, ordering that Noriega be brought into the courtroom despite his attorney's request that he be allowed to waive his initial appearance. The 1977 Jimmy Carter appointee has presided over many lengthy, complex federal cases, ranging from a marijuana-smuggling trial of members of the Zion Coptic Church to jail overcrowding cases. Last year, the judge threatened to jail Broward County Sheriff Nick Navarro for contempt of court after he disobeyed his wishes and put inmates in a tent because the jail was full. Navarro, a colorful, strong-willed lawman, wound up apologizing. ``If it wasn't clear before, I think it is now,'' Hoeveler said. ``I am in charge of this case and I expect the orders to be followed without question.'' The slim, white-haired tennis buff and his wife, Griffin, have four children. He's a former Marine who studied at Temple University and Bucknell and earned his law degree at Harvard. He is annually ranked the best or near-best federal judge by Dade County lawyers and in 1983 was called the best district judge in the three-state 11th U.S. Circuit by American Lawyer magazine.

DOC.HEAD: Western Politicians Recommend International Supervision of Elections
DOC.TEXT: Western politicians said Friday the plan to hold elections in only three months could give the interim leadership an unfair advantage, and they recommended international supervision of the vote. U.S. Rep. Frank R. Wolf, R-Va., said Romania's new political parties lack the ``tools of democracy,'' and proposed a referendum on the election date. New parties have asked that elections be delayed beyond April so they will have time to organize. Wolf and Otto Lambsdorff, both of whom were visiting Bucharest, recommended international monitoring of the elections. Lambsdorff is a former West German economics minister. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze was scheduled to visit Bucharest on Saturday for the first meeting between the new leaders and a ranking Soviet official. Silviu Brucan, a member of the National Salvation Front, said Thursday the Soviets had promised extensive aid, including fuel for the hard winter. The Front has governed Romania since the downfall of Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, who was deposed Dec. 22 and executed Dec. 25. Lt. Gen. Victor Stanculescu, who is in charge of the economy for the Front, said in an interview published Friday some trading partners had agreed to accept exports of industrial products instead of food. He did not name the countries, but food has been one of Romania's exports to the Soviet Union. The interim leadership has stopped food exports and redirected supplies to the nation's 23 million people, who endured rationing for years as part of Ceausescu's successful plan to repay the foreign debt. Its revolution appears to have brought Romania closer to the Soviet Union, despite the collapse of the Communist Party. Ceausescu often was at odds with the Kremlin on trade and foreign policy, and rejected Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plans for economic and social reform. Shevardnadze and Romanian leaders are expected discuss the sensitive issue of Soviet Moldavia, one of several restive Soviet regions. Most of the republic is former Romanian territory annexed in 1940 under a secret protocol of the Hitler-Stalin pact of 1939. Moldavians, whose language is virtually identical to Romanian, have demanded increased autonomy and Romania's revolution has prompted speculation they may seek reunification. The National Salvation Front initially said it would not run candidates in the April elections, but later reversed itself. The half-dozen parties founded since the revolution have said they need time to organize. Wolf said the Front's control of radio and television ``could be a real concern'' in a campaign, and parties outside the Front should be allowed access to the media. Without media access and scarce equipment such as typewriters and copiers, the independent parties would be at a serious disadvantage, Wolf said. Lambsdorff also expressed concern that the interim leadership would have an edge, and said at a news conference: ``It would perhaps be necessary to assure international supervision for the results of the elections to be completely fair.'' Wolf has visited Romania before and had pressed Congress, because of human rights violatons, to revoke the Most Favored Nation trade status granted Ceausescu's government. He suggested some form of international supervision and recommended ``a national referendum in April to have a decision on when the elections should be held.'' A ``verifiable free election'' was ``very important to the U.S. Congress,'' he said, and ``there needs to be a guarantee'' that free elections and other promises of democratic change will be carried out. Wolf said he expected the United States to have a ``warm and close relationship'' with Romania and a ``high-ranking official'' would visit Bucharest. He gave no details. ``People have asked me, `Can I get a copy of the U.S. Constitution? Another group asked me for paper _ tools of democracy that maybe Thomas Jefferson would have asked for,'' he said. The congressman proposed that the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and National Association of Independent Businessmen organize a program to teach management skills and free enterprise to Romanians. Stanculescu, the general managing the economy, said in an interview with the daily Romania Libera that Ceausescu's regime inflated production figures, and said the value of production and exports were lower than reported. Exports last year were worth $392 million less than the official total, the report said. Rompress, the national news agency, said Stanculescu's deputy, Constantin Bostina, had been dismissed because of his association with the Ceausescu regime.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Patrols Come Under Fire Near Jordanian Border
DOC.TEXT: Israeli patrols came under fire twice Friday along the Jordanian border, raising to four the number of shooting incidents this week along the normally quiet frontier, the army reported. The troops sustained no injuries, and the army was unable to determine if there were casualties on the other side, said an army official on condition of anonymity. The shootings occurred near the Hamat Gader sulfur springs park, five miles east of the Sea of Galilee. Israel radio said a jeep in which an Israeli officer was traveling was hit in the first incident, and the official said shots were fired later from the Jordanian side on Israeli army vehicles. Israeli troops returned fire both times. The radio and witnesses said that after the second incident, army troops and police evacuated dozens of tourists who were bathing in the area's hot sulfur springs. Jordanian troops were seen searching their side of the border after the incident, they said. In Amman, a Jordanian official said on condition of anonymity that Jordanian soldiers were unable to find any evidence of shooting from their side of the border. On Monday, Israeli troops came under fire near the same area and also suffered no casualties. On Thursday, Israeli soldiers opened fire on two men who appeared to be attempting to infiltrate from Jordan about six miles south of the sea. One of the men was wounded, the Israeli army said. There were seven incidents along the normally quiet Jordanian border last year, six of them infiltrations, according to Israeli army reports. The other incident, on Sept. 7, involved Katyusha rockets fired at Israel from Jordan. Three Israeli soldiers were killed and at least seven soldiers and civilians wounded in the incidents in 1989, the army said.

DOC.HEAD: Chilean President-Elect Asks Air Force, Police Commanders to Stay On
DOC.TEXT: President-elect Patricio Aylwin met Friday with the commanders of the air force and national police and asked them to stay on when the military ends its 16-year rule in March. Gen. Fernando Matthei, the air force chief, and Gen. Rodolfo Stange, national police director, are considered politically moderate. Both advocate a return to the barracks and an exclusively professional role for the military. The two are expected to mitigate the influence within the armed forces of hard-line rightist Gen. Augusto Pinochet, who gives up the presidency to Aylwin on March 11 but plans to retain command of the powerful army. He has rejected a request from Aylwin that he retire. Matthei and Stange, along with top aides, visited Aylwin separately Friday at the president-elect's home in Santiago. Upon leaving, each disclosed to reporters that Aylwin had asked him to stay on. Matthei said he would postpone his planned retirement for a year. He said Aylwin told him ``it would be good for the stability of the country and to strengthen the beginnings of the new government.'' Stange previously had said he would stay on briefly, but on Friday said he would remain as national police chief for up to four years, which is the length of Aylwin's term. ``I told him that I'd be pleased to stay on,'' Stange said. Pinochet seized power in a September 1973 coup that toppled civilian President Salvador Allende. A clause in the country's 1980 constitution, crafted by his own administration, allows him to stay on as army commander for eight more years. The same clause also shelters Matthei, Stange and navy chief Adm. Jose Merino. But Merino, a hard-line rightist, has said he plans to retire when the change in government takes place. Pinochet was obliged to call elections when voters rejected a referendum proposal, in October 1988, that would have extended his rule to 1997. Matthei was the first to recognize Pinochet's loss in the referendum and, according to local news reports, was instrumental in persuading Pinochet to accept the vote's outcome and call the elections. Matthei and Stange also are believed to have had a moderating influence in the four-man military junta that has served as a legislature under Pinochet. The junta is made up of the navy, air force and police commanders and an army general designated by Pinochet. Aylwin, 71, the leader of a 17-party center-left coalition, defeated Hernan Buchi, a former Pinochet finance minister, in the election Dec. 14. On Thursday, the government and representatives of a pro-Aylwin political coalition announced agreement on a new law establishing the armed forces' authority under democracy. Pinochet had proposed virtual autonomy for the military, but the agreement extended civilian authority and trimmed the powers of a joint command.

DOC.HEAD: People In The News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Sylvestor Stallone is going in for another round of struggle and success in the boxing ring. Stallone, Talia Shire, Burt Young and company will begin filming ``Rocky V'' here Jan. 15, Mayor W. Wilson Goode announced Thursday. The new film will feature the familiar formula _ fighting, winning with the boxing backdrop. Rocky Balboa, perhaps Philadelphia's most famous resident since William Penn, faces his greatest challenge, producers say, a test that will pit him against his own values, strength and, ultimately, his own spirit. Boxing heavyweight contender Tommy Morrison is featured as Rocky's protege, Tommy Gun. John Alvidsen, who directed the first ``Rocky'' in Philadelphia in 1975 with the then-unknown Stallone, will direct the fourth sequel and filming is expected to last about six weeks.

Portions of Bruce Willis' ``Die Hard II'' will be filmed at Stapleton International Airport, which has angered airline officials who say it endorses terrorism. ``It involves terrorism, violence against airports, destruction of an aircraft and a crash,'' Jack Ekey, general manager of United Airlines' Denver operations, said Thursday. ``As a matter or principle, we don't believe that kind of thing represents either airports or airlines in a way which we see ourselves or want the public to see us,'' he said. Representatives of all airlines that use Stapleton lodged a complaint last week with airport officials. Twentieth Century-Fox plans to start shooting the film at Stapleton and in Weld County on Jan. 15. Greg Lazzaro, location manager of the film, said the airlines' position is ``total, unadulterated bull,'' and ``preposterous and stupid.'' Ekey said the film script, which has not been shown to the airlines, is the story of police officer's battle against terrorists who try to take over Dulles International Airport in suburban Washington, D.C. The plot of the sequel to ``Die Hard'' is heavy on wisecracks and liberal in the use of automatic weapons and plastic explosives, he said.

Actress Martha Raye, the exuberant 73-year-old comedian known as the ``Big Mouth,'' broke several ribs in a fall at home that forced a hospital stay, officials said Miss Raye was listed in fair condition Friday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, said hospital spokesman Ron Wise. She fell on Tuesday. ``We're not sure yet when she's going to be released yet, but I don't expect it to be more than a few days,'' Wise said, adding that she was in good spirits. Miss Raye worked in theater and in movies such as Charlie Chaplin's ``Monsieur Verdoux,'' but is perhaps best known for entertaining troops with Bob Hope. She did shows at military bases during World War II, the Korean War and in Vietnam. Her morale-boosting efforts earned her presidential praise and a special Academy Award in 1969. Most recently, she has appeared in TV commercials, capitalizing on her widely elastic smile and nickname to promote a denture adhesive.

Filmmaker and art collector Billy Wilder said his artworks were unharmed by the flames of a rampaging fire that whipped through his apartment building last month. ``Nothing was lost. We just had smoke damage,'' Wilder said in a recent interview. Inside the posh Westwood-area apartment he shares with his wife, Audrey, were African sculptures, French primitives, drawings by Saul Steinberg, pre-Columbian artifacts and more than 2,000 books, he said. The Dec. 23 fire spread from a construction site to more than a dozen nearby buildings as high winds blew embers over a wide area. More than 150 people evacuated to escape the fire that caused an estimated $25 million damage. Wilder would not disclose the value of his art collection. Wilder, 83, was a busy Hollywood film producer, director and screenwriter during Hollywood's Golden Age. His feature film credits include ``Double Indemnity'' in 1944, ``Some Like It Hot'' in 1959, ``The Apartment'' in 1960 and ``Irma la Douce'' in 1963. ``The Apartment'' earned him the Academy Award for best director.

Former New York City mayor Edward Koch says he feels like he has a ``whole new life'' now that he's out of office. Koch launched the United Jewish Appeal here on Thursday, just four days after he left his mayoral post. ``I have a whole new life,'' said Koch, who said he was starting a diet and expected to make commercials if he's successful. Koch said he will keep busy as a member of a law firm, a newspaper columnist, a television and radio commentator, a lecturer and an adjunct professor at New York University. Koch spoke at Temple Beth El here, and also took the opportunity to comment on events in Eastern Europe. ``Communism has failed and God has prevailed,'' Koch said. In his first newspaper column, published Friday in the New York Post, Koch scored Archbishop Desmond Tutu of South Africa, accusing him of saying ``the Jews in South Africa will pay'' if Israel fails to support equality for South African blacks. Koch said Tutu, a Nobel Peace Prize winner, made the comment at a dinner party with the then-mayor and about six other people some years ago. Koch went on to accuse Tutu of unfairly criticizing Israel last week, in remarks Koch called ``standard third-world radical, and clearly an act of malice.'' The ex-mayor also appared before reporters in New York on Thursday to be a pitchman for a diet aid, saying he was using it because ``I know I'm fat. I can tell you how I know I'm fat. I see myself in the mirror, naked. Horrible.''

DOC.HEAD: Ousted East German Leader Needs Surgery for Kidney Tumor
With AM-Germany
DOC.TEXT: Ousted East German leader Erich Honecker has a malignant kidney tumor and a decision on surgery will be made soon, the official news agency ADN said Friday. Honecker, 77, was examined by doctors and found to be too ill to be jailed while being investigated for alleged government corruption. He was forced out of office on Oct. 18 under increasing pressure from East German pro-democracy reform groups and a flood of young skilled workers fleeing to West Germany. In December, officials announced that Honecker was under investigation for corruption and had been placed under house arrest because of his health. Seven former Communist Party Politburo members were jailed at the same time and investigations against them for suspected corruption also continue. Honecker underwent gallbladder surgery in August. ADN and other East German media have said he has never fully recovered. Reform groups, including the 200,000-strong New Forum, allege Honecker and other government leaders had lived in luxury in the Wandlitz government housing area outside East Berlin, while normal citizens were forced do make do with bare necessities. On Thursday, ADN said he had been released from house arrest several weeks ago because no grounds were found to justify it. The agency said he would be moved out of Wandlitz to a new home.

Q: Do you think that the Latin leaders have been hypersensitive to the _ given the fact that in back channels, apparently, they've been supportive of the invasion _ can you say if that is correct? And then also because of that, do you think they've been hypersensitive in their public statements about U.S. forces? A: I like to feel that, given the way the situation has resolved, there is more support than has manifested itself in votes at the United Nations or in public statements. The Vice President's trip will help on this. My own consultations will help decide _ you know, give me a clearer answer to your question. But, I _ I am absolutely convinced, given what happened and the reason why it happened, that if there is damage, I can repair it; we can repair it; State Department and whoever else is involved can repair it. Q: But is it hypersensitive _ their reaction so far? A: Well, I think predictably so. Q: Mr. President? Q: Mr. President? A: Here's the last one. Way in the back. Q: Mr. President, some countries, with the precedent now of Panama, feel that their sovereignty might be violated if the United States pursues drug dealers in their countries. And there has been some change in laws. Can _ you know, can it be reasonable that they are worried about this in the sense of the CIA, the FBI going _ being able to apprehend people outside the United States territory. A: And so the question is what? Q: Do these countries have reason to be worried that the precedent of Panama might serve as _ A: Oh. Panama was more than that. Panama had clearly other ingredients that caused American action. It wasn't a simple case of going after a person who had been indicted for narcotics. You know we had the abortion of democracy, but you also had this threat to the lives of Americans. Let me do something in conclusion that may be a little risky, and it's a housekeeping detail, and it relates mainly to television. I got a lot of mail after the last press conference, I had some calls, because when I was speaking here in this room juxtaposed against my frivolous comments at the time were some _ a split-screen technique that showed American lives, the bodies of dead soldiers in the caskets _ dead soldiers coming home. And all _ I would respectfully request that, if the urgency of the moment is such that that technique is going to be used, if I could be told about it and will stop the proceedings, or if it's something less traumatic _ but that one, I could understand why the viewers were concerned about this. They thought their President, at a solemn moment like that, didn't give a damn _ and I do, I do. I feel it so strongly. So, please, help me with that if you would. Thank you all very much.
DOC.HEAD: END BUSH TEXT-6 Takes
Precede TAMPA
Authorities Find Engine Lost in Flight
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to update with engine found; picks up 3rd graf, `Investigators found...' DELETES outdated grafs 8-9, `Authorities said...'.
DOC.TEXT: An engine that dropped off a Northwest Airlines jetliner was found this afternoon on a wooded cattle farm near this North Florida town, federal officials said. The 3,500-pound Pratt & Whitney engine was spotted by a Madison County sheriff's helicopter pilot and immediately secured until a federal air safety investigator makes it to the site. ``It was roped off and we were told not to mess with it,'' said Madison County sheriff's dispatcher Fred Register. Ted Lopatkiewicz, spokesman for the National Transportation Safety Board in Washington, said the nearest inspector was traveling more than 200 miles from Tampa and would not make it to the site until close to nightfall. He said the engine would be inspected and then moved to the nearest maintenance facility for further examination. Sheriff's deputies said the engine was found on the property of a rancher who reported hearing a loud crash Thursday. Deputies were not able to follow up on the tip until after heavy fog cleared late this morning. The engine, one of three from a Boeing 727, fell off Thursday's Flight 5 from Miami to Minneapolis. The flight diverted to Tampa and landed safely with 139 passengers and six crew members on board. Officials believe the engine will provide the best evidence on what caused the mishap. Investigators found the forward right lavatory had leaked blue-tinted water over the outside of the aircraft. At the 35,000-foot altitude where the right tail-mounted engine fell off, the fluid could have frozen and entered the intake of the engine, an official said. ``That is a possibility,'' said Andrew Alston, a National Transportation Safety Board investigator. But Boeing spokesman Tom Cole in Seattle noted that engines on a 727 are designed to break off if sudden vibrations threaten to tear a plane apart, and the so-called ``blue ice'' could cause such vibrations. ``Blue ice is a definite possibility,'' he said. Twice before when engines fell off Boeing 727s _ on a Dallas-to-San Diego flight in 1985 and on a flight over Sierra Blanca, Texas, in 1975 _ lavatory ice was raised as a possible cause, he said. ``It can do serious damage,'' Cole said. ``Chunks have been found that weighed 10 to 15 pounds.'' The flight crew initially believed the No. 3 engine had shut off and they made several attempts to restart it, flying for several minutes without realizing the engine had fallen off, Alston said. The crew ``all stated that they heard a loud noise and that the plane yawed to the right,'' Alston said. ``They felt since there was no massive pitching of the aircraft that the engine had just shut down.'' Investigators said the plane dropped about 100 feet in altitude after losing the engine, but there were no major problems with control, cabin pressure or hydraulics. Passengers said the flight was surprisingly smooth. ``We were amazed when we got out and saw an engine fell off,'' said passenger Mark Lawrence of LeSeur, Minn. ``Except for a bump and a little dip, you couldn't feel a thing. Some passengers even slept through it.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Reassures Israel on Peace Talks, But Withholds Guarantees
DOC.TEXT: The United States is not pushing Israel to talk to the PLO but is unwilling to meet Israel's demand for rigid guarantees in advance of Middle East peace talks, a newspaper reported Friday. The daily Yediot Aharanot quoted from a document it said was a draft letter from U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III to Israeli Foreign Minister Moshe Arens. Israeli officials did not confirm the existence of the letter. Baker has been working to get Israel to accept an Egyptian invitation to open a dialogue with Palestinians as a step toward Israel's plan for elections in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. In November, the Israeli government accepted a five-point Baker plan to facilitate the Egyptian meeting. But it demanded U.S. ``side assurances'' that the Palestine Liberation Organziation will have no role and that the dialogue will be limited to Israel's elections plan. Baker has urged that Arens and Egypt's foreign minister, Esmat Abdel-Meguid, join him in preliminary talks in Washington, and Israeli officials say the Washington meeting could come next month. According to Yediot, the Baker letter said ``the goal of the United States, in the present effort, is not bringing Israel to a dialogue with the PLO.'' It continued, however, that the United States was not willing to give assurances on what Palestinians would say at the meeting and that delegates' in their opening statements ``would be free to raise other issues and not limit themselves to elections.'' ``These are the assurances that we plan to provide,'' Yediot quoted the letter as saying. ``The president and myself are convinced that these are enough to dispel Israel's worries and allow progress in the (peace) process.'' The draft letter reportedly was carried to Israel by Cabinet Secretary Eliakim Rubinstein, who talked with State Department officials in Washington last month. Yediot said that in addition to Arens, the draft letter was given to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin and Finance Minister Shimon Peres. The newspaper did not say how it obtained a copy. Avi Pazner, a Shamir adviser, said of the newspaper report: ``Many things there are not new, many things there are not accurate.'' He added: ``We are still engaged in a discussion with the United States on the question of guarantees that the PLO will not be part of the negotiating process. Until we have reached an agreement with the Americans, we would prefer not to relate to all kinds of press speculation.'' Yediot said that Rubinstein, in a summary of his talks, advised the Cabinet ministers that Baker wants to include two Palestinian deportees in the delegation for the Cairo meeting, despite Israel's demand that the delegates must come from the occupied lands. Egypt has suggested that including people deported from the occupied territories would make the talks more acceptable to the PLO, which has demanded it name the Palestinian delegates. In an interview on Israel radio Friday, Yossi Ben-Aharon, director-general of the prime minister's office, indicated that Israel was holding firm to its earlier conditions. Since the Palestinian uprising against occupation began two years ago, at least 642 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians, and 43 Israelis have been slain by Palestinians. Israel's elections plan is aimed at choosing Palestinians to hold talks with Israel on limited autonomy in the occupied lands. Palestinian leaders here have rejected the call, saying their goal is an independent Palestinian state.

DOC.HEAD: Militia War Drives 15,000 Villagers From Battleground
DOC.TEXT: War between rival Shiite Moslem militias in the hilly orchards of south Lebanon's apple country has driven 15,000 villagers to refuge in the mosques and schools of nearby towns, police said Friday. While fighting raged in south Lebanon, President Elias Hrawi prepared to establish headquarters in Moslem west Beirut, where his predecessor was assassinated six weeks ago. Amal and Hezbollah miltiamen traded grenade and mortar fire for the 14th day Friday in a struggle for supremacy among the 1.2 million Shiites, Lebanon's largest sect. Police said four people were killed and 12 wounded, raising the toll to 77 killed and 275 wounded since the battle began Dec. 23 just south of Sidon, the provincial capital of south Lebanon, and about 30 miles south of Beirut. The refugees sought shelter in Sidon and in Nabatiyeh, a market town, police reported. Three members of a Palestinian guerrilla force that had tried to disengage the combatants were reported among the wounded. Police said they were caught in cross fire between Hezbollah, which is loyal to Iran, and militiamen of the mainstream Amal, which Syria supports. They were the first Palestinian casualties since 300 guerrillas were deployed last weekend on a hill overlooking contested villages in Iqlim al-Tuffah, the Apple Province. A police spokesman said the guerrillas Yasser Arafat's Fatah faction of the Palestine Liberation Organization, did not shoot back when they came under fire on Hamade Hill, which overlooks Kfar Hatta. Amal militiamen who control the village repulsed two Hezbollah assaults from nearby Kfar Milki, said the spokesman, who cannot be named under police regulations. The two militias have fought intermittently since May 1987 and, by police count, total casualties are 648 dead and 1,854 injured. Hezbollah renewed an offer Friday of an ``immediate and complete cease-fire to be swiftly followed by negotiations.'' A Hezbollah statement said fighting among Shiites was ``senseless'' and neither side could win. There was no response from Amal. Its leader, Nabih Berri, has said he would accept a cease-fire only when Hezbollah withdraw from captured territory. Hrawi has been staying at an army barracks in the Syrian-controlled Bekaa Valley of east Lebanon since Parliament elected him Nov. 24 as part of a peace plan intended to end the sectarian civil war, now nearly 15 years old. He plans to live and work in a seaside apartment building to avoid commuting in west Beirut, where his predecessor, Rene Mouawad, was killed by remote-controlled bomb Nov. 22. Hrawi is a Maronite Catholic, as was Mouawad. The police spokesman said Friday that Hrawi would move to west Beirut by the weekend, but ``the army and police haven't finished security arrangements to protect the president during the trip.'' Mouawad lived in the same seaside duplex, provided by Saudi Arabian businessman Rafik Hariri, but had offices at the prime ministry, a 10-minute drive away. He was being driven home from an Independence Day ceremony when the car bomb exploded, killing him and 23 other people. A government official said privately that Hrawi ``will not leave the building except for foreign trips. He wants to avoid risks.'' The presidential palace in Baabda, a Christian suburb east of Beirut, is occupied by Gen. Michel Aoun. The rebel Christian commander refuses to recognize Hrawi and calls him a Syrian puppet. Syria has 40,000 soldiers in Lebanon under an Arab League mandate issued in 1976, the year after the civil war began. Aoun calls them an occupation army and the 20,000 Christian troops he commands fought a six-month artillery war with the Syrians last year. At least 929 people were killed and 2,744 wounded before the Arab League arranged a cease-fire in September. Nearly all the casualties were civilians.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Prime Minister's Mother Dies
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov's mother has died, Tass reported Friday in an unusual mention of a ruling Politburo member's family affairs. The state-run news agency released a one-paragraph statement saying the Politburo ``expresses deep sympathy for N.I. Ryzhkov on the passing away of his mother, Alexandra Pavlovna Ryzhkova.'' Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov said earlier this week that Ryzhkov's mother's illness might prevent him from attending the Comecon meeting in Bulgaria on Jan. 9. There was no word Friday on whether he would be present. The Comecon meeting promises to be a crucial one, with members clamoring for an overhaul and Czechoslovakia reportedly planning to propose that the East bloc economic alliance be disbanded. Czechoslovakia Finance Minister Vaclav Klaus said Thursday there was no reason for Comecon to exist anymore, and he said his nation would pull out unless the bloc is totally overhauled. Polish Foreign Trade Minister Marcin Swiecicki echoed Klaus' views Friday, saying the alliance is outdated and should be replaced by a less-rigid organization. Hungarian Foreign Minister Gyula Horn also said Friday that Comecon needed ``radical reform.'' The report of the death of Ryzhkov's mother went against the Soviet custom of keeping leaders' personal affairs strictly private. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's more relaxed style has led to the lowering of the veil around leaders' lives somewhat. Politburo conservative Yegor K. Ligachev discussed his hobbies with a Soviet weekly and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze admitted at a news conference that he wrote love poems in his youth.

DOC.HEAD: Ceausescu Had Planned to Flee to China, Former Security Chief Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 9th graf pvs, A spokesman, to update arrival of daughter.
DOC.TEXT: Executed Romanian dictator Nicolae Ceausescu once drafted an elaborate plan to flee to China and direct a guerrilla war from there against anyone who tried to oust him, his former head of security says. ``My job would have been to take Ceausescu out of Romania,'' Ion Pacepa said in a telephone interview with The Associated Press. The flight to China was part of what Ceausescu called ``Plan M,'' which also called for the Securitate secret police to adopt civilian disguises, retreat to hidden bunkers and wage guerrilla war, Pacepa said in one of the few interviews he has given since defecting in 1978. ``Ceausescu's refuge at that time was China, where he was to live there as long as need be,'' said Pacepa. He declined to disclose his current address, where he lives under an assumed name. Ceausescu, the last of the hardline Warsaw Pact bosses to fall from power, kept close ties with officials in other conservative communist countries, such as China and North Korea, as well as with Islamic leaders in Iran. At the time of his defection, Pacepa was a two-star general and acting head of Romanian external intelligence. In his book, ``Red Horizons,'' he detailed Ceausescu's efforts to obtain Western technology on behalf of Moscow. The book also chronicled the extravagant use of power and wealth by Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, who were executed after a secret trial on Christmas Day. Pacepa said he agreed to speak to the AP because his daughter, Dana Damaceanu, her husband and two other relatives were being escorted to safety from Romania by U.S. Rep. Frank A. Wolf, R-Va. His daughter had been under virtual house arrest for a decade and was arrested by the Securitate during the upheaval, he said. The group was arriving at Dulles International Airport near Washington on Saturday, a day earlier than expected, said Charles Lyons, a spokesman for Wolf. The contingency plan for Ceausescu to survive a rebellion, as described by Pacepa, resembled what was occurring in Romania until the fugitive leader was captured on Dec. 23. Officials of the provisional Romanian government said they executed the Ceausescus because they feared the Securitate might rescue them and because they wished to encourage pro-Ceausescu forces to give up. Romanian television repeatedly broadcast footage of the secret trial and the bodies of the executed Ceausescus to prove they were dead. By the time Pacepa defected, Ceausescu had built miles of secret tunnels linking his downtown palace to other buildings and to two airports on the outskirts of Bucharest, the Romanian capital. Romanian radio reported during the uprising that the Securitate retreated into a maze of secret tunnels, from which it was launching attacks. As part of Plan M, said Pacepa, Romanian intelligence established safe houses in West Germany and two neutral countries, Austria and Switzerland, to ``give Ceausescu the means to wage a guerrilla war from abroad.'' The safe houses were occupied by Romanian ``illegals,'' Romanian-born agents who had documents saying they were natives of the countries in which they were living. They used ``burst transmitters'' to broadcast coded messages in brief transmissions that are hard for intelligence agencies to detect, he said. ``There were a dozen radio stations to illegally communicate with the Securitate in Romania and Ceausescu in China,'' he said. Pacepa cooperated with Western intelligence after he defected and said most of the ``illegals'' had disappeared or were taken into custody. Ceausescu's agents tried several times to kill Pacepa after his defection, and they harassed and repeatedly arrested and beat his daughter in Bucharest, he said. The threats and harassment worsened after Radio Free Europe broadcast Pacepa's book over its Romanian-language service, he said. The U.S.-funded radio station ``deserves a lot of the credit'' for toppling Ceausescu, said Pacepa. ``In Romania, people were not able to watch West German or Austrian television'' as reformers could in East Germany, Hungary and Czechoslovakia. ``The only source of information was Radio Free Europe, and they did a marvelous job.'' The Securitate numbered 10,000 agents when Ceausescu took power in 1965, said Pacepa, and reportedly reached 180,000 by the time of his ouster, about the same size as the regular army. ``Because he did not have confidence in the army, he built his own army,'' said Pacepa. In the end, the Romanian army revolted and defeated the Securitate.

DOC.HEAD: Jobless Rate Holds Steady; Manufacturing Jobs Drop Again
DOC.TEXT: The nation's unemployment rate held steady at 5.3 percent last month as gains in service industries offset the ninth consecutive monthly drop in manufacturing jobs, the Labor Department said Friday. The steady civilian jobless rate, which ended 1989 just under the level where it began, gave private analysts hope that the economy's current sluggish growth will not worsen into a recession. ``That's a good number and it certainly suggests that the economy isn't falling out of bed,'' said Robert Dederick, chief economist for the Northern Trust Co. of Chicago. In other good economic news, the Commerce Department said Friday that orders to U.S. factories for manufactured goods, which have been lackluster in recent months, shot up 2.4 percent in November to a seasonally adjusted $239.7 billion, their best showing since April. The increased demand was widespread across most industries, led by another big jump in orders for aircraft. Economists said the rise in orders, if it continues in coming months, should halt the slide in manufacturing employment, probably by the middle of next year. Analysts were still concerned that the slowdown in the overall economy, which many feared would last until the spring, would translate into higher jobless rates in the months ahead. ``There definitely is some weakness out there in the land. ... The steady growth of the service industry is what's keeping us from slipping into a recession,'' said economist Cynthia Latta of DRI-McGraw Hill. During all of last year, the unemployment rate fluctuated in a narrow range within a tenth of a percentage point of 5.3 percent, except for March when it dipped to a 15-year low of 5 percent. The average for the year was 5.3 percent. Based on a workplace survey, manufacturing industries lost another 25,000 jobs in December, bringing factory job losses since March to 195,000. U.S. manufacturing suffered in 1989 with widespread layoffs in auto plants and other factories producing big-ticket consumer goods. This job loss has not been enough to pull the country into a recession because of a continued boom in the service sector, where most Americans are employed. In December, the service sector added 206,000 jobs, bringing total job growth for the year to 2.4 million. ``There's a kind of tug of war going on to see whether (service industry increases) will pull ahead of the manufacturing losses,'' said Pierre Ellis, an economist at the Boston Co. The addition of 142,000 non-farm jobs in December was not considered a particularly strong advance, given that it was artificially inflated with the return of about 55,000 striking telephone workers in New York. Some analysts were concerned by a 0.6 percent rise in average hourly earnings in December, which would translate into wage gains above 7 percent if it persisted for a year. However, other analysts dismissed the jump as a one-month aberration and not a signal that wage pressures were threatening to set off an inflationary spiral. They noted that the 4.1 percent increase in hourly wages over the past year was still under consumer price inflation, which has been increasing by 4.5 percent. The Labor Department on Friday revised the November unemployment rate to 5.3 percent, which it had earlier reported as 5.4 percent. According to a household survey by the department, the economy produced 1.7 million new jobs during 1989, bringing the civilian work force to 117.9 million. That was down from job gains of 2.3 million in 1988. Construction jobs fell by 38,000 in December with analysts attributing the drop to the deep freeze that gripped most of the nation last month. Transportation employers added 73,000 jobs on a seasonally adjusted basis last month. Business services added 14,000; health services, 47,000; government, 34,000; and finance, insurance and real estate, 13,000. Retail employment grew by 12,000 fewer jobs than the normally expected seasonal gain. In a separate calculation of unemployment that counts members of the armed services stationed in the United States, the December jobless rate was unchanged at 5.3 percent, the same as the civilian rate.

DOC.HEAD: New Leader is Favorite Son of Border Town
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: To residents of this city on the Soviet border, Romania's new leader Ion Iliescu is a caring man capable of ending their nation's quarter-century of despair. Iliescu had clashed with dictator Nicolae Ceausescu before his posting as the city's Communist Party chief in 1974-76. The job was one of several demotions for Iliescu, who emerged as leader of the revolution that last month toppled and executed Ceausescu. Through a filter of suffering and revolution, the people of Iasi see in Iliescu not only a talented economist, but a man who cares about people and culture. ``He was the only local party secretary who didn't treat Ceausescu like a king,'' said Adi Cristi, a poet and member of the National Salvation Front committee that now runs the city of 300,000 people. ``I think Mr. Iliescu will restore liberty and the possibility to say anything you think,'' said Pavel Zaharia, who waited on Iliescu's table 15 years ago and now manages a hotel in the city. There is also praise from those on the Soviet side of the border who worked with Iliescu. Mikhail S. Platon, a deputy premier of the Soviet republic of Moldavia across the Prut River, was a local party official in the border region when Iliescu was in charge in Iasi. Among Soviets, Platon said in an interview, Iliescu had a reputation as ``an energetic, businesslike, thoughtful and progressive person.'' As a hydrologist, he concentrated on land improvements in an area where a lack of rainfall inhibits otherwise favorable growing conditions, Platon said. Iliescu studied at Moscow State University, and much has been made of the fact that he was a student there at the same time as President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. It is unclear, however, whether he actually knew Gorbachev. But Platon said that by temperament and conviction, the 59-year-old Iliescu is close to Gorbachev. ``By nature he is a good mixer, he likes to be with the people,'' he said. ``He saw the difficulties and the hardships of their lives.'' Iliescu reached his peak under Ceausescu as a member of the Central Committee and the minister of youth affairs in 1967-72, but then progressively fell into disfavor until he was named the head of a technical publishing house, the job he held until he announced the arrest of Ceausescu on national TV on Dec. 23. It is not known whether Iliescu took part in organizing the revolt before he appeared on television. Despite his demotion, observers in Bucharest say he was one of the few Romanians who had the stature and experience to rally the country against the dictator. He is president of the revolutionary Council of the National Salvation Front, and has pledged to guide the country toward free elections in April. He has announced the reintroduction of private property, abolished the death penalty and signed a decree establishing the basis of a multiparty system. With the fall of Ceausescu, the Romanian Communist Party virtually has ceased to exist. Other top officials of the National Salvation Front have said they no longer consider themselves Communists. Iliescu showed his economic prowess with documents and numbers rather than ideological bluster, the new Iasi officials said. The president of the local Salvation Front, Doru Tigau, recalled a speech on sugar production in which Iliescu compared the efficiency of a local factory with that of factories in Italy, France and other countries. ``He never appeared before people without documents,'' Tigau said. Another time in Iasi, in what was then a feat of daring, Iliescu made an official speech that lasted several hours and only mentioned Ceausescu once, Tigau recalled. He referred to him as ``Comrade Ceausescu'' instead of preceding Ceausescu's name with all of the former leader's titles, as was customary at the time. Iliescu's unorthodox style was evident in his approach to the arts as well, Iasi's new officials said. ``He protected the arts without taking political nuances into account,'' Tigau said. Cristi said Iliescu built a library and a children's and youth theater that is the only one of its kind in Romania. Iasi residents said what they saw of him in the 1970s convinces them that Iliescu should be given a chance to be elected president. ``There's no other choice,'' said Marius Frangiliu, a 25-year-old student.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Spent $224,000 in Futile Effort to Find Leak
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department said Friday that it spent $224,000 on a futile attempt to identify the source of an unauthorized disclosure of a preliminary criminal investigation involving Rep. William H. Gray III. The department conducted a five-month investigation to determine who leaked information that the FBI was investigating alleged financial irregularities in Gray's congressional office. An initial CBS-TV story that Gray was the subject of the preliminary investigation prompted a storm of accusations from Democrats on Capitol Hill that the Republican-run Justice Department was trying to smear the Pennsylvania Democrat with news leaks. The department quickly took the unusual step of issuing a statement that Gray was not a target and was cooperating with FBI agents. The CBS story was particularly embarrassing for Attorney General Dick Thornburgh because it was aired as Gray was seeking election as House majority whip, a job he later won. Thornburgh ordered an investigation of the unauthorized leak. The $224,000 included the salaries and travel expenses of 11 FBI agents, as well as prosecutors and support personnel, Runkel said. Agents took sworn statements from 109 Justice Department and FBI employees and 10 were asked to take polygraph tests, the department said. The investigation was conducted with money already available for that purpose, Runkel said. During the investigation, the Justice Department told Congress that it had changed its longstanding policy barring prosecution of government officials for unauthorized disclosure of sensitive information. Under the new policy, officials could be prosecuted for conversion or theft of government property by making an unauthorized disclosure of information about a criminal investigation. The charge carries a maximum 10-year sentence. But Thornburgh said last week in a letter to Congress that there would be no prosecutions or disciplinary action because the investigation of the Gray leak was ``unable to identify with certainty the original source'' of the disclosure.

DOC.HEAD: West Germans to Bankroll Housing, Urban Projects in East Germany
DOC.TEXT: Officials from both German nations announced a multibillion-dollar project Friday to renovate crumbling cities in East Germany and provide more and better housing for people on both sides of the border. Also Friday, East German's official news agency reported that ousted Communist leader Erich Honecker, who faces corruption charges, is too ill to be jailed and needs surgery to remove a kidney tumor. The first beneficiaries of the joint renovation project will be the East German cities of Meissen, Weimar, Brandenburg and Stralsund. Those cities and many other urban areas of East Germany require major restoration following damage during World War II. General neglect under a socialist system that gave priority to industry over living conditions, and the devastating effects of the brown-coal haze choking major cities, have contributed to their deterioration. West Germany's construction minister, Gerda Hasselfeldt, said Bonn will contribute $4 billion to the project in the next two years. Ms. Hasselfeldt and East Germany's minister for construction and housing, Gerhard Baumgaertel, said the reconstruction of the four cities will be the pilot project for cooperation between the German states. ``It is my hope that by pursuing all means of improving housing and construction in this country, that our housing market can be eased as well,'' Ms. Hasselfeldt said. East Germany suffers a serious housing shortage because many residential buildings are unfit for habitation. West Germany's housing problem is due more to a lack of space and the high cost of construction. Tens of thousands of apartments in East Berlin are empty because of last fall's exodus to the West of disgruntled East Germans. If the apartments were upgraded to Western standards, arrangements could be made to rent some of the space to West Berliners, who are short at least 50,000 homes in their crowded city of 2.1 million people. Ms. Hasselfeldt said more incentive for ``private ownership and individual responsibility'' was needed to ensure the joint projects succeed. She said West Germany was not putting any conditions on the financial and technical aid it will give to the renovation but said the projects ``cannot function successfully without structural changes'' in the East German economy. The new chairman of West Germany's Deutsche Bank visited East Berlin on Friday, but no details of the talks were disclosed. Deutsche Bank is expected to play an important role in turning around East Germany's stagnant economy after 40 years of socialist mismanagement. Communist Premier Hans Modrow has called for limited steps to attract foreign investment and encourage some private enterprise. His plan for guiding the nation out of its economic morass is to be disclosed next week. Modrow became premier during the pro-democracy movement that resulted in Honecker's ouster Oct. 18. Honecker, 77, has been in seclusion at a former Communist Party estate since Oct. 18, but he must be moved from the compound by the end of the month as it is to be converted to a state home for the handicapped. The official ADN news agency said Thursday that doctors had asked to examine him to determine if he could be imprisoned pending investigation of corruption charges. On Friday, ADN said Honecker was too ill to be jailed. Another new opposition group announced its formation Friday. The pro-Western party calls itself the Social Citizens Union of Germany and advocates reunification with West Germany and transition to a full market economy. Most other pro-democracy groups are pressing for closer ties with West Germany but retention of East German sovereignty. National elections are scheduled in May.

DOC.HEAD: President Supports Baker On Statements About Secret Trips To Beijing
With AM-US-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush stood by Secretary of State James A. Baker III on Friday in a failed attempt to keep secret a July visit to Beijing by two senior U.S. officials. After the trip became known last month, Baker acknowledged he may have been misleading in saying that a trip earlier that month to China by Brent Scowcroft, the president's national security assistant, and Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger was their first mission to Beijing. Baker said his intention had been to protect the president and his policy. The trips, for talks with Chinese leaders, were criticized in Congress and elsewhere as undercutting U.S. disapproval of China's bloody crackdown of pro-democracy forces and Bush's own policy of moderate punitive sanctions against the Chinese government. Bush, responding to a question at a White House news conference, began by saying ``some things will be conducted in secrecy,'' then told reporters: ``I know you don't like it. Your business is to get everything out in the open and my business is to conduct the foreign affairs of this country in the way I think I was elected to... . He acknowledged that the missions to China were ``controversial'' and that ``some think the best way to make change for human rights in China is isolation.'' Bush said, however, that he had not chosen the path of ``excommunication'' of the Chinese leaders. As for the inaccurate statement by Baker that the December trip by Scowcroft and Eagleburger to Beijing in December had been their first, Bush said: ``I don't think Jim Baker would ever deliberately mislead somebody. And so I will stand _ stand with him.'' Pressed about Baker's explanation that his intention had been to protect Bush, the president cut the questioner off. ``Ask him about it,'' Bush said. ``I support my secretary of state.'' Asked what the visits had accomplished, the president said the Voice of America had been permitted to send a new bureau chief to Beijing. Her predecessor was ousted during the June 3-4 crackdown in which hundreds of protesters were killed by Chinese troops. In defense of his overtures, Bush also cited a reported decision by China to end missile sales to Middle Eastern countries.

DOC.HEAD: Churches Hopeful Under New Leadership
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Baptists, probably the most oppressed worshipers under Nicolae Ceausescu, are professing their faith openly for the first time since the dictator's relentless persecution stifled them decades ago. ``Numerous people from all walks of life, including many army officers and soldiers, have been coming here in the past few days to tell us how afraid they had been in the past to say they were believers,'' the Rev. Ilie Tundrea of Bucharest's Bethany Baptist Church said Friday. As in other countries with rigid Communist regimes, believers were considered unreliable citizens, not allowed to hold leading positions in an officially atheist system. No religion was encouraged, but Tundrea said in an interview ``it was worse for Protestants, because the authorities could not tolerate our evangelical activity.'' Ceausescu was overthrown Dec. 22, and the first large Baptist gathering was held Dec. 31 in Oradea, northwestern Romania. About 10,000 worshipers packed a sports arena with the approval of the new authorities. For the first time since the Communist takeover in 1947, state radio and TV broadcast a live Christmas service from the Patriarhie Cathedral in Bucharest. In recent annual U.S. State Department reports on human rights, the Ceausescu regime ranked among the worst offenders. It was accused of running a police state with no freedom of expression, and religious tolerance only for such recognized faiths as the Romanian Orthodox or Jews. Baptist pastors were denied permission to preach and arrested for distributing Bibles. The Communists never recognized the Roman Catholic church because the Catholic bishops refused to recognize the supremacy of the state. About 80 percent of Romania's 23 million people are believed to be nominal followers of the Orthodox faith and 6 percent are Roman Catholics. Romania has about 300,000 Baptists, up from 60,000 two decades ago. Most of the Baptists, Pentecostals, Seventh-day Adventists and other Protestants are in the western Transylvania region and in Bucharest. Under Ceausescu, who ruled Romania for 24 years, the Baptist Church was given special attention because its rapid growth was seen as a threat. The Romanian Orthodox church was treated more leniently because it generally limited itself to such traditional ceremonies as Mass, marriages and funerals. ``Securitate officers were present at every single service to record what was being preached and we were forbidden from baptizing,'' Tundrea said, referring to the Ceausescu's secret police.
