He said police cars always were parked outside the church and the telephones of leading Baptists were tapped. Believers who refused to become informers were harassed at work and ``many were jailed for years after they were accused of being servants of Western capitalism,'' the pastor said. Official reaction to construction of a church in Comanesti, 135 miles north of Bucharest, illustrated the hardships Baptists faced under Ceausescu. The building was torn down in 1989 after authorities accused local church leaders of ``stealing construction materials and other socialist property,'' and four were imprisoned. They were released after the revolution. Lack of Bibles and other Christian books forbidden in Romania was partially overcome through the efforts of missionaries from Western Europe and the United States, who imported the books in special hidden compartments in their vans, Tundrea said. Pastors often were summoned for interrogation by the security police and were even forbidden to preach from specific sections of the Bible. They could not mention the Book of Revelations ``because it speaks of the second coming of Christ; this Ceausescu did not accept,'' Tundrea said while helping unload a Dutch truck bringing food aid for distribution by his church. In 1977, a group of pastors wrote a letter to Ceausescu complaining about persecution in the country, Tundrea said. ``After that, every one of us was interrogated each day for six weeks,'' he said in a whisper, then laughed and said aloud: ``You see, I am still living in the era before the revolution.'' ``For us, the revolution was a miracle. We can now be free to participate'' in a ``Christian revival in Romania,'' the pastor said. ``I believe ... we will have opportunity to print Bibles and magazines, establish new contacts and organize evangelical activities, because people feel such a big hunger for them now.''

DOC.HEAD: Must Judges Warn People on Perils of Legal Self-Defense? Maine Court Says No
DOC.TEXT: A judge is not required to warn a defendant that he could be making a mistake by serving as his own lawyer, Maine's highest court has ruled. The ruling by the Maine Supreme Judicial Court came in the appeal of a former policeman with a ``strongly held dislike for attorneys'' who was convicted of having sex with a child. Former state Trooper Richard Morrison was charged with having sex with a 13-year-old baby sitter in 1985. He defended himself at trial, lost the case, then hired a lawyer and appealed his conviction on grounds that he had inadequate legal representation. Johnson was in jail after surrendering following Thursday's 4-2 ruling. He was sentenced to 10 years. A popular saying among lawyers is that a person who acts as his own attorney has ``a fool for a client.'' The gist of Morrison's appeal was that the judge should have warned him how foolish he was. His lawyer, Peter B. Bickerman, said he would meet with Morrison before determining whether to appeal the Maine ruling to the U.S. Supreme Court. ``It's generally believed that the judge should give some kind of warning'' to defendants who act as their own lawyer, Bickerman said. But Bickerman said guidelines for such warnings have never been firmly laid out. The court majority said Morrison had no right to a new trial because, before his trial, he had been warned by family, friends and even the prosecutor that he should get an attorney. Morrison's wife contacted a lawyer, ``only to have Morrison become angry with her and refuse the lawyer's help,'' said the majority opinion written by Chief Justice Vincent L. McKusick. ``Morrison had a strongly held dislike for attorneys, and despite repeated warnings he never budged from his early decision to conduct his own defense at trial,'' McKusick wrote. The justices said they were refusing to create a rule that would throw out convictions of people who represent themselves ``if the trial court failed to give the defendant Miranda-like warnings of the risks of self-representation and the benefits of counsel on the record.'' Miranda is the landmark U.S. Supreme Court ruling that requires police to read suspects their rights. The two dissenting justices said Morrison should have received more than warnings from his wife and fellow troopers. They noted that the trial judge informed Morrison of his constitutional right to a lawyer and determined Morrison was able to afford a lawyer, but he did not warn Morrison about the dangers of self-representation. The dissenting opinion also quoted from a California case in which the U.S. Supreme Court held that defendants who represent themselves ``should be made aware of the dangers and disadvantages of self-representation, so that the record will establish that `he knows what he is doing and his choice is made with his eyes open.''' Morrison was convicted of rape, gross sexual misconduct, unlawful sexual contact and assault. Thursday's ruling dismissed the conviction on the unlawful sexual contact count, saying the prosecution had inadequate evidence on that charge. That did not change Morrison's 10-year prison sentence, Bickerman said.

DOC.HEAD: Atlanta Mayor, King's Widow Urge People to Turn Backs on Klan Rally
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Maynard Jackson and Martin Luther King Jr.'s widow Friday urged Atlantans to ignore a Ku Klux Klan rally planned at the state Capitol on Saturday. A white supremacist rally and march in downtown Atlanta a year ago turned violent as thousands of counterdemonstrators gathered to oppose a handful of white suprematist protesters. Jackson joined Coretta Scott King for a news conference outlining events for the city's King Week celebration, which runs Sunday through Jan. 15, Martin Luther King Jr. Day. ``The Klan rally is not worthy of your attention,'' Jackson said. ``Stay home, go shopping, rake leaves ... do whatever you do on Saturdays. There's no sense in wasting your time on that. Leave them alone, and let them say what they have to say _ to each other.'' ``That would be a good thing to do,'' agreed Mrs. King, president of the King Center. ``It would be much better if people stayed away.'' Mrs. King said she and the center ``believe in the First Amendment privileges of all people. But we certainly don't agree with the philosophy of the Klan.'' The Southern White Knights of the KKK plan a morning demonstration at the state Capitol and an afternoon rally in Forsyth County, the virtually all-white county north of Atlanta where ``brotherhood marchers'' were pelted with rocks in 1987, prompting a second march by 20,000 civil rights supporters. The Ad Hoc Committee Against the Klan has called this week for counterdemonstrators to gather in opposition to the Klan. Police plan to keep the groups apart, and the National Guard is on standby. Mrs. King told reporters that King Week events will go on despite recent violence and threats against civil rights activists. The commemorative activities come less than a month after four mail bombs arrived at civil rights and judicial targets in three states, killing a federal judge in Alabama and a Savannah alderman who was an attorney for the NAACP. King Week in Atlanta will include an ecumenical service at King's old church, Ebenezer Baptist, and a parade down Peachtree Street and historic Auburn Avenue, site of the King Center and the civil rights leader's crypt. ``The precautions one should take _ we always try to take them,'' said Mrs. King, adding that she was reluctant to draw further attention to those responsible for the bombings. ``To talk about this only invites people to do more of this kind of violence,'' she said. Mrs. King noted that threats of violence are nothing new to the civil rights community. ``There have been threats on my life ... and, of course, my husband's life was constantly threatened.'' King was assassinated in 1968. For the first time in the five-year history of the King federal holiday, the Monday legal holiday falls this year on King's actual birthday, Jan. 15. He would have been 61.

DOC.HEAD: Unemployment in 11 Major States
With AM-Unemployment Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are the December unemployment rates for 11 large states as reported Friday by the Labor Department: California, 5.3 percent, up from 5.0 percent in November. Florida, 5.8 percent, up from 5.6 percent. Illinois, 6.3 percent, down from 6.8 percent. Massachusetts, 4.6 percent, up from 4.4 percent. Michigan, 7.2 percent, down from 7.3 percent. New Jersey, 3.6 percent, down from 5.1 percent. New York, 5.6 percent, up from 5.2 percent. North Carolina, 3.1 percent, up from 2.8 percent. Ohio, 6.2 percent, down from 6.3 percent. Pennsylvania, 5.3 percent, down from 5.4 percent. Texas, 6.6 percent, down from 7.2 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Withholding Judgment on Role of Women in Combat
With AM-US-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush hailed the ``heroic performance'' Friday of American women who fought in the U.S. invasion of Panama, but said he will reserve judgment on the role of females in combat pending Pentagon review. The involvement of approximately 600 women of the nearly 26,000 American troops who took part in the U.S. invasion has renewed the debate over women in combat. Army regulations prohibit women from serving in combat and U.S. law bars women from combat in the Navy and Air Force. Questioned about the participation of women in the invasion, Bush said their original assignments were non-combat, but, ``any time you have a highly trained, gung-ho volunteer force and they're caught up in some of the firefights that went on, a person can be ... put into a combat situation.'' During the invasion, Army Capt. Linda L. Bray led male and female troops from a military police platoon into combat with approximately 40 members of the Panamanian Defense Forces hiding in a dog kennel. Three members of the Panamanian Defense Forces were killed. ``I would let the heroic performance of these people be weighed and measured, and then see if the Defense Department wanted to recommend to the president any additional changes,'' Bush told reporters at a news briefing. Earlier in the day, the ranking Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee said Congress will ``probably take a step forward'' on the role of women in combat in light of their stepped up role in Panama. But the senator, John Warner of Virginia, said he does not foresee ``full equality'' for female soldiers. ``There are still certain areas where we cannot co-locate men and women in close confinement,'' Warner, said in a telephone interview with reporters. The former Navy secretary, joined by Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, traveled to Panama this past week to review the military operations in the wake of the Dec. 20 invasion that unseated Manuel Antonio Noriega. Warner said he met with a number of the women involved in the Panamanian invasion and they ``performed with extraordinary professional skills.'' ``We will re-examine in Congress based on their experiences and determine if we have the right policy,'' said Warner, who cautioned against rushing toward any change. Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., a member of the House Armed Services Committee, said this past week that she is drafting legislation that would allow women to serve in Army combat as part of a four-year test program. Warner, in his telephone interivew from San Jose, Costa Rica, said, ``We'll probably take a step forward based on the events in Panama ... but it will not result in full equality.'' Warner, who plans to travel to El Salvador and Guatemala and is awaiting approval of a visa to Nicaragua, said the initial opposition among the Central American nations to the U.S. military intervention in Panama has subsided. ``The mood is beginning to shift as they realize that the military part was near perfection,'' Warner said.

DOC.HEAD: State Media to Mark Orthodox Christmas
DOC.TEXT: State-run media will broadcast Serbian Orthodox Christmas celebrations for the first time since Communists came to power in Yugoslavia 45 years ago, the Tanjug news agency said Friday. On Orthodox Christmas, which will be celebrated Sunday, TV will broadcast live the liturgy service from a Belgrade church, and the radio will feature a Christmas message by Patriarch German of the Serbian Orthodox Church, the official news agency said. Also for the first time in Communist Yugoslavia, religious festivities are scheduled to take place on the main Republic square in Belgrade on Saturday, Christmas Eve. Yugoslavia is officially an atheist state, but in recent years people have openly celebrated religious holidays without interference by the authorities. Most of the country's 10 million Eastern Orthodox live in the republic of Serbia, while about 5 million Roman Catholics live in the northwestern regions of Croatia and Slovenia.

DOC.HEAD: Yamaha, Sumitomo Life Insurance To Finance Poland's Chopin Center
With AM-Poland
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese piano maker and a life insurance company said Friday they will help finance a plan to establish a Chopin memorial center in Poland. Sumitomo Life Insurance, Co. spokesman Yasuhisa Tanabe said his compnay and Yamaha have reached initial agreement with the Polish Culture Ministry to finance the project. The Chopin center, to be built in memory of Polish composer and pianist Frederic Chopin, will organize seminars and lessons, and provide an international meeting place for young pianists, Tanabe said. He said details of the financial assistance have not been finalized. Comments from Yamaha were not available due to a company holiday Friday. The nationally circulated Asahi Shimbun newspaper reported Friday that Poland asked the two companies for assistance due to the country's financial difficulties. Construction will require an estimated $18 million, it said. The paper said Yamaha will lend $2 million and Sumitomo $4 million by purchasing shares that are to be issued by the center. Construction will start sometime this year and is to be completed in 1992 or 1993, the newspaper reported.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle to Undertake Fence-Mending Trip to Latin America
With AM-US-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Friday he will dispatch Vice President Dan Quayle on a fence-mending trip throughout Latin America in an effort to counter negative reaction to the U.S. military invasion of Panama. ``To some degree I am concerned,'' about that reaction, Bush told a White House news conference. ``Because I am well aware of how our friends south of our border, including my friend President (Carlos) Salinas (of Mexico) look at the use of American force anywhere. So I am concerned about it.'' Quayle's agenda and the timing of the trip were still being decided, said his press secretary, David Beckwith. The only country that was definitely on his schedule was Honduras, where he already had planned to attend the Jan. 27 presidential inauguration. At least seven Latin heads of state are expected to attend and Quayle could lay the groundwork for the rest of his visits in meetings with them. Bush indicated he recognizes Latin sensitivity to what historically has been seen as a heavy-handed U.S. policy toward Central and South America, including military interventions in years past, toppling of leaders and installation of governments friendly to the United States. ``I view this as very, very important diplomacy,'' the president said of Quayle's trip. None of the Latin countries voiced support for his Dec. 20 invasion of Panama, and many of them strongly condemned it. Peru went so far as to withdraw in protest from the upcoming drug summit with Bush in Colombia. It later reversed course and said it would send a representative. The Organization of American States overwhelming passed a resolution deploring the invasion, with only five absentions from countries who wanted a condemnation of Noriega as well to be included in the resolution. Bush insisted, however, that the negative feeling that has resulted from the invasion is ``something that's correctable, because I think they know that I have tried a lot of consultion, that we have exhausted the remedies in this particular case of multilateral diplomacy. ``But given the history of the use of U.S. force, I would be remiss if I didn't face up to the problem that we must go forward diplomatically now to explain how this president looks at the protection of American life, that we acted, in our view well within our rights, but that we will continue consultation.'' He said Quayle ``will be in a position to explain very clearly not only U.S. policy, but our aspirations for Panama, and indeed, for this entire hemisphere.'' He said the Latin nations must understand the invasion was motivated by ``the protection of American life.'' Asked if he was reverting to old U.S. policies that have upset the Latin countries for years, Bush said that Quayle's trip ``takes on enormous importance to convince the people of the truth.'' ``We are not reverting to just a willful ... use of force that has no rationale,'' he said. ``But when it comes to the protection of American life, please, our friends south of the border, understand that this president is going to protect it.'' Bush noted that the U.S. military intervention that drove Noriega from power was well-received by many of the Panamanian people themselves. ``It has been overwhelming,'' he said of the Panamanian response. Although no timetable has been set for Quayle's trip, it will force postponement of a Feb. 4-11 European journey the vice president had been planning. He was to have visited several countries to consult with U.S. allies.

DOC.SECOND: Bush Weighing Ways to Revitalize Panama's Economy
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Friday he is considering housing programs, business development and bank loans to help Panama's shattered economy recover from the U.S. invasion and years of economic sanctions. Bush was not more specific on what the United States might do to help Panama recover from invasion-related damage, estimated at perhaps $2 billion, and from two years of economic decline that flowed partly from the U.S. sanctions against Manuel Antonio Noriega. Nor did Bush address where his administration will find money to help Panama in a foreign aid budget already strained past its limits. Foreign assistance is among the least popular programs on Capitol Hill, where the president would have to secure approval for aid to Panama. It was learned separately that Bush administration officials are looking into possible aid that includes: _Building houses for people left homeless by the bombing and combat. _Helping Panama to pay its $543 million in foreign debt so it can get new loans. _Getting other nations involved in the recovery effort. _Loans to help businesses recover. While recommendations have yet to be drawn up and presented to Bush, one administration source said ``there's a sense of urgency and we want to move quickly and respond quickly.'' One official, who, like the others, requested anonymity, said it also is likely the administration will move up from March the date on which officials must certify whether Panama is cooperating in antidrug efforts. By speeding up the evaluation, the administration could enable Panama to receive U.S. trade benefits and Caribbean Basin Initiative benefits and have its sugar quota reinstated, that official said. The embryonic, U.S.-installed government of President Guillermo Endara has expressed strong antidrug sentiments and would be expected to win certification, said the official. Such certification was denied to Panama under Noriega, now in U.S. custody on a variety of drug charges. ``The revitalization of the Panamanian economy is a major priority in the months ahead,'' Bush told a White House news conference, ``as are our efforts for humanitarian assistance. ``I can report today that considerable progress has been made so far in returning Panama to a normal state of affairs. The new government has taken charge, and President Endara is working tirelessly to meet the needs of his people.'' Bush said the team led by Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger that visited Panama this week had praised the Endara government. ``They are discussing housing programs, business development, bank loans that will help spur economic growth. We are committed to be a part of that process,'' Bush said. The president noted that he already has released nearly $400 million in assets in U.S. banks that was frozen under the sanctions against the Noriega regime. U.S. officials involved in the discussions with Panama said Endara did not present a laundry list of economic requests, but rather talked about general needs. ``The Endara government has to sort out its priorities,'' said one official, who also requested anonymity. Just how much money the administration might find to help Panama is an unanswered question. Bush's press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, acknowledged this week that the current 1991 budget, to be sent to Congress on Jan. 29, includes no money to help Panama. The Endara government indicated to the Eagleburger team that it recognizes that private businesses in Panama will play a major role in restoring the economy and does not expect the U.S. governement to do everything, said one source. It is expected the administration will turn to friends around the world to help Panama. In particular, officials have mentioned Japan. Japanese ambassador Ryohei Murata discussed the matter Friday with Vice President Dan Quayle. Afterward, Quayle's press secretary, David Beckwith, said he could not disclose the substance of the discussion other than to say, ``The vice president complimented Japan for considering extending aid.'' Japan retained its ties with the Noriega government despite U.S. urgings that the Tokyo government help isolate the dictator. Japan has had substantial economic interests in Panama.

DOC.HEAD: Government Revises October Thrift Withdrawals
DOC.TEXT: The nation's thrift institutions lost $6.4 billion in deposits in October, rather than the $5.6 billion in outflows originally reported, the Office of Thrift Supervision said Friday. The revision of Wednesday's reported losses was based on additional data not previously included in its monthly thrift activity report because it had not been validated, the OTS said. ``The data announced by OTS on Jan. 3 was based on reporting by 96 percent of the industry, with statistical estimates made for the remaining 4 percent,'' it said. Despite the revision, the October loss, while representing the 16th outflow in 17 months, still was an improvement over September's $8.7 billion in net withdrawals. The thrift office also revised previous data for October that showed that assets at thrifts showed little change after a string of sharp declines. In fact, October represented another sharp decline, $6.4 billion, the same as the deposit outflow.

DOC.HEAD: Stuart Was Suspect After Shootings, but Only `Routine' One
LaserPhoto BX5
DOC.TEXT: The man who summoned police with his car phone and said a black robber had abducted and shot him and his pregnant wife was only a routine suspect in the case until his own brother gave police evidence of an elaborate, grisly hoax, officials said Friday. Charles Stuart killed himself Thursday after learning his brother had revealed evidence against him in the Oct. 23 killing of his wife, Carol. Stuart had been seriously wounded himself. While hospitalized he wrote a moving letter to be read at his wife's funeral. Then he made a dramatic appearance at the deathbed of his newborn son, who was delivered by Caesarean section after the shootings and died 17 days later. And he gave a description of a black man as the killer. ``He thought he had the perfect crime ... the eulogy at the church that he had a friend read ... This guy went way out. He really thought he had a perfect crime,'' said Reading Police Chief Edward Marchand. Paul Leary, first assistant Suffolk County district attorney, said although there were some apparent discrepancies in Stuart's account, investigators felt they were not significant enough to pursue. He would not elaborate, citing a grand jury investigation. But Leary said Stuart was a routine suspect from the beginning because investigators always check out husbands when wives are killed. ``No one was ruled out,'' Leary said. ``I am told (investigators) checked out that which was at the crime scene and also went back into the personal lives of these individuals and found that they were something just short of a storybook-type couple, according to relatives on both sides of the family.'' John Dawley, who had served as Stuart's lawyer, said that until this week's developments in the case, he ``had no reason to believe this was anything but a random act of violence.'' ``The guy was a remarkable guy and I don't say that lightly. I say that in light of everything I know. I would never have expected it in a million years.'' Jack Levin, a professor at Northeastern University and expert on crime, said if Stuart was his wife's killer, the crime was so premeditated and elaborate it could only be the work of a sociopath _ ``the last people you expect. We're talking about the cream of the crop in killing.'' The scales tipped when Stuart's brother, Matthew, 23, went to police Wednesday. The younger Stuart told police his brother asked him to meet him the evening of Oct. 23 in the city's Mission Hill area, which is where the shooting took place, said Matthew's attorney, John Perenyi. The Stuarts had been at a hospital for birthing classes. Stuart told police a gunman forced them to drive to the Mission Hill area and robbed and shot them. When police found them, Mrs. Stuart was near death in the passenger's seat. Perenyi said Stuart drove up to the meeting place that evening, tossed a sack to Matthew, who was sitting in his car, and told his younger brother to take it home to Revere, where Matthew lives with their parents. Stuart suggested to his brother that the bag might have to be disposed of, according to the attorney. Inside the sack, Matthew found a pistol, Mrs. Stuart's supposedly stolen pocketbook and engagement ring, Perenyi said. Matthew took out the ring and disposed of the rest of the items in the Pines River in Revere, his lawyer said. After police heard the account from Matthew, police divers found the pocketbook Thursday but not the gun. Matthew gave the engagement ring to investigators Wednesday night. It was dark the night of the shooting, but Perenyi said Matthew told him he saw something in his brother's car that, on reflection, might have been Mrs. Stuart. Perenyi said the shootings apparently had taken place by that time. Stuart committed suicide Thursday by jumping off a bridge. Perenyi said the district attorney's office told him Matthew was not a suspect in the case. Investigators refused to comment whether there were any other suspects besides Charles Stuart. Perenyi said Matthew could not offer a motive. A black man with a long criminal record, William Bennett, was named in published reports as a suspect. Although Thursday's developments cleared him of suspicion in the Stuart shootings, he remained in jail Friday on unrelated charges.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Orders New Trial in Cigarette-Safety Case
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court Friday threw out a $400,000 verdict against a cigarette maker in the death of a smoker but gave her family a chance for a new trial on another aspect of their case against three tobacco companies. The damage judgment had been the first in the nation in a smoker-death case. Rose Cipollone of Little Ferry, N.J., died of lung cancer at age 58 in 1984, after smoking for 42 years. In its complex ruling, the 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed a U.S. District Court ruling that dismissed claims of Mrs. Cipollone's family that the cigarette companies failed to warn of the risks of tobacco smoking after 1965, when a federal labeling requirement took effect. In addition, the court reversed a jury's award of $400,000 against Liggett Group Inc. to Mrs. Cipollone's husband, Antonio Cipollone of Lakehurst, N.J., on grounds the company had violated an express warranty, or advertising promise that its products were safe. But the family did win the right to a new trial against the three on one aspect of the case. The court, in an opinion written by Judge Edward R. Becker, said Cipollone has ``live claims'' against Liggett and the other two companies, Lorillard Inc. and Philip Morris Inc., on grounds they marketed the product knowing the risks of cigarette smoking. That ``risk-utility'' theory of liability involves whether the average user can easily recognize the risks of using it. The District Court had barred Cipollone's claim of ``risk-utility'' against all three. In addition, the circuit court ruled Cipollone could make additional claims against Liggett that had been denied in lower court. Cipollone had won in District Court on his contention that the tobacco companies promised through advertising that their products were safe, which resulted in the $400,000 award. The appeals court said the District Court erred on that point, by preventing Liggett from trying to prove that Mrs. Cipollone didn't believe the companies' advertisements in the first place. However, the court said Cipollone could pursue other points that had been denied in District Court. ``Plaintiff's attorneys are back to square one after having spent nearly six years and nearly $3 million in lawyer and legal fees,'' said Josiah Murray, Liggett's general counsel. Murray said he was ``extremely gratified'' by the portion of the decision that reversed the $400,000 award.

DOC.HEAD: Priest Who Enforced Dress Code Asked to Leave
DOC.TEXT: A priest asked to give up his parish post for enforcing a dress code banning shorts and miniskirts said Friday the archbishop who made the request will face an ``angry Christ.'' The Rev. Roger Griese of Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church ``has been asked to leave,'' said Rita Reilly, spokeswoman for the Archdiocese of Cincinnati, which includes Griese's 80-member church in downtown Dayton. She refused to say what his response was. A published report said the head of the diocese, Archbishop Daniel Pilarczyk, had ordered Griese to give up his post, effective last Wednesday. The Rev. Daniel Conlon, chancellor of the archdiocese, declined to comment. Griese, pastor of Sacred Heart for 21 years, came under fire for denying communion to worshipers wearing clothes he considers inappropriate for church. In a statement the 73-year-old Griese released through a spokeswoman, he accused the media of character assassination. ``I do not hate Archbishop Pilarczyk,'' Griese said. ``I have only pity for him since he will have to face an angry Christ in judgment.'' A woman answering the door at Sacred Heart Rectory on Friday said Griese would not see anyone. Messages left for Griese were not returned. The Cincinnati Enquirer reported that Pilarczyk's order came after a three-month correspondence in which the archbishop wrote that Griese's conduct ``often led to embarrassment for the church'' and asked the priest to resign. The newspaper reported that Pilarczyk ordered Griese to accept retirement, saying the decision was based on the priest's ``public challenge of my rightful authority as diocesan bishop'' and Griese's refusal to follow instructions on maintaining a dress code. Griese criticized the archbishop from the pulpit during Mass in September after after Pilarczyk instructed him to ease enforcement of a church dress code banning shorts, miniskirts, sun dresses and jeans. Griese had twice denied communion to worshiper James Garvey when he came to church dressed in shorts. ``It is people like him across this world that drive Catholics away from the Catholic Church,'' Garvey said at the time. ``My faith was taken away from me by not giving me communion for two Sundays in a row for wearing shorts. ... That tells me he's judging me based on what I wear.'' Griese will remain a priest in good standing, Pilarczyk said in a letter quoted by the Enquirer. The church's mandatory retirement age is 75. ``Three months ago I concluded that you could no longer fulfill effectively your office of pastor,'' Pilarczyk said in the letter. ``Since then ... I have several times encouraged you to resign from office or to offer concrete evidence that I should not proceed with removal. You have responded in the negative to both requests.'' However, in statement from Griese released through a spokeswoman, the priest accused the media of ``character assassination.'' A spokesman for Griese said he plans an appeal to the Vatican, which is a priest's right under the church's Canon Law. The archbishop's letter is to be read Sunday to Sacred Heart parishioners, announcing Griese's removal and the appointment of the Rev. Francis Pilliod of Dayton as the new pastor, the Enquirer reported. Reached Friday, Pilliod declined to comment.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Seeking No Deal on Noriega Trial
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Friday he is ``not seeking a deal'' on a reduced charge for Manuel Antonio Noriega and vowed to ``bend over backwards'' to avoid saying anything that would interfere with the deposed Panamanian ruler's trial. ``Our case is strong, our resolve is firm and our legal representations are sound,'' Bush told a nationally televised news conference after discussing Noriega's prosecution on drug-trafficking charges with Attorney General Dick Thornburgh. Bush also announced he is dispatching Vice President Dan Quayle on a fence-mending tour of Latin America ``within the next several days'' to explain the U.S. military action and muster support for the new Panamanian government of Guillermo Endara. Conceding the Dec. 20 U.S. invasion of Panama had upset U.S. allies in Central and South America, the president said: ``I am concerned, because I am well aware of how our friends south of our border ... look at the use of American force anywhere.'' But, he added, ``I think it's something that's correctable.'' Bush said he had ``no immediate plans'' to visit Panama. However, an administration official, who declined to be identified, said a presidential visit is under consideration and that Panama might also be included on Quayle's itinerary. The president called revitalizing Panama's economy ``a major priority'' to help it recover from the U.S. military invasion and economic sanctions. He did not put a price tag on the U.S. aid, but some estimates for the damage have run as high as $2 billion. Even as he savored Noriega's capture, Bush said he would be ``ever mindful'' of the legal process from now on, suggesting he would refrain from his previous characterizations of Noriega as a ``thug'' and criminal. ``He is now in custody. Time for rhetoric is over,'' he said. Bush said he was convinced Noriega would get a fair trial and ``I am going to bend over backwards and not answer hypothetical questions or not do anything that might prejudice that.'' With Noriega securely in U.S. custody in Florida, Bush said he hoped to bring U.S. combat troops home from Panama ``as soon as possible.'' But he declined to give a timetable. Still, he ruled out a long-term peacekeeping role for U.S. troops. ``I'd like to see their police forces, whatever emerges, reconstituted,'' Bush said. Noriega's Panamanian Defense Forces were decimated in the U.S. military action. Bush said the some 12,000 troops stationed at U.S. bases in Panama before the invasion would be left there, but would not serve a police role. Some 2,900 combat troops were brought home this week, leaving about 24,500 military personnel, according to the Pentagon. In an opening statement at his news conference, Bush said, ``Our government is not seeking a deal with Noriega. Our policy remains that we have brought him to this country for prosecution.'' ``We are committed to a fair trial and to providing all the protections guaranteed by the U.S. Constitution and laws,'' Bush added. Asked if he would rule out a plea bargain with Noriega _ perhaps offering reduced charges to Noriega in exchange for his information on drug-trafficking _ Bush said, ``I'm not ruling it in.'' He added: ``I'm just saying he's got his rights and he ought _ we ought not to stand up here and try to define narrowly what they are.'' In Miami, Noriega attorney Steven Kollin said Noriega wasn't interested in a plea bargain. ``A man who is innocent is not receptive to any plea bargain. General Noriega is not guilty of any of these charges.'' Noriega refused to answer the charges against him at a brief hearing Wednesday, and the federal judge in his case entered an innocent plea on his behalf. The general remained in custody at an undisclosed location Thursday. Bush dismissed as ``ridiculous'' a question on whether the invasion of Panama and surrender of Noriega had become a ``political jackpot'' for him. ``A president's called on to take certain actions. We're not going in to try to furbish a political image,'' he said. Even so, Bush was asked if the action would silence Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell's criticism that Bush had a timid foreign policy. ``Knowing George, he'll find a way. And that's his job. Look, we're going into an election year.'' An aide to the Maine Democrat, Diane Dewhirst, said: ``Sen. Mitchell has consistently said that when he agrees with Bush on foreign policy he will be vigorously supportive and that when he disagrees he will offer constructive alternatives. That has not changed.'' Bush took the unusual step of ending his news conference with a complaint to television networks about coverage of his last news conference, on Dec. 21. He protested that some networks juxtaposed his lighthearted banter with reporters with pictures of bodies of U.S. servicemen killed in Panama being unloaded from a transport plane. ``I could understand why the viewers were concerned about this,'' Bush said. ``They thought that their president at a solemn moment like that didn't give a damn.'' His voice choking, Bush said: ``And I do, I do, I feel it so strongly.'' In other comments, the president: _ Said he did not envision a change in U.S. policy against intentionally sending military women into combat, although he would weigh such a recommendation if presented to him by the Pentagon. He praised the ``heroic performance'' of a ``highly trained, gung-ho'' group of women who did engage in combat in the Panama action. _ Deplored the death of an American nun in Nicaragua, but refused to fix blame on the U.S.-backed Contra rebels. He noted that the Contras had denied a role, but he added: ``It is extraordinarily murky.'' _ Defended anew two secret missions to China by National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft, saying ``there has been progress'' toward reform as a result of the visits.

DOC.HEAD: Ban Lifted on Public Singing of `Germany United Fatherland'
With AM-East Germany
DOC.TEXT: East Germany on Friday lifted a ban on singing in public of the original version of its national hymn, ``Germany United Fatherland,'' declaring the anthem written in 1949 to be part of its cultural heritage. Government spokesman Wolfgang Meyer said the hymn would once again be sung on official radio and television broadcasts. The hymn was banned by the communist government 20 years ago because it implied support for reunification of Germany _ a theme long resisted by the East German government. Meyer dismissed concerns that restoration of the hymn could be seen as encouragement of rightist elements or support for a formal union with West Germany. He said officials decided the song should again be sung because it was a part of East Germany's cultural identity. Singing the song again means ``dealing with our own history and acknowledgement of the time of those historical conditions and thoughts that inspired'' the hymn, Meyer said. ``Germany United Fatherland'' was written by East Germany's first culture minister, Johannes R. Becher. East Germany dropped the national hymn from public gatherings in 1969 because of its inferences to reunifying East and West Germany. ``Resurrected and facing the future out of ruins, let us serve you well, Germany united fatherland,'' the hymn runs in part. ``Old wants compel us, and united we compel it, because we must succeed, so that the sun shines more beautiful than ever before over Germany.''

DOC.HEAD: US Makes Conditional Offer on Contra Demobilization
DOC.TEXT: The United States is prepared to provide up to $3 million to an international commission to begin planning the voluntary relocation of Nicaraguan Contras to their homeland if democratic conditions exist, it was announced Friday. State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said the funds would be given to a commission comprised of United Nations and Organization of American States officials. The commission, known by its Spanish initials, CIAV, was set up partly to oversee the dismantling of the Contras, most of whom are based in Honduras. ``We have explained our intentions to the government of Honduras and the Nicaraguan resistance,'' Boucher said. ``Both have reacted favorably. The UN and OAS secretaries general have also been informed.'' The commission, Boucher said, will be asked to submit proposals for use of the funds. The disclosure was part of what appears to be an increase in diplomatic activity concerning the fate of the rebels as Nicaraguan elections draw closer. The Feb. 25 election in Nicaragua will match President Daniel Ortega against an opposition coalition led by presidential candidate Violeta Chamorro. Sources close to the Sandinista government said Nicaraguan officials would meet Saturday with Contra representatives in Tegucigalpa. CIAV officials also will attend. Amnesty for rebels willing to return in peace to Nicaragua will be discussed, sources said. In addition, State Department officials are expected to confer with CIAV officials at an undetermined location next week on the peace process. Most of the Contras are at camps in southern Honduras. The five Central American presidents have called for the demobilization of the Contras but the rebels, with U.S. support, have said they should remain intact until after next month's elections. Boucher's announcement of a conditional U.S. commitment to fund the demobilization of the Contras was in response to a communique approved by the five Central American presidents last month. According to some interpretations, the communique required the immediate transfer of all U.S. aid funds for the Contras to the CIAV. However, the State Department disputes that interpretation and says it has gone beyond the requirements of the communique. U.S. aid to the rebels consists of food, clothing, shelter and medical services and is due to run out at the end of February. The Sandinistas have given high priority to promoting the dismantling of the Contras, but the rebels have insisted that must be voluntary and in the context of a free and fair electoral process in Nicaragua. The biggest setback occurred in early November when the Sandinistas, contending that the rebels engaged in terrorist activities, suspended a cease-fire that had been in effect informally with the Contras for the preceding 19 months. Nine days of talks between the Sandinistas and the Contras aimed at restoring the cease-fire ended in failure Nov. 21.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Jackson Told First Lady of Displeasure Over Invasion
With AM-US-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Friday that former Democratic presidential candidate Jesse Jackson registered his disagreement with the U.S. military invasion of Panama in a telephone call to the president's wife, Barbara. Asked at a news conference if the Dec. 20 invasion was a ``political jackpot,'' Bush said, ``Well, Jesse Jackson doesn't think so. He talked to my wife. And so there's differences of opinion on that.'' He did not elaborate on Jackson's call. Presidential press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Jackson called Mrs. Bush on Thursday ``to inquire about her health. He also raised the issue of Panama. I guess he said the same things he's been saying in the press,'' the spokesman added. Mrs. Bush's press secretary, Anna Perez, confirmed that Jackson called to talk about Mrs. Bush's health, the subject of recent news accounts because she is undergoing radiation treatment for a persistent eye ailment. But Perez declined to give further details of the call. ``It was a private conversation,'' she said. Asked if Jackson and Mrs. Bush conversed often, she said, ``I don't think they're phone pals.'' Jackson has said the invasion caused a loss of the U.S. ``moral authority. He said in comments published in the Los Angeles Times that the action dealt a setback to the war on drugs, jeopardized the upcoming drug summit in Colombia, ``undermined the global movement toward peaceful democratic change and respect for the rule of law and ``revived a long history of imperial interference in Central America.'' ``One wonders if we have damaged our national soul to feed our national ego,'' he wrote. ``In a world rapidly turning away from military solutions, the American action looks morally untenable and obsolete.''

DOC.HEAD: Clark Air Base Gets New Commander
DOC.TEXT: Maj. Gen. William Studer assumed command Friday of the 13th Air Force stationed at Clark Air Base, the U.S. Air Force said. Studer, former vice commander of the 12th Air Force at Bergstrom Air Force Base in Texas, replaced Maj. Gen. Donald Snyder, who will report to Hickam Air Force Base in Hawaii as new Deputy Chief of Staff for Operations, a statement said. Clark is in Angeles City, about 50 miles north of Manila. It added that Studer, a command pilot with more than 5,000 flying hours, has served in the Air Force for 28 years in Southeast Asia, Europe and the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Link with CIA Looms as Tough Trial Issues
LaserPhoto MH4
DOC.TEXT: One of the thorniest issues facing Manuel Noriega's prosecutors is ``graymail'' _ the threat that his trial might expose embarrassing details about the ousted Panamanian leader's longtime connections with U.S. intelligence agencies. The former chief assistant U.S. attorney who forged the February 1988 drug-trafficking indictment against Noriega said Friday that during his investigation he was thwarted in his efforts to see CIA material bearing on the case. ``I went to look at what they had, but it was worthless _ it couldn't be all there was,'' said Richard Gregorie, now in private practice here. Viewing any tapes, photos or documents bearing on the case is essential for prosecutors, he said. ``It could be exculpatory if Noriega had ever told anybody about narcotics activity, which he could use to say he was acting as an agent'' in his dealings with Colombia's Medellin cocaine cartel, said Gregorie. Noriega defense attorney Steven Kollin has said he will seek Noriega's CIA files. ``We're looking for the truth and the only way to get to the truth is to get to those documents,'' Kollin said Friday. There is ample evidence that Noriega had some relationship with the CIA and other U.S. agencies, but the exact extent is disputed or still secret. In August 1988, the White House halted a General Accounting Office probe into those connections, refusing to turn over material requested because it was beyond the congressional agency's authority and dealt with ``sensitive intelligence material,'' according to presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. The CIA used Noriega as an ``asset'' from the 1970s on, according to congressional testimony, with some witnesses saying he eventually was paid as much as $200,000 a year for information when he became head of his nation's intelligence service and then commander of the armed forces in 1983. That period included George Bush's term as CIA director in the mid-1970s under President Ford. Bush has since said that although there were reports of Noriega's drug dealing at that time, he had no proof then. One of the principal witnesses cited in the indictment was Jose Blandon, a former top member of Panama's intelligence apparatus who fell out with Noriega and fled to the United States. His grand jury testimony is secret, but Blandon told a Senate subcommittee just after the indictment that Noriega had met twice with then-National Security Council representative Lt. Col. Oliver North in 1985 to find ways around the congressional ban on aid to the Contra rebels in Nicaragua. Blandon also told senators that Bush, then vice president, called Noriega before the 1983 invasion of Grenada to ask him to intercede with Cuban President Fidel Castro. Blandon said Bush wanted Castro to tell his troops on the Caribbean island not to fire on U.S. forces. Bush at the time of the hearing called Blandon's account a ``total fabrication.'' Blandon also said the CIA sent Noriega files on the private lives of U.S. senators with an interest in Panama. The CIA issued a statement saying it ``categorically denied'' Blandon's assertion, but Blandon stuck by his testimony. Noriega often traveled to Washington to meet with then-CIA director William Casey to discuss the Contras and other issues, according to testimony. Noriega's cozy relationship with the United States began to sour in 1985 when he was linked to the brutal slaying of his foe, Hugo Spadafora, and the firing of the nation's president. Adm. John Poindexter, then national security adviser to Reagan, went to Panama in December 1985 to demand Noriega's resignation, according to The Miami Herald. Noriega immediately flew to Washington to meet with Casey, who told the administration that Noriega was too valuable an intelligence source to lose. Last week, the Justice Department acknowledged that, in its haste to indict Noriega, guidelines in the handling of CIA material ``may not have been completely followed,'' according to spokesman David Runkel. But both Bush and Attorney General Dick Thornburgh continue to insist that there are no smoking guns that would embarrass the president or the CIA, or cause the case to unravel in court.

DOC.HEAD: Thornburgh Urges Experienced Prosecutors Fill Strike Force Vacancies
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh has urged U.S. attorneys around the country to choose experienced prosecutors to fill vacancies on the organized crime strike forces being transferred to their offices, a spokesman said Friday. The strike forces, which operated for 22 years as field offices of the Justice Department, have lost 33 attorneys, nearly a quarter of their force, since Thornburgh announced plans in February to put them under the control of U.S. attorneys. Some who have left said more, experienced mob prosecutors are likely to depart now that a year of controversy and objections from Congress have failed to block the merger. Departing strike force attorneys and former Justice officials said the merger was unattractive to many mob prosecutors because the U.S. attorneys, appointed by the president, tend to concentrate on shorter-term cases with quick impact and publicity rather than the complex, long-term investigations used during the last two decades to imprison the mob leadership in more than 11 eleven major cities. Thornburgh imposed the change, which he has sought since he was U.S. attorney in Pittsburgh 15 years ago, on New Year's Day. Justice spokesman Dave Runkel said Thornburgh spoke at an all-day meeting in a suburban motel with the strike force chiefs, affected U.S. attorneys and members of the Criminal Division's Organized Crime and Racketeering Section. The meeting Thursday was closed to the public. ``The attorney general stressed the need for the U.S. attorneys to put experienced prosecutors in vacant spots on the strike forces _ prosecutors who previously worked on sensitive and complex cases,'' Runkel said. ``And the U.S. attorneys reported that that is exactly what they are doing where there are vacancies.'' Some 115 strike force positions are being turned into assistant U.S. attorney posts committed to working on organized crime; another 20 attorneys are being recruited to join a squad in Washington available to handle emergency assignments around the country. Runkel said that of the 135 slots, 116 are filled and five more attorneys are in the process of being hired. Runkel said Thursday's meeting went well. ``Everybody's committed to making this system work,'' he said. ``There may be some who felt there wasn't a need for this change now, but all recognize that the change has occurred.'' He said Thornburgh and other top officials who addressed the planning session stressed that they want organized crime investigations ``carried out as vigorously in the future as in the past.'' Thornburgh has said the move was needed to end turf battles between strike force chiefs and U.S. attorneys and to address to forms of organized crime such as Colombian drug lords and street gangs. ``The only hot point came when I spoke and gave them advice on how to handle the press,'' Runkel said, declining to elaborate. The strike forces operated in 14 headquarters cities and 11 sub-office cities. They are being merged with 23 U.S. attorney offices that cover the same areas.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Approves Bacteria Treatment for Cross-Eye, Other Eye Disorder
DOC.TEXT: The government on Friday approved a type of food poisoning bacteria for use as a treatment for cross-eye and another eye disorder that renders its victims legally blind. The Food and Drug Administration said a sterile, purified botulism toxin was approved as an injection therapy to treat strabismus, or cross-eye, and blepharospasm, a muscle disorder that makes the eyes close involuntarily. ``This is seen as the first successful treatment for both conditions,'' said Eva Kemper, an FDA spokeswoman. When eaten in improperly handled food, the toxin can cause botulism or food poisoning, an ailment that can lead to paralysis or death. ``However, in clinical studies, the injected form was used safely in thousands of men and women to weaken muscles that pulled an eye in or out or to reduce spasms in muscles that pull the eyelid closed,'' the agency said in a written statement. ``With the blepharospasm, patients are legally blind because they can't hold their eyelids open,'' said Kemper. Strabismus can be the commonly known cross-eye, in which the eyes look inward at each other, or wall-eye, in which they look out. Doctors would inject the drug, botulinum toxin type A, into muscles near the eye, not the eye itself, to aid in ``turning off'' the muscle, the FDA said. The injection would take effect in a day or two and would last for about three months, according to the agency. FDA approval requires product labeling that indicates it is not recommended for use for children under 12 and an advisory to physicians that sedentary patients treated with the drug resume activity slowly. ``At least two patients who had been incapacitated and sedentary because of their previous condition apparently over-exerted too quickly and died of cardiac collapse,'' the agency said. ``The most common side effects are that some patients' eyelids may droop or their eyes may feel irritated,'' it said. The product, which will be sold as Oculinum, will be available in approximately 30 days once the FDA-mandated label changes have been completed, according to Carolyn Henderson, spokeswoman for the California-based distributor, Allergan Pharmaceuticals division of Allergan, Inc. There are about 100,000 new cases of strabismus diagnosed each year but most of those cases can be treated with more traditional therapies like eyeglasses, surgery on the muscles or exercises, the FDA said. However, the agency said about 15,000 severe cases don't respond to those therapies and they would likely be aided by the new drug. Blepharospasm affects between 3,000 and 5,000 Americans who are rendered legally blind by the condition.

DOC.HEAD: Arguments Heard in Vermont's Appeal of Judge Retirement Case
DOC.TEXT: States' rights and the intent of Congress in outlawing age discrimination were the focus of oral arguments Friday in Vermont's appeal of a ruling that bars the state from forcing a 71-year-old judge to retire. Vermont Supreme Court Justice Louis Peck is challenging a provision in his state's Constitution that requires judges to retire at age 70. William Gray, the attorney for the state, urged three judges of the U.S. 2nd Circuit Court of Appeals to overturn a lower court ruling that struck down the mandatory retirement rule. Gray said the ruling upset the balance of power between state and federal governments by taking away Vermont's right to make decisions about its judiciary. The states of Massachusetts, Connecticut and New Mexico have filed briefs backing Vermont. Massachusetts and Connecticut have mandatory retirement provisions for judges. New Mexico does not, but filed the brief through the Lincoln Legal Foundation on the issue of states' rights. Peck, who continues to sit on Vermont's highest court, filed an age discrimination complaint with the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission in May, five months after he turned 70. His retirement had been scheduled to go into effect June 30. The EEOC picked up Peck's case and filed a complaint in federal court in Vermont, where U.S. District Judge Lee Gagliardi ruled that Peck and other appointed state judges in Vermont could not be forced to retire because of their age. Gagliardi said state judges were protected by the federal Age Discrimination and Employment Act, which prohibits age discrimination against most employees. Gray argued that that act could not be applied in this case because it did not specifically name state judges. He said there had to be a clear Congressional intent to pre-empt a state constitution. That argument found favor with the 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Boston in an earlier ruling on Massachusetts' mandatory retirement provision. The 1st Circuit ruled it could not find ``a sufficiently clear statement by Congress that it intended to overrule the clear intent of the people of a state in an area intimately and fundamentally related to that state's self-governance.'' The 1st Circuit ruling has meant judges in Massachusetts must retire at age 70. EEOC attorney Paul Bogas cited a similar case in Wyoming in which the Supreme Court found that the state's interests were not seriously threatened by the federal age discrimination law. Bogas spent most of his arguments countering another position forwarded by Gray _ that state judges were covered by an exemption to the Age Discrimination and Employment Act for elected officials and policy-making appointees who work for elected officials. ``The constitutional and legal duties of state judges are completely independent from the governor who appoints them,'' Bogas said. He said judges clearly were not policy makers. The appeals court will issue a written ruling at a later date. Peck was not in court for the arguments but two other judges who are fighting similar battles were present. They were Robert Satter, a senior Superior Court Judge from Connecticut, and Justice Isaac Rubin of the Appellate Division of New York's Supreme Court.

DOC.HEAD: Police Say Prosecutor Fabricated Shooting Story
DOC.TEXT: A county prosecutor resigned and checked into a psychiatric hospital Friday after state police determined he had fabricated a story that two men tried to assassinate him on New Year's Day. Camden County Prosecutor Samuel Asbell, who routinely accompanied police on drug busts, may face criminal charges pending the outcome of the investigation and a psychiatric evaluation, Attorney General Peter N. Perretti said. Asbell said Tuesday that gunmen opened fire on him during a high-speed car chase through the streets of Camden, and that he was sprayed with glass from his car windows but not seriously injured. He also said he shot one of his assailants in the head. Asbell said he believed the attack was related to his tough stance on illegal drugs. ``Thank God I'm alive,'' the 46-year-old Asbell had said. ``I guess it just wasn't my day or my time.'' But Perretti said at a news conference Friday that ``the event was staged by Prosecutor Asbell, apparently acting alone.'' Perretti said Asbell was questioned for several hours Thursday night into Friday morning at the state police barracks in Bellmawr, where he was confronted with details of the state police investigation. Police found he had shot out his own car windows. Perretti would not comment on why Asbell might have staged the shooting. Asbell's five-year term as prosecutor had expired, and he was serving as a holdover. It was unclear if he was going to be reappointed by Gov. Thomas Kean or Gov.-elect James Florio, who takes office Jan. 16. Gloucester County Prosecutor Richard Hickey III, said he considered Asbell a close friend and that ``he loved what he was doing. I really feel for his family right now.'' Asbell had said his Lincoln Town Car was ambushed by two men in a green Toyota station wagon about 5 p.m. Monday after he left his office, where he had gone to catch up on paperwork and get his paycheck following a vacation. When the gunmen opened fire, Asbell said, he fired one round from a 12-gauge sawed-off shotgun that he kept in his car and unloaded seven rounds from a semi-automatic handgun. ``I had my shotgun on my lap and I just let go,'' Asbell said Tuesday. ``I saw his head explode.'' Word of the alleged attack sparked increased security at other county prosecutors' offices across the state. Asbell entered the Carrier Foundation in Somerset County for psychiatric evualation, Perretti said, adding that if Asbell decided to check out, authorities could move to have him held involuntarily. The hospital said it would neither conform nor deny Asbell's presence, citing privacy laws. Perretti, who appointed Assistant Attorney General James F. Mulvihil as acting prosecutor, said there is no evidence that Asbell's psychiatric problems affected his work as prosecutor. ``We are very satisfied this is a sudden and aberrational turn of behavior by Prosecutor Asbell,'' Perretti said. Kean said he was shocked by the events of the past week, and added that if Asbell is found mentally incompetent, ``prosecution would not serve any purpose.'' Asbell maintained his story as late as Thursday. ``I have met with the attorney general, and he made it explicitly clear to me that I am a victim ... of a violent crime. He very kindly said I have to get (in) my mind the fact that I am not a prosecutor in this matter, but I am a victim,'' Asbell said at a news conference. Asbell and his family were placed under 24-hour state police protection after he told authorities of the attack. But authorities said they were somewhat confounded by the lack of leads in the case. No body was found, and a victim did not turned up at hospitals. Asbell, while in private practice, was shot in the chest in 1970 while representing a client whose property was put up for sheriff's sale. The bullet remains lodged in his chest.

DOC.HEAD: Rain In The South, Snow In Utah
DOC.TEXT: Heavy snow fell early Friday over parts of Utah, and rain fell over much of the South. During the early morning, 4 to 11 inches of snow fell in the mountains of northern Utah, and there were 3- to 4-inch accumulations in the lower elevations of Utah County. Snow also fell along the southern shore of Lake Superior at midday, and snowshowers were scattered over northeastern and northwestern New York state and southern North Dakota. Rain fell from west-central South Carolina across central and northwestern Georgia, southeastern Tennessee, northern Alabama, northern and central Mississippi, much of Louisiana, southeastern Texas, and the Florida Peninsula. A cold front approached the northern Pacific Coast and gale warnings were posted along the Washington and Oregon coasts, with a high wind warning for Saturday over the Front Range of the Montana Rockies. Rain fell over western Washington state. There were no reports of measurable snowfall during the six hours up to noon and rainfall amounts during the same period were less than an inch, the National Weather Service said. Miami warmed to a record high Friday of 83 degrees. Friday's low for the Lower 48 states was 7 degrees below zero at Gallup, N.M. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 5 at International Falls, Minn., to 85 at Fort Myers, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Engine Found Friday on Cattle Ranch
DOC.TEXT: A 3,500-pound engine that sheared off a Northwest Airlines jet in flight was found Friday at a wooded cattle ranch, officials said. The engine was spotted by a Madison County sheriff's helicopter and the area was secured by deputies as a federal air safety inspector made his way to the site. ``They have been instructed not to do anything with the engine until he gets there,'' said Ted Lopatkiewicz, spokesman for the National Transportation Safety Board in Washington, D.C. The inspection would probably begin Saturday, Lopatkiewicz said. The engine was found on the ranch of a man who reported hearing a loud noise Thursday, said sheriff's dispatcher Fred Register. Deputies were unable to check the tip until late Friday morning because of heavy fog. The engine fell Thursday from the right tailwing of a 14-year-old Boeing 727 on a flight from Miami to Minneapolis with 139 passengers and a crew of six on board. The plane diverted to Tampa and landed safely. Radar showed the engine separating from the plane and investigators believed its six-mile plunge landed it near Madison. Officials believe the engine will provide the best evidence on the cause of the separation. Boeing spokesman Tom Cole in Seattle noted the 727's three engines are each designed to break off if sudden vibrations threaten to tear a plane apart and the plane can continue with two engines or even with one. The incident caused little disturbance to passengers and the aircraft lost only 100 feet of altitude immediately following the engine loss. Before the incident, engines had broken off Boeing jets three times since 1985. In each case, the pilots landed the planes safely and without injuries to passengers. But after the last two incidents, the Federal Aviation Administration ordered emergency inspections of the bolts holding the engines in place.

DOC.HEAD: President Lowers Duties on Polish Imports
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Friday granted Poland more duty-free access to U.S. markets, saying the move will ``open the door for investment, trade and the interaction of two free peoples.'' In a White House ceremony, Bush signed a proclamation which should provide typical savings of between 3 and 10 percent for the producers of Polish exports into the United States. The president's action qualified Poland for concessionary trade rules known as the Generalized System of Preferences, under which duties are lifted on about half of the products on the U.S. tariff schedule. In Poland's case, the benefit would apply to about one-fourth of the goods subject to duties it now sends to the United States. ``This ... means that Polish exports will enjoy the most liberal access possible to the American market,'' Bush said. ``And it will pave the way for increases in Polish exports to the United States _ a vital contribution to Poland's economic recovery.'' ``The past year has been one of outstanding change in Eastern Europe,'' the president said. ``But it was the brave people of Poland, under the banner of Solidarity, that led the way ... Poland has blazed the trail _ the freedom trail.'' Bush addressed a small audience that included Secretary of State James A. Baker III, Trade Ambassador Carla Hills and Poland's ambassador, Jan Kinast. In addition to the new trade concessions, Bush noted, the U.S. government is committed to a three-year economic assistance program to Poland totaling $1 billion and has already contributed $200 million in aid since last spring. The Western alliance has promised more than $8 billion in economic aid to Poland over the three-year period. Poland previously was granted most-favored-nation trading status by the United States, meaning its products qualified for the lower tariffs accorded U.S. allies. The new designation allows many of those same goods to enter the country without paying the tariffs charged developed countries on the most-favored-nation list. The concession does not guarantee sales in the United States, but is designed to provide a savings margin that could prove decisive on the American market and thus spur increased trading activity. About $50 million in Polish goods already enter the United States duty-free. Administration officials said that, by volume, the Polish products likely to benefit the most include tractors and parts, furniture, cutting tools, machine tools, titanium dioxide and copper wire. Duties for those goods now range from 2.2 percent to 7.2 percent. The concession also would benefit several Polish products on which high duties, ranging between 17 percent to 45 percent, now are charged _ vodka and other alcoholic beverages, cork products, Brussels sprouts, preserved vegetables, and clincial thermometers. Based on 1988 trade data, dutiable Polish products worth $73.3 million were imported into the United States in categories for which tariffs now will be lifted. That would amount to a potential savings, based on that year's volume, of $3.5 million. If Poland fully utilized its latest eligibility, its trading volume under the concession would be estimated to rank with that of Turkey, Zaire and Costa Rica.

DOC.HEAD: Obscure Rebel Group Claims Western Ethiopian Town
DOC.TEXT: Fighting has flared in western Ethiopia where an obscure rebel group claims to have killed, captured or wounded more than 1,200 government troops and seized a town along the Sudanese border. The fighting has disrupted a U.N. refugee operation in the region, according to relief officials, and comes at a time when the government is engaged in heavy battles with northern insurgents. The Oromo Liberation Front, a loosely grouped insurgency that draws its strength from the Oromo tribespeople across western, central and southern Ethiopia, claims to have taken the town of Asosa in fighting Tuesday. In a clandestine rebel broadcast monitored in Nairobi, the Oromo rebels said they killed 957 government troops, wounded more than 200 and captured 117. Asosa is ``completely under control and the inhabitants have been totally liberated from foreign oppression,'' said the broadcast. Diplomats and other sources in Ethiopia's capital, Addis Ababa, could not confirm the rebel claims. However, a spokeswoman for the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees said an unknown number of refugees had fled a UNHCR camp about 18 miles from Asosa because of fighting and that the agency had evacuated three employees from the area. The spokeswoman, Meryam Amar, said the agency had been unable to get any details about the fighting or the refugees' flight because the government was refusing to allow anyone to travel to the region. She said there had not been any disturbances in the region prior to Tuesday's fighting., ``It was sudden and brand new for us,'' she said. Asosa, 300 miles west of Addis Ababa, is the field office for four UNHCR camps that house about 385,000 refugees who have fled drought and war in southern Sudan. The camp near Asosa, Tsore, houses 41,219 refugees, a quarter of whom have arrived in the last two months fleeing renewed fighting in Sudan's civil war, said Amar. With the Oromo rebellion, ``the refugees are being caught between the cross-fire for a second time,'' she said. The Oromo rebels, who advocate self-determination for the Oromo people, have been fighting sporadically since the early 1970s. Diplomats say their battles have more resembled tribal warfare than organized dissidence and have tended to flare in patches and pockets in western and central Ethiopia. Sources say the Oromo have been more of an irritant than a threat. However, the recent battle comes at a time when the government is concentrating its attention and troops on fighting with Tigrean rebels who since August have made significant advances from their northern province toward the capital. President Mengistu Haile Mariam's government also is facing food emergencies in Tigre and its northern neighbor, Eritrea, where the United Nations said crop failures threaten as many as 4 million people with starvation.

DOC.HEAD: Sudanese Rebels Claim Major Victory
DOC.TEXT: The rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army claimed Friday it scored a major victory over government troops in Western Equatoria by dispersing an army brigade of more than 3,000 soldiers. An SPLA radio broadcast, monitored in London, said the victory came on Thursday near the border of Uganda and climaxed six days of fighting in south Sudan. It said brigade commander Brig. Gen. Isaiah Paul fled toward Uganda. The rebels now are pursuing the fleeing soldiers and conducting mopping-up operations, it said. No casualties were reported. ``With the destruction of this force, the junta's backbone in Western Equatoria has been effectively destroyed,'' the radio said, referring to the 15-man junta that seized power in Sudan in a military coup June 30. It said the brigade was the same force that entered Uganda on Dec. 29 and overran the northwestern border town of Oraba. The SPLA engaged the brigade at Kirwa, four miles from the Ugandan border, as the government soldiers crossed back into Sudan on Dec. 30, the radio said. It said the brigade had advanced eight miles when it was destroyed by the SPLA. Uganda said on Wednesday its troops retook Oraba last week after three days of occupation by the Sudanese army. The SPLA launched its rebellion in early 1983, demanding greater autonomy and economic reforms in the three southern provinces of Bahr el-Ghazal, Upper Nile and Equatoria.

DOC.HEAD: $1 Million Noriega Reward Likely to Go Unclaimed, Officials Say
DOC.TEXT: The $1 million reward offered by President Bush for information leading to the capture of deposed dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega will apparently go unclaimed, admimistration officials said on Friday. The administration had offered the bounty on Dec. 21, a day after the U.S. invasion of Panama and while Noriega was still at large. Deputy presidential spokesman Roman Popadiuk said that the decision on what to do with the reward remains with the Justice and State Departments, and not the White House. However, he said he believed that the bounty would probably go unclaimed. Rep. William Broomfield, R-Mich., said Friday in a letter to Bush that the papal nuncio in Panama, Monsignor Jose Sebastian Laboa, deserved the reward because he persuaded Noriega to surrender. ``I am sure Monsignor Laboa has many worthy projects that could use some infusions of cash,'' Broomfieldl said. A senior administration official, who briefed reporters at the White House on Thursday on the condition of anonymity, shrugged off a question on whether the Vatican might qualify for the reward. ``I don't know. I'll tell you Monday when the collection plate comes around,'' he said. Administration officials, who asked not to be identified, said the Vatican probably wouldn't qualify for the reward because its role in Noriega's surrender was an indirect one. Noriega was holed up in the Vatican embassy from Christmas Eve until this past Wednesday when he surrendered to U.S. forces. In addition to the as-yet unclaimed $1 million, the administration also has been paying $150 per-weapon to Panamanians who turn in their firearms.

DOC.HEAD: Eisenhower Granddaughter to Wed Soviet Scientist
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to include Sagdeev's ties to Gorbachev. INSERTS 2 grafs after 7th graf pvs `Miss Eisenhower,...' to ADD details of Sagdeev's role and Eisenhower's previous marriages
DOC.TEXT: Susan Eisenhower, granddaughter of President Dwight Eisenhower, said Friday she will marry an adviser to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Roald Z. Sagdeev, a rocket scientist and political reformer. They will be married in a Feb. 9 civil ceremony in Moscow and then will be ``blessed'' at a religious ceremony at the U.S. Embassy there, Sagdeev said in a telephone interview from Washington. Sagdeev, a Volga Tatar, said he has ``no religious assignment;'' Miss Eisenhower is a Protestant. The couple will maintain two homes, living in Washington with Miss Eisenhower's three school-age children during the fall and spring, and spending summers in Moscow, said Sagdeev, 57. He said he has two grown children. They met 2{ years ago, and the romance blossomed while they collaborated on a book about ``survival, how a very thin layer of intellectuals survived through difficult years, through purges,'' before Gorbachev rose to power in 1985, Sagdeev said. The first draft of the book is finished, he said. Miss Eisenhower, 38, was not immediately available for comment on the wedding, which she announced through the Eisenhower World Affairs Institute. She is the daughter of John Eisenhower. Her brother, David, is married to Julie Nixon Eisenhower. The marriage will be Miss Eisenhower's third, said a friend of the family. Her first husband was London barrister, Alexander Bradshaw, with whom she had one daughter. Her second husband was John Mahon, an attorney in Rochester, N.Y., the father of her two youngest daughters. Sagdeev is thought to have Gorbachev's ear on a range of scientific issues, and has said that he offered the Soviet leader advice on Star Wars, which Sagdeev opposes. Sagdeev was elected to the Soviet Congress of People's Deputies last year, and was a political ally of the late Andrei D. Sakharov, even when Sakharov was banished from Moscow for his human rights activities. Soviet and U.S. scientists say Sagdeev quietly supported Sakharov during his exile. Sagdeev said he met Sakharov three decades ago, when both were engaged in secret research, and admired his work on controlled thermonuclear fusion. ``I witnessed his gradual shift toward a broader view of the world and life. He became interested in arms control and then human rights,'' Sagdeev said. ``When he was under strong attack, when every member of (the Soviet Academy of Sciences) was pressed to denounce him in the mid-1970s, I had to ask myself whether I would be drawn into such condemnation or stay independent. It was very important as a moral step in my life, which liberated me from the conformism of that period,'' Sagdeev said. A portion of the planned book will deal with Sakharov, he said. Miss Eisenhower, who has been active in promoting U.S.-Soviet ties, was formerly president of the Eisenhower World Affairs Institute and now heads her own consulting company, the Eisenhower Group Inc., which handles commercial ventures for major U.S. companies dealing with the Soviet Union. She served as co-chairman of the 1986 Chautauqua Conference in the Lativian city of Riga in the Soviet Union, one of the early testing grounds for Gorbachev's policy of glasnost. Sagdeev recently resigned as head of the Soviet Space Research Institute. He criticized the Soviet space program, among other things, for concentrating on a new space shuttle. He continues to work as head of the institute's Theory Division.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer Says Admitted Madam Was Valuable Police Informant
LaserPhoto LA4
DOC.TEXT: A madam who admits furnishing call girls to wealthy clients shouldn't be prosecuted because she helped police track down a terrorist and reported on drug and sex criminals, her lawyer said Friday. Elizabeth Adams claims she and police had an arrangement by which they would ignore her business if she supplied law enforcement with valued information garnered from clients through ``pillow talk.''
