Ms. Adams, 56, has been called the Beverly Hills Madam because many of her clients allegedly booked trysts in posh Beverly Hills hotel suites. Prosecutors claim some of her clients were famous. Defense attorney Anthony P. Brooklier contends prosecutors don't have a case against Ms. Adams, who faces two felony counts of pimping and pandering, since the police department encouraged his client to continue her operation in exchange for inside information. In court documents, Ms. Adams is said to have cooperated in investigations of fugitives including financier Robert Vesco, who was being sought on federal charges. Vesco is the only felon mentioned. A U.S. Senate subcommittee investigating Vesco's activities mentioned that Ms. Adams acted as a police ``agent,'' according to court documents that did not elaborate on her relationship to Vesco. At a pretrial hearing Friday, police Detective Mike Brambles described Ms. Adams as ``extremely reliable.'' He said she supplied him with valuable information, including the identity of an Irish Republican Army terrorist allegedly planning to bomb the British Parliament. The detective also testified that Ms. Adams identified a number of people involved in child molestation and child pornography, and that she gave information on drug dealers, including some the Drug Enforcement Administration classified as top traffickers. Deputy District Attorney Alan Carter, who is pressing for a prison term, asked Brambles to name the IRA terrorist but the witness refused to divulge the name. Ms. Adams, who came from Manila about two decades ago, said she was a mother and a widow until she was approached by an ``English madam'' who offered her a client book.

DOC.HEAD: Horn Chides Eastern Trading Bloc, Defends Botha Visit
With AM-South Africa
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Gyula Horn said Friday that Comecon, the Soviet bloc's version of the European Common Market, is too expensive and must be remodeled. He also defended the visit to Hungary this week of the South African foreign minister, R.F. Botha. ``Comecon is not only unsuitable to meet its tasks, but also costs too much in its present form,'' Horn told a news conference. ``It needs a total overhaul.'' When asked about similar views expressed in a Polish newspaper interview by Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier of Czechoslovakia, he said: ``Hungary agrees that there is a need for radical reform,'' A conference of Comecon, the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance, is scheduled for Tuesday in Sofia, Bulgaria. About the Botha visit, Horn said preparatory talks spanned three months and ``the South African side offered to have the foreign minister pay Hungary a visit on an unofficial basis.'' ``We assessed the changes in South Africa and saw that the dismantling of apartheid has begun,'' he said. ``Our talks with Botha were important. We made clear that we oppose apartheid and that its total end is the precondition to diplomatic recognition.'' ``At the same time, the meeting offered an opportunity to have direct contact with South African political and business circles, and we were also led by the consideration that there are over 10,000 people of Hungarian origin living in South Africa.'' Noting criticism of Hungary by some black African states, Horn said similar circumstances had arisen after the government recognized South Korea and Israel. He said he would visit Israel next week. Horn said Hungary supports a Middle East settlement that guarantees Israel's security while recognizing the right of Palestinians to self-determination and statehood.

DOC.HEAD: Murder Linked to Kidnapping of Younger Brother
DOC.TEXT: A reputed Harlem crack dealer may have been murdered while trying to negotiate the return of his kidnapped 12-year-old brother, whose severed finger accompanied a ransom demand, police sources said Friday. The body of Richard Thomas Porter, 25, was found in the Bronx early Thursday. He had been shot several times, but investigators who found identification and $2,239.78 on the body discounted robbery as a motive. ``There is a possibility that this guy was trying to re-negotiate the return (of his brother) without the police,'' said a source close to the investigation, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Porter, reputedly a mid-level drug dealer who controlled several street dealers in Harlem, had refused to cooperate with police investigating his brother's kidnapping, the sources said. Porter's brother, William, was abducted Dec. 5 on his way school and is still missing, police said. ``There's no indication that we have that this kid was anything more than a schoolboy,'' a source said. The family learned of the abduction later that day when when William called home around 5 p.m. and tearfully told his mother he had been kidnapped. Four hours later, a male caller warned the family not to call police, but made no ransom demand. The following day, the family received a call demanding $500,000. Later the same day, a caller asked to speak with Richard Porter, and told Porter he would settle for $350,000 for the boy's return. At 4 p.m. on Dec. 6, the kidnapper told the family to go to a McDonald's restaurant at 125th Street and Broadway and look under the sink in the men's room. There, a friend of the family found an audio cassette, a two-inch piece of a finger, believed to belong to William, and two of William's rings in a coffee cup, the sources said. ``They cutted my finger off. ... They said if you don't do as they say, they are going to cut my hand off,'' William said on the tape, according to a report published in the Daily News. ``Please help ... I love you, mommy.'' The kidnapper called the family again at 9 p.m. on Dec. 6 and repeated the demand for $350,000. Porter offered the man $200,000, the police sources said. The man did not call back. The family's last contact with the kidnappers was Dec. 10, when a woman handed a ransom note to a child in upper Manhattan and told him to deliver it to William's aunt, who lived nearby. According to the News, the note read: ``We still want the money. The child is in pain and he needs medical attention.'' Police officials refused to comment on the kidnapping case so as not to jeopardize William's safety. The sources said it appeared the kidnapper or kidnappers knew the family. ``They knew the brother, the mother and an aunt,'' a source said. ``It had to be someone who knew about the family.'' The family's telephone number is unlisted. Sixty city detectives were assigned to the abduction case, which also is being investigated by the FBI. Detectives also have been following leads that Porter may have been involved in a turf war over control of the area's lucrative drug trade, and that he may have been having an argument with a relative who was recently released from prison, the sources said.

DOC.HEAD: Cabinet Shake-Up Aims at Boosting Mexican Tourism, Production
DOC.TEXT: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari completed an overhaul of his Cabinet Friday aimed at further developing tourism and boosting agricultural production, two of Mexico's principal money-earners. A surprise announcement Thursday evening said Agriculture Secretary Jorge de la Vega Dominguez was named a special adviser to Salinas and Tourism Secretary Carlos Hank Gonzalez, 63, would take over agriculture. Former Gov. Pedro Joaquin Coldwell, 40, of Quintana Roo state in the Yucatan, was named tourism secretary on Friday. Hank's appointment was hailed by business leaders, who have been fretting that rising food prices and lagging production from Mexico's antiquated farms and ranches was fueling inflation and eroding export income. President Eduardo Garcia Suarez of the National Chamber of Commerce urged Hank to lift existing prices controls and ``pave the way to attract new investments in agriculture so as to raise productivity.'' One major problem, which every government has ducked in the 60 years the Institutional Revolutionary Party has been in power, is the so-called ``ejido'' system, under which entire villages own land that the villagers work in small parcels but by law cannot be sold or merged. The system was revived by the 1910-20 revolution, which called for ``land for everyone who works it.'' Land expropriations and agrarian reform continued until the early 1980s, but now the government says there is no more land to expropriate. Mexico, once a net exporter of agricultural products, has been increasingly relying on purchases of wheat, corn and other foodstuffs abroad to feed its growing population and make up for shortfalls in domestic production. It now spends close to $3 billion a year on these imports. Salinas pledged to modernize Mexico from top to bottom when he was inaugurated Dec. 1, 1988, for a six-year term. Word has circulated around government halls that the agrarian reform and the agriculture departments will soon be merged under Hank. In his one year as tourism secretary, Hank lined up Japanese, Western European and Canadian investors, helped privatize and deregulate the airline industry and laid out plans to build new hotels and resorts in a program to double the number of tourists coming to Mexico by 1994. About 6 million foreign tourists now visiting Mexico annually spend an estimated $3 billion a year. Coldwell, a businessman and former congressman, moved up from being chairman of the National Tourism Fund, a government organization that helps finance development of tourism facilities. He helped turn Cancun off the Yucatan into one of the Caribbean's leading luxury beach resorts.

DOC.HEAD: More Than 720,000 Ethnic Germans Moved to West Germany in 1989
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to CORRECT that nearly half, not most, were East Germans; picks up 4th `The number'
DOC.TEXT: More than 720,000 ethnic Germans resettled in West Germany in 1989, nearly half of them from East Germany, the Interior Ministry said Friday. It was the largest immigration of ethnic Germans to West Germany in the country's 40-year history. The largest group were young, skilled workers fleeing East Germany at the start of the pro-democracy movement last year. The Interior Ministry said 343,854 East Germans arrived in West Germany. In 1988, the number was 39,832. The number of arrivals of ethnic Germans from other Eastern European countries last year was 377,055, the ministry said, compared with 202,673 in 1988. Of this year's emigrants, 250,340 came from Poland, 93,134 from the Soviet Union, and 23,387 from Romania. The remainder came from Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Yugoslavia, the ministry report said. East Germans and ethnic East European Germans resettling in West Germany are automatically granted citizenship. The flood of East Germans to West Germany began last summer after Hungary began dismantling its border barriers with Austria, prompting East Germans to cross from Hungary through Austria to the West. Tens of thousands of East Germans seeking legal passage to West Germany then began crowding West German embassies in Hungary, Poland and Czechoslovakia. The exodus and subsequent pro-democracy rallies drew hundreds of thousands to the streets of major East German cities and forced the opening of the borders.

DOC.HEAD: Attorneys Meet With Noriega, Say No Deals Discussed
LaserPhoto MH4
DOC.TEXT: Defense attorneys met for two hours Friday with deposed Panamanian dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega and later denied reports that a deal was in the works with the U.S. government. As military helicopters circled above the federal courthouse in downtown Miami, defense attorneys Frank Rubino and Steven Kollin met inside with Noriega and discussed legal options. ``His demeanor is fine,'' Rubino said of the 51-year-old Noriega. ``He's cheerful and very relaxed. ... Most of the time we spent discussing the case and its ramifications.'' ``He has no complaints,'' added Kollin. The attorneys declined to discuss the details of their legal discussions, but Kollin said there were no plans to make a deal with the government on the drug trafficking charges faced by Noriega. ``A man who is innocent is not receptive to any plea bargain. General Noriega is not guilty of any of these charges,'' Kollin said. In Washington, President Bush said Friday the government's case is strong and he is also ``not seeking a deal'' on a reduced charge for Noriega. ``We are preparing for trial,'' said Justice Department spokesman David Runkel. He wouldn't rule out any discussion of a deal if Noriega came forward, but stressed, ``There is no indication of anything along those lines.'' The New York Times, citing a senior administration official, reported Friday that ``the government would be prepared to discuss a negotiated settlement if General Noriega provided detailed information about international drug trafficking activities.'' Noriega reportedly spent Thursday night inside the courthouse. Officials have been extraordinarily quiet about security precautions taken in the Noriega case. The Miami Herald quoted government sources as saying Noriega was housed in in a room so secret that the Marshals Service will not confirm its existence: A 10-by-12 room called the ``submarine,'' under the old courthouse. Tunnels connect the old section with the new building, where Noriega faced U.S. District Judge William M. Hoeveler on Thursday in a ninth-floor courtroom. The isolated room has a bed, a television and a toilet, the Herald said. The door is not visible to occupants, who usually are participants under the Federal Witness Protection Program. Noriega, who surrendered to U.S. troops in Panama City on Wednesday night, is charged with taking $4.6 million in bribes from Colombia's Medellin drug cartel to turn his nation into a way station for the cocaine trade. Noriega is also charged on a separate indictment in Tampa for alleged marijuana-smuggling activities. Kollin said Thursday he had heard ``some talk about about moving him to Tampa'' to deal with court proceedings awaiting him there. But later Kollin said he'd found nothing to support the Tampa rumors. ``We don't think they're going to move him in the immediate future,'' Kollin said. ``The marshals are being very nice and cooperative and they have assured us he will be available whenever we want to talk to him.'' Federal officials in Tampa said they knew of no plans to bring Noriega there to deal with the marijuana indictment. No decision will be made regarding the Tampa case until the Miami case is disposed of, said Doug Tillett, spokesman for the Justice Department. Both attorneys also met with the prosecutors and with representatives of the U.S. Marshal's office. In another development, a federal magistrate Friday ordered an alleged Noriega pilot named in the indictment to be held without bond in pretrial detention, despite his attorney's claim that he is not a risk of flight. Michael O'Kane, a Fort Lauderdale attorney representing 36-year-old Daniel Miranda, argued that the charge against Miranda of flying $800,000 in drug proceeds from Fort Lauderdale to Panama in 1983 carried a maximum sentence of only five years. O'Kane said he would appeal the magistrate's ruling to Hoeveler, the trial judge.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Cancels Meetings to Focus on Domestic Woes; Markets Unsettled
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to include British comment; picks up 9th `Soviet Azerbaijanis'
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev put off meetings with foreign guests Friday to concentrate on domestic crises, and news of it unsettled Wall Street and caused a steep decline in the Tokyo stock market. Among the foreign visitors affected was Neil Kinnock, leader of the opposition socialist Labor Party in Britain. A senior Communist Party official said privately Gorbachev was dealing with border riots in Azerbaijan and the breakaway Communist Party of Lithuania. Soviet media did not report the schedule change, but it was felt abroad. The Tokyo Stock Exchange recorded its sharpest drop since Oct. 16, plummeting 438.12 points. Analysts blamed concern about Gorbachev's fate. A slight decline in stock prices on Wall Street and a steep drop on the Hong Kong exchange were attributed to the same cause. ``To Japan, the worst thing that could happen to the world scenario would be for Gorbachev to drop from sight,'' Chris Schreiber, an investment analyst with New Japan Securities, said in Tokyo. The market reactions illustrated how closely the capitalist world links Gorbachev to the success of the reforms and improved East-West relations he has pursued since gaining power in March 1985. In London, Foreign Office minister William Waldegrave said on Channel 4 News: ``It is in our interests that current Soviet foreign policy should be maintained, and we should therefore respond imaginatively and positively to what he is trying to do. ``He is going in the right direction and we want him to survive. He still dominates the political scene. He has shown himself willing to be open to new ideas.'' The party official in Moscow asked about Western news reports that Gorbachev had postponed meetings with Kinnock and other foreign dignitaries, replied: ``It's right. We have many problems right now.'' He mentioned disturbances in Azerbaijan along the Iranian border and the Lithuanian Communist Party's decision to break away from the ruling national party led by Gorbachev. Soviet Azerbaijanis tried over the New Year's holiday to force open the frontier and reunite with their ethnic brethren in Iran, tearing down guard towers and prompting the KGB to reinforce security along the frontier. Fences remain flattened and other barriers out of commission along the border, Soviet TV reported Friday night. Gorbachev is expected to travel to Lithuania next week on a mission from the national party's Central Committee to try to mend the rift with the Lithuanian Communists. They voted two weeks ago to split off from the 20 million-member ruling party and pursue local independence, and Lithuanian party leaders who met with Gorbachev for five hours Thursday said he failed to sway them from their decision. A dissenting faction of Lithuanian Communists who voted to remain loyal to Moscow were on their way to the capital Friday to meet with party leaders, said Eduardas Potashinskas, a Lithuanian TV journalist. Meanwhile, the Estonian Communist Party threw its support to the Lithuanians in the dispute with Moscow, reports said Friday. The Estonian party's Central Committee meeting Thursday set March 23 for a session of its own full congress, which is expected to vote on a similar proposal to split from the Soviet party, Estonian journalist Tarmu Tammerk said. Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov, in a telephone interview, would neither confirm nor deny that Gorbachev was putting aside foreign questions to concentrate on domestic problems. Asked about a report from London that the Soviet ambassador to Britain, Leonid Zamyatin, had told Kinnock that Gorbachev was postponing a Jan. 16 meeting with Kinnock and all other contacts with foreign politicians this month, Gerasimov replied: ``Has this meeting been planned? Let The Associated Press compose its own commentary. For me this is all clear. Let them comment on that as they wish.'' Gorbachev's calendar is rarely made public, and whenever he disappears from the public eye, speculation about his activities and even his health becomes rife. He scoffed at such rumor-mongering this summer at the first session of the Congress of People's Deputies. ``Let's end these rumors,'' he said. ``In four years, I have already died seven times and my family was killed three times.'' Gorbachev, 58, was last seen on state-run TV on Dec. 31 delivering a taped address to the nation. Moscow-based official media did not report on his closed-door meeting Thursday with the Lithuanians. In London, a Labor Party spokesman said Zamyatin had delivered a personal message from Gorbachev to Kinnock, who had been scheduled to visit Moscow for talks with the Soviet leader. The message said the meeting had to be postponed because ``political events in the Soviet Union'' required Gorbachev's ``personal attention and participation,'' and that he was ``postponing contact with foreign politicians scheduled for January.''

DOC.HEAD: 10 Palestinians Wounded, Activist Barred from Traveling Abroad
DOC.TEXT: Israeli troops shot and wounded 10 Palestinians in stone-throwing clashes in the occupied lands Friday as authorities barred a leading pro-PLO activist from traveling abroad. The three-month travel ban against Feisal Husseini was issued by Interior Minister Arye Deri late Thursday, Israel radio and Arab reports said. In the document, dated Jan. 3, Deri wrote that he decided on the step because he was convinced Husseini's departure abroad ``may harm the security of the state,'' the Israeli news agency Itim said. The ban followed the Dec. 6 restriction barring Husseini from entering the occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip for six months. Husseini, who lives in the Israeli-annexed East Jerusalem, has been named in court documents as a leader of the two-year-old Palestinian uprising. He could not be reached for comment Friday. However, in an interview published Friday in East Jerusalem's Arabic-language daily Al-Fajr, Husseini said in response to the ban that ``instead of tackling the issue of peace, Israel is behaving to contradict the peaceful efforts.'' ``The problem is not what countries Feisal Husseini can go to, it is the degree of Israel's readiness for peace,'' he said. In stone-throwing clashes in six villages and refugee camps in the occupied territories, meanwhile, Israeli troops shot and wounded 10 Palestinians, Arab hospital officials said. The army confirmed two wounded. At least 642 Palestinians have died in the revolt, and 43 Israelis have been slain by Palestinians, who have also murdered 166 of their fellow Arabs for being suspected collaborators.

DOC.HEAD: Neighbors Shocked After Five Bodies Found Under Barn
With AM-Buried Bodies, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Doris Straka has cared for the chickens, ducks, rabbits and cats abandoned by her former neighbor, a religious cult leader, since he and his wife disappeared from their farmhouse in April. She was stunned to learn that Jeffrey Lundgren may have left something else behind: buried bodies. ``Oh, gracious, it's unreal,'' said Ms. Straka, 44, who lives across the street from the farmhouse rented by Lundgren in this town of 6,000 people in northeast Ohio, about 30 miles east of Cleveland. ``Yesterday I was numb.'' Authorities, acting on a tip from an anonymous informer, discovered the bodies of five family members in a mass grave on the property. Lundgren, 39, his wife Alice, 38, and 11 other people assumed to be members of his religious commune have been charged with murder or conspiracy. ``It's terrible. This is a small town, and it affects everyone. There's a real mixture of people out here, and that's what makes it a nice community,'' said Jim Zarobila, owner of Cinema Transit Video in Kirtland. Lundgren and his wife are still being sought, said George Rodriguez of the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms in Kansas City, Mo. Seven others have been arrested. Rodriguez said the five dead were identified tentatively as Dennis Avery, 49; his wife, Cheryl, 42; and their three daughters, Trina, 13; Rebecca, 9; and Karen, 5. Glen Blabolil, assistant to the superintendent of Kirtland schools, said a Lake County crisis intervention team has been assembled to help students cope with the news. ``There are a few students upset. But they only knew the Averys a few years. They kind of kept to themselves,'' he said. Rodriguez said the Averys were members of a splinter religious group led by Lundgren, a former lay minister of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, which is based in Independence, Mo. The Cleveland Plain Dealer, quoting unidentified police sources, said the five may have been killed as part of a religious sacrifice. Dale Luffman, president of the northeast Ohio chapter of the church, said he believed the killings may have resulted from a dispute over money, sex or fear that the Averys wanted to leave the cult and would notify authorities about it.

DOC.HEAD: Peru Violence Worsens, Claimed Average of 9 Lives a Day in 1989
DOC.TEXT: An average of nine people died every day in 1989, most of them civilians caught up in Peru's political violence, in the worst year of the 10-year-old guerrilla war, according to a report Friday. The report by a Senate human rights commission put last year's death toll from politically inspired violence at 3,198, a steep rise from the 1988 figure of 1,986. ``Peru is definitely a sick country,'' said Sen. Enrique Bernales, chairman of the commission, whose reports are considered one of the most reliable sources of information on Peru's civil unrest. Shining Path rebels have been fighting to topple Peruvian governments since 1980. Other anti-government groups include the pro-Cuban Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement and the Rodrigo Franco Command, a paramilitary death squad believed linked to radicals in the governing, center-left Aprista party. Bernales said 1989 was costliest year since the violence began. He estimated damage to the country last year at $3.2 billion, including a half-billion dollars because of attacks on Peru's hydroelectric power grid. Economic damage to the country since 1980 were put at more than $15 billion. The report said of the 3,198 deaths last year, 1,251 were rebels, 348 were members of security forces, 149 were drug traffickers, and 1,450 were civilians. Among the civilian deaths were 52 mayors killed by rebel groups. At a press conference at which he presented the report, Bernales displayed a map of Peru showing areas where guerrilla groups operate. He said the Shining Path had spread its influence in 1989, but that the Tupac Amaru's area of operations had shrunk. However, he said this was the first year the commission had recorded deaths by unidentified terrorist groups _ 153. ``Either Peru resolves to end this violence problem or it will become another Lebanon,'' Bernales said.

DOC.SECOND: ups on the date of the general
DOC.TEXT: elections, the economy and engaging the new political parties in the decision-making process. Koeszeg said they also had documents allegedly concerning other opposition groups and that he had already been in touch with Jozsef Antall, the head of the Hungarian Democratic Forum. The Free Democrats and FIDESZ said they had requested the state prosecutor's office began an investigation and criminal proceedings against ``persons unknown'' for violating the constitution and the penal code. Premier Miklos Nemeth later urged prosecutors to investigate the charges. Through the state news agency MTI, Nemeth issued a statement condemning ``all illegal activities, including the methods formerly employed by the state security organization.'' Hungary's security organs regularly monitored dissident activities during four decades of Communist rule but the reforms in Hungary and throughout the East bloc since last year have caused many of those operations to cease. Earlier, the Free Democrats and FIDESZ had demanded in an open letter to Nemeth that Interior Minister Istvan Horvath resign and two top security officials be suspended. One of the officials whose suspension was demanded, Deputy Interior Minister Ferenc Pallagi, who is in charge of the state security said in an interview with a Budapest daily last November that his department was ``not concerned with the legitimate alternative organizations.'' The letter called on the premier to ``make public what organizations and which people were privy to the information (and to) ... impound immediately all such documents.'' Nemeth's statement said the government was drafting legislation to redefine the state security networks' duties.

DOC.HEAD: Veteran Republican McClure Retiring From Senate
DOC.TEXT: Senate Republican James McClure of Idaho, a critic of gun control and federal efforts to bar development of western lands, announced Friday he will retire when his third term ends next year. ``I would rather leave than have people ask me to,'' the 65-year-old conservative joked at a news conference. He was considered all but unbeatable if he had gone for a fourth term. McClure said, however, he would not run for reelection in 1990. His term expires in 1991. McClure is top Republican on the Interior and Natural Resources Committee and is a member of the Appropriations Committee. He was elected to three terms in the House before moving to the Senate in 1972. He and Rep. Harold Volkmer, D-Mo., were chief sponsors of a measure that became law in 1986 that substantially eased federal gun control laws. He also fought a number of battles with advocates of barring development of wilderness areas. The announcement was expected to touch off an intense round of Idaho politicking. Rep. Larry Craig, R-Idaho, was believed set to announce for the Senate nomination next week and Republican Attorney General Jim Jones also indicated he planned to enter the race. Democratic Rep. Richard Stallings said he was considering the possibility. On Capitol Hill, a Democratic spokeswoman said McClure's retirement makes the Idaho Senate race this year competitive for Democrats. ``The Republicans are now defending three open seats; three more than we are,'' said Anita Dunn, spokeswoman for the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee. She noted that Sens. Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H., and William Armstrong, R-Colo., also have decided not to seek reelection. ``Now Repupblicans will be spending time, attention and money in a state where they had intended to spend none,'' she said. After initially winning his seat, McClure was re-elected twice with only token opposition.

DOC.HEAD: Settlement Near in Dispute Over Home for Mentally Retarded Adults
DOC.TEXT: A proposed group home for mentally retarded adults that prompted discrimination lawsuits against this Chicago suburb will likely be given the go-ahead, officials said. The Justice Department and the developer sued, charging the city disciminated when turning down a permit request for the home. The developer, Residential Facilities Management Services, and the suburb are ``close to a settlement'' that will resolve the case and allow construction of the home, City Attorney James Creswell said. Attorneys for the two sides expect to submit a written agreement Jan. 16, they told U.S. District Judge William Hart on Thursday. ``Our hope is we may have reached some accommodation by next week,'' said attorney Richard Friedman for the developer in Galesburg, in western Illinois. The Justice Department filed a lawsuit against the city June 20, seeking an injunction to allow the project to proceed. It was the first case brought by the government under the Fair Housing Amendments Act, enacted March 12 to bar housing discrimination against the handicapped. The developer filed its own federal lawsuit June 21. Cresswell, who is not directly involved in the negotiations, said Thursday he did not know whether the home would be built on the original site in a residential neighborhood in this community of about 32,000 people. But Friedman said there are no other residential sites available that are large enough for the home. Company officials said they face a June 30 deadline for exercising their option to buy the property. Creswell and Mayor Charles Panici were not in their offices Friday afternoon and could not be reached for comment on the proposed settlement. City Council last May denied a special-use permit for the home, which is to house 15 mentally retarded adults. An attorney representing the city later said the permit was denied because the developer's application was deficient. Group homes for the handicapped, usually established in residential neighborhoods, are designed to encourage independence. Residents live under supervision, but are given greater responsibility for everyday decisions. The lawsuits contend the council denied the permit because of opposition from residents based on fear and prejudice against the mentally retarded. The mayor's office, in a release last June, noted there are two day-care and special-education centers for the developmentally disabled in the city. ``The record of the City of Chicago Heights and its citizens in the area of assisting the mentally handicapped is outstanding,'' the release said.``We are not an insensitive community, unfeeling and uncaring when it comes to those less fortunate than we.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Free Parliamentary Elections by June
DOC.TEXT: The Communists and the country's sanctioned opposition groups decided at round-table talks Friday that free elections should be held by June, the state news agency CTK said. Civic Forum, the umbrella opposition group now governing in coalition with the Communists and other official parties, has been pressing for June elections to the 350-member parliament, which remains dominated by the Communists despite reforms that resulted in the ascension of Vaclav Havel to the presidency. Havel, a banned playwright, had been jailed for five years by the Communists before the reforms that have changed Eastern Europe since last year propelled him to the leadership of Czechoslovakia. Some Communist leaders also have talked of elections in the first half of 1990, but Friday's action appeared to mark the first time a time has been set at the round table, a forum used to create the coalition government and decide political events after President Gustav Husak stepped down Dec. 10. The Communists, opposition and permitted official parties such as the Socialists attended the round table, which is to meet next on Jan. 11, CTK said. In a brief statement after the talks, CTK said participants had discussed a draft constitutional law on recalling and electing parliamentary deputies, and reviewed first drafts of a law on staging free elections. It was decided ``that elections to the highest legislative bodies should take place still in the first half of 199O,'' CTK added. No specific date was given. ``Elections to local representative bodies should take place later, after the necessary political climate in the society is created,'' CTK said without elaborating. While the opposition and other political parties no longer subservient to the Communists are in government on the federal level, there have not yet been significant leadership changes on local levels in Czechoslovakia, one of several East bloc countries undergoing political and economic reforms. Last Dec. 10, a government controlled by non-Communists took power for the first time in 41 years. The next day, Army units began pulling down the Iron Curtain border with neutral Austria.

DOC.HEAD: Black Leaders Denounce Police, Media in Shooting Investigation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `On Friday, ..., to restore first reference to Mayor Raymond L. Flynn.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Stuart Shooting, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the black community Friday harshly criticized the investigation of a white couple's shootings in an inner-city neighborhood, saying police were too willing to believe a black man was to blame. They accused police and the media of giving less attention to black crime victims and charged police abused residents of the Misson Hill neighborhood where Charles and Carol Stuart were found shot in their car last October. Stuart told police a black assailant fired the shots, killing his pregnant wife and critically wounding him. Stuart committed suicide Thursday after his brother implicated him in the shootings. ``People wanted to believe that African-Americans and the African-American community are mad-dog killers and this is not true,'' said Rep. Gloria Fox, who spoke at the first of two news conferences held Friday by community leaders. At the second meeting, the Rev. Grayland Ellis-Hagler said police have a ``lynch mob mentality'' toward black suspects. ``We can not forget a police department and a commissioner who so readily used Gestapo tactics against the black community,'' he said. On Friday, Mayor Raymond L. Flynn reiterated that he regretted the negative publicity surrounding the Stuart incident and that, ``believe it or not I'm sad for the city of Boston.'' No one was ever charged in the Stuart case but a black man held on an unrelated charge had been repeatedly mentioned in news accounts as the likely suspect. Police cleared him in the case on Thursday. Sadiki Kambon, director of the Black Community Information Center in the Roxbury neighborhood, said the man was jailed ``because of his skin color and the Boston police's need for a victim to satisfy the hunger of white racism in Boston and America.'' Asked later to comment on the allegation, police spokeman Scott Gillis said the police commissioner had no immediate comment Friday. Paul Leary, Suffolk County assistant district attorney, denied police ignored evidence implicating Stuart, saying ``there was no corrobative evidence or any forensic evidence or anything at that time that would have led the police to believe that his story was other than what he had stated it to be.'' Kambon also complained of allegedly abusive behavior by police in searches of black residents during the investigation. He said police must learn to ``respect us as human beings. If I'm walking down the street with my daughter, don't come up to me and ask me who I am.'' At Mohammad's Mosque, black politicians and religious leaders delivered impassioned speeches, punctuated by frequent applause and shouts from the audience of about 60 people. The Rev. Don Muhammad, a minister at the church, said he rejected any apologies from city officials. ``An apology is nothing. That's like stabbing me in the back, pulling the knife out and saying you're sorry,'' he said over a wave of applause. Pastor Mickarl Thomas compared the situation in Boston with the racial tensions in Alabama during the civil rights era. ``Thirty-five years ago my people were walking the streets of Montgomery, Alabama. Today in Boston we're not much better as we go into the next decade,'' he said. ``When black men are afraid to put on their jogging suits and go out and jog because they might be arrested or accused, something is wrong.''

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Political Prisoners Leave Vietnam for New Lives in U.S.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with official Washington reaction. Picks up 3rd, `Nearly 2,000 ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BK4
DOC.TEXT: The first Vietnamese allowed to resettle in the United States after paying for helping the Americans in the Vietnam War with years in Communist ``re-education'' camps stopped here Friday en route to their new lives. Three chartered jets brought the first 156 former camp inmates and their families to Bangkok from Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon, on Friday and 151 more were expected Saturday. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher expressed pleasure on hearing the news in Washington and said the administration hopes at least 7,000 former detainees and their kin will be resettled in the United States by Sept. 30. Nearly 2,000 Vietnamese, including family members, are scheduled to leave their homeland by March, said Richard Kocher, head of the Thailand office of the International Organization For Migration. His agency handles medical processing and transportation of the refugees. ``I have come to the free world,'' said former army officer Nguyen Thuong Hiep after arriving at Bangkok airport with his wife and two children. ``Everyone loves their country, but our country suffers, as you know. We do wish to come back sometime.'' The two young daughters of another former officer wore white lace dresses and red hair ribbons in celebration. ``I cannot say how happy I am after all these years,'' said Nguyen Cao Son, who taught at a military academy. He spent three years in a re-education camp, then three years in jail for trying to flee the country by boat. Hundreds of thousands of Vietnamese were subjected for years to a spartan regimen of manual labor and political study for serving the U.S.-backed government of South Vietnam, which fell in April 1975. A U.S. source in Bangkok has said Washington believes about 100,000 former camp inmates are among the 600,000 Vietnamese who have applied to emigrate to the United States. He said the Vietnamese government estimates former inmates and their families total 550,000 people. Vietnam has freed hundreds of the prisoners in recent years, and Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach had said in June only about 120 people remained interned. An agreement on resettling former camp inmates was reached in July. The U.S. negotiator, senior State Department official Robert L. Funseth, said at the time it would help heal ``the last big wound remaining from the war.'' Many of those who arrived Friday will join relatives in California and other parts of the United States after a few days in a Thai immigration facility. Nguyen Van So has been trying to join his sister in Oklahoma since he was freed in 1981 after six years years of confinement. He said conditions in the camps were ``very, very bad. It was hard labor.'' Ho Van Phuoc, a helicopter pilot who flew hundreds of missions during the war, said he saw about 25 people shot for trying to flee a re-education camp and many others died of disease. Some family members of the former inmates were not as happy to leave home. ``It is very sad to be separated,'' said Nguyen Hoang Bich Van, 18, who left her boyfriend behind. The refugees said people in Vietnam were following the pro-democracy movements in Eastern Europe closely and hoped the revolution would come to their own country. ``I hope the government will be good enough to understand the situation and open the society,'' said Nguyen Cao Son. ``We don't want a situation like that in Romania to happen in Vietnam.'' Nicolae Ceausescu, the Communist dictator of Romania, was overthrown and executed last month after a bloody uprising. Hundreds of thousands of Vietnamese have been resettled in the United States since the war. The two nations do not have diplomatic relations and political problems hindered progress on emigration of the former inmates, but major progress on humanitarian issues has been made in recent years.

DOC.HEAD: `Beauty and the Beast' Canceled by CBS
DOC.TEXT: CBS has canceled its low-rated ``Beauty and the Beast,'' with the show's last broadcast set for Jan. 24, the network announced Friday. Craig Hoffman, a spokesman for the network, said the action-comedy series ``Grand Slam'' will replace ``Beauty and the Beast.'' ``Beauty and the Beast,'' a combination crime-fighting romance series set in the underground chambers of New York City, first came to the network in the 1987-88 television season. The show originally starred Ron Perlman and Linda Hamilton. ``Beauty and the Beast'' was not on CBS' fall schedule this year, but made periodic appearances as a mid-season replacement. The character played by Ms. Hamilton was killed off earlier this season.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Aide Linked to Noriega Surfaces on Israeli TV
With AM-Panama
DOC.TEXT: The man identified by U.S. officials as a top aide to deposed Panamanian leader Manuel Noriega, appeared on Israeli television Friday night to deny he had served as security adviser to the dictator. Mike Harari, a former Israeli spymaster, also denied he had been detained by U.S. troops in Panama during the American invasion. Some U.S. officials reported Dec. 28 that Harari had been arrested in Panama by American troops, and a U.S. diplomat in Panama described Harari as a close adviser to Noriega and an instructor to Panama's defense forces, which Noriega headed. The reports of Harari's arrest later proved to be incorrect. ``As you can see, I'm here. I did not arrive (disguised) as a blonde girl and did not come in a suitcase. My name is Mike Harari, Michael Harari,'' he said in a taped interview recorded in an Israel Television studio and broadcast Friday night. The television did not say when the interview was filmed, but it first reported that Harari was in the country on Dec. 30. It was an extremely rare appearance by Harari and the first since the Dec. 20 invasion of Panama by U.S. troops. ``I was not hiding and was not imprisoned by the Americans on any occasion. I was in Panama when the war started and I avoided it without any help, by my own means ... and, as you can see, I'm here, in my country, at home, among my family and friends,'' Harari said. He spoke of Israeli media reports that said the Israeli embassy in Panama helped arrange his escape: ``Even before I came to Israel, on the way, I saw all the system of disinformation about me: that I was detained, that there were talks about me, that I was being transferred and released,'' Harari said. Besides U.S. officials, foreign and Israeli media reports have widely identified Harari as Noriega's personal security chief. Israeli reports said he had considerable influence in Panama and was once appointed by Noriega as Panama's honorary consul in Israel. But Harari insisted this was ``only disinformation that proves what has happened in the last three years. ``What haven't they said about me? ... In which way haven't they smeared me? They said I was Noriega's adviser.'' ``I want to tell you: I'm not Noriega's adviser and have not been in the past. I'm not No. 1 or No. 2. Noriega is not my partner. I have not been in charge of his business affairs, I have not been in charge or instructed his forces, I have not organized his personal security. I'm just a private man who deals in trade,'' Harari stated. Harari's exploits have been widely described in newspapers and books. According to the daily Yediot Ahronot, Harari, 62, was chief of operations at Israel's Mossad secret agency when he headed the unit trying to kill the leader of the Palestinian Black September group that massacred 11 Israeli athletes at the 1972 Munich Olympics. The case is also described in the book ``The Quest for the Red Prince'' by Israeli authors Michael Bar-Zohar and Eitan Haber. In the book, the team leader is referred to as ``Mike.'' According to the accounts, the Israeli squad traced a man they believed was Ali Hassan Salameh, alias the Red Prince, to the resort of Lillehammer, Norway. The suspect was killed May 23, 1973, but turned out to be a Moroccan-born waiter living in Lillehammer with his Norwegian wife. Six of the Israeli agents involved in the mission were arrested by Norwegian police to further Mossad embarrassment. Salameh was killed in a Beirut car bomb blast on Jan. 22, 1979, believed to be organized by Israeli agents. According to Israeli newspaper reports, Harari helped Noriega recruit Israeli mercenaries as his personal bodyguards the last year.

DOC.HEAD: European Finance Chiefs Readjust Value of Italian Lira
DOC.TEXT: Finance chiefs late Friday lowered the value of the Italian lira in the European Monetary System but left untouched the currencies of other nations in the exchange arrangement. It was the first realignment of any currency in the system in nearly three years. Analysts had widely predicted the finance officials would bump up the value of the German mark, which has been gaining increasing strength in recent weeks against other European currencies and the U.S. dollar. The move to readjust the lira was unlikely to have any effect on the dollar. In a statement, the European Community announced the Italian government agreed to narrow the band in which the lira is allowed to fluctuate in the exchange rate mechanism of the European Monetary System. The arrangement seeks to prevent wide fluctuations in exchange rates. The currencies of nine of the 12 nations of the European Community trading bloc are linked in the exchange rate mechanism. Only the currencies of Britain, Portugal and Greece remain outside. The Italian government decided to reduce the lira's range from 6 percent to 2.25 percent, which means the currency will be able to move up or down by that much from a central rate. All the other currencies except the Spanish peseta have a 2.25 percent band. The peseta trades in the 6 percent range. Once the Italian authorities agreed on the narrower band, the other finance officials set the new central rate for the lira at 1,529.7 to the European currency unit, an accounting unit created by the community. The lira's midpoint had been 1,483.58. The new rates will begin Monday. Because the United States is not part of the European Monetary System, or EMS, the dollar's value is not directly affected by the shift. A senior European monetary official, who demanded anonymity, predicted the currency shift would be remembered as ``one of the smoothest'' in the history of the 10-year-old monetary system. He said telephone discussions among the finance officials began Friday afternoon and ended nine hours later. The finance officials also welcomed the change as a sign community nations were getting ready for the first phase of their campaign for an economic and monetary union. The initial phase, which will go into effect on July 1, calls for closer cooperation on economic and monetary policies. They urged Italy to work harder to pare its federal budget deficit. ``This will also foster greater economic convergence in the community,'' they said. As word spread that the monetary officials were working on a realignment, analysts expected they would rejigger the value of most of the currencies, lowering many of them but lifting the German mark. German authorities have been pressing for a realignment to bolster their currency's value but French officials have opposed any move to clip the franc. The value of the mark has soared with the opening of borders between East and West Germany and the economic reforms in other Eastern European countries. Expectations are high that Germany will take advantage of the openings in the East and strengthen its already powerful economy. Before the community's announcement, Earl Johnson, a vice president at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago, said a change in only the lira would increase pressure to realign the other currencies. Zlatko Glamuzina, chief dealer at Banco di Sicilia in New York, said the EMS needed ``fine-tuning'' from time to time.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Says Charges Will Be Filed In Governor's Mansion Investigation
DOC.TEXT: Three juveniles and one adult will be charged in connection with an alleged rape at the South Dakota governor's mansion, a prosecutor said. Gov. George Mickelson and his wife, Linda, were out of town on the date of the alleged rape on Nov. 28. The whereabouts of their 17-year-oldson David, who also lives at the mansion, have not been disclosed. A source close to the investigation has said a small group of high school students, including David Mickelson, had a drinking party at the governor's mansion on the night of the incident. Yankton County State's Attorney Craig Kennedy, hired as special prosecutor in the case, would not say Thursday what charges will be brought against the juveniles. State law makes all juvenile court matters confidential, he said. The adult, who must be at least 18, will be charged with underage consumption of alcohol, Kennedy said. ``I expect that would happen the first part of next week,'' he said. The legal drinking age in South Dakota is 21. Police received a report Nov. 30 saying four boys at the governor's home in Pierre raped a girl who was later identified as a 16-year-old Fort Pierre high school student. The governor has said the charges are unfounded, but he has refused to make any detailed public comment about the incident. Kennedy said he has had no contact with the governor about the investigation. ``I've never talked to the governor about this,'' Kennedy said. ``He's never tried to contact me about it.''

DOC.HEAD: Paroled Killer Charged in Rochester Serial Slayings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT to killer sted murderer; conviction was for manslaughter; SUBS 5th graf, `Authorities had ..., to ADD date of latest disappearance.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos ROC1, ROC2
DOC.TEXT: A paroled killer charged in the slayings of eight women was ordered held without bail Friday and authorities say they have linked the man to a total of 11 killings over the last two years. The break in the serial slayings was ``just a matter of luck,'' said one of the police officers who spotted the suspect's car from a helicopter. After his arrest, Arthur Shawcross, 44, of Rochester made statements about the slayings and told police where to find three bodies, said Police Chief Gordon F. Urlacher, who refused to say if the suspect confessed. A state police source, who spoke on condition on anonymity, said Shawcross had confessed to 11 slayings. Authorities had been investigating the deaths and disappearances of 16 women in the Rochester area since March 1988 and as recently as Dec. 26. Urlacher and Monroe County District Attorney Howard R. Relin said five of the slayings are not related to the others. ``The number that we believe that he's responsible for was 11,'' Urlacher said. ``We've said all along that we don't believe all these cases were related, and that's the way it turned out.'' Most of the women Shawcross is accused of killing were involved in prostitution and drugs, police said. ``He went to them posing as a `john' (customer), was able to get them in the car, then took control of them _ took them to various locations, wherever it might have been,'' State Police Superintendent Thomas Constantine said in Albany. ``In most cases, the death was strangulation.'' Constantine also said some victims were mutilated. Shawcross pleaded innocent to eight counts of second-degree murder in Rochester City Court on Friday. Judge John Manning Regan ordered him held without bail. A preliminary hearing was scheduled for Wednesday. Shawcross was also charged with one count of patronizing a prostitute. In addition to the eight cases in which charges were filed, the district attorney said evidence linking Shawcross to three other deaths will be presented to grand juries in Monroe and neighboring Wayne counties. Relin said Shawcross moved to Rochester in 1987, when he was paroled from prison. He had serving 15 years for the 1972 strangling of 8-year-old Karen Ann Hill of Rochester while she was visiting Watertown, 150 miles to the northeast. Police said the break in the serial slayings came Wednesday while officers in a helicopter were searching a park 12 miles east of Rochester where clothing of a missing woman had been found. The officers spotted Shawcross' car, then the body of another missing woman. ``It was kind of like (we saw) the vehicle first, and then the second time around we both saw the body,'' said state police Sgt. Ken R. Hundt, a helicopter pilot. ``As far as I'm concerned, it was just a matter of luck.'' ``The two pilots and the investigator may have been flying that plane, but the hand of God was also at the controls,'' said Deputy Rochester Police Chief Terrence Rickard. Police on the ground followed Shawcross to a nursing home. He was questioned there Wednesday and taken into custody Thursday, said state police Maj. Salvatore F. Valvo. Police refused to say why Shawcross was at the home. ``The person derives some type of satisfaction from the murder and it's very possible that they go back and look at the results,'' Constantine said. Two of the bodies whose location Shawcross revealed were found Thursday night and the third was found Friday as Shawcross was being arraigned. The third was that of a 22-year-old missing since Nov. 6. Police refused to comment on an motive for the slayings. ``It's very difficult to get inside the head of a person like this,'' Urlacher said. Shawcross had appeared to be adapting well to life outside prison, said Edward Elwin, executive director of the state Division of Parole. Shawcross worked as as a salad-maker at a restaurant, Elwin said. ``Superficially, he was making a good adjustment,'' Elwin said. Shawcross had tried to settle elsewhere in New York state but was moved by parole officials from both places because of complaints of local residents. According to state records, Shawcross, a Watertown native, was imprisoned from 1969 to 1971 for a burglary conviction, and was married three times. He earned a high school equivalency degree while serving time on the manslaughter conviction, prison records showed. Shawcross was charged in the slayings of: Darlene Trippi, 32; Felicia Stephens, 20; June Stotts, 29; Frances Brown, 22; Patricia Ives, 25; Anne Marie Steffen, 27; Dorothy Blackburn, 27; and Dorothy Keller. Clem Brown of Rochester, grandfather of Frances Brown, said Shawcross should be put to death for the slayings. ``What the hell did they let him out for if he does that?'' Brown told the Syracuse Herald-Journal. ``If he killed kids, he sure as hell would do it to someone else.''

DOC.NOTE: EDs: Edits throughout to fix typos; subs next to last graf to CORRECT spelling of disbursed ...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Friday released $184.6 million in disaster aid to help with recovery from the California earthquake in October and Hurricane Hugo in September. The White House said in a statement the money would be used for school reconstruction, debris removal, transfer of patients to Veterans Administration hospitals from damaged facilities and repairing federal parks, forests, wildlife refuges and medical facilities. It also will be used for forest fire prevention and stabilization of historic properties. The Education Department will distribute $62.8 million for school reconstruction and related costs in the Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico, South Carolina and North Carolina, the White House said. It said the Veterans Affairs Department will distribute $56.8 million for construction and repair of its facilities as well as transfer of patients. The money comes from a congressionally approved package that Bush signed Oct. 26, allocating a total of $2.85 billion in disaster relief for regions that suffered from Hurricane Hugo and the Northern California quake. Of that money, Bush was left $250 million to spend as he saw fit on unanticipated needs from both disasters. He already has disbursed $20 million for earthquake preparedness planning by the Federal Emergency Managment Administration and other agencies. After distribution of the funds announced Friday, Bush will have $45.5 million left in the fund for unanticipated needs.

DOC.HEAD: Yale Team Wins World Debate Championship
Laserphotos LON1 and LON2
DOC.TEXT: Yale University has defeated three Australian colleges to win the World Student Debating Championships. History student John Wertheim and political science major Matt Wolf, both 21, from the New Haven, Conn., university, won the finals Thursday night in a debate on East-West relations. Their prize, a silver Scottish drinking cup from the contest sponsors, brewing group Guinness PLC, was presented by Queen Elizabeth II's daughter Anne, the Princess Royal, at Glasgow University. Wertheim and Wolf beat other finalists from Sydney University; Ormond College, Melbourne; and the Australia National University, Canberra. The London School of Economics' team reached the semifinals, and Scotland's Aberdeen University reached the quarterfinals.

DOC.HEAD: Commission Says Oil-Transport System Needs Overhaul to Prevent Spill
DOC.TEXT: A state commission on the Exxon Valdez oil spill called Friday for an overhaul of the nation's oil-transportation system, and blamed the disaster partly on the Coast Guard's ``unduly friendly relationship with industry.'' The commission's report also blames the nation's worst oil spill on a reckless rush to profits by the oil industry, and criticizes government agencies and the public for not insisting on stringent environmental safeguards. Better monitoring of tanker traffic, increased use of double-hull tankers, larger tanker crews and a stronger commitment by industry and government to environmental protection are among the report's recommendations. ``Obviously, the present system _ providing minimum penalites for creating massive environmental damage _ has not deterred the industry from putting the coasts and oceans of the world at constant hazard,'' it says. The preliminary report by the Alaska Oil Spill Commission makes 59 recommendations that the state and federal governments and oil industry can adopt to prevent oil spills and improve their spill response. The report is especially critical of the Coast Guard for its ``confusion of mission and an unduly friendly relationship with industry.'' ``The Coast Guard has failed the American people in providing oversight of the country's oil-transportation system,'' the report says. ``Enforcement must be strengthened and the penalty structure raised.'' The report blames the Coast Guard's lax safety enforcement and reduced state oversight on ``the national mood under President Reagan'' toward less government regulation. ``Safety does not do well in a laissez-faire environment,'' it says. Lt. Ray Massey, a Coast Guard spokesman in Juneau, said the agency had not received a copy of the report and would have no comment. Les Rogers, a spokesman for Exxon Co. USA in Houston also declined to comment. The Alaska Legislature formed the investigatory commission in the weeks after the Exxon Valdez spill last spring, in which nearly 11 million gallons of Alaska crude gushed into Prince William Sound. Its seven members were appointed by Gov. Steve Cowper. ``This disaster could have been prevented, not by tanker captains and crews who are only fallible human beings, but by an advanced oil-transportation system designed to minimize human error,'' commission chairman Walt Parker said in the report's foreward. The captain of the tanker, Joseph Hazelwood, was fired amid charges he had been drunk at the time of the accident. His trial is scheduled to begin Jan. 22. Parker was on a task force that helped set tanker standards for the Port Valdez trade in the late 1970s. He said that when tankers began moving oil from the trans-Alaska pipeline at Valdez in 1977, a good system to prevent spills was in place. But the system fell apart because of legal action by the oil industry that pre-empted the state from enforcing many of its rules. ``The shippers simply stopped following the rules, and the Coast Guard stopped enforcing them,'' Parker said. Tankers originally were to remain inside tanker lanes at all times in the sound, and slow down to minimum speed when ice was present, he said. The Exxon Valdez was allowed to go outside the lanes at full speed when it neared ice, which led to it running aground on Bligh Reef. ``The original rules were consistently violated, primarily to ensure that tankers passing through Prince William Sound did not lose time by slowing down for ice or waiting for winds to to abate,'' the report says. ``Concern for profits in the 1980s obliterated the concern for safe operations that existed in 1977.'' The report also cites the state Legislature's failure to provide enough money for the Department of Environmental Conservation, which is responsible for spill prevention and cleanup plans. ``The department's small staff was overwhelmed by technical licensing and permitting activities, leaving no opportunity for the agency to perform its role as overall environmental policy watchdog,'' it says. Cowper described the report as ``a cold and sober assessment of what happened'' in the Exxon Valdez disaster. ``A key event here was the striking down of Alaska's laws that would have controlled tanker movements and the degree of preparation for oil spills,'' Cowper said at a news conference. ``The commission came to the conclusion that our oil-spill response capability is still primitive.'' Cowper and state House Speaker Sam Cotten said legislation to adopt some of the report's recommendations may be considered during the 1990 legislative session, which begins Monday. ``It's a little bit too early to specifically respond to the spill report's findings right now. But I think we will probably do whatever is recommended here,'' Cowper said. Cotten said he was unsure if the Legislature has the will to get any new spill laws passed this session. Some legislators have said they first want to take a second look at the package of ``spill bills'' they quickly passed last spring after the Exxon Valdez spill. Among the report's other recommendations: _The party responsible for the spill not be in charge of the cleanup. ``A spiller should be obligated to respond with the resources it can summon, but government should command the response,'' the report says. _A formal command system with a predesignated coordinator be established to handle the cleanup. A lesson from the Exxon Valdez spill is that such a system is needed to avoid confusion and disagreements between the agencies and companies involved, the report says. _Congress either strengthen the Coast Guard's ability to respond to spills or transfer its cleanup duties to the Army Corps of Engineers. The report says Congress also needs to provide more money for the Environmental Protection Agency for spill prevention and response.

DOC.HEAD: Video Business Sets Records in 1989
DOC.TEXT: Sales of prerecorded videocassettes in 1989 soared 40 percent from a year ago, as ``Batman'' helped spark $7.1 billion in video sales and rentals. While 1989 box-office revenues also set a record in excess of $5 billion, video shoppers spent $2.2 billion on videocassette purchases, according to Paul Kagan Associates. ``Batman,'' the top film at the nation's theaters, was estimated to have sold 11 million cassettes. ``Bambi'' sold 10.5 million cassettes and ``Who Framed Roger Rabbit'' sold 8.2 million copies. Retail sales surged to 138 million units, up from 95 million units in 1988, Kagan reported. According to a study by the research firm Alexander & Associates, sales were up 24 percent in the September to mid-December period to $620 million, compared to $470 million from the same period a year ago. The sales figures reflected the increased presence of mass merchandisers like K mart and Target in the video business. Alexander & Associates said video stores accounted for only 16 percent of holiday video sales while mass merchants did 37 percent of the volume.

DOC.HEAD: Former Beatle Ordered to Pay Album Producer $74,000
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, `Superior Court ..., to restore first reference to Chips Moman.
DOC.TEXT: The lawsuit over Ringo Starr's attempt to block the release of a record album ended Friday when a judge ordered the former Beatle to pay more than $74,000 to the record's producer. Superior Court Judge Clarence Cooper, who issued a permanent injunction in November preventing produer Chips Moman's company from releasing the 1987 album, ruled that Starr must pay Moman $74,354 to cover costs of the recording sessions, and 7 percent interest. Starr contended he was under the influence of alcohol at the time the album was recorded and said he was not satisfied with the results after returning home to England and listening to the tapes. He sued Moman and his CRS Records of College Park, Ga., to block the album's release. The album included some new songs along with some older songs, such as ``I Can Help'' and ``Ain't That a Shame.'' At the non-jury trial in November, Moman testified that Bob Dylan made a guest appearance on one song. An attorney for Starr, Robert Fleming Jr., said Friday he had not seen the ruling but indicated he was satisfied with it as he understood it. ``This amount is right in line with what the expenses were and what we were ready to pay,'' he said. ``The judge must have agreed that the agreement was what we said it was and enforced it accordingly.'' Moman had contended that Starr owed him $146,239. Moman's attorney did not immediately return a telephone call. Starr testified in November that he went to Memphis, Tenn., to work with Moman in February 1987 after a brief meeting with the producer the previous year. Attorneys for Moman said Starr came to the producer in an attempt to revive his career. Starr, who had a successful U.S. tour last year, testified he was not desperate when he talked to Moman. ``It was just a move for your career,'' he said. He said his business agent had told him that he and Moman ``would be a winning combination.''

DOC.HEAD: Rhino Population Increased by One
DOC.TEXT: Zoo officials celebrated on Friday the birth of a baby black rhinoceros, boosting the captive population of the endangered species. ``It's a female weighing 66 pounds,'' said Zoo Director Charles Hoessle. ``We're always very cautious for the first 24 hours with any newborn animal, but she seems strong and normal.'' Hoessle said the baby is the result of a reeding program in cooperation with other zoos in North America. ``The mother, Betsy, belongs to the Detroit Zoo,'' Hoessle said. ``The father, Toto, is ours. All the zoos manage the North American black rhino population as one population, moving the animals around to avoid inbreeding.'' Hoessle said there are 70 or 75 black rhinos in captivity in this country, more than half of them born in zoos. ``In contrast,'' Hoessle said, ``in the wild the population of the animals has crashed from more than 100,000 to less than 3,500 in a little over 10 years. Drastic efforts are being made to save the few that are left by putting them in heavily protected parks.'' Hoessle said poachers were rapidly destroying the animals in the wild, killing the large beasts just for their horns. ``The horns are really nothing more than tightly compacted hair,'' Hoessle said. ``They are used for dagger handles in Yemen and for folk medicines and sex potionts in the Orient. There's no real medicinal value in them, of course.'' Hoessle said no photographs of the newborn rhino were immediately available. ``The mother is very aggressive,'' he said, ``and we have to be cautious. We plan to try to sneak in our staff photographer as soon as we think it's safe.''

DOC.HEAD: Polish Government Urges Patience on Economic Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: 4 grafs SUB for 19th and final graf, Niezabitowska said ... UPDATING with comment on Johnson deal.
DOC.TEXT: The non-Communist government on Friday acknowledged widespread shortages after a radical economic plan took effect, but it urged patience to allow for the transformation of Poland's economy to capitalism. ``The first few days are behind us so there is a lot of confusion, anxiety and panic, understandable in a situation of deep and radical changes which also are being introduced quickly,'' said government spokeswoman Malgorzata Niezabitowska. Shoppers wiped out supplies of flour, sugar, and meat in many stores after the announcement of sharp increases for many goods and services Monday and Tuesday. ``We have to give time so the medicine can work. We have to show patience and calm so the new economic mechanisms can start working,'' she said. Deputy Finance Minister Marek Dabrowski said problems in food deliveries led to shortages, especially for meat and butter, and that some enterprises were having trouble paying their bills. The Solidarity-led government was encouraged by the stabilization of the zloty following a 32 percent devaluation on Monday, an increase in bank deposits and an improvement in export figures in December, Dabrowski said. One of the central elements of the plan, which aims to halt Poland's 900 percent annual inflation and transform an economy directly managed by Communists for four decades, is to make the zloty a convertible currency. Poland until now has had two rates of exchange _ an official rate set by the government and a higher black market rate. This week, for the first time in memory, the average official rate of 9,500 zlotys to the dollar was higher than the unofficial rate. The government hopes that a convertible currency will help attract foreign investors who until now have hesitated to develop projects in Poland without a guarantee of being able to expatriate their profits. But Dabrowski said individual consumers have suffered, partially because producers have withheld reverves of meat from the market while they waited to see if the new plan would work. ``We found ourselves in a new reality, a shock took place after the prices of energy and fuels went up,'' he said. Also Friday, the government announced the reversal of a decision by previous Communist authorities to close the Lenin Shipyard in Gdansk, where the Solidarity trade union was born in 1980. Niezabitowska told a news conference that the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Industry and the shipyard had decided to tranform the firm into a joint stock company during talks Wednesday. The former Communist-led government announced the decision to close the historic shipyard on Oct. 31, 1988. The move was immediately denounced by Solidarity leader Lech Walesa _ an electrician at the plant _ as a ``provocation.'' Walesa vowed to fight to save the shipyard and began a search for potential investors. Barbara-Piasecka Johnson, a Polish-American businesswoman and heir of the Johnson & Johnson pharmaceutical fortune, in June said she would spent up to $100 million on the plant if she received ownership of 55 percent of the stock. But her letter of intent expired Monday. It was unclear whether she would make another offer for plant. In Washington, Bazyli Samojlik, economic counselor at the Polish Embassy, said Friday night Mrs. Johnson's agreement was ``a business agreement so the government is not involved in it.'' Asked about the Dec. 31. limit for completing discussions, he said, ``It's not a deadline as I understand it.'' John Peach, an adviser to Mrs. Johnson at her estate in Princeton, N.J., was on vacation and could not be reached for comment, according to a woman who answered the telephone at Peach's office. ``My understanding is that negotiations will continue,'' the woman said, refusing to identify herself or her function. Niezabitowska said shipyard workers will be able to purchase shares on a preferential basis and other shares will be made available to foreign investors.

DOC.HEAD: Oscar-Eligible Films Slump 25 Percent
DOC.TEXT: A total of 217 feature-length films are eligible for 1989 Academy Award consideration, down almost 20 percent from the 270 titles eligible last year, the Academy announced Friday. The list of qualified films will be sent to 4,750 Academy members next week along with official Oscar ballots, the Academy said. The ballots for the 62nd annual awards ceremony are due Feb. 2, with the nominations set to be announced on Feb. 14. Bob Werden, a spokesman for the Academy, said he had no explanation for why fewer films were eligible, but that a number of independent film companies had gone out of business in recent months.

DOC.HEAD: Papal Nuncio Denies Giving Noriega Ultimatum to Leave Embassy
With AM-Panama
DOC.TEXT: The papal nuncio, Monsignor Jose Sebastian Laboa, denied Friday that he gave Gen. Manuel Noriega an ultimatum to leave the Vatican mission where the Panamanian leader had been in refuge for 10 days. ``He left of his own accord. The nuncio never told him to leave,'' Laboa told The Associated Press by in a telephone interview. ``There was no threat. There is not a single basis for thinking that.'' He said letters Noriega wrote to Pope John Paul II, the nuncio and others before he left Wednesday night and was taken by U.S. authorities to Miami to face drug trafficking charges indicated ``he left of his own free will.'' ``In the letters that he wrote he said that they advised him that this was the best,'' Laboa said. Among those in the nunciature with Noriega were his personal security chief, Capt. Eliecer Gaitan, and Lt. Col. Nivaldo Madrinan, a top Noriega adviser and head of his secret police. Madrinan surrendered to U.S. troops on Thursday. Gaitan is seeking asylum in Spain, Laboa said. Thursday night, the Rev. Javier Villanueva, who was assisting Laboa during Noriega's stay, said, ``If he would not have given himself up, the Panamanian government, not the U.S. government, would have been invited to send in forces to take him out. We would have lifted the diplomatic immunity.'' Asked about the statement, Laboa said, ``I don't know how such craziness could have come out.'' Villanueva was not reachable at the nunciature or at his parish Friday night. He heads Christ the King Church, whose members include top officials of the new government of Guillermo Endara and their supporters. During the months of protests last year to demand Noriega's ouster, the congregation often waved white handkerchiefs, a protest symbol, during Mass, and held demonstrations outside the church afterwards.

DOC.HEAD: Disney World Reaches Settlement in Vulture Case
DOC.TEXT: Walt Disney World has pleaded guilty to one federal misdemeanor charge for its handling of vultures that invaded the Discovery Island theme park. As part of a settlement announced Friday, Disney agreed to pay a federal fine of $10,000 and contribute another $10,000 to the Florida Audubon Society. Disney also agreed to contribute $75,000 to the State Game and Fresh Water Fish Commission's conservation program. In exchange, the state agreed to defer 13 misdemeanor charges filed against Discovery Island and five employees for abusing the vultures and other wild birds. The state will drop all charges if the company and the employees adhere to all environmental and wildlife laws for the next year. Disney pleaded guilty to one federal count of moving 149 vultures to another area when it only had a permit to move 100 birds. Two other federal charges were dropped. Disney accepted the settlement because of the legal expenses necessary to fight the case, spokesman Charlie Ridgeway said. Charges were filed in September after the deaths of vultures and the alleged mistreatment of other birds at Discovery Island, an 11-acre zoological site. Disney said the wild birds were attacking animals, stealing their food, defecating on park boardwalks and making too much noise. Among the state and federal charges filed against Disney and the five employees were allegations that workers beat vultures to death; held dozens of them in a small, overheated shed with little food and water; shot hawks and falcons; and knocked eggs from the nests of egrets and ibises. ``The employees involved will be reassigned to jobs not relating to wildlife or Discovery Island,'' Ridgeway said. ``We expect to make improvements to the island and the park worthy of the public's and authorities' approval.''

DOC.HEAD: Brown Pelican Population Hit By Freeze
DOC.TEXT: Louisiana's tropical Brown Pelican population was barely on the mend when it was ravaged by a record freeze that turned the marsh into a moss-draped icicle, the state's wildlife chief said Friday. Temperatures dropped to single digits the week before Christmas and the effect is just being felt in the wetlands. ``We know we've lost 50 birds and it may be in the hundreds before it's all over,'' said Wildlife and Fisheries Secretary Virginia Van Sickle. ``Even 50 is a major loss when you think in terms of a population of just 2,000.'' Preliminary findings don't show any major damage to other wildlife and fish with the exception of nutria, or water-dwelling rats, said Van Sickle. Louisiana is wealthy in oysters, shrimp, alligators and nutria but the symbol of the state _ the Brown Pelican _ had disappeared by 1970, another victim of the pesticide DDT.
