More than 600 Brown Pelicans were imported from Florida 10 years ago in a restocking program that has been closely followed. ``One of the 50 birds we've found so far was a banded bird, one of the original pelicans brought from Florida,'' Van Sickle said. ``They appeared to have been killed by exposure or injuries caused when they dived into ice. Some had broken legs, wings and had died of starvation. Injured, they were just too weak to find food.'' A few injured birds were found and taken to Audubon Park Zoo in New Orleans for treatment, she said.

The Bush administration, after months of condemning Panama's Manuel Antonio Noriega as a ``thug'' and a criminal, is toning down its rhetoric to avoid prejudicing the deposed dictator's drug-trafficking trial. An administration official disclosed Thursday that Noriega surrendered to the U.S. military in Panama City only after the Vatican Embassy gave him a deadline to leave. As defense officials were replacing U.S. combat troops in Panama with rebuilding forces, a senior official said Noriega's longtime CIA ties have been reviewed and that any potentially damaging disclosures Noriega might use in his trial defense will be ``manageable.'' President Bush kept a low profile on the day after he announced Noriega's Wednesday night surrender to U.S. forces in Panama. Only days earlier, he had called Noriega a ``thug.''

With potential new democracies springing up in Panama and Eastern Europe, there is a growing demand for the United States to get out its foreign aid checkbook at a time when the world's leading democracy can ill afford it. ``We have a hell of a problem, and it's getting tighter and tighter and tighter,'' said Mark Edelman, the acting director of the State Department's Agency for International Development. The Bush administration this week sent a delegation to Panama to evaluate the need for U.S. assistance in reviving a formerly robust economy crippled by American trade sanctions. Early estimates of needed aid are running upwards of $1 billion over the next few years. The president also has pledged that Eastern European countries that adopt democracy and reform their economies can expect help of the sort that Congress voted last year for Poland and Hungary, which are getting $840 million over the next three years.

Romania's provisional government is developing closer ties with Moscow than the communist regime it replaced, welcoming Soviet offers of aid and expecting a productive visit by a top Soviet official. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze is to arrive in Bucharest on Saturday for the first consultations between the new government and the Kremlin since dictator Nicolae Ceausescu was toppled Dec. 22 and executed with his wife Elena on Christmas Day. Silviu Brucan, a top foreign policy official, said Thursday the new leadership had assurances from the Kremlin that Romania will get extensive assistance, including plentiful energy supplies for the harsh winter. Unlike other East European revolutions, which have pulled former satellite nations further from Moscow, Romania's uprising appears to have strengthened what had been deteriorating relations between Moscow and Bucharest.

Overweight people fighting the battle of the bulge can diet themselves to death in improperly supervised very-low-calorie programs that are used by more than a million Americans, doctors warned today. Such liquid diets require management by a specially trained physician, and by a behavioral psychologist and dietician, the doctors wrote in the Journal of the American Medical Association. Although the diets are ``unquestionably safer'' than their liquid-protein predecessors, which were blamed for at least 58 deaths during the 1970s, they still have dangers, said the article's authors. ``The recent and zealous marketing of various formula products to physicians, as well as the public's appetite for such diets, could lead to yet another round of complications and fatalities,'' wrote the doctors, who are from the University of Pennsylvania, Columbia University and Harvard Medical School.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Students Turn in Required Self-Criticism Reports
DOC.TEXT: After it crushed the democracy movement last spring, the Chinese government ordered university students to write self-criticism reports on their involvement. They have now turned them in _ more as grudgingly done homework than soul-searching reflections. Students say they passed around a few ``master'' reports before the December deadline, or plagiarized government propaganda to satisfy authorities overseeing the political education exercise. ``My report was nonsense. I just said silly things, all lies,'' said a student at Beijing University, which was at the forefront of the movement. ``I said I didn't agree with the hunger strike and posters, and that I didn't participate in anything.'' In fact the student took part in the hunger strike and occupation of Tiananmen Square, printed and handed out leaflets, and broadcast pro-movement messages over school loudspeakers. Yet the student's report echoed with numbing mimicry the government line drummed into the populace since the June 3-4 crackdown that left hundreds if not thousands dead. ``Soldiers rushed in to Beijing to enforce martial law as the city suffered a serious counterrebellion,'' the student's 11-page report said. ``The soldiers, who were brothers and sons of the people, gave their blood to save the country and protect the people's peace. The masterminds of the turmoil used every means possible to achieve their despicable political aims, manipulating the hunger-striking students, treating students' lives like betting chips, disrupting the martial law order and uniting social forces to beat, smash, steal, burn and kill, and try to use violence to overthrow our legitimate government.'' Such parroting of the official line was reflected in other students' similarly written reports, which were reprinted for several weeks in Beijing's two local newspapers, the Communist Party's Beijing Daily and the tabloid Beijing Evening News. The written testimonies have been the price the government has asked for not punishing the tens of thousands of students who took part in the spring demonstrations. Dozens of student leaders have been arrested and face long years in prison. Students say the key was to write the proper view about the movement, and how their attitudes have changed since June, or the reports will be returned for rewriting. ``Mainly they wanted to know precisely what we did. We just said we were used by a small handful of people because we were too young, too childish,'' said one student who took a report that had been submitted to her father, a teacher, and shared it with several classmates. ``We didn't copy it completely, just changed things around,'' she said. ``Some of us turned them in to the same teachers, so we had to be careful.'' Ideological education is being stressed at Beijing University, more than any other school. Its entire freshman class is spending a year at an army academy for political study and military training. ``A lot of people didn't want to waste time writing these things,'' the Beijing University student said. ``It was pretty easy to find the proper things to say. We have so many references _ news reports, books _ to copy from. Some of my friends copied whole paragraphs from newspapers.'' At one of Beijing's technical universities, numerous master copies of essays were floating around. ``We had to change details of the reports to match ourselves, so people couldn't tell they were from the same model,'' a management student at the university said. The student wrote a report by copying from newspapers, and a roommate copied that report in turn. ``I think the reports should be written,'' a student at Beijing Normal University, another activist hotbed, said resignedly. ``It keeps things quiet and then people won't bother you.'' He did note he did not take part in any marches or rallies. ``Nothing's going to change anyway,'' he added. ``We'll still have the same leaders and the same society.'' Students were not the only ones required to produce reports. Professors and some party members, intellectuals and workers were also obliged. ``I only wrote three pages,'' said a worker in the publishing business. ``I said _ truthfully _ that I kept on working throughout the turmoil and had no part of it.'' The worker added, however, that none of his colleagues wrote reports sympathetic to the protesters. ``These are all given to our superiors, you know,'' he said. A professor at a prestigious professional university in Beijing who had to give his report on the turmoil orally to colleagues says students were wrong to neglect their studies. ``I gave a little speech and said the problem is with education,'' he recalled. ``I said young people aren't interested in studying these days. My school is the best in its field, but so many students at my school are from the `T-faction' _ all they think about is taking the TOEFL exam.'' The TOEFL, or Test of English as a Foreign Language, is required by all schools in the United States of foreign students. Supervision of the students' essays was not uniformly rigorous. ``Of course, our leaders know a lot of us aren't serious,'' the management major said. Writing the essays was nevertheless a necessary exercise for staying on track for this student, who took part in many of the activities around Tiananmen Square but still plans to join the Communist Party. ``If I want to go abroad, I'd better join,'' the student said. ``It will be very useful for my future, for me to get a good job.''

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Army Resorts to Disguises to Nab Palestinian Activists
DOC.TEXT: Israeli soldiers have been seen in disguise _ civilian clothes, masks or even traditional embroidered dresses of Arab women _ in their effort to capture leaders of the Palestinian uprising. The tactic, along with the commandeering of cars with West Bank or Gaza Strip license plates, is designed to fool lookouts who often guard entrances to Palestinian villages and camps. In November, two 20-year-old men who had been shot came to a hospital in the West Bank town of Jenin and told doctors they were in a car fired on by Jewish settlers or other Israelis in civilian clothes. The Israeli army later confirmed two men were shot near Jenin but said it was soldiers who opened fire when the car's driver ignored orders to stop. A spokesman refused comment when asked if the soldiers were wearing civilian clothes. The pattern of disguise has been emerging over the past four or five months. Arab reporters say eight people have been killed by men in civilian cars or in disguise who shot at wanted Palestinians, stone throwers or people painting anti-Israeli graffiti. On Dec. 1, according to Arab witnesses, soldiers wearing Arab robes and kaffiyeh scarves killed four members of a radical group called the Black Panthers on a narrow street in Nablus, the West Bank's largest town. In that case, officials insisted the troops were in uniform. Generally the army has refused official comment on reports of disguised soldiers. When asked about the disguises, an army spokesman, Col. Nachman Shai, said the army ``does not reveal details of its operational activities.'' In Kafr Kaddum, residents told of Israelis in civilian clothes arriving in the village in a minibus with blue West Bank license plates Sept. 10, then opening fire and killing Zaher Obeid, 28, and Fahed Ishtawi, 14. Obeid's brother Jawad, a retired school principal, said this is what happened when the minibus entered the village: ``Some 100 people gathered around. ... A boy recognized a man inside the car as an army officer who questioned him two days before. Zaher shouted ... `These are spies.''' Half an hour later, Obeid was dead, reportedly chased and shot by one of a dozen soldiers who stormed out of the vehicle, which had cardboard-covered windows, firing pistols and M-16 assault rifles. Six others were reported wounded in the army action. The army confirmed the raid on Kafr Kaddum, 31 miles north of Jerusalem. It said soldiers opened fire after being attacked with stones and metal bars. No references to disguises were made. Although the army does not officially acknowledge it uses disguises, one military source, speaking anonymously, told The Associated Press that security forces resort to disguise to capture Palestinians wanted for attacks on fellow Arabs accused of collaborating with Israel. At least 155 suspected collaborators have been slain in the two-year uprising, and 626 other Palestinians have died from Israeli gunfire. Forty-three Israelis have been killed. The Israeli newspaper Hadashot quoted a senior military source as saying soldiers would keep using disguises ``until the wanted men won't know where (the army) is coming from and will be afraid of everybody and everything around them.'' During the uprising, police have acknowledged they posed as journalists, and Israeli newspapers have repeatedly reported soldiers commandeering vehicles with license plates from the occupied lands. In November, two Palestinians were sentenced to 25 months in prison after documents were submitted to an Israeli military court in the Gaza Strip saying they stoned a local civilian vehicle and then were arrested by soldiers who got out of the car. In Gaza and the West Bank city of Nablus, Arab reporters say soldiers have been seen with Arab kaffiyehs over their faces in imitation of uprising activists or in women's scarves and colorfully embroidered dresses. In an August incident, a crowd in Gaza's Shati refugee camp chased away seven masked men painting anti-Israeli graffiti on walls when onlookers became suspicious the artists actually were soldiers, a Gazan source said. ``They painted a Palestinian flag with wrong colors,'' he added. In the West Bank city of Bethlehem, Mayor Elias Freij quoted witnesses as saying security agents dressed up like tourists, with backpacks and cameras, opened fire Aug. 19 on Arab demonstrators, killing one. The army said the men were soldiers and again did not mention disguises.

DOC.HEAD: Singapore Beckons People of Hong Kong: Come to Us
DOC.TEXT: Worried about a labor shortage and the migration of its skilled professionals, Singapore is wooing people from Hong Kong who fear for their future after the British colony reverts to China in seven years. They are in demand here because they are thought to be a natural fit for Singapore's Chinese-dominated society, where language would not be an insurmountable barrier. Many have come already to stay or to just to look around. Real estate brokers say Hong Kong people like Singapore's lush greenery and relative quiet, both are in short supply where they come from. They also like the prices of condominiums and houses, usually far cheaper than in Hong Kong. Some of the Hong Kong visitors are taken on carefully conducted ``emigration tours'' to meet government officials, bankers and others who could be helpful if it becomes necessary to find homes in a new land. Confidence in Hong Kong's future under Chinese control after 1997, after shrinking slowly since the joint declaration was signed by China and Britain in 1984, dropped dramatically following the violent crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing's Tiananman Square in June. Earlier attempts by Singapore to lure business people with the equivalent of $510,000 in capital, college graduates and professionals met with little success. Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew said in 1987 that Singapore came ``a poor third'' after Canada and Australia in enticing people from Hong Kong. That changed within weeks of the Tianaman Square bloodshed when Lee's government relaxed the rules for as many as 25,000 skilled workers and their families. The quota applies to those with a high school education, five years of on-the-job experience and an income of at least $770 a month. Some 10,000 hopefuls swarmed Singapore's Consulate in Hong Kong within hours of the announcement. A key attraction is that successful applicants can wait for as long as five years to take up residence, and get an option to extend for another five, giving them a chance to experience post-1997 Hong Kong before deciding. Canada, Australia and other destinations require them to move in promptly. But as nurses, teachers and others aggravated an already serious brain drain by taking jobs in Singapore, newspapers and others in Hong Kong hit at what they saw as opportunism on Singapore's part in taking advantage of the colony's troubles. Hong Kong and Singapore, a city-state of 2.6 million people at the tip of the Malay Peninsula, have long been rivals as hubs for regional trade, finance and communications, although they are about 1,600 miles apart. Both are free-trade ports, have limited space and no natural resources except strategic locations and the skill of their peoples. George Yeo, Singapore's minister of state for foreign affairs, denied that his government acted to make things more difficult for Hong Kong or China. If those in Hong Kong intended to leave anyway, he said, it would be better to keep them in the region so their talent would not be lost to North America or Australia. One analyst said the wave of migration might allow Singapore to reprise one reason for Hong Kong's economic boom. Thousands of entrepreneurs left cosmopolitan Shanghai before it fell to the Chinese communists 41 years ago to find refuge in Hong Kong, and helped it prosper. Singapore expects a value-added to the economy per worker of about $42,000 to $52,000 a year, said Mah Bow Tan, the minister of state for trade and industry. Using the lower figure, Mah said 25,000 skilled migrants would add $1.05 billion, about 4 percent of the country's gross domestic product. Not everyone awaits the newcomers with open arms, however. ``Our workers certainly do not want a flood of foreigners to come here and steal their jobs,'' said Chaim See Tong, secretary-general of the Singapore Democratic Party and one of two opposition members of Parliament. The Straits Times newspaper reported that dentists in private practice, an already crowded field in Singapore, are concerned about potential competitors from Hong Kong. Meantime, while trying to lure likely prospects from Hong Kong, affluent Singapore faces its own drain of talented people. More than 4,700 families from what Prime Minister Lee called ``our top 25 percent'' left in 1988, most bound for Australia, New Zealand, Canada and the United States. Exit interviews indicate they left mainly for better job opportunities, less stressful work and school conditions or to join relatives. ``They want less regulations, more freedom,'' Mah told Parliament. ``They complain ours is a `one-mistake' society, with no tolerance for failure, no second chance. They don't want their children to be pressured in school. They don't want to be told to excel. In short, they want to opt out of the rat race.''

DOC.HEAD: Media Buzzwords: Clarifying or Confusing the News?
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega called them ``dignity battalions.'' NBC's Tom Brokaw said ``Norega's goons.'' Should ``anti-abortion'' replace ``pro-life?'' Is it ``crippled'' or ``physically challenged?'' And what about ``black?'' Why not ``African American?'' In the quick-draw world of media buzzwords, it's far simpler to spot a ``pro-democracy'' movement than to find easy answers to these linguistic dilemmas. After all, one person's ``freedom fighter'' might be another's ``terrorist.'' Even what some consider the most straightforward labels now are being challenged. The Rev. Pat Robertson has objected to being called a ``televangelist.'' Special Olympics holds that ``hearing impaired'' is preferable to ``deaf.'' Why the attention to detail? Public-relations consultants and special-interest groups are convinced journalistic shorthand affects public opinion _ one word can shift sympathies in subtle, but lasting, ways. If you're fighting for citizenship, it's better to be called an ``undocumented worker'' than an ``illegal alien.'' And since ``liberal'' has taken on negative connotations, some left-of-center organizations now say they're ``progressive.'' The fight over language, politics and the media was examined at length by George Orwell in 1946. But with the advent of news compression _ ``Give us 22 minutes, and we'll give you the world!'' _ the semantic scrap has intensified. ``The terminology is extremely important,'' said Douglas Gould, vice president of communications for Planned Parenthood Federation of America. ``It helps form an impression in people's minds about what the different groups are really all about. ... It is the first step in framing the debate.'' Nowhere is the fight over buzzwords more intense than in the abortion battle. After calling the opposing sides ``pro-abortion'' and ``pro-life'' for several years, the media now often refer to the rival sides as ``pro-choice'' and ``anti-abortion.'' Even that description, some journalists and media critics agree, is biased in favor of abortion-rights advocates: The implication is that anyone who's not ``pro-choice'' is ``anti-choice.'' ``The other side wants to be for something, and they want us to be against something,'' said Dan Donehey, director of public relations for the National Right to Life Committee, which opposes abortion. ``The public tends to lean toward a group that is in favor of something.'' Yet if reporters were to reverse course and describe Donehey's constituents as ``pro-life,'' the implication would be that the other camp is ``anti-life.'' So what's to be done? ``The closest that I could come up with, as neutral terms, and I'm not satisfied with this either, is `abortion-rights advocates' and `abortion opponents,''' said Jeff Greenfield, a reporter for ABC News. Some organizations send language guidelines to news outlets. People with AIDS should be called just that, not AIDS victims, the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation says in its style guidelines. ``Victim,'' the activists say, is better used to describe the target of a criminal act. Similarly, children born with AIDS should not be called ``innocent victims'' of the disease, as that implies other people with AIDS are guilty of something, the alliance says. In its language guidelines, Special Olympics asks that people with handicaps not be labeled by their disabilities. ``A person uses a wheelchair rather than is confined or restricted to a wheelchair,'' the guidelines say. ``A person has a seizure disorder or epilepsy, rather than is epileptic.'' Pat Krebs, director of education for outreach projects for Special Olympics, acknowledged that some of the guidelines border on euphemism _ ``physically challenged,'' she said, may not be an appropriate substitute for ``physically disabled,'' the latter replacing ``crippled.'' All the same, even accepted shorthand quickly can become outdated and offensive. At the turn of the century, the labels used for degrees of retardation were idiot, imbecile and moron, Krebs said. ``Then (those terms) took on such negative connotations with society,'' Krebs said. ``So we're constantly changing terminology.'' Other snappy labels _ ``Star Wars'' or ``pro-democracy'' _ may add little to our understanding of complicated issues. ``The genesis for this is really television, with its short attention span and its desire to compress everything into little nuggets of information,'' said media critic Mark Hertsgaard, author of ``On Bended Knee: The Press and the Reagan Presidency.'' ``I think the use of shorthand has becomes at least as much a liability'' as an asset, Hertsgaard said. ``It discourages any kind of nuance or complex understanding of political events.'' ``Pro-democracy,'' Hertsgaard and others say, doesn't spell out differences between movements in China, East Germany, Czechoslovakia, Poland and the Soviet Union. But time is so short for elaboration. Said ABC's Greenfield: ``If I'm doing a piece for the network news, and it's supposed to run 1 minute and 45 seconds, and I say, `Can I please have 20 more seconds to explain the pro-democracy movement?'... that might put my piece over. That's why people are so desperate for those shorthand terms.''

DOC.HEAD: War Has Helped Turn Afghanistan into Major Heroin Producer
LaserPhoto Planned
DOC.TEXT: The 11-year-old war in Afghanistan has destroyed much of the country's agrarian economy and helped turn its small, centuries-old tradition of poppy cultivation into a multimillion dollar industry. Officials say the colorful flowers' sticky yield of opium is being refined into heroin powder in remote laboratories along the mountainous Pakistan-Afghanistan frontier and shipped to the West. Western narcotics agents estimate that as much as 80 percent of the heroin sold in Europe and 25 percent sold in the United States comes now from the region. The remainder is from Mexico and the ``Golden Triangle'' of Southeast Asia, experts say. Afghan Aid, a British emergency relief organization, began a program last June of offering agricultural incentives in hopes of weaning farmers away from opium poppies in rebel-controlled areas. The United States, which has spent billions of dollars as the main arms supplier for anti-government Moslem guerrillas, plans to launch a similar program this year. No country has felt the effects of the illicit industry more than Pakistan, through which most of the heroin passes on its way to the West. Khalim Dilkhan, chairman of the Pakistan Narcotics Control Board, said local agents in 1988 alone seized 13,669 pounds of heroin, compared with 950 pounds in 1980. Narcotics agents say a kilogram (2.2 pounds) of 97 percent pure heroin fetches $1,000 at the Pakistan-Afghan border. ``Multiply that about 100 times for New York City,'' said Dilkhan. He said heroin addiction was virtually unknown in Pakistan, a Moslem country of 109 million people, but now, more than a million poor, mainly urban young Pakistanis, are hooked. ``In 10 years, the problem has multiplied a thousand times,'' Dilkhan said. No statistics are available on the number of addicts in Afghanistan and experts do not even hazard a guess. Opium production, and to some extent export, has existed for centuries in Afghanistan and what is now Pakistan. But experts said three events in the late 1970s combined to help make heroin a huge export industry: _Turkey's crackdown on heroin labs operating in eastern Anatolia, which forced production into western Iran. _Iran's Islamic revolution, which purged corrupt officials who had participated in the opium trade. _The war in Afghanistan, sparked by a Marxist coup in 1978, which has dislocated about half the country's 15 million people and spawned anarchy in the countryside. Soviet combat troops intervened to prop up the Marxist government in Kabul from December of 1979 to last February, but the ruling People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan controls only the country's major cities. Almost all the poppy cultivation occurs in areas held by the U.S.-armed Moslem guerrillas _ the mujahedeen or ``holy warriors'' _ where farmers once raised wheat, corn and barley. Experts say these are the areas that have been hit hardest by artillery shelling and aerial bombing. ``The main thing is the destruction of the irrigation systems. Opium poppy takes very little water,'' said Peter Rees, Afghan Aid's field director in the frontier city of Peshawar. The major mujahedeen groups, which are headquartered in Pakistan, acknowledge that some of their local commanders are involved in poppy cultivation. However, the leaders of those groups deny that they condone it. ``In some areas, there must be some benefit to mujahedeen commanders,'' said Rees. ``But I've seen no clear evidence to show that high commanders are involved.'' Pakistani and U.S. narcotics experts based in Pakistan say they agree with that assessment. Afghan Aid's program offers assistance in the form of advice and development projects to farmers, mainly in Afghanistan's eastern Nangarhar province, who sign contracts promising not to grow poppy. ``In the spring, we'll go and monitor each and every recipient,'' Rees said. ``I'm reasonably confident they'll uphold these contracts.'' The U.S. Congress has approved $12.5 million for a similar, three-year program to be run by the U.S. Agency for International Development in consultation with the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Thursday PMs, Jan. 11

DOC.HEAD: Deruddere, Like His Hero, Waits Until Spring
DOC.TEXT: Like his movie hero, Svevo Bandini, filmmaker Dominique Deruddere must wait until Spring to see if America will fulfill his expectations. Fortunately for the Belgian director, he stands a better chance than Bandini, the European immigrant in ``Wait Until Spring, Bandini,'' a bittersweet tale of Italian family life in the land of broken dreams. With the off-screen backing of Francis Ford Coppola and writer Charles Bukowski, and sparkling on-screen performances by Faye Dunaway and Joe Mantegna, Deruddere is confidently awaiting the U.S. premiere of his movie in Florida at the Festival of Miami on Feb. 4. National release is set for mid-March. The movie opened to good reviews in Western Europe just before the holiday season, perfect timing for a heartwarming story set in the cold and snowed-in Rockies. ``It would help the film if it were released now in the United States,'' said Deruddere, sipping an espresso at his favorite Art Deco bar in Brussels. But at age 32, he doesn't want to get picky over such things as when and where his movies are shown. He made just one full feature film in Belgium. ``Crazy Love,'' a movie on how rejected love can ultimately lead to necrophilia and suicide, earned him enough laurels to get a shot at a big break overseas. ``Most European directors have the American dream,'' he said. ``In the end, non-conformists like (Rainer Werner) Fassbinder also wanted an Oscar. When you're in your bed at night, you just see yourself standing there on a U.S. movie set.'' Last February and March, he stood on an American set, and the reality was sobering. ``It is the just the same as working here. You're only making a movie.'' But he had to cut his original plans for shooting ``Bandini'' in 11 weeks down to seven after he could only raise $4 million instead of $6 million. As a result the schedule was so tight, the hours so long he once fell asleep on the set during the last week. By then, however, he had already accomplished a Tinsel Town rarity: He stayed within the budget and the deadline. ``It was a miracle,'' Deruddere said, crediting the tiny European budgets that forced an iron discipline upon him in his early days. Only half-mockingly, he was told he could become a star in Hollywood simply on that merit. But Deruddere wants to be an artist, not ``an employee.'' For that reason, he rejected a $15 million offer from American producers to direct ``Bandini'' provided he relinquished a final say in the production. Had he accepted, he said, the film's story line ``would have been too sweet. I wanted to make an emotional film, not a tear-jerker.'' Set in Rocklin, Colo., in 1925, ``Wait Until Spring, Bandini'' tells the story of a poor, unemployed Italian bricklayer who has to feed his large family through the winter. Svevo Bandini (Mantegna) loses his money to gambling and his heart to the rich widow Mrs. Hildegarde (Dunaway), while his wife (Ornella Muti) prays for his return. In the end, Svevo's son, Arturo, lures Bandini back into the family fold with a couple of lies. ``It is not such a wholesome theme,'' Deruddere said. ``The family comes back together because of the lie. The end is very ambiguous.'' Central to the story is an Italian immigrant's American dream and his son's musings about baseball and movie stars _ not the most obvious subject for a European director. ``It is not typically American because the dream is seen as something unattainable. The Italian immigrants can only hope to belong.'' It also helped that the Bandini family closely resembled his own. Coming from Belgium, where just about anything is allowed on the set, he faced for the first time the strongly regulated U.S. movie industry. ``The homely amateurism that can be so stimulating does not exist there,'' said Deruddere, whose first task was to find a non-union state in the Rockies to shoot his film. ``Otherwise the movie could never be made.'' He settled on Utah, and location shots were made near Salt Lake City. Even so, Utah's child labor laws forced him to work at a ``diabolical rhythm'' to ensure the young stars were in bed at night. Shooting was marred by a lack of snow in the Rockies, and artificial snow had to be used for countless takes. But when Deruddere himself provided a helping hand in the time consuming job, some jaws dropped. ``When the snow was not spread fast enough, I just got on the truck to help. Some people freaked out and pointed: `Look at the director.' You could never do a thing like that in Hollywood.'' But moving to California is not exactly his dream. ``You don't have to work there, you have to earn respect there.''

DOC.HEAD: First Turkish Movie to Enter Academy Awards Contest
DOC.TEXT: For the first time ever, Turkey is seeking an Academy Award nomination for foreign film, choosing as its entry a stirring drama about the friendship between a female political prisoner and a 4-year-old boy in prison with his mother. Director Tunc Basaran says it is a major reversal of government policy that will allow his film, ``Do Not Let Them to Shoot the Kite,'' to compete. ``The history of the Turkish movie industry goes back 75 years,'' the 52-year-old filmmaker said in an interview. ``And for the first time the government convened a jury to select Turkey's entry. They would always promise in the past but never did this.'' More than bureaucratic inertia has been overcome with the choice of this movie. Turkish officials, who in the past have censored works that exposed social or political ills in the country, have paved the way to Los Angeles for a film that takes place in the women's wing of a high security prison. The movie centers around the child Baris, who enters as a baby when his mother gets a jail term for a drug peddling offense. He literally is growing up in jail. The practice is common in Turkey because there are no institutions to care for children of imprisoned parents. The mother is in a ward with women imprisoned for petty crimes. Most of them are illiterate and unable to deal with the bright and curious child who is forever asking questions. In the next ward are political prisoners, all university students or graduates, who take over the education of Baris. One of them, Inci, becomes a special friend to the boy who is heartbroken when she is released. The film is based on a novel by Feride Cicekoglu, an architect imprisoned for four years after the 1980 military takeover for belonging to an outlawed leftist organization. It is a real life story, director Basaran said. The character Inci is based on the author. Many books and several movies have emerged from the prison experiences of Turkish artists and intellectuals put behind bars during the 1980-83 martial law crackdown on leftist and rightist terrorism. Cicekoglu, who also wrote the screenplay, and Basaran have avoided cheap sentimentality and ideological messages. Nor have they attempted to support the thesis of the ruling generals that all the leftists incarcerated were blood-thirsty terrorists. The female political prisoners are more peace-loving than the women convicted of petty crimes, and often break up their fights. The political prisoners show a strongly human and maternal side in their concern for Baris, who acts as a bridge between the two wards. His innocent questions force adults to think over their own beliefs and ways of expressing them. ``Why are you carrying a gun?'' he asks the soldier escorting his mother during a hospital visit. ``What is a communist?'' he asks Inci, using a word that would have been censored out of a movie in the past. Basaran said Cicekoglu's story could not be filmed without the right child actor, Ozan Bilen, who was actually 4 years old when the movie was shot. The five nominations, to be chosen from among 44 entries for the 1990 best foreign film Oscar, will be announced Feb. 17. Basaran's movie has already won a Golden Orange, Turkey's national equivalent of the Oscar, and is a box-office smash in Istanbul against heavy competition from such foreign films as ``Who Framed Roger Rabbit.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PM Thurs Jan.

DOC.HEAD: Plants Just Love This Music _ So Do People
DOC.TEXT: Close your eyes and imagine a band like this on stage: On the right stands cheerful, heavyset Al Anderson. A pink guitar is strapped around his neck, but he could just as easily be carrying a clipboard and sending in plays to his quarterback, or wearing an apron and weighing a package of fresh ground beef. On the left is keyboard player Terry Adams, attacking his instrument like a toddler making mudpies. Elbows, legs and shoulders fly. His eyes roll to the ceiling, his face frozen in a silly grin. The ivories seem in danger of coming loose and spilling over the floor. Joey Spampinato, the bassist, is centerstage. He's the romantic of the group, a long-haired balladeer with a lazy smile and faraway stare _ the kind of guy who gets away with such corn as ``I Love Her, She Loves Me.'' People even ask for sheet music to play at weddings. Behind them sits drummer Tom Ardolino. Dark curly hair and beard to match. The beat is steady, but his head bobs and jerks as if attached to a spring, like the souvenir dolls sold at baseball parks. The music is clean, fast, loud and everyone shares vocals. The songs recall the Beatles, the Beach Boys, TV shows, jazz, blues and just about everything else. The band members look like they've never had more fun in all their lives. Meet the New Rhythm and Blues Quartet, known to Q-heads and others as NRBQ. Adams, who founded the group after meeting Spampinato in Miami in 1967, sums up their message: ``Don't roll the dice if you can't pay the price. Everything's possible, everything's impossible. Ain't no horse that can't be rode, ain't no man that can't be thow'd.'' For non-Q-heads, Adams meant this is a band that does what it wants, no matter what the cost, or lack of cost. That's after more than 20 years in rock 'n' roll, hundreds of songs and millions of laughs. All that's missing is a touch of gold. A long, very strange trip it's been, their devoted fans divided between stars _ Keith Richards, Elvis Costello, Ray Davies _ and plain old Q-heads. One memorable stop came at New York's Fillmore East back in the early days. ``They had this light show,'' Adams recalled, ``and it went on top of the bands at the Fillmore all the time. We asked them to turn it off for our set and they got really upset and made it worse. ``They were showing films over us, which didn't fit with what we were doing. I didn't think they had any respect for the music, so while they were showing the films, we stopped playing, one at a time, and sat down and watched the films. ``That was a kind of turning point in the businees. People said we were never going to make it because we did that.'' But what does ``making it'' mean? To NRBQ, making it means making music. When they're not playing or recording, they're thinking about it. If they were worried about hit records, could they possibly be having as much fun after all this time? ``I remember friends starting when they hit 30 to say, `I'm turning 30 and I'm not making any money and I'm getting out,''' Adams said. ``I thought: `How did you survive this long? You weren't making any money before, either.''' Success for NRBQ means no band member has ever had a regular job. The only resume these guys have is a lengthy discography, notably the 1978 release ``At Yankee Stadium'' and the current ``Wild Weekend,'' their first studio record in six years. The songs range from agonizing covers of Gordon Lightfoot's ``The Wreck of the Edmund Fitzgerald'' and the Village People's ``Y.M.C.A,'' to Spampinato's Beatle-esque ``This Love Is True'' and Adams' ``Little Floater,'' a love song about man's best friend, his car. The band plays in true rock 'n' roll spirit; that means have as much fun as you want, but keep the rhythm going. Anything goes, as long as you can dance to it. You don't need sheet music to read between the lines. ``You study the music, get good at the instrument, learn eveything you can and then you've got to throw that all out,'' Adams said. ``You got to drop the academics, you got to be able to get that part out of the way. You got to start playing music for the music's sake, rather than what you're going to get financially.'' This is good music that's actually good for you, Adams insisted. Doubters are urged to try a simple test: ``You ever see reports where they try music on plant life? They played classical music for these plants and they did very well and they did rock music and some of them started shriveling,'' Adams said. ``I always said, `What rock music?' Play our music to the plants and they won't shrivel.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Tuesday AMs, Jan. 9

DOC.SECOND: AM-AP Arts: Once a Hero, Adv 10,0754

For Release Wednesday AMs, Jan. 10, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Books and Authors: From Vietnam to Leavenworth
DOC.TEXT: At various times and to different degrees, Jim Little was a good cop, a bad cop, a loving husband, a marital louse, a war hero and a hard-drinking, pot-smoking religious fanatic. He was a loner who often craved companionship, usually female. As a crack helicopter pilot, he was a coldly efficient killer skimming across the jungles of Vietnam or a brazen bandit swooping down on target banks in Texas, Louisiana and Nevada. The quarry in a year-long FBI manhunt, Jim Little today is a convict. In his book ``Once a Hero'' (Texas Monthly Press, $17.95), author-journalist Howard Swindle launches the saga of Jim Little with these lines: ``Before the sun would hit its zenith on February 15, 1984, an icy-cold helicopter pilot and four uniformed men carrying automatic weapons would scare absolute hell out of The System.'' Bull's-eye! What follows is a psychodrama that Texas Monthly Press calls ``the true story of one man's tragic odyssey from Vietnam to Leavenworth.'' It is the story of a heavily decorated but mentally confused war hero who returns from two tours in Vietnam and serves with honor, distinction and considerable controversy as an Alaska state trooper. Little is fired, rehired nd quits, but not before winning Alaska's Medal of Honor for risking his life to save his partner. He then becomes one of history's most innovative bank robbers, the first to use helicopters for the assault and getaway. The decline and fall of a genuine American hero ends with Little in a notoriously oppressive federal prison and locked away with a multiple cop-killer. In between, the reader is introduced to a parade of weirdos, including but not limited to Little's airborne bank robbing buddies. According to Swindle, the villain in this gripping story is not Little, nor is it drugs, drink, scarlet women, religious fanaticism or even the ``mastermind'' of the daring and dazzling bank heists. It is post-traumatic stress disorder, PTSD, a mental affliction only recently diagnosed and most often linked to Vietnam combat. An estimated 500,000 Vietnam veterans suffer from some form of the disorder, which can be triggered by isolated sounds and sights. ``Many of the sufferers still live in the nightmares of scenes witnessed in the jungles of Vietnam,'' said Swindle, an assistant managing editor at The Dallas Morning News and himself a Vietnam combat veteran. It is the author's extensive research and reporting of this grim phenomenon that makes ``Once a Hero'' more than a compelling true crime story. There also is an undercurrent of cruel irony in ``Once a Hero.'' The author went to great lengths to examine and explain post-traumatic stress disorder and to demonstrate, often painfully, its time-bomb effect on Jim Little. Yet after he was captured, Little refused to use post-traumatic stress disorder as a defense. He pleaded guilty to bank robbery, and a federal judge in Texas sentenced him to 25 years in prison. Swindle points out that a government which Little once served so vigorously seemed disinclined to recognize and respond to his plight or the plight of others like him. ``Prisons punish the manifestation of the act,'' he observed. ``They do not probe the mental process that motivated it.'' Despite his guilty plea, Little remains despondent and disillusioned. ``Am I bitter?'' he wrote in one of many letters critical of a government he calls the Beast. ``Wouldn't you be? I went to Vietnam twice and enforced the law in Alaska the best I could. And the Beast betrayed me both times. I fought back in the only way I knew how and the Beast put me in prison. ``Yeah, I guess you could say I'm bitter. There's nothing left. The Beast has it all.'' Near the end of his book, Swindle writes: ``Until age 37, Jim Little was a starched, creased example of public service and staunch defender of traditional American values. For 12 years he had worn Army green; for four years, he had worn Trooper blue. In both uniforms, his colleagues held him as an example of excellence. ``Little has been incarcerated more than three years, and no one has asked him why he inexplicably robbed a bank on a February morning in 1984.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Wednesday, Jan. 10

DOC.HEAD: One English Actress-Comedian Pays Homage to Another
DOC.TEXT: Maureen Lipman plays Joyce Grenfell. Who?, you ask. If the play works, says its star, it shouldn't matter if these names mean anything or not. ``You don't have to know either to enjoy both,'' Lipman said of her solo turn as British actress and revue artist Joyce Grenfell, whom she plays in ``Re:Joyce!'' at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, Conn., through March 4. ``That's going to be the issue, really: whether the show stands or falls on its own merits without pre-knowledge of the lady herself,'' she said. ``It doesn't matter whether audiences know me.'' In Britain, they certainly do. Lipman is as much a household name as was the gawky, angular Grenfell, whose films include ``The Happiest Days of Your Life'' (1950) and ``The Belles of St. Trinian's'' (1954). ``Re:Joyce!'' was one of London's most successful West End plays of the past few seasons. Co-written by Lipman and James Roose-Evans, it began at a suburban theater south of London in February 1988 and opened on the West End that September. It was brought back twice to meet demand, and the 43-year-old Lipman says the show is with her for life. ``I don't suppose I'll ever stop doing it now,'' the actress said over lunch at Elstree studios 13 miles north of London, where she is filming some television commercials for British Telecom. ``I don't like repeating myself, but somehow I feel impassioned to take this show on the road,'' said Lipman, who plans a tour of Britain and Australia following the Long Wharf run. ``I don't think I'm ever going to get a better vehicle, so why should I throw it away?'' Born a tailor's daughter to a middle-class Jewish family in northern England, Lipman acknowledges that her background could not be further removed from her subject's. Actress-comedian Grenfell was a Christian Scientist and, as a niece of the viscountess and member of Parliament Nancy Astor, moved in glittering circles. But Lipman says she and Joyce Grenfell nonetheless have their affinities: ``I did always have a cartoonist's eye, and so did she. It's almost an inability to hear what people say because I'm so fascinated by the way they say it, which is what she had. ``She would much rather be the clown of the class, as I did. .. . She had a very pretty and outgoing mother who was much more attractive than she was. We share that,'' Lipman said of Grenfell, who died in 1979 of eye cancer, at age 69. ``Re:Joyce!'' combines several of Grenfell's best-known sketches _ a nursery school class, a girls' reunion, a Women's Institute meeting _ with songs and occasional commentary. But Lipman said her show ``must not be seen as a piece of whimsy. ... It's very, very delicate. We have found the shape, and it's right.'' The play is one of several activities that have kept the actress busy of late. She starred on British television this fall in ``About Face,'' six original plays, one of which was written by her husband, Jack Rosenthal. Her British Telecom TV commercials have made her Britain's most recognizable Jewish mother. In them, a gray-haired, dowdily dressed Lipman plays the aging Beattie, whose one wish in life is that her son phone more frequently. Her theater credits range from London's best musical revival this decade _ Leonard Bernstein's ``Wonderful Town'' in 1986 _ to the maid in the 1971 production of ``Long Day's Journey Into Night'' with Laurence Olivier and Constance Cummings. Lipman has often visited the United States but has never before performed there, and says she has no desire to be the latest Briton to conquer Broadway. ``I don't think I have the driving ambition to conquer anything except myself,'' she said wryly. ``This is why in a way I'm glad I'm going there in a small theater and quietly, and if they wish to come and see the show and discover it, that's wonderful. If they don't, then it's an experience, and I come home and carry on doing what I'm doing.''

DOC.HEAD: Home Shopping Network Emerges Leaner After Legal Fight
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note Jan. 17 court date in 14th graf. Also on financial wires.
DOC.HEAD: Graphic planned
DOC.TEXT: Not long ago, it looked as if Home Shopping Network Inc.'s picture tube had gone kaput. The television retailer was losing money for the first time. A big lawsuit against GTE Corp. boomeranged into a $100 million libel award for the telecommunications giant. Analysts and investors were ready to play taps for the company that had popularized zirconium cube jewelry peddled live on TV. The tune has changed. Home Shopping Network is rebounding. Its stock has more than doubled since hitting a low of $3 in mid-1989. Sales are setting records. The GTE issue was settled in November for $4.5 million in insurance. What had been diagnosed as a fatal cash hemorrhage turned out to be just a near-death experience that led to some serious rethinking by once-cocky HSN executives. ``The one thing you can say about Home Shopping Network is it takes a licking and keeps on ticking,'' said Peter Grandich, a securities analyst at Affiliated Financial Management Inc. in Howell, N.J. ``After the GTE award, everyone thought the party was over.'' The relatively painless resolution with GTE was a fortuitous boost for the 4-year-old company, now leaner after shedding several unprofitable ventures to concentrate on TV sales operations. But HSN no longer is the undisputed titan of the TV marketplace following the merger of two rivals. It also is engrossed in another courtroom brawl, this time with junk-bond investment firm Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. That battle, which could determine the value of $100 million worth of HSN securities issued in 1986, illustrates the company's crash landing after years of heady expansion. In dispute are bonds that pay interest of 5.5 percent and are convertible to HSN stock. They were an immediate hit, reflecting investor confidence in the Clearwater, Fla.-based company that had dazzled TV viewers with buying opportunities on items ranging from ersatz diamond rings to vitamin pills. The price of HSN shares climbed to $47, making the convertible bonds even more attractive. But rising costs and unprofitable diversification began to erode gains, and the stock weakened. It took a big beating after HSN became mired in the $1.5 billion suit against Stamford, Conn.-based GTE, claiming an inadequate telephone system cost HSN $500 million in business in 1986 and '87. When the date arrived to reset the bond's conversion rate in 1987, HSN shares were worth a fraction of their earlier value. Drexel, the bond's underwriter, negotiated a conversion rate of $7.05 a share, down from the original $28.50. Before the change could take effect, however, HSN sued in federal court in Tampa claiming Drexel artificially manipulated HSN stock down to get the lower conversion price on the bonds. HSN claimed Drexel's motive was to reap huge profits by selling the bonds later if HSN's stock price rose. Drexel is fighting the suit and a hearing is set for Jan. 17 in Tampa federal court. For its fiscal quarter ending Nov. 30, HSN reported sales up 27 percent from a year earlier to a quarterly record $255.2 million. After-tax profit nearly doubled to more than $20 million. ``To paraphrase Twain, `Reports of our death were greatly exaggerated,''' said Nando DiFilippo, HSN's general counsel. HSN also plans to discontinue its financial service operations and scale down a pharmaceutical unit to include only its line of vitamins. HSN now reaches about half the nation's homes via cable or regular channels. ``We're going to stick with the business we do best: video retailing,'' said Les Wandler, HSN's chief financial officer. ``When you have a gold mine, you mine gold. You don't go looking for other business. We learned that.'' The merger of two competitors, CVN Cos. of Minneapolis and QVC Network of West Chester, Pa., could pose a strategic threat to HSN, which tried unsuccessfully in 1987 to merge with CVN. But HSN executives say they aren't worried. ``The more people get used to buying off television, the better off everyone in the industry is,'' Wandler said. Larry Gerbrandt, a media analyst at Paul Kagen Associates in Carmel, Calif., said the HSN stock could dip if bondholders exercise their stock-conversion option once the Drexel suit is resolved. But he said assets such as its St. Petersburg-based studios and cable network give HSN intrinsic value. ``I see HSN well north of $12 a share,'' he said. ``The GTE suit was a misadventure that totally distracted Home Shopping Network from its core business,'' said Gerbrandt. ``They've gotten a second chance.''

DOC.HEAD: Kremlin and Panama Not the Only Places With Palace Intrigues
DOC.TEXT: While attention focused on Mikhail Gorbachev's domestic problems and the U.S. handcuffs on Manuel Noriega, the business world witnessed its own intrigues, which touched two troubled tycoons and products ranging from securities to mushroom soup. Canadian developer Robert Campeau lost more control of his debt-ridden retailing network this past week, while halfway around the globe, money-hungry creditors circled Australian entrepreneur Alan Bond like the toothy sharks of the Great Barrier Reef. At the same time, leadership changes hit Campbell Soup Co., Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. and the Fisher-Price toymaking subsidiary of Quaker Oats Co. None of these developments were related. But they showed how swiftly corporate crises can lead straight to the top, just as the Soviet Union's ethnic unrest has raised speculation about the political future of Gorbachev, and Panama's chaos resulted in the demise of dictator Noriega. For Campeau, the body blows have come one after another in the past several weeks, hitting the Toronto businessman at the height of the holiday shopping season on which his retailing chains depend for survival. National Bank of Canada threw the latest punch, seizing about half his voting shares in the company that bears Campeau's name after he defaulted on loans for which he'd pledged the shares as collateral. The bank's move intensifies pressure on Campeau to restructure or sell the department stores he acquired during the 1980s, which saddled his operations with nearly $8 billion in debt that the businesses are having trouble repaying. The latest development also raised new doubt about the business future of Campeau himself, who has speculated in property for nearly half his 63 years. In Australia, meanwhile, the troubled empire of Alan Bond got more bad news when U.S. investors joined the battle against his Bond Corp. Holdings Ltd., which owns businesses ranging from newspapers to beer breweries and is nearly $6 billion in debt. Bond won a reprieve Friday from a move to liquidate his operations but he still must fend off angry creditors. The senior management changes at Campbell, Shearson and Fisher-Price came as little surprise, because each company's performance has foundered. But for Campbell at least, the appointment of new chief executive David Johnson after a yearlong search could have little bearing on the company's future. Campbell's future could depend on the outcome of infighting among the controlling Dorrance family, some of whom want to sell the business and have made Campbell a takeover target. Shearson, the Wall Street giant known for its solemn ``We Believe'' TV commercials about investing, raised questions about what its top leaders believe themselves. Jeffrey B. Lane, the chief operating officer until he recently was demoted by Chairman Peter A. Cohen in a restructuring, abruptly quit. Cohen had partly blamed Shearson's slumping business on Lane, a longtime friend. Slumping business also felled Fisher-Price's president R. Bruce Sampsell, who quit after a poor Christmas sales performance for the toymaker. Parent company Quaker Oats named experienced manager Paul E. Price to replace him. In other business and economic news this past week: _While domestic automakers flaunted futuristic cars at auto shows in Los Angeles and Detroit, more bad news rolled in about lousy sales and the growing dominance of foreign rivals. Sales of North American-made vehicles plunged in late December, capping a year in which 1 million fewer cars were sold and the first car with a foreign name became the bestseller, Japan's Honda Accord. _Major retailers said pre-Christmas buying boosted sales about 5.5 percent but the gains were uneven, mainly benefiting apparel stores. Some analysts said the sales gains were eroded by aggressive discounting. _Oil prices surged to the highest levels in four years because of cold weather and rising demand. But the long-term outlook for the energy market remained unclear and some petroleum experts predicted prices would decline again soon, lessening the impact on consumers. _Orders to U.S. factories for manufactured goods rose 2.4 percent in November to their second-highest level ever, the Commerce Department reported. Separately, the Labor Department said U.S. unemployment held steady at 5.3 percent in December.

DOC.HEAD: Real Estate Worries Hit Home
DOC.TEXT: The real-estate scare that hit Wall Street in the waning weeks of 1989 now has prompted many analysts to reappraise their economic forecasts for the new year. These observers have set out to look beyond the problems that might arise for builders, brokers, bankers and others whose business fortunes are directly linked to the health of the real estate market. Rather, they are trying to sort out whether weak demand and prices for properties might depress consumer spending in general, and create new difficulties for the Federal Reserve in its effort to avoid a recession. Many analysts maintain that recent talk of a developing downtrend in home prices across the country has been excessive, if not utterly unwarranted. ``Home prices are down in some areas, up in others, and in general disappointing,'' said John Connolly, an analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``They are not crashing, however, despite the tales of woe that are frequently cited. The notion of a housing market disaster doesn't square with the numbers.'' Richard Hoey, economist at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., agrees that the ``worst case'' projections now made in some quarters for real estate are unlikely to come true. But he argues that the mere idea of a letdown in the long-buoyant property market could still have an important emotional impact on the economy and contribute to a recession. ``Real estate is the core of middle-class net worth,'' Hoey observes. ``Negative sentiment on real estate prices can help depress consumer confidence and spending, above and beyond any direct wealth effect from actual price changes.'' When homeowners worry that their houses have become less readily saleable at or near presumed market value, Hoey says, they may decide to spend less and save more of their incomes. ``In this sense,'' he says, ``the psychic liquidity of housing wealth can drop more sharply than average house prices themselves and can rebound more rapidly than house prices themselves. ``We would note that the weakest housing market, the Northeast, is the center not only of the financial community but also of the national media. Thus it is quite possible that the news flow about real estate may be more negative than the reality on a nationwide basis. ``Negative media coverage of real estate price trends is likely to have only a limited impact on the wealth effect but could have a more substantial impact on the psychic liquidity effect.'' Such concerns about the business outlook made their presence felt in the stock market's first trading week of 1990, blunting a strong early rally right after New Year's. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up 56.95 points on Tuesday, showed a net gain for the week of just 20.05, at 2,773.25, by Friday's close. Other readings for the week showed the New York Stock Exchange composite index down .40 at 194.64; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market up 3.40 at 458.22, and the American Stock Exchange market value index up 4.45 at 382.45. Big Board volume averaged 172.48 million shares a day, up from 121.33 million the week before. Whether real estate fears are exaggerated or not, many analysts continue to assert that the situation isn't one to dismiss lightly. ``Since October 1987, Americans have not quite viewed their paper wealth in quite the same way as before,'' say the economists David A. Levy and S. Jay Levy in their business advisory letter Industry Forecast. ``With the boom in real estate prices over in the Northeast and ending in the West, home equity is no longer the rationale for spending freely that it once was.'' Even an optimist like Connolly acknowledges, ``Notwithstanding the numbers, real estate jitters will remain with us until the current economic picture clarifies.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Weekend Editions

DOC.TEXT: Many of the nation's big retailers reported that they got what they expected but not necessarily what they wanted for Christmas: conservative sales growth. General merchandise chains, department stores and discounters on Thursday posted December results that mostly met their expectations for a moderate holiday season. Analysts said the industry was saved from a lackluster sales performance by price discounts, aggressive advertising and special promotions.

Despite concerns that cash-strapped Campeau Corp. might not pay its bills, clothing makers want to maintain ties with the company's retailers because they have been good customers. But their worries are mounting as the financial crisis facing the Canadian retailer and property developer continues dragging on. The National Bank of Canada said Thursday it had seized 13 million shares of Campeau Corp. after a company controlled by Robert Campeau defaulted on loans from the bank.

Overall late-December sales of North American-made vehicles fell 10.5 percent from the same period in 1988, although buyer incentives spurred a rise in light truck sales, the companies reported. The period completed a year that saw annual sales fall by some 1 million vehicles from 1988, and for the first time saw a car with a foreign automaker's nameplate _ the Honda Accord _ become the nation's best-selling car. The figures released Thursday provided further evidence of the industry recession that has especially hit car sales by the Big Three U.S. automakers _ Ford Motor Co., Chrysler Corp. and General Motors Corp.

The Commodity Futures Trading Commission decided to consider placing some restrictions on the controversial practice of dual trading. The five-member CFTC voted unanimously Thursday to take the first step in what may be a long journey toward limiting futures brokers from trading for themselves as well as their customers. Under the decision, a proposed rule that would phase in some limits on dual trading over a 12-month period will be submitted for public comment.

The government makes uncharged and unproven claims of insider trading in its sentencing recommendation for former arbitrager Robert Freeman, according to court documents filed in the controversial Wall Street fraud case. Defense attorneys are seeking to block public release of the memo, in a dispute that hinges on the disclosure of sensitive grand jury matters and has delayed sentencing of the former Goldman, Sachs & Co. executive. The government contends that releasing the memo does not jeopardize grand jury secrecy and shows a broad range of questionable conduct by Freeman that should be considered in sentencing.

Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. paid a $1.3 million fine to the state of Illinois for securities fraud, an administrative penalty stemming from a highly publicized Wall Street corruption case. The negotiated settlement is the biggest such penalty for securities law violations in the state's history, Secretary of State Jim Edgar said Thursday. The settlement also exceeds by nearly $1 million the highest penalty collected by any of the 36 other states with which the brokerage has reached agreements.

Investors who gambled on junk bond mutual funds saw red in 1989, but those sticking with biotechnology companies or fast-growing businesses stood above the heap, according to a tally of the best- and worst- performing mutual funds. The Alger Small Capital fund scored last year's biggest gain, 65.08 percent, through a strategy of picking small companies that showed potential for rapid growth, Lipper Analytical Services Inc. reported Thursday.

A son-in-law in charge of buying and selling land in Phoenix millionaire Charles H. Keating's now-collapsed real estate and savings and loan empire said he was advised by attorneys he did not need appraisals on the deals. Testifying Thursday in Keating's suit to overturn a federal takeover last April of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, Robert M. Wurzelbacher Jr. also said he did not investigate the ability of some buyers of the land to repay loans from the thrift financing the deals.

Alan Bond's struggle for corporate survival edged closer to collapse as U.S. investors joined the battle against Bond Corp. Holdings Ltd. and an Australian Supreme Court said it would rule on a government request to liquidate the company's assets. A ruling in favor of the State Government Insurance Commission, which asked the court to appoint a provisional liquidator, would topple Bond's media, brewing, natural resources and real estate empire. Bond Corp. has asked the court to dismiss the commission's petition.

Stock prices lost ground Thursday amid increasing doubts about the staying power of the rally that greeted the start of 1990. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 13.65 points to 2,796.08. A group of European central banks launched a surprise attack on the dollar that sent the U.S. currency tumbling around the world. Gold prices were mixed. Bond prices were unchanged to marginally higher. Hog and pork belly futures prices shot up their permitted daily limits; oil and orange juice futures turned lower; precious metals advanced strongly; and grains and soybeans were mixed.
