DOC.HEAD: National Bank of Canada Seizes Campeau Stock
With PM-Retail Sales, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The National Bank of Canada said it had seized 13 million shares of Campeau Corp. after a company controlled by Robert Campeau defaulted on loans from the bank. National Bank President Andre Berard said Thursday that Campeau, the chairman of the struggling retailing and developing firm, had personally taken out the loan _ the amount of which was not revealed _ to purchase stock in Campeau Corp. The bank said the 13 million shares, which had been held by Robert Campeau, represented 29 percent`of the voting stock in Campeau Corp. The bank's decision to transfer the stock to its name had nothing to do with the recent deterioration in Campeau Corp. finances, Berard said. ``It's a different matter altogetherl'' he said in a telephone interview. A Campeau Corp. spokeswoman, Carole Sanger, said in Cincinnati, ``It is a personal situation involving the bank and Robert Campeau and it would be inappropriate for the company to comment.'' A reporter calling Robert Campeau's office in Toronto was referred to Ms. Sanger. National Bank said it had also seized about $60 million in debentures that it held as security and has taken steps to have transferred to its name another 4 million of Campeau Corp.'s subordinate preference shares. The bank said in a statement the shares were provided as collateral by Robert Campeau Capital Inc. and a second company. The latter firm had received the loan from the National Bank. National Bank said its action ``aims at consolidating its position'' pending the outcome of restructuring negotiations for Campeau's Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. in the United States. Berard said the bank wanted the parties involved in those talks to be aware that it now owned the stock. On Tuesday, a syndicate of banks led by Citibank agreed not to declare Federated and Allied in technical default on $2.34 billion in loans. The syndicate agreed not to press the point before Jan. 15, giving Campeau more time to show it is making progress`in sorting out its financial problems. The bankers previously said they might ask for full repayment of the loan, a demand that presumably could have forced Campeau to file for protection under U.S. bankruptcy laws. In exchange for the delay, Federated agreed to pay off a $250 million bridge loan. Campeau Corp., which owns 258 stores, went heavily into debt to buy Federated for`$6.6 billion in 1988 and to take over Allied at a cost of $3.4 billion in 1986. The company announced in September it was having trouble making its interest payments. Besides the bank loans, the company must pay interest on approximately $7 billion in high-yield junk bonds it sold to finance the buyouts. Campeau is trying to sell its star Bloomingdale's department store chain. National Bank said the voting rights on the stock will now be exercised by National Bank representatives, the bank said. Berard said in a statement the bank does not intend to dispose of the Campeau securities or acquire additional ones. Beside's Bloomingdale's, Federated's divisions include Abraham & Strauss, Burdines, Lazarus, and Rich's. Allied's divisions are Jordan Marsh, Stern's, Maas, Jordan Marsh Florida, and The Bon Marche.

DOC.HEAD: MCI, Mexican Phone Company Sign Agreement
DOC.TEXT: MCI Communications Corp. and Telefonos de Mexico SA have signed an agreement to provide direct voice and other telecommunications services between the United States and Mexico. The accord, announced Thursday, marks the first time in its history that Telefonos de Mexico has connected its Mexican network with more than one U.S. carrier for the provision of voice services, MCI said. American Telephone & Telegraph Co., MCI's biggest competitor, has been the only U.S. company in that position for several years. MCI and Telefonos de Mexico expect to begin providing voice service early next week. Under the operating agreement, MCI also will provide to the Mexican company certain MCI training programs and technical expertise. There is no monetary value attached to the agreement, said Jane Levene, an MCI spokeswoman.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Plans to Become Major Steel Exporter, Minister Says
DOC.TEXT: Iran is set to become a major steel exporter through plans to invest 1 trillion rials, or around $15 billion, in the steel sector, an Iranian minister`said. Musa Lankarani, deputy mines and metals minister, was quoted Thursday by the official Islamic Republic News Agency as saying that a major part of that amount already has been invested. Several steel plants will become operational during the first 5-year development plan, Lankarani was quoted as saying by IRNA, monitored in Nicosia. He said once all the projects are completed Iranian steel production will reach 7 million tons a year. Iran currently has to import steel. President Hashemi Rafsanjani said during a visit to the Ahvaz steel complex`in southern Khuzestan province last month that Iran currently needs 6 million tons of steel a year. He added that the government had paid special attention to the steel sector in its 5-year plan and should ``strive for exporting steel.'' A steel mill in the southern city of Isfahan, the largest in the country, is currently being expanded with Soviet assistance and its eventual capacity has been estimated at 4 million tons a year. A Soviet-Iranian economic cooperation agreement signed by Rafsanjani in Moscow last September also envisages the construction of steel rolling mills in Khorassan, Hormozgan and Azerbaijan provinces.

DOC.HEAD: Avon: No Longer Exploring Sale of Giorgio Fragrance Division
DOC.TEXT: Cosmetics maker Avon Products Inc. said it has given up the idea of selling its Giorgio Beverly Hills retail fragrance division. A company spokeswoman said Thursday that potential buyers didn't offer adequate amounts. The company also said the sale of its smaller retail subsidiary, Parfums Stern, has been completed. Parfums Stern was bought for $210 million in cash by Safrep, an affiliate of Sanofi, the diversified French company specializing in perfumes and beauty products, pharmaceuticals and food ingredients. Parfums Stern markets the Oscar de la Renta, Cher, Perry Ellis and Deneuve fragrances. They will be added to Sanofi's stable of well-known beauty product brands including Nina Ricci and Stendhal. Sanofi, which has annual sales of more than $2 billion, is part of the Societe National Elf Acquitaine Group. Proceeds from the sale of Parfums Stern will go toward reducing Avon's debt, the company said in a news release. Avon previously had said its debt totaled $1 billion at mid-year. Avon decided to stop exploring the possibility of selling Giorgio Beverly Hills when it didn't receive high enough bids. ``We had some interested bidders,'' Avon spokeswoman Elaine Benvenuto said. ``We didn't think the offers reflected the inherent value of the company.'' She declined to disclose how much Avon waned for the division that markets the Giorgio Beverly Hills and Red fragrance lines, among the country's hottest sellersn Giorgio and Parfums Stern were together expected to do $300 million in sales for 1988, Avon said when it first announced it might sell the subsidiaries. Avon didn't provide separate sales estimates for each one. Avon, known chiefly as a direct marketer of cosmetics and other personal products, announced in September that it was looking into the sale of Giorgio and Parfums Stern. At the time, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer James E. Preston said a final decision hadn't been reached to divest the two retail holdings. The reduction of debt has been part of Avon's plan to improve its balance sheet. The company has sold off its health care services subsidiaries to focus on its core direct-marketing business. The strategy aimed at improving profitability was accelerated last year when Avon became a takeover target.

DOC.HEAD: Typesetter Settles SEC Charges
DOC.TEXT: A typesetting company worker accused in the Business Week insider trading investigation has settled civil charges that he illegally traded on confidential information from advance copies of the magazine. Without admitting or denying guilt, the defendant, John Joseph Lynch, agreed Thursday to pay more than $44,000 in alleged illegal profits, interest and fines to the Securities and Exchange Commission. Lynch, 29, of Leonia, N.J., works for Applied Graphics Technology of Carlstadt, N.J., where Business Week is typeset. He was suspended with pay after the SEC charges were filed Nov. 30. The civil SEC complaint alleged that between April and November, Lynch purchased securities of at least 22 companies he knew would be mentioned in upcoming editions of Business Week. The SEC said Lynch passed on tips to his girlfriend and her family, who also traded on the information but were not charged. The case against Lynch was of interest because the alleged illegal trades took place long after the SEC settled several similar, highly publicized cases. The Business Week investigation also resulted in criminal cases. S.G. (Rudy) Ruderman, a former Business Week broadcast editor, and William Dillon, a former Merrill Lynch & Co. stockbroker, both pleaded guilty to trading on advance information and were sentenced to six months in prison. Lynch's settlement calls for him to pay back his and his girlfriend's alleged illegal profits of $30,324 and $1,067 in interest. He also was fined $14,768.

DOC.HEAD: Retailers Post Moderate December Sales Gains
With BC-Retail Sales-Table
DOC.TEXT: Price cuts, an advertising blitz and special promotions helped the nation's major retailers ring up moderate holiday sales gains. But the results reported Thursday by the nation's major retailers confirmed that this past Christmas was a time of conservative spending compared to Christmas 1988. General merchandise chains, department stores and discounters posted December results that mostly met their expectations _ a fairly unexciting holiday season. Walter Loeb of the investment firm Morgan Stanley & Co. estimated that industrywide sales grew about 5 percent in December compared with the same month a year earlier, down from a 7.5 percent`increase in December 1988. The performances differed depending on the type of retailer, while various regional factors, such as the weather, also had an impact. Store executives generally expressed satisfaction with their results. But some retailers said they didn't get as much as they had anticipated for Christmas. Retailers' sales are considered an indicator of total consumer spending, which accounts for the bulk of the nation's economic activity. The holidays are a crucial time for retailers because half or more of their profits come from sales between Thanksgiving and Christmas. Worried about softness in consumer spending, this past year retailers poured on the promotions, many offering big pre-Christmas bargains. ``If the retailer hadn't had the hook out he wouldn't have had any customers in the stores,'' said Loeb, only half-jokingly. Still, he said, sales were a bit better than he had expected. Unusually cold weather in parts of the country spurred purchases of warm clothing and automotive products. Car batteries and snow tires were mentioned as fast sellers by some general merchandise chains _ but the items weren't meant for under the Christmas tree. One of the most upbeat assessments came from Kenneth A. Macke, chairman and chief executive officer of Dayton Hudson Corp., who said solid gains at all divisions were ``more encouraging because they came on top of a strong December'' in 1988. Dayton Hudson, owner of department stores plus the Target discount chain, reported an overall increase of 15.1 percent. Contrary to the industry trend, Macke said, Dayton Hudson was slightly less promotional than the year before. Analysts said Dayton Hudson probably had a more profitable season than many other retailers that relied heavily on markdowns to attract customers. Price cutting is assumed to have taken a bite out of profits but earnings won't suffer too much, thanks to tight inventory and other cost controls as well as fairly low inflation, analysts said. Stores catering to clothing shoppers fared better than mass merchants that have much of their business devoted to expensive durable goods, such as stereos, televisions or home appliances. The large specialty apparel retailer Limited Inc. reported an 11 percent gain in December sales. But not counting stores opened in the past year, Limited's sales rose a more moderate 5 percent. Retailers and industry analysts attach greater significance to tallies that exclude newly opened stores. Results at stores open at least a year, called comparable- or same-store sales, are considered a better guide to a retailer's health. The biggest retailer in the country, Sears, Roebuck and Co., had a mediocre showing but it probably wasn't any worse than the company's internal forecasts. A low pricing policy adopted last March to help Sears compete with faster growing discount rivals has cut into Sears' results. Sears said its sales rose 3.6 percent in the five weeks ended December 30 to $4.696 billion from $4.53 billion a year earlier. But on a same-store basis Sears eked out only a 1.6 percent gain. Among other retailers reporting Thursday: K mart Corp., which ranks second behind Sears based on 1988 annual revenue, said its December sales rose 11.8 percent to $5.12 billion from $4.58 billion a year earlier. Its same-store sales rose 3.1 percent. Fast-growing Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the third largest U.S. retailer, posted a 22 percent overall December sales gain, to $3.63 billion from the year-earlier's $2.97 billion, and an 8 percent same-store sales increase. Among stores that predominantly sell apparel: J.C. Penney Co. Inc. said its sales rose 9.7 percent to $2.72 billion from $2.48 billion in December 1988. Comparable-store sales were up 8.6 percent. May Department Stores Co. said its sales rose 8.7 percent to $1.80 billion from $1.65 billion and same-store sales were up 5.9 percent. Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. reported sales rose 3.5 percent to $531.4 million from $513.4 million. The same-store gain was 3 percent. Philip M. Hawley, chairman and chief executive officer of the West Coast retailer, said sales were slightly below the planned amount due to unseasonable weather in parts of California and elsewhere.

DOC.HEAD: Sales Skid Again, But Not Trucks; Accord is Best Seller in 1989
DOC.TEXT: Late-December`car and truck sales dropped 10.5 percent, while for the first time, a vehicle with a foreign nameplate has become the best-seller of the year in the United States. Americans bought more Honda Accords in 1989 than any other automobile, according to figures released Thursday. ``Obviously, we're real pleased about it,'' said American Honda Motor Co. spokesman Bob Butorac. About 60 percent of Honda's Accords sold in the United States were built at the company's plant in Marysville, Ohio. The rest were built in Japan. For the year, U.S. and foreign automakers said their U.S. sales of cars and light trucks fell 5.5 percent from 1988, to 14.6 million from 15.4 million. Americans bought 362,707 Accords last year, topping the Ford Taurus`at 348,061 and the Ford Escort, last year's sales leader, at 333,535. Rounding out the top five were the Chevrolet Corsica and Beretta, which are variations on the same model, at 326,006 and the Chevrolet Cavalier at 295,715. ``We're not talking about a car that is particularly stylish,'' auto analyst Joseph Phillippi of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. in New York said of the Accord. ``But it's a supremely competent vehicle, it does everything very well.'' The eight major automakers`with U.S. assembly plants said they sold cars and light trucks at an average daily rate of 39,798 during Dec. 21-31, compared with a rate of 44,477 during the same time the year before. The late-December skid was softened by strong light-truck sales by Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp., both of which placed incentives on their popular minivans in the middle of the month. General Motors Corp. didn't follow suit. Car sales tumbled 20.2 percent but truck sales, bolstered by the minivan rebates and low-interest`loan deals, soared 10 perent. In mid- and late-December 1988, automakers loaded their dealers with lots of incentive cash to move cars off showroom floors by year's end. The selling rate for late December 1988 was the highest for that year. Despite the decline in year-to-year comparisons between the periods, Phillippi said: ``Incentives work on everything. The (selling) pace picked up nicely in the last 10 days.'' In mid-December 1989, Chrysler slapped incentives on a variety of its vehicles, including, for the first time, rebates on the Dodge Caravan and Plymouth Voyager minivans. Ford followed suit with incentives on its Aerostar minivan. Chrysler's light truck sales jumped 19.8 percent in late December while Ford's rose 16.1 percent. Meanwhile, truck sales by GM, which did not have new incentives in December, slipped 1.6 percent. Overall, 1989 appeared to be the automakers' seventh-best sales year, pending release of heavy-truck sales figures. Including heavy-truck sales, the automakers sold 15.8 million vehicles in 1988. Final 1989 sales of the big rigs won't be completed until later, but if past selling patterns hold, automakers will wind up selling about 1 million fewer vehicles in 1989 than in 1988. The industry's best year was in 1986, when 16.3 million vehicles were sold. ``It's been two years since the industry peaked and that suggests that we're closer to the trough,'' said auto analyst Doug Laughlin of Bear, Stearns & Co. of New York. During the past several months, auto executives and others have speculated that the first half of 1990 would be a weak period, with a rebound coming in the second half of the year. ``It's already starting to be a rather lengthy downturn in autos,'' Laughlin said. ``The duration of the industry downturn has been about 2 to 2{ years.'' The current slide in auto sales began in October. Chrysler, which used incentives extensively in 1989, reported a 2.1 percent decline in late-December total vehicle sales compared with the same period in 1988. Car sales at the nation's No. 3 automaker were down 24.1 percent. For all of 1989, Chrysler's combined car and truck sales`were down 7.1 percent compared with 1988. Ford said its cars and trucks sold at a pace 9.5 percent slower in late December than during the same period in 1988. Car sales fell 22.4 percent. Ford's vehicle sales in 1989 showed a 3.9 percent decline compared with 1988 sales. GM said its combined car and truck sales for late-December last year came in 21.3 percent behind the swollen period in 1988. Car sales were down 29 percent. For 1989, GM's car and light truck sales ran 6.7 percent behind the pace set in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Futures Regulators Consider Dual Trading Limits
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators have taken the first, tentative step in what may be a long journey toward barring brokers from trading for themselves as well as their customers. The practice is known as dual trading, and while legal it has been controversial in the wake of fraud scandals at the nation's two largest futures exchanges. Officials of those exchanges, the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, immediately criticized the move Thursday by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. The federal agency voted to consider placing some restrictions on dual trading on some contracts at the seven largest futures exchanges. The five-member CFTC, which oversees the futures industry, voted unanimously to submit for public comment a proposed rule that would phase in some limits on dual trading over a 12-month period. Critics claim dual trading creates the potential for conflicts of interest and possible fraud. Supporters, however, say dual trading helps keep markets liquid _ and thus less volatile _ when there are few customer orders. Not all futures exchanges would be affected by the proposed rules change, which may not win final approval for as much as a year. Upon approval, the initial dual trading restrictions will be reviewed and the CFTC will consider extending or easing those limits, said Chairwoman Wendy Gramm. ``We do intend to proceed carefully and thoughtfully in that process,'' she said. The CFTC also voted unanimously to accept a staff recommendation that the agency keep closer tabs on ``broker associations'' to prevent possible trading abuses such as those undercovered in Chicago last year. In November, the CFTC released a study disputing the economic benefits of dual trading. But Commissioner Robert Davis, who reluctantly agreed to submit the proposal for public comment _ as a way of obtaining more data _ expressed reservations about making a decision based on a single study. ``Before tampering with the formula, other hypotheses must be tested, other data must be analyzed and alternative explanations of the results must be considered,'' he said. Legislation that would severely limit dual trading is pending in both the House and Senate. The proposal would bar floor brokers from trading or placing futures or options orders for their own accounts while handling a customer's order on the same day in the same commodity. The Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, which account for about 90 percent of the nation's futures trading volume, would each be required to impose dual trading restrictions on just one of their three most actively traded agricultural commodities and their single-most active financial commodityn Five other exchanges _ the New York Mercantile Exchange, the Commodity Exchange Inc., the Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange Inc., the MidAmerica Commodity Exchange and the New York Cotton Exchange _ would have to impose restrictions on only one of their two most active commodities. And four smaller exchanges _ the Kansas City Board of Trade, Minneapolis Grain Exchange, New York Futures Exchange and the Chicago Rice and Cotton Exchange _ would be exempt from restrictions during the implementation period. CBOT President and Chief Executive Thomas R. Donovan said: ``There are futures exchanges developing all around the world and most allow dual trading. If we cannot handle customer business because of ill-founded restrictions on trading, then we will lose that business to our foreign competitors.'' Added CBOT Chairman Karsten Mahlmann, ``The CFTC's proposal to ban dual trading flies in the face of the evidence of its own study, which shows benefits from dual trading and which provides no evidence that dual trading imposes costs or harms customers.'' On broker associations, the CFTC staff recommended adopting a rule defining the term and requiring exchanges to register the members of such associations. The commission's Division of Trading and Markets said registration of broker association members would allow exchanges to monitor their trading activity as a safeguard against abuses. Broker associations are formal or informal groups of futures traders formed to provide more capital to finance trades and more people to handle them. Supporters of broker associations claim they help service customer orders by increasing the capital of individual brokers and providing continuous service. But the CFTC staff found that broker associations ``may increase the potential for certain types of trading abuses.'' The CFTC study was an outgrowth of last year's undercover investigation of trading at the two Chicago exchanges that resulted in scores of indictments.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Says Records Set In New Investigations, Recalls
DOC.TEXT: The government opened a record number of investigations of possible automobile safety defects in 1989, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said. The agency said Thursday it had begun 213 defect investigations last year, the most in its 20-year`history. Additionally, the agency said it`influenced a record 77 percent of the recalls ordered in 1989. A total of 6.7 million vehicles were recalled for safety problems. ``An aggressive safety`defects program is essential to our safety mission,'' said Jerry R. Curry, administrator of the agency. But the Center for Auto Safety, a group founded by consumer advocate Ralph Nader, accused the agency of reporting meaningless statistics to mask poor performance. ``Those are phony numbers,'' said Clarence Ditlow, the center's executive director. ``What they're doing is creating a smokescreen to conceal from the public that they're not enforcing the mandatory recall law.'' The center repeatedly has complained that under the Reagan administration, the agency abandoned investigations that should have produced recalls. The agency said it pursued recalls when needed but discontinued probes when it was plain there was no widespread safety problem. Ditlow said the agency should not boast of influencing the highest percentage of recalls ever when the number of recalls was well below those of the late 1970s. Jeffrey Miller, deputy administrator of the agency, said Ditlow's comments were ``patent nonsense.'' Miller acknowledged that recalls rose in the late 1970s and fell in the early 1980s, but said both trends were largely the result of tire problems that were corrected. There was a steady`upward trend in recalls in the late 1980s, he said. ``We have an active, robust investigation which takes consumer complaints very seriously and looks at them and evaluates them all fairly,'' Miller said. Recalls ordered last year, Curry said, included 1.7 million General Motors vehicles to correct sticking throttles, 1.4 million Ford Escorts`to fix a problem with the driver's seat, and 650,000 Chrysler vehicles and 481,000 Escorts to prevent engine oil leaks. Also recalled were 500,000 Chrysler vehicles to fix front-suspension corrosion and 408,000 Toyota Camrys to repair jamming safety belts.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Proposes Gasoline Evaporation Regulations
DOC.TEXT: The Environmental Protection Agency has proposed regulations to reduce hydrocarbon releases from cars and trucks when gasoline evaporates. Proposed changes in how vehicle emission tests are to be run would require automakers to modify vehicle emission control equipment in a way that atmospheric hydrocarbon levles would fall about 5 percent, the agency said Thursday. The modifications are said to be minor and should add only about $10 to the cost of a car, an amount that would be more than offset by better fuel economy, according to the EPA. Hydrocarbons, or volatile organic compounds, released from motor vehicles react with the sun to form ozone. When also combined with particulates in the air, the result is the smog that plagues many of the nation's urban centers. The regulatory proposal announced Thursday applies only to hydrocarbon releases from the normal evaporation of gasoline, especially`in hot weather, both when a vehicle is running and when it is idle. The proposal would require emissions testing procedures to be changed to assure that such evaporated fuel losses are better controlled, especially during summer driving and after a vehicle has been idle for a day or more. In some cases, automakers are expected to equip vehicles with larger charcoal cannisters so emission control systems are not overloaded by gasoline vapors or make other changes to improve the system's ability to purge such vapors when a car is running, officials said. The new requirements, when made final later this year, will apply to all gasoline-fueled passenger cars and trucks.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Rejected Recycling Tax
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration considered but rejected the idea of proposing new taxes on various materials in an effort to encourage recycling, an administration official said. The official, who spoke Thursday on condition that he not be named, said the proposal had been given a good chance of becoming part of the president's fiscal 1991 budget request to Congress but that it was finally rejected by the Office of Management and Budget. OMB Director Richard Darman stripped the proposed tax _ along with other so-called ``user fees'' _ to avoid charges from congressional Democrats that President`Bush was violating his no-new-taxes pledge, the official said. The proposal would have imposed new taxes on paper, glass, plastic and metals that were not recycled. The Environmental Protection Agency, which favored the tax concept as a way of encouraging greater use of recycled materials by U.S. industry, wants to reduce the nation's output of waste by 25 percent`by 1992. Bush, as part of his 1988 presidential campaign, promised to ``make a national commitment to reduce waste by recycling and developing technology that produces less waste.'' By making products`made from virgin materials more expensive, supporters of the tax had argued it would encourage businesses to use more recycled materials. Another revenue raiser rejected by the administration in recent days would have imposed a sales tax on off-road vehicles, camping equipment, motor homes and pleasure boats. Supporters of that rejected proposal wanted to have the new revenue earmarked for specific recreation and conservation programs on federal lands, but it, too, fell victim to Darman's concern that critics would charge the president with violating his pledge against new taxes. The various decisions on spending and taxes are being made as the administration puts the finishing touches on a proposed $1.23 trillion budget for the fiscal year beginning next October. The budget will be sent to Congress on Jan. 29.

DOC.HEAD: Mutual Funds In '89: Bad Year For `Junk,' Good For Biotech, Growth Companies
DOC.TEXT: For mutual fund investors, 1989 was a banner year for biotechnology and growth companies but a waste of time when it came to many bonds. A tally of the best- and worst-performing mutual funds released today by Lipper Analytical Services Inc. says the Alger Small Capital fund scored last year's biggest gain, 65.08 percent. The fund made money through a strategy of picking small companies that showed potential for rapid growth. In the cellar was Strategic Gold-Minerals, with a 17.75 percent loss due largely to its investments in coal mines that went sour, although most funds specializing in gold performed well for the year. Many of last year's losers were concentrated in fixed-income investments, particularly in high-yield, high-risk junk bonds, or in the world income category, which includes funds in overseas bonds denominated by fluctuating currencies. Among junk bond funds are the Dean Witter High Yield fund, which declined 13.64 percent; Alliance Bond: High Fund, down 12.94 percent; and American Capital High Yield, down 12.04 percent. Performance figures in Lipper's rankings of 1,683 continuing funds for 1989 assume that investors reinvest all dividends`and capital gains distributions paid by the funds. A. Michael Lipper, the firm's president, said 1989 was a surprisingly good year for stock funds even though the economyM muddled along. ``You had a nice recovery in 1988 (after the 1987 stock market crash), but you developed real strength in 1989 that was`somewhat surprising,'' Lipper said in an interview Thursday. ``If the gains had been half of what they were a number of people probably would have been happy.'' Equity fund gains averaged nearly 24 percent last year, compared with 9.42 percent for fixed-income funds. Stocks also did well for the entire decade, with equity funds gaining an average 322 percent. Although a number of individual funds sustained losses in 1989, all of the 22 fund categories had a positive overall performance for the year, with an average gain of 18.48 percent, according to Lipper. But the gap between the top and bottom performers was wide. Health and biotechnology funds were the leaders of 1989 with average gains of 43.5 percent, while world income funds eked out a 6.02 percent average gain. Lipper said the biotechnology and health industry was ``an area that continues to grow at a much faster rate than the rest of the economy.'' ``We've seen some mergers and new drugs during 1989. It's a worldwide business,'' he said. Rounding out the top five mutual funds were: natural resources funds, up 32.13 percent; utility funds, 28.96 percent; growth funds, 25.44 percent; and capital appreciation funds, 23.81 percent. Among the bottom five, fixed income funds, including junk bond funds, gained an average 9.42 percent; option income funds, 12.45 percent; and convertible securities funds and mixed income funds, each up 13.84 percent. By comparison, the Dow Jones industrial average of 30 blue-chip stocks had a rate of return of 31.64 percent and the S&P 500 index had a rate of return of 32.24 percent for the year, assuming dividend reinvestment.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyers Seek To Block New Allegations in Freeman Case
DOC.TEXT: Attorneys for admitted inside trader Robert Freeman are seeking to block the government from making public a sentencing recommendation that alleges a series of new and unproven fraudulent transactions. The government also names several individuals`in the memo who allegedly lied during the 2{-year grand jury investigation of the Freeman case, according to documents filed in Manhattan federal court. The dispute hinges on the disclosure of sensitive grand jury matters and has delayed sentencing of the former head of arbitrage at Goldman, Sachs & Co., arrested in 1987 in a highly publicized case that later fell flat. The government contends that releasing the memo shows`a broad range of questionable conduct by Freeman that should be considered in sentencing. Freeman has admitted to one instance of insider trading. ``In connection with his sentencing, Freeman loudly contends that this was the only occasion in which he engaged in insider trading,'' Assistant U.S. Attorney John McEnany wrote. ``The government has evidence to the contrary which it believes the court should consider ...'' The issue marks another twist in a case that began with the touted February 1987 arrests of Freeman and two others based on information linked to jailed inside trader Ivan Boesky. Government prosecutors boasted that initial charges were ``the tip of the iceberg.'' But the indictments later were dropped and prosecutors last year abandoned an investigation of the two other Wall Street traders, Timothy Tabor and Richard Wigton. Wigton even was handcuffed after his arrest. The case now is widely viewed as the government's biggest embarrassment in the three-year insider trading investigation begun by former U.S. Attorney Rudolph Giuliani. In a draft of the sentencing memo given to defense lawyers, prosecutors allege a series of insider trading transactions beyond the one Freeman admitted, attorneys Paul Curran and Robert B. Fiske state in court documents. The sentencing report has not been filed, pending a ruling by U.S. District Judge Pierre Leval on whether it should be kept under seal or allowed into the public record. ``The government's allegations are false and they unfairly implicate not only Mr. Freeman but also other persons, none of whom has been charged with respect to these allegations,'' Curran and Fiske state in a motion seeking to seal the memo. The government and The Wall Street Journal have filed papers arguing that the sentencing document should be released. Freeman pleaded guilty last August to one count of mail fraud for using inside information in January 1986 to trade in connection with the proposed takeover of Beatrice Cos. by the investment firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. He admitted receiving the information from former Kidder, Peabody & Co. investment banker Martin A. Siegel, who has pleaded guilty to two counts and is awaiting sentencing. Freeman's lawyers contend that`only material dealing with the Beatrice transaction should be made public. ``Freeman is someone who cares about his reputation. If he is seen as someone who has been trading with the abandon of an Ivan Boesky, he'll be unemployable,'' said John C. Coffee Jr., a Columbia University securities law professor. In court papers filed last month, attorneys for Freeman charge that the sentencing report will ``tarnish Mrn Freeman's already scarred reputation and cause serious injury to the reputation of others.'' ``Some individuals are branded as liars. Still others are accused of insider trading,'' the lawyers state. ``The stigma that the publication of such accusations would impose is irrevocable ...'' The sentencing memo reportedly cites about a dozen instances of uncharged insider trading by Freeman, including two named in his original indictment, and includes the names of some who testified before the grand jury. Under existing case law, grand jury secrecy protects defendants from disclosure of accusations that are not contained in an indictment returned by the panel, which determines whether or what criminal charges can be filed. In the Freeman case, the government acknowledges that a ``significant portion'' of the memo relies on grand jury matters but that no testimony is directly quoted and the information is merely summarized. McEnany stated the government agreed only not to prosecute Freeman for other matters uncovered in its investigation. The Supreme Court has allowed sentencing judges to consider alleged conduct that a defendant has not been convicted of or admitted to. Freeman faces a maximum five years in prison and up to $1.9 million in fines.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed; Gold Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed in European trading this morning as speculators retreated in the face of central bank interventions. Gold was higher. Currency traders in Milan said any speculative initiatives had been quashed by central bank intervention, particularly moves by the West German Bundesbank on Thursday. ``The market is walking very cautiously, stepping gingerly, like the Pink Panther,'' said one trader in Milan. News that Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev had canceled meetings with foreign visitors to concentrate on domestic problems sent Japan's stock exchange into a skid and halted a rapid drop in the dollar's value against the yen. Naoki Kiyohara, chief of currency options at Fuji Bank, said the Bank of Japan intervened several times in the afternoon in an attempt to drive the dollar below 144 yen, but the news about Gorbachev was the most influential factor in weakening the currency. The dollar finished the day in Tokyo at 144.15 yen, down 1.05 yen from Thursday's close. Later, in London, it fell to 144.06 yen. In London, the British pound fell to $1.6234 from $1.6290 late Thursday. Other mid-morning dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.6880 West German marks, up from 1.6825; 1.5438 Swiss francs, down from 1.5722; 5.7556 French francs, up from 5.7500; 1.9058 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9275; 1,267.00 Italian lire, up from 1,265.25; and 1.1600 Canadian dollars, unchanged. London's gold dealers fixed a recommended price of $401.20 an ounce this morning, up from Thursday's late bid price of $395.00. In Zurich, the metal rose to a bid of $401.00, from $395.70 bid late Thursday. Gold in Hong Kong rose the equivalent of $6.03 an ounce today, to close at $400.92. Silver bullion rose in London to a bid price of $5.28 a troy ounce, from $5.16 bid late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Japan's Asahi Breweries To Produce Beer In U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Asahi Breweries Ltd., the third largest beer producer in Japan, announced Friday the company plans to build a plant in the United States and produce its ``Super Dry'' beer, one of the company's largest exports. Asahi is planning to invest about 10 billion yen, or about $70 million at Friday's exchange rate, to build a plant near Denver, Colo., in April, aiming to complete it by the end of 1991, said a company official who declined to be named, in accordance with Japanese practice. The company currently exports ``Super Dry'' through its wholly owned subsidiary Asahi Breweries U.S.A., Inc. The product sold about 4,300 kiloliters in the United States in 1989. Overall U.S. beer consumption was 1.3 billion kiloliters to 1.4 billion kiloliters last year, the official said. One kiloliter is equal to 264 gallons. The company expects sales of the beer to increase in the future, the official said. The new plant will be capable of producing up to 12,700 kiloliters a year, which is about 10 percent of the amount currently produced at the company's plant in Japan. Asahi plans to increase the capacity of the U.S. plant five times within three years of completion of construction, the official said. The beer initially will be marketed mainly in California, and later in other states, Asahi said.

DOC.HEAD: December Unemployment Steady at 5.3 Percent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 4th graf, The unemployment, with quote from Labor official; INSERTS 2 grafs after pvs 8th graf, The economy, with quote from private analyst
DOC.TEXT: The nation's unemployment rate held steady at 5.3 percent in December, ending 1989 at about where it began, despite weaker-than-average job growth in the final month of the year, the government said today. The civilian jobless rate as measured by a household survey by the Labor Department was unchanged despite the gain of 142,000 jobs in December, a figure artificially bolstered by the return of 55,000 striking telephone workers in New York. The survey of employers, from which the job growth figure is derived, is often considered a more reliable indicator of economic developments by analysts. The unemployment rate began 1989 at 5.4 percent in January and since then has fluctuated in a narrow range within a tenth of a percentage point of 5.3 percent, except for March when it dipped to a 15-year low of 5 percent. The average for the year was 5.3 percent. ``In fact, the jobless rate remained markedly stable during the whole year of 1989,'' Janet L. Norwood, commissioner of labor statistics, noted. Last month, the Labor Department said the November unemployment rate was 5.4 percent, but today it revised that figure down to 5.3 percent. The unemployment stall in 1989 was due primarily to a slowdown in the manufacturing sector, which lost 25,000 jobs in December, bringing job losses since March to 195,000. Overall job growth during the last six months of the year averaged around 160,000 a month, down sharply from the average 270,000 monthly gain during the previous 2{ years. The economy, according to the household survey, produced 1.7 million new jobs during 1989, bringing the civilian workforce to 117.9 million. That was down from job gains of 2.3 million in 1988. Economist Michael K. Evans, who heads a consulting firm in Washington, said the unemployment rate has remained stable because the total available labor force has been growing more slowly at the same time fewer new jobs are becoming available. ``Things are in balance. It's a pretty healthy situation,'' he said. More manufacturing layoffs are expected. Automakers have already announced plant shutdowns this month. The average manufacturing work week held steady in December at 40.7 hours, as did overtime at 3.7 hours. Construction employers reported a seasonally adjusted 38,000 fewer jobs in December than a month earlier. Analysts are attributing the drop to the deep freeze that gripped most of the nation last month. In contrast, service-producing industries continued to demonstrate healthy gains, adding 206,000 jobs to bring growth for the year to 2.4 million. Transportation employers added 73,000 jobs on a seasonally adjusted basis last month. Business services added 14,000, health services, 47,000; government, 34,000; and finance, insurance and real estate, 13,000. Retail employment grew by 12,000 fewer jobs than the normally expected seasonal gain. Mining industries, which includes oil drilling, lost 1,000 jobs. Average hourly earnings posted a 0.6 percent rise in December to $9.84, bringing the gain for the year to 4.1 percent. That wasn't enough to keep up with consumer price inflation, which has been running at about 4.5 percent. The unemployment rates among major demographic groups last month were: _Adult white men, 3.9 percent, the same as in November. _Adult white women, 4.1 percent, up from 4.0 percent. _White teen-agers, 13.0 percent, up from 12.9 percent. _All blacks, 11.8 percent, down from 11.9 percent. _Adult black men, 10.8 percent, up from 10.6 percent. _Adult black women, 10.0 percent, down from 10.2 percent. _Black teen-agers, 30.7 percent, down from 32.5 percent. _Hispanics, 8.5 percent, up from 8.0 percent. In a separate calculation of unemployment that counts members of the armed services stationed in the United States, the December jobless rate was 5.3 percent, the same as November. The rates were also the same as the civilian rate.

DOC.HEAD: Three Countries Deny Entry To Stricken Iranian Tanker
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Spanish government confirming refusal to grant access to ship, comment from Spanish government spokeswoman. Pickup penultimate graf pvs, `Aqazadeh said...
DOC.TEXT: A crippled Iranian tanker that spilled 19 million gallons of oil off the Moroccan coast was turned away today by Portugal, the third country to refuse entry to the ship. A Portuguese navy patrol boat escorted the Khark 5 away from the Portuguese island of Madeira after the tanker entered its territorial waters there, the national news agency Lusa said today. The salvage company Smit Tak, which is commanding the three tugs towing the Khark 5, said it planned to take the tanker to the Cape Verde islands, through more than 1,200 miles of open seas. Cape Verde is a former Portuguese colony off the West African coast. Smit Tak has been trying to find a safe haven for the Khark 5 since an explosion ripped through the ship's hull Dec. 19 when it was 400 miles north of Las Palmas in Spain's Canary Islands. Morocco, 400 miles west, refused to let the tanker dock there, and a 100-square-mile oil slick threatened Morocco's coastline. Pollution experts said Thursday nearly all the oil had dissipated and that there was no danger of an environmental disaster. At a weekly Cabinet meeting today, the Spanish government confirmed an earlier decision to deny a request to tow the 1,837-foot tanker to sheltered waters off the southern coast of Tenerife in the Canary Islands. Smit Tak said the tanker is no longer leaking oil, but it wants to find a sheltered spot so it can unload the remaining 53 million gallons of crude oil and perform emergency repairs. ``The essential thing is that the remaining oil be transferred in the high seas to another ship,'' said Spanish government spokeswoman Rosa Conde after today's Cabinet meeting. The government has offered all help ``within its power'' to the stricken ship as long as it remains outside Spanish waters, she said. On Thursday, environmental experts said more than 90 percent of the oil that spilled into the sea had either evaporated, dissolved in the sea, been broken up in high waves or been dispersed by chemicals sprayed on the water to fight the slick. The edge of the oil slick was 20 miles off the Moroccan oyster farming town of Oualidyia on Thursday, and sailors laid floating barriers to stop its advance. Iranian Oil Minister Gholamreza Aqazadeh said Thursday that a storm ripped a hole in one of the tanker's storage tanks, causing the explosion that started the leak. Aqazadeh said reports of environmental damage caused by the spill were exaggerated and that the ship met all safety specifications. The vessel, built in 1975, was damaged at least three times in Iraqi air strikes in the Persian Gulf during the Iran-Iraq war. The normal life span of a tanker of its size is 15 to 20 years.

DOC.HEAD: Diet Coke Unveils 1990 Advertising Campaign
DOC.TEXT: Celebrity consumers say ``goodbye'' to Pepsi Cola in Diet Coke television commercials for 1990 unveiled by the Coca-Cola Co. Pepsi spokesman Tod MacKenzie immediately branded the tactic of comparing the sugared Pepsi and the sugar-free diet Coke ``a feeble attempt to get the playing field changed.'' The 1990 Diet Coke advertising campaign unveiled Thursday features model Jerry Hall, tennis star Chris Evert, ``Cosby Show'' actress Phylicia Rashad and TV personality Vanna White in 30-second commercials. The theme is an extension of last year's ``The Move Is On'' campaign, which was designed to draw drinkers of Pepsi, the No. 2 soft drink behind Coca-Cola, to No. 3 Diet Coke. According to Beverage Digest, an industry publication, Pepsi last year had 18.3 percent market share in the nation, while Diet Coke was third at 8.9 percent. But Diet Coke's share of the market rose 0.7 percent _ the biggest jump by any in the Beverage Digest Top 10 _ while Pepsi declined 0.4 percent, the biggest drop and an apparent reflection of the overall increasing popularity of diet drinks. Pepsi's diet drink, fourth-ranked Diet Pepsi, also had a healthy gain _ 0.5 percent _ to claim 5.7 percent of the market. MacKenzie, from Pepsi's Purchase, N.Y., headquarters, said he hadn't seen the new Diet Coke ads but noted that Diet Pepsi launched a new campaign featuring comedian Billy Crystal last week. ``Rest assured, we've got a pool of spots we're going to bring out to take the wood to Diet Coke,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Lower at Midday
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS penultimate graf to insert full name, title of Gorbachev; picks up last graf, ``The market ...
DOC.TEXT: London share prices were steady at lower levels at midday Friday, after recovering from early falls induced by Tokyo's earlier stumble. At about noon London time, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 10 points, or 0.4 percent, at 2,441.6. Traders said the index slumped by around 15 points in pre-market trading, but lack of follow-through selling inspired the market to perk up. At its best, the index touched a morning peak of 2,448.7 points, before once again moving lower. ``The market is very nervous and isn't quite sure which direction to go in,'' one dealer said. Volume amounted to 277 million shares by midday, compared with 407.5 million shares at the same time Thursday. Dealers said that many investors were reluctant to get into large deals ahead of the release of U.S. unemployment figures for December early Friday. Tokyo's Nikkei index of 225 selected issues closed down 438.12 points at 38,274.76 earlier Friday on news that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has canceled all his January foreign engagements to concentrate on domestic troubles. ``The market hates political uncertainty,'' one dealer said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Developments Send Market Falling; Dollar Plunge Checked
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS new 3rd graf with closing on Hong Kong stock market; picks up 3rd graf pvs, `News reports ...
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange today went into their worst plunge since Oct. 16 on reports Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev canceled all foreign engagements to deal with domestic unrest. The news braked a rapid fall in the value of the U.S. dollar against the yen. The dollar finished the day at 144.15 yen, down 1.05 yen from Thursday's close. The Hong Kong Stock Exchange also closed sharply lower, with the Hang Seng Index, the market's key indicator of blue chips, falling 28.01 points to 2,839.94. Brokers attributed the losses to the news reports and to the drop on the Tokyo market. News reports that Gorbachev canceled a meeting with British Labor Party leaders in Moscow and postponed all other contacts with foreign politicians hit the Tokyo market in early afternoon trading, sending the 225-issue Nikkei average into a tailspin. The leading market indicator closed at 38,274.76, down 438.12 points, or 1.1 percent, from the day before. It was the largest single-day loss on the Tokyo Stock Exchange since a 647-point plunge on Oct. 16. Within the last hour of trading, the decline had approached 600 points, but late buying cut the loss. ``To Japan, the worst thing that could happen to the world scenario would be for Gorbachev to drop from sight,'' said Chris Schreiber, an investment analyst with New Japan Securities. Gorbachev is regarded in Japan as the key to global stability, he said. ``Trading houses were hard-hit today because they had been recommended by brokers on the detente theme,'' Schreiber said, citing a 5 percent loss for Marubeni and an even larger drop for C. Itoh and Co. But he added that the market was already ``very touchy'' in view of difficulties that may lie ahead for the governing Liberal Democratic Party following Lower House elections expected on Feb. 18. ``The current market perception is that (the LDP) is going to just hold on to a majority,'' he said, but added that governing with a slimmer majority is expected to be difficult for the party. Schreiber also attributed the drop to traders' expectations of a ``speed correction'' following several months of rapid gains on the Tokyo market. The dollar, having opened sharply down at 143.40 yen, climbed during the morning to 143.65 yen. The dollar continued rising in the afternoon despite intervention by the Bank of Japan. During the day's trading, the dollar moved between 143.35-144.18 yen. Naoki Kiyohara, chief of currency options at Fuji Bank, attributed the dollar's rise from its morning level to the news about Gorbachev, together with a trading-floor rumor that Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu was canceling his scheduled trip to Eastern Europe. The rumor was denied by the Foreign Ministry, but Kiyohara said its effect was already felt in the market. Kiyohara said the Bank of Japan intervened several times in the afternoon in an attempt to drive the dollar below 144 yen, but although ``many dealers were wary of intervention...the news about Gorbachev was the most influential factor.''

DOC.NOTE: $adv08
For Release Monday Jan. 8
DOC.HEAD: Latest Bull-Market Mania: Country Funds
DOC.TEXT: Stock-market investors have wasted no time lately speculating on the potential benefits of growing international trade in an increasingly democratic world. In recent weeks they have scrambled to buy shares of ``country funds'' investing in corners of the globe ranging from Germany to Chile to Thailand. As Wall Street closed the books on 1989, these funds clearly stamped themselves as the latest in a long line of hot financial properties that helped keep the bull market bubbling throughout the '80s. Among the 42 issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange that doubled or more in price during 1989, no less than eight were closed-end investment companies specializing in securities of a single country or region of the world. Spain Fund, which almost tripled; Asia Pacific Fund; Thai Fund, and the Germany Fund all made the Top Ten. World events provided several sparks to keep enthusiasm for these stocks going. The most obvious was the toppling of economic and political barriers in eastern Europe after decades in the shadow of communism. The apparent end to the Cold War raised visions of vast new opportunities for the economies of western Europe, which had already begun to gear up for business and financial alliances set to take effect in 1992. Heiko Thieme, investment strategist for Deutsche Bank Capital Corp. in New York, projects that the opening up of eastern Europe will in time raise the world's total economic output by a full percentage point. Meanwhile, investors searched frenetically elsewhere in the world for upwardly mobile nations that might be ready to follow in the footsteps of such modern success stories as Japan. Even if that reasoning were as good as it sounded, however, many analysts who have watched the mania develop say buyers of country funds seem to be willing to pay almost any price to satisfy their appetites. Nearly all the country funds are closed-end investment companies. They operate in much the same manner as mutual funds, except that their sponsors do not continuously buy and sell shares at the prevailing net asset value. Instead, the funds have a fixed number of shares that trade on stock exchanges or in the over-the-counter market, just like other common stocks. So the price they command is determined by market forces, and can fluctuate above (at a ``premium'' to) or below (at a ``discount'' to) the net asset value. Some country funds, notably in the Far East, have traded at premiums almost all of the time since their inception, in part because foreigners have few or no other ways to participate in those countries' markets. Lately, however, other country funds in Europe and elsewhere that once traded at discounts also have soared past the per-share value of the investments they own. ``In recent months the share prices of single country closed-end funds have been bid up to unrealistic prices,'' asserts Norman Tepper, an analyst at the Value Line Investment Survey, in the advisory service's latest appraisal of the group. However bright the funds' long-term prospects, ``most major world economies are either experiencing inflation, rising interest rates or stagflation,'' Tepper says. ``Most will probably show slower economic growth in 1990. Several stock markets look rather perilous.'' As has been demonstrated in the past, a popular closed-end fund can keep trading at lofty premiums for a long time. But analysts point out that a big premium in a fund is like a high price-earnings ratio for an industrial stock, suggesting that expectations of many good things are already built into the price. Securities in that position are considered vulnerable to any disappointment that might arise from, say, greater weakness than expected in the pace of the world economy. In Tepper's view, the present circumstances ``certainly suggest that investors exercise caution with respect to foreign investments, and in particular closed-end funds with stakes in overseas-based companies.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday Jan. 8

DOC.TEXT: Stock prices fell today in an atmosphere of uneasiness over the economic outlook and political developments in the Soviet Union. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 16.86 to 2,779.22 in the first half hour of trading. Losers outnumbered gainers by more than 2 to 1 in the early tally of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 311 up, 715 down and 435 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 23.39 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. The Labor Department reported that the civilian unemployment rate held steady at 5.3 percent in December. The data showed a smaller-than-expected 142,000 increase in nonfarm payroll employment. Traders in the bond market took that as favorable news, suggesting that the pace of the economy remained sluggish enough to allow the Federal Reserve to consider further moves toward easier credit. But stock-market investors evidently read the figures as a sign that further weakness might be in store for corporate earnings in the months ahead. DOC.NOTE: $adv08
For Release Monday, Jan. 8
DOC.HEAD: Most Economists Say Interest Rates Headed Down
DOC.TEXT: Short-term interest rates should drop in the coming months as the Federal Reserve Board eases monetary policy further to forestall a recession, most economists believe. Declining interest rates are good news to bondholders since it means the value, or price, of their fixed-return investments should increase. The Fed has been easing interest rates since the middle of last year, when it became apparent that the economy was slowing. The policy is consistent with the Fed's aim of a ``soft landing'' for the economy, which is in the eighth year of a record-breaking expansion. David M. Blitzer, chief economist at Standard & Poor's Corp., is among the more pessimistic observers of the health of the economy. ``The U.S. is teetering on the edge of recession,'' he wrote last week in a commentary. He said that unless the Fed eases rates further, the economy will fall over that cliff. ``Interest rates for 1990 are relatively easy to forecast,'' Blitzer said. ``Either the Fed will ease and rates will come down now, or it will not ease, there will be a recession, and rates will come down later.'' Barclays de Zoete Wedd Government Securities Inc. predicts the government will report in late January a 1 percent decline in fourth-quarter real gross national product. That decline, the investment house projects, will prompt the Fed to lower its discount rate for the first time since the central bank has been headed by Alan Greenspan, who took charge in the summer of 1987. The discount rate, currently 7 percent, is the interest the Fed charges member banks for loans, and it provides a floor for other interest rates, such as bank loan rates. Previously, the Fed has worked to lower general interest rates by easing the federal funds rate, the rate banks charge on overnight loans to each other. However, the financial consulting firm Griggs & Santow Inc. cautions that while the GNP figure is an important gauge of the economy, the fourth-quarter figure may be distorted by the hurricanes, the California earthquake and strikes during the three months. ``Moreover, a quite weak GNP number can occur even as important areas of the economy are doing well,'' the firm says. ``Thus, even though GNP will be weak in the fourth quarter, the consumer, energy, export, investment and non-defense spending sectors are all likely to expand.'' Other experts are less certain of continued Fed easing as long as core inflation remains at about 4.5 percent. Recent weather- and accident-related increases in the prices of crude oil, orange juice and other commodities fuel this belief. In addition, some economists say not all signs point to a recession. ``Barring either a severe financial disruption or the imminence of recession, we foresee no quick exit from a still-tight monetary policy,'' John Lonski, senior economist for Moody's Investors Service Inc., wrote recently. ``Without pressing reasons to do otherwise, the danger of higher inflation may have to pass before the Fed relaxes its firm monetary grip.'' Many analysts say the predicted drop in interest rates will occur almost entirely among short-term bonds. Yields on long-term issues, such as the Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond, should remain steady. Currently, the 30-year bond is trading at about 8percent. The belief is that the yield will not decline due to the need to attract overseas investors in the bonds, which help finance the federal deficit. Interest rates in West Germany and Japan have been rising, increasing the competition for global investors' funds. In addition, the rate may remain at its current level due to the 4.5 percent core inflation, which cuts the actual yield by more than half, analysts say. This factor may limit any drop in short-term yields as well, as bond investors continue to demand compensation for inflation. With short term rates dropping more than long-term issues, the Treasury yield curve, which plots the yield of Treasury securities along a line measuring their maturity, will steepen further in a positive direction. This means investors will be rewarded ever more for tying up their money in longer-term bonds.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, Jan. 8

DOC.HEAD: Bond Corp. Of Australia Wins In One Court, Still Faces Problems
DOC.TEXT: Bond Corp. Holdings Ltd. won a reprieve Friday as the Western Australian Supreme Court dismissed a government petition to liquidate the media, brewing, natural resources and property empire. The court ruled against the State Government Insurance Commission, which had asked the court to appoint a provisional liquidator for Bond Corp. on the grounds that the company controlled by financier Alan Bond was insolvent. A judge ruled that the insurance commission had failed to prove its claim. ``There is no evidence that the creditors of (Bond Corp.) aren't being paid,'' the judge said. The future of Bond Corp. may be uncertain, the judge said, but a petition should not be filed on speculation ``that a company may possibly at some time in the future experience severe financial difficulties.'' He also ruled that a nearly $668,000 debt that was the basis of the petition was disputed by Bond Corp. While Bond Corp. succeeded on one front, the company, whose debts total $5.6 billion, was still battling in another court to overturn an order to appoint receivers and managers to its Australian brewing units. The company is also trying to negotiate with U.S. holders of debentures issued by its Bond Brewing Holdings Ltd. unit who have demanded immediate repayment of $510 million of the securities and overdue inerest. Lawyers for the debenture holders said in court here Friday they intend to support continuation of receivers appointed last month to operate Bond's brewing units. The court appointed the receivers at the request of a syndicate of international banks led by National Australia Bank Ltd. U.S. noteholders were due to receive a $32.19 million interest payment from Bond's brewing arm, but the courts froze that payment at the request of the bank syndicate. Bond Brewing has asked the court to lift the bank's stop-payment notice. Alan Bond, who controls about 58 percent of Bond Corp., gained virtual hero status in Australia when he won the 1983 America's Cup yachting trophy. The millionaire industrialist has been selling assets in recent months to reduce debt. In its fiscal year ended June 30, Bond Corp. lost 980.2 million Australian dollars, the largest annual loss in Australian corporate history. Bond Corp.'s G. Heileman Brewing Co. unit in the United States so far is not involved in the receivership proceedings. Heileman spokesman Bill Eiler said in a telephone interview from Pittsburgh Thursday the U.S. brewer has separate financing from Bond Corp. and as a matter of policy does not comment on matters involving Bond. Bond purchased La Crosse, Wis.-based Heileman in 1987 for about $1.3 billion and reportedly still owes about $850 million after selling the profitable Heileman Baking Co. and other Heileman subsidiaries. Heileman officials said recently they have been meeting with creditors and reviewing alternatives ``aimed at favorably modifying Heileman's existing debt structure.'' Separately, Adolph Coors Co., the fourth-largest U.S. brewing company, acknowledged this week it has held talks with Heileman for over a year about the possible purchase of the Wisconsin brewer.

DOC.HEAD: British Motorists To Pay Extra for Cold U.S. Weather
DOC.TEXT: Cold weather in the United States will pinch motorists in Britain, where gasoline prices are going up by 5.5 pence, or about 9 cents per imperial gallon. Esso announced on Friday that it was raising its price on top-grade leaded gasoline, and other companies were expected to follow suit. The increase raised the price of gasoline to the equivalent of $2.13 per U.S. gallon, or 41.5 pence per liter. An imperial gallon is the equivalent of about 1 and one-fifth U.S. gallons. Esso said one factor in the price increase was the cold weather in the United States, which has driven up prices of gas oils by 60 percent on the Rotterdam spot market.

DOC.HEAD: Keating Acknowledges Bookkeeping Hid True Buyer in Land Deal
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Top 9 grafs new with Keating testimony today, picking up at pvs 4th graf, Keating has; DELETES last 4 grafs to shorten
DOC.TEXT: Phoenix millionaire Charles H. Keating Jr., the central figure in a $2 billion savings and loan scandal, acknowledged today that bookkeeping by his thrift institution hid the true buyer in a major real estate deal. But, Keating, chairman of American Continental Corp., parent company of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif., said the bookkeeping was a proper part of a land syndication deal and that government examiners should not have cared about the identity of the true buyer. U.S. District Judge Stanley Sporkin, who is hearing evidence in Keating's suit to overturn the government seizure of Lincoln last April, reacted skeptically, asking: ``How is it you can manage billion-dollar businesses and have transactions where the paperwork did not reflect what took place?'' ``When you run a bank or a savings and loan, you have the highest responsibility of anyone because you're not dealing just with stockholders, you're dealing with people's savings,'' Sporkin told Keating. ``... The only way regulators (can ensure that an institution is being run properly) is if the books and records accurately reflect transactions.'' In 1987, Lincoln sold 1,000 acres, for which it had paid $3 million, to WestContinental Mortgage Co. for $14 million. However, government regulators maintain that WestContinental was just a straw buyer for Arizona developer and stockbroker Ernest C. Garcia. They say the land transaction was improperly linked with another transaction between Lincoln and Garcia on the same day. Keating told the judge, ``I can't believe that anyone was innocent of the fact that the deal was being made with Garcia. Everybody who was there and present at that time, including the (government) examiners, knew what we were doing.'' However, in response to a later question from his own attorney, Keating acknowledged that he did not know whether his own auditors knew that Garcia was the buyer. And, Kevin O'Connell, a supervisory official with the federal Office of Thrift Supervision, told reporters after Keating's testimony: ``There is nothing in the record that we were ever advised that Garcia was the real buyer.'' On Thursday, Keating broke his self-imposed silence with more than an hour of testimony in which he described how he used Lincoln to finance massive residential projects in the Phoenix area. Keating has had little to say in public since September, when government regulators filed a $1.1 billion fraud and racketeering civil suit charging he operated Lincoln for his own and his family's benefit. A grand jury in Los Angeles is examining possible criminal charges against Keating. The government seized Lincoln in April, claiming it was operating in an unsafe and unsound manner. In November, Keating asserted his constitutional protection against self-incrimination and refused to testify before a House committee investigating the failure. But Keating sought the court action and, in response to the judge's questions, he readily described his disappointment when the seizure of Lincoln blocked the completion of a large residential project west of Phoenix. ``The saddest thing in my life is that we were brought to this pass,'' he said. Keating also is at the center of a Senate Ethics Committee investigation, examining the actions of five senators who accepted more than $1.3 million in contributions from the financier and later met on his behalf with federal regulators. In Thursday's hearing, government investigators focused on a stock transaction with Garcia which denied up to $12 million in profits to a Lincoln subsidiary and instead benefited American Continental, which provided Keating and his family with millions of dollars in salaries and benefits. The Lincoln subsidiary sold $1 million of Memorex common stock to Garcia. The subsidiary retained an option to repurchase the shares for $4.25 million, should their value skyrocket. Four months later, in late October 1987, American Continental repurchased the stock from Garcia for $2 million and the subsidiary, headed by Keating's son, Charles H. Keating III, waived its option. Later, in March and April 1988, American Continental sold the stock for $13.3 million. Because it waived its option, the Lincoln subsidiary didn't get any of the profits, which would have offset taxpayer losses in the S&L's later failure. The Memorex transaction is one of four deals the government has cited as examples of ``unsafe and unsound'' practices that justified its takeover of Lincoln. The elder Keating testified he approved the decision for American Continental to buy back the Memorex stock from Garcia. But, he said, ``I don't believe that I made the decision where to put it. I don't know who made the decision on waiving the (Lincoln's buyback) option.'' He said he assumed that was done because federal S&L regulators were pressing Lincoln to get out of stock market investments. However, Sporkin said, ``I can't see the regulators objecting'' to retaining the Memorex option, which could only benefit Lincoln.

DOC.HEAD: New Charges Returned Against Former USX Official
DOC.TEXT: A federal grand jury has added three charges against a former USX Corp. official in an investigation of pensions the company awarded to union negotiators in 1983. James Bruce Johnston, indicted on one felony count last month, now faces four charges and may stand trial with USX and two Birmingham union leaders in March. Johnston said in a statement that the new indictment, returned Thursday and made public today, is ``outrageous.'' The charges against Johnston, USX, and Thermon Phillips and E.B. Rich of the United Steelworkers of America stem from a federal investigation of the negotiations leading to a 1983 union contract for USX's Fairfield Works at Birmingham. The indictments alleged that as part of the negotiations the company agreed to secretly set up pensions for Rich, Phillips and four other union negotiators, although the six were not eligible for the benefits. In return, the grand jury alleged, Rich and Phillips agreed to make concessions in the Fairfield Works contract. Johnston, then a USX labor-relations executive, played a key role in USX's change of its pension-plan rules to include the union negotiators. Thursday's indictment charged Johnston, of McMurray, Pa., with conspiracy, causing USX to make the pension payments to Phillips and Rich, and causing the company's pension fund to fail to inform its participants of the rule change. The grand jury had indicted Johnston on the latter charge two weeks ago. In a court document, Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael Rasmussen reported the government would seek to combine Johnston's case with that of the company and union leaders, who face trial March 5. Johnston, if convicted on all four counts, could face a maximum penalty of 20 years in prison and a $1.1 million fine, said U.S. Attorney Frank W. Donaldson. Johnston repeated a statement he issued last month in which he defended his actions and those of the company in granting the pensions. He said the union had requested the rule change for years, other large companies had similar rules and the change was based in part on a written legal opinion of the U.S. Department of Labor. The company rescinded the change in 1987 after learning of recent court decisions indicating it was illegal, Johnston said. Fairfield employees had sued the company and the union leaders, claiming collusion in the granting of the pensions and seeking the voiding of the 1983 agreement, which cut wages and benefits in return for the reopening of the plant. That lawsuit is on hold in Birmingham federal court pending the resolution of the criminal charges. In the news release, Johnston's lawyer, Stanley S. Arkin of New York City, said the charges result ``from the economic frustrations of some former union-represented employees of USX Corporation and is no more and no less than a classic example of translating dissatisfaction into scapegoating.''

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Retreat On Slack Exports
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mostly lower this morning on the Chicago Board of Trade following a weekly Agriculture Department report showing relatively light export sales of corn and soybeans. The early declines also reflected followthrough selling from Thursday's weaker close in the soybean market, which fell sharply late in the day when commercial players became heavy sellers. ``Yesterday's session was really disappointing,'' said analyst Joel Karlin of Research Department Inc. in Chicago. ``We had a perfect environment for these things to rally ... and they couldn't rally.'' An overnight increase in farmer sales of corn and soybeans added to the selling pressure this morniing. Karlin predicted the losses would be offset by buying later in the session as traders even up their positions ahead of the weekend. In early trading, wheat futures prices were { cent to 1 cent lower with the contract for delivery in March at $4.08{ a bushel; corn futures were { cent to 1{ cents lower with March at $2.37{ a bushel; oats were { cent lower to } cent higher with March at $1.51 a bushel; soybeans were } cent to 2 cents lower with January at $5.61{ a bushel. Some hog and pork belly futures surged their respective daily trading limits of 1.5 cents and 2 cents a pound on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in a continuing reaction to Wednesday's USDA report showing a smaller hog-and-pig supply than traders had expected. Live hog futures were .75 cent to 1.5 cents higher with February at 51.42 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 2 cents higher across the board with February at 53.47 cents a pound; live cattle were .02 cent to .40 cent higher with February at 77.10 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent lower to .20 cent higher with January at 84.75 cents a pound. Pork futures settled limit-up Thursday; cattle futures were mostly higher.

DOC.HEAD: Bridgestone@Firestone Recalls Ceratin Truck Tires
DOC.TEXT: About 86,000 radial truck tires have been recalled by Bridgestone@Firestone Inc. because of potential cracking in the inner lining, the company said. The recall announced Thursday involved over-the-road, drive-axle truck tires with the model designation T546 PSD Radial, in sizes 10R22.5, 11R22.5, 11R24.5, 295@75R22.5 and 285@75R24.5. The tires were produced during the past two years at a company plant in Bilbao, Spain, the company said. Most of the recall tires were sold by independent Firestone dealers. The tires were sold across the nation without a focus on any single region, said Firestone spokesman Bob Troyer. He said replacement tires have an average selling price of $250 each. Firestone brand dealers and stores were being notified Thursday. The defect could result in sidewall failure, but there has been no report of any accident or injury resulting from the condition, the company said in a statement. Chicago-based Bridgestone@Firestone is relocating its corporate to Akron, which had long been headquarters of the former Firestone Tire & Rubber Co. The potential defect was noticed when some of the tires in question were checked after road damage during retreading. ``We want to be certain that our customers obtain the maximum potential from Firestone radial truck tires both during the original tread life and in the retread stage,'' said Thomas R. Mertz, director of sales and marketing for Firestone brand tires. ``Therefore, on a voluntary basis, we are initiating this recall today to replace these tires,'' he said. Only the tubeless tires are involved, he added. Troyer also on Thursday confirmed an Akron Beacon Journal report that the company has targeted about 80 of its 1,600 MasterCare auto service stores for sale or closing. Troyer said the closings or sale of stores are part of the normal course of business and do not reflect a financial problem.
