DOC.HEAD: Anheuser-Busch to Buy Rights to Shamu, Sea World Star
DOC.TEXT: Anheuser-Busch Cos. Inc., which recently acquired the Sea World parks, has agreed to pay $6 million for marketing rights to their star resident, Shamu the killer whale. The Shamu license is held by Watson General Pictures Inc. in a joint venture with Lion's Den Productions Inc. The agreement to sell the rights to Sea World Inc., a subsidiary of Anheuser-Busch, was made Thursday. Anheuser-Busch has owned Shamu since it paid $1.1 billion in November to buy four Sea World parks, two additional theme parks and adjacent land from Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., but the marketing rights were not part of the deal. Under the agreement, Watson General also will get royalties of 10 percent on the gross sales of Shamu merchandise sold outside the theme parks and 50 percent of all the net proceeds from ``Shamu ... The Beginning,'' a recently completed animated film included in the sale.

DOC.HEAD: Prospect Group Plans To Spin Off Illinois Central, Sylvan
DOC.TEXT: The Illinois Central railroad has gone through another management twist with the announcement that The Prospect Group Inc. will spin it off just 10 months after its acquisition and one year after it went independent. Prospect, a New York-based conglomerate, announced plans Thursday to distribute common stock in Illinois Central Corp. and Sylvan Foods Inc. to Prospect shareholders. Prospect said it will retain a stake of about 50 percent in Illinois Central's common stock and will completely divest itself of Sylvan Foods common stock. But Prospect said it will retain voting control over both companies for several years through its preferred stock holdings. Prospect said it expects stock in both companies to be traded, like Prospect's, on the over-the-counter market. Sylvan, based in Worthington, Pa., is a major producer of mushrooms and mushroom spawn, the equivalent of seed. The Chicago-based railroad hauls freight between the Great Lakes and the Gulf of Mexico. It has undergone several changes in the past year. Last January the railroad's parent, formerly IC Industries Inc., spun off Illinois Central to shareholders. IC changed its name to Whitman Corp. to reflect its commmitment to consumer products, including Whitman chocolates. The 139-year-old railroad immediately attracted investors because of its growth potential. With the Mississippi River drawn down sharply by the previous summer's drought, the Illinois Central provided Midwestern grain shippers with an alternative to logjammed river barges. The railroad's common stock began trading on the New York Stock Exchange Jan. 3, 1989, at $11 a share and climbed to $14 by Jan. 16 after Illinois grain processor Archer Daniels Midland Co. announced it had acquired 8 percent of Illinois Central's stock. Prospect came in with an unsolicited $20-a-share cash tender offer on Jan. 27 and the parties announced a $436 million deal on March 10. Prospect already had three Southeastern railroads and either owned or was affiliated with the Forschner Group Inc., the U.S. marketer of Swiss army knives; the National Automobile and Casualty Insurance Co.; and the National Spirit Group, which runs cheerleader camps and manufactures cheerleader uniforms. In a statement issued late Thursday in New York, Prospect Chairman W. Wallace McDowell Jr. said Illinois Central and Sylvan had both done well under the Prospect umbrella. ``The performance of both of these companies in the past several months makes us very optimistic about the future,'' McDowell said. ``By making the distributions at this time, Prospect shareholders will realize the direct benefit of appreciation in the two companies while retaining their interest in The Prospect Group.'' Illinois Central had operating income of $25.5 million on revenue of $125.8 million for the quarter that ended Sept. 30, Prospect said. For the quarter that ended Sept. 30, Sylvan had operating income of $2.3 million on revenue of $18.7 million.

DOC.HEAD: McDonnell Douglas Computer Systems Lays Off 100
DOC.TEXT: McDonnell Douglas Computer Systems, which laid off 100 of its 450 workers this week, is the latest minicomputer maker to be hurt by the popularity of desktop computers and workstations as replacements for larger machines. Norma Bryga, Computer Systems marketing director, said Thursday the latest layoffs cut across all departments and involved managers as well as factory workers. Such companies as Prime Computer Inc., Data General Corp. and MAI Basic Four have been forced to trim workers and regroup as sales of minicomputers have plunged in the past year. McDonnell Douglas Computer Systems, which laid off another 60 employees in October, is one of several computer-related divisions that parent company McDonnell Douglas Corp. said earlier this year it would spin off or sell because of poor performance.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
USX Says Senate Bill Endangers Coke Plants
DOC.TEXT: A clean-air bill pending in the Senate would force virtually every coke plant in the nation to close, endangering the domestic steel industry, a USX Corp. official said. ``If this legislation goes through the way it is now being shaped in the Senate, there's a good chance it will signal the end of coke-oven operations in the nation,'' said Philip X. Masciantonio, vice president of environmental affairs for the USS division of USX. ``If we can't make coke here, we don't have a steel industry,'' he told The Pittsburgh Press on Thursday. Coke is a primary ingredient for making steel. The toxic pollution provisions of Senate Bill 1630, passed last month by the Environmental and Public Works Committee, would submit coke plants to strict new emissions standards and overhaul the Clean Air Act in the areas of acid rain and urban smog. Environmentalists give varyng assessments of the bill. Anthony Picadio _ a lawyer for the Group Against Smog and Pollution, a Pittsburgh environmental group that has sparred with USX for 20 years _ said he opposes the bill because coke plants could not meet its stringent health-protection standard. He said the bill would never be enforced. But lawyers with the Natural Resources Defense Council, a Washington-based environmental group, said the bill provides exemptions if pollution-control technology cannot achieve the standards. As a result, there's no reason to worry that wholesale plant closings would occur, they said. ``I think it's part of a general campaign (by U.S. industry) to paint this legislation as extreme,'' said Richard Ayres, a senior attorney with the defense council. Senate Majority Leader George J. Mitchell, D-Maine, has said the bill will be the first one considered when senators return Jan. 23 from their winter recess. About 40 plants in the United States bake coal in ovens to produce coke. USX's Clairton Works, a sprawling network of ovens and smokestacks along the Monongahela River at Clairton, is the largest coke plant in the nation. The Senate bill would require each coke plant to gradually reduce air emissions to the point that emissions would pose no more than a one in 1 million risk of cancer to a person living downwind all his life, Masciantonio said. An Environmental Protection Agency analysis shows that coke plants pose among the highest cancer risks of all U.S. industrial plants. For example, oven emissions from the Clairton plant pose a cancer risk of one in 130 in the most extreme hypothetical case, Masciantonio said. A 10,000-fold reduction in emissions would be needed to achieve the bill's goal, and that's not possible with today's technology, he said.

DOC.HEAD: The Grassroots Are Murmuring Recession
DOC.TEXT: By one reckoning, the states of New York and Connecticut dropped into recession in December, joining 27 other states that earlier had descended to that level. Those 29 states, representing 37.3 percent of the 89.9 million households in America, soon could be joined by three or four borderline states. Should that happen, it would bring the total percentage of households to more than 50. These are not official government estimates, but the result of detailed telephone calls to 3,948 households during December by Sindlinger & Co. of Wallingford, Penn., a pioneer in consumer and economic studies. Decades of experience have shown, said Albert Sindlinger, founder and chairman, that the point at which the survey tops 50 percent of households will later be recognized officially as the time when recession began. That means waiting eight months. Historically, a national recession is declared after two consecutive quarters of shrinking gross national product. Then, it takes two more months for statistical analysis and confirmation. For this reason it is often said that economists are the last to know about a recession _ that most people sense a recession long before it is officially confirmed, based on their own economic experience. By Sindlinger's calculations, just two states and 2.4 percent of households were in recession last January. By June, the figures had risen to 18 states and 15.9 percent of households, and by November to 27 states and 28.3 percent. The percentage of households took a big jump when Connecticut and New York joined the recession states in December. And that percentage could take an even bigger jump _ to more than 50 _ if borderline states slump just slightly. Those four states _ New Jersey, Texas, Pennsylvania and North Carolina, plus the District of Columbia _ account for 17.9 percent of households. In each of these states less than 51 percent of households responded positively. The greatest strenghth of all was concentrated in what used to be called the Midwest Rust Belt, in Ohio, Indiana, Michigan, Illinois and Wisconsin. But, Sindlinger says, they too could be endangered by auto industry layoffs. Utah, Washington and Delaware were among stronger states. Rated just above borderline were Minnesota, Oregon, California, Nevada, Florida, Virginia and Maryland. All others _ Alaska and Hawaii excluded _ were in recession. Sindlinger's definition of recession is based on answers to four questions put to the head of each household: 1. In your geographical area will economic conditions be better, worse or the same next June than they are now? 2. In your place of employment do you expect there will be more, the same or fewer jobs? 3. In your household do you expect higher combined income? Lower? The same? 4. Compared to last June, is your household income now higher, the same or lower? When the respondent reports at least one negative answer the household is said to have ``negative household liquidity,'' suggesting a curtailment of consumer spending and postponement of discretionary spending or investing. When a respondent replies positively or neutrally, it means the household is likely to continue spending and borrowing willingly and freely at a level dictated by current income and borrowing capacity. Albert Sindlinger doesn't claim we are now in a recession, but he will make that claim if more than 50 percent of respondents give at least one negative answer during this month. It isn't the first time he has been ready to make such a declaration. His research showed 31 states in recession in 1986, but the total of households involved amounted to just 49.5 percent, or just shy of a majority. His research at that time did point out conclusively, however, that a nation as large as the United States can go through regional or industry recessions that stop short of becoming national economic phenomena. In terms of geographic size, most of America was indeed in recession in 1986, but the national figures were skewed by relatively strong economies in California, Nevada, New Mexico and in much of the East Coast and Michigan. Government statistics later confirmed the Sindlinger measurements. And, says octogenarian Albert Sindlinger, they'll do it again sometime in late summer. The grassroots, he said, know the story before the economists.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Denies IRS Attempt to Block Settlement
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court in Georgia has cleared the way for creditors of former Ohio financier Marvin Warner to begin receiving payments from a $16 million settlement approved last month by federal bankruptcy judge. In a two-sentence order released Thursday, the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta denied an attempt by the Internal Revenue Service to block the immediate distribution of $10 million under Warner's settlement agreement. The remaining $6 million pledged to creditors will be distributed over the next three years. A total of $3.6 million in payments to attorneys and accountants also can begin, attorneys for the creditors' committee said Thursday. The IRS objected to the Chapter 11 settlement approved last month by Bankruptcy Judge George L. Proctor in Jacksonville, claiming Warner's assets would diminish over the coming years and the IRS would not get $13 million it claims Warner owes in taxes and interest. Warner's settlement plan calls for those charges to be paid over six years. Warner, 70, the former owner of Home State Savings Bank of Ohio, ran into financial trouble when the thrift collapsed in 1985, triggering a crisis for Ohio savings and loans. Warner, a former U.S. ambassador to Switzerland who now lives on an Ocala horse farm, filed for Chapter 11 financial reorganization in October 1987 to consolidate $4.5 billion sought in lawsuits against him as a result of the Home State collapse. The thrift collapsed in March 1985 four days after ESM Government Securities Inc. of Fort Lauderdale was closed by government regulators for insolvency. Home State had invested heavily in ESM through securities trades and lost $144 million when ESM closed. Meanwhile, Ohio prosecutors are trying to get reinstated Warner's conviction on charges related to the Home State collapse.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Approval Grants for First Direct Phone Link between Alaska, Soviets
DOC.TEXT: An Alaskan telephone company Friday received final federal approval for what is believed to be the first direct telephone link between Alaska and the Soviet Union. The Federal Communications Commission said Alascom may establish as many as 12 two-way, UHF radio-phone circuits between Gambell, Alaska, and Provideniya, Magadan, the Soviet Union. The service began in August after federal authorities gave Alascom verbal approval to proceed, pending final authorization, according to Alascom's Washington attorney, Charles Naftalin. He said several circuits were operating smoothly except for occasional technical difficulties on the Soviet end. Gambell, which is on St. Lawrence Island, is only about 62 miles from Magadan across the Bering Strait, but prior to this new service, telephone calls between Alaska and the Soviet Far East were routed through thousands of miles of land and undersea phone lines or satellite relays. Naftalin said it was the ``first terrestrial link ever between the U.S. and Soviet Union,'' but at this point it's only for Alaskans. The transmitter at Gambell is linked to a satellite ground station that can relay telephone signals to an Alascom receiving station near Fairbanks. But, Naftalin said, ``It's not configured yet to allow both nations to generally call back and forth.'' In seeking federal permission, Alascom said ``a direct link is important in light of the strong community of interest between Alaskans and the Soviet Far East, including close family ties among native populations,'' the FCC said. The commission, in finding the new service in the public interest and convenience, noted that Alascom's proposal was supported by the State Department, contingent upon a finding that there will be no transfer of equipment that may be used militarily. Alascom will own and supply all transmitting and receiving equipment, including the equipment installed on the Soviet end, the FCC said. The FCC previously ruled that Alascom could use radio frequencies generally reserved for cellular phone services. The new service will include messaging, private line and data communications.

DOC.HEAD: EC Seeks Improved Ties With Romania
DOC.TEXT: European Community officials may meet soon to mull additional aid to Romania and to seek normal diplomatic relations with that country now that dictator Nicolae Ceausescu has fallen, EC officials said Friday. A paper by the European Commission, the community's executive body, also urged the community to financially support economic reform efforts in the East and reach trade agreements with those countries. ``There is a common interest on the part of the community, its neighbors and all states sharing its fundamental values in ensuring that reform in East Europe does not founder,'' the paper read. The paper presented Thursday at a meeting of top commission officials, said a meeting could be held soon to examine Romania's need for additional assistance from the 12-nation trading bloc, also known as the Common Market. ``In the course of these discussions, it will be pointed out to the Romanian side that the time has come to establish normal diplomatic relations with the community,'' according to the document. The paper also stated the Common Market should be prepared to restart negotiations, which have been stalled since 1987, on a trade and economic cooperation agreement with Romania. The two sides arranged a limited trade pact in industrial products in 1980. The community agreed in 1986 to discuss extending the arrangement to agricultural products and economic cooperation, but no serious negotiations were held. The community has negotiated four trade-expanding agreements with Eastern European countries since it established formal ties in June 1988 with the socialist economic bloc, known as the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance, or Comecon. The Common Market has wide-ranging trade and economic cooperation accords with Poland, Hungary and the Soviet Union and a smaller pact with Czechoslovakia. The commission document also said the community was close to a pact with Bulgaria. It also said new negotiations with East Germany should end in an agreement within the first half of the year and that informal contacts have been made with Czechoslovakia to discuss extending its arrangement to trade and economic cooperation. The paper reflected the community's growing interest in developing strong ties with the emerging democracies in Eastern Europe. It has led an effort by two dozen Western nations to fashion an economic aid program to encourage reforms in Hungary and Poland. ``The pace of change in East Europe, the expectations of the peoples concerned and of their governments as well as the community's own interests in the political and economic future of Europe now require the community to take further initiatives,'' the paper read. The paper said Ireland, which currently holds the community's rotating presidency, was considering calling a special meeting this month of community foreign ministers to discuss further aid to Romania and other topics. But a spokesman for the presidency later issued a statement saying there were no immediate plans for a special session. The foreign ministers already are scheduled to meet in early February. In a separate document, the commission said it will provide a total of $7.7 million in emergency aid, including food and medical supplies, over the next three months to Romania. It said it has sent at least $1.2 million worth of help since late December.

DOC.HEAD: Anhueser-Busch Plans National Rollout of Non-Alcoholic Beer
DOC.TEXT: Anheuser-Busch Inc. said Friday it plans to begin selling its new non-alcoholic brew, O'Doul's, around the country starting on Monday. The brewery reported strong initial sales in selected cities, where the beer has been on shelves since March, it said in a news release. Anheuser-Busch, the world's largest brewery, said O'Doul's would meet the desires of a growing segment of consumers who like the taste of beer but don't want the alcohol. Other breweries, including Miller Brewing Co., have recently introduced non-alcoholic beers in an effort to meet head-on a growing anti-drinking sentiment and to offset falling beer sales with a wider variety of products. Miller's entry, called Sharp, has been on sale around the nation for several weeks. Annual production in the United States of non-alcoholic beers is about one million barrels a year, compared with the national beer market of more than 182 million barrels. But analysts say the non-alcoholic segment is growing at the rate of 10 percent to 15 percent a year, while the overall beer market has been stable.

DOC.HEAD: Maine Attorney General Files Antitrust Challenge To Great Northern Takeover
DOC.TEXT: The Maine attorney general asked a state judge on Friday to block Georgia-Pacific Corp.'s $3.8 billion bid to take over Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. on antitrust grounds. The state said in a lawsuit filed in Superior Court that a successful takeover of Great Northern by Georgia-Pacific would ``substantially lessen competition'' in several portions of the pulpwood industry in Maine, particularly hardwood pulpwood. In response, Georgia-Pacific Chairman T. Marshall Hahn Jr. said in a statement from Atlanta that the lawsuit was without merit. Hahn promised a vigorous defense and predicted Georgia-Pacific would win. ``We do not believe our acquisition of Great Northern violates antitrust laws in Maine or anywhere else,'' Hahn said. The suit also said an acquisition by Georgia-Pacific similarly could harm the real estate market by reducing competition in ``the sale of remote lakeshore property of significant recreational and scenic value.'' ``The primary concern underlying the state's case is that Georgia-Pacific's acquisition will thwart Great Northern's ongoing development of a major world-class pulp mill in Millinocket,'' Attorney General James E. Tierney said in a prepared statement. ``Great Northern's mill will be in operation by 1995. However, that mill and the increased competitive activity which it will bring to northern Maine's forest products industry will be lost if this acquisition is completed,'' Tierney said. By acquiring Great Northern's mills and land in Maine, Tierney said Georgia-Pacific would ``control too much power in the market for the purchase of wood.'' ``Georgia-Pacific's high market share will allow it to suppress the price paid to landowners and contractors below competitive levels,'' he said. Georgia-Pacific disputed those claims, noting that the federal government had already looked into the proposed merger but found no potential antitrust problems. ``Not only are the charges without merit, but in large part duplicate the exhaustive antitrust examinations already completed by the Federal Trade Commission,'' Hahn said. ``We are confident that Georgia-Pacific will prevail on all counts.'' Great Northern applauded the state's challenge to the merger attempt. ``We feel that the attorney general's action reflects our view that it would be illegal,'' Great Northern spokesman Stephen M. Hill said from his office in Norwalk, Conn. Great Northern has a separate lawsuit in federal court in Connecticut that challenges the merger attempt on antitrust grounds. On Thursday, Great Northern asked U.S. District Judge Gene Carter in Portland to issue a preliminary injunction halting Georgia-Pacific's takeover attempt, as well as its attempt to have Great Northern's board ousted. Great Northern has set March 2 as the date of a special shareholders' meeting to decide whether the company's present board of directors should be ousted. In a separate meeting on March 20, Great Northern shareholders are scheduled to decide whether to exercise so-called ``poison pill'' provisions to avoid the takeover.

DOC.HEAD: Pork Futures Get A Bullish Jolt; Energy, OJ Rallies Falter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: An ADD with weekly price trends will follow later in the cycle.
DOC.TEXT: The overheated fuel oil and orange juice futures markets showed signs of cooling but commodity bulls quickly found another pasture: the hog futures pit at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Pork futures prices shot up late in the week following a government report that showed a smaller hog supply than most traders had expected. The report was the latest in a series of bullish fundamental factors that have kept hog futures prices moving mainly upward since late summer. Hogs for February delivery settled Friday at 50.95 cents a pound compared with 48.70 cents a week earlier and about 43 cents at the end of August. The gains came in reaction to the Agriculture Department's quarterly hogs-and-pigs inventory, which showed a 3 percent drop in the national herd size from the end of 1988 to the end of 1989. The report also indicated that springtime farrowing intentions _ a measure of expected herd expansion _ were down 6 percent from a year ago. The numbers surprised market analysts whose observations of slaughter rates relative to the September inventory report had led them to expect little change in the end-of-the-year tally. The new numbers partly reflected a sharp downward revision in the September inventory number. Some market analysts were incensed by the change, contending the USDA's quarterly inventory numbers are too frequently out of whack with reality. But the numbers can't be ignored by the farmers, meatpackers, food processors and traders who plan their livelihoods based in part on the government reports. ``In one sense, they're the only game in town so we have no choice but to use their numbers,'' said analyst Dale Durchholz of AgriVisor Services Inc. in Bloomington, Ill. Charles Levitt, senior livestock analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., said large-scale revisions in the quarterly inventory numbers have become too common, creating uncertainty and risk in the futures market. ``If we get a supply report like this that moves up the price and then turns out to be wrong, the break on the back side is going to be double the increase,'' he said.
DOC.HEAD: Energy
DOC.TEXT: The dramatic rally in energy futures that began with last month's cold snap appeared to be slowing as temperatures rose, reducing demand for heating oil and easing the strain on oil refineries. A 10-cents-a-gallon plunge in the February heating-oil contract over the last two trading sessions of the week was the strongest indication that the runup had peaked. Nevertheless, the American Petroleum Institute reported U.S. heating-oil inventories at a 10-year low and ``maybe at the lowest level ever in terms of demand,'' said analyst Andrew Lebow of E.D. & F. Man International Futures Inc. ``The underlying fundamentals of heating oil are still favorable,'' he said.
DOC.HEAD: Orange Juice
DOC.TEXT: Orange juice futures gained for the fourth straight week on the New York Cotton Exchange, but the rate of increase slowed as Brazilian processors resumed shipments of juice to the United States on Thursday after a week-long suspension. Brazil, which accounted for 20 percent of the orange juice consumed in the United States last year, suspended exports to take stock of the market and raise prices after a damaging freeze struck Florida's citrus belt over the Christmas weekend. Frozen concentrated orange juice for January delivery settled Friday at $1.7965 a pound compared with $1.6565 a week earlier.
DOC.HEAD: Precious metals
DOC.TEXT: Gold and silver futures ended higher on the week after snapping a two-day losing streak that analysts attributed largely to the absence of buyers from Japan and other Far Eastern markets. Those markets reopened Thursday after a five-day New Year's break and the precious metals soared.
DOC.HEAD: Grains and soybeans
DOC.TEXT: Most prices fell slightly in a quiet week dominated by technical factors, slack export sales and improved growing conditions in the South American soybean belt.

DOC.HEAD: Hallmark Buying Toy Company Dakin
DOC.TEXT: Hallmark Cards Inc. has agreed to purchase Dakin Inc., one of the world's top producers of stuffed toys, a joint announcement said on Friday. The purchase price was not disclosed. The tentative sale, subject to a final agreement expected within three months, merges the world's largest producer of greeting cards with the world's largest marketer of plush stuffed toys, with sales of $150 million annually. Founded in 1955, San Francisco-based Dakin grew to its current position from initial annual sales of $500,000, the company reported. ``Dakin is an outstanding company whose strengths complement those of Hallmark's core business,'' said Hallmark President Robert L. Stark at company headquarters in Kansas City, Mo. Hallmark has annual sales of about $2.5 billion. Besides stuffed toys, Dakin makes dolls, puppets, photo frames and other gift items. The company employs some 600 people, with manufacturing plants in Lindsay, Calif., and Honolulu.

DOC.HEAD: Financial Markets Have Mixed Reaction To Gorbachev Cancellations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf to UPDATE with closing Dow average
DOC.HEAD: By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices in the Far East fell sharply Friday on the news that Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev had canceled foreign engagements to deal with domestic worries. But the jitters were less severe in other world markets. In Tokyo, the 225-share Nikkei index tumbled 600 points before recovering to finish 438.12 points lower at 38,274.76. The decline measured 1.1 percent decline and was the worst showing since Oct. 16, when the key index lost 647 points. The high-flying Japanese market, which had chalked up several record highs in the final days of 1989, was ripe for a big selloff, according to some experts. But the sharp reaction to the Soviet report underscored Japanese investors' attention to the situation in Eastern Europe and Gorbachev's key role in establishing stability in the region. ``To Japan, the worst thing that could happen to the world scenario would be for Gorbachev to drop from sight,'' said Chris Schreiber, an investment analyst with New Japan Securities in Tokyo. The Hong Kong Stock Exchange also closed sharply lower, with the Hang Seng Index falling 28.01 points to 2,839.94. Brokers there also attributed the losses to reports that Gorbachev canceled a meeting with British Labor Party leaders in Moscow and postponed all other contacts with foreign politicians. ``It created a public embarrassment and a setback for him,'' said Robert Brusca, chief economist for Nikko Securities Co. International Inc. in New York. Gorbachev's move prompted traders to speculate that the problems in the Soviet Union ``must be pretty bad,'' Brusca said. But the response in other major world markets was more tempered. On Wall Street, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials lost 22.83 points to close at 2,773.25. In London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100 share index lost 7.1 points, or 0.3 percent, to close at 2,444.5. In Frankfurt, the DAX index fell 15.88 points to finish at 1,820.00, but well up from the day's low of 1,804.35. Analysts said that hardest hit among Tokyo stocks were those of Japanese trading houses, which had been recommended by brokers based on the ``detente theme.'' Marubeni shares lost 5 percent and C. Itoh and Co. suffered an even greater decline. ``One of the big themes (in Japan) is that the greatest opportunites are going to be in Russia,'' Brusca said. ``As you set that back, you set all the investment strategies everyone has been pushing.''

DOC.HEAD: Nippon To Invest $200 Million In American Express
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to UPDATE with closing stock price.
DOC.TEXT: American Express Co. said Friday it will receive a $200 million cash infusion from Nippon Life Insurance Co., strengthening an alliance between the two financial services giants that began more than two years ago. Under terms of their agreement, Nippon will purchase American Express exchangeable preferred shares, which can be converted at any time to American Express common stock at a share price of $42.50. Should Nippon exercise those rights, as well as a warrant issued in 1987 allowing it to purchase 2 million American Express shares at $50 apiece, the Japanese insurance giant would have a 1.6 percent stake in American Express, according to American Express spokesman Matthew Stover. On the New York Stock Exchange, American Express fell 37{ cents to close at $34.50 a share. The stock's 52-week high is $39.37{ a share. Nippon and American Express forged an alliance in May 1987 when Nippon purchased a 13 percent stake in Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., the brokerage firm controlled by American Express. Shearson, Wall Street's second-largest brokerage, has suffered recently from weak profits and is in the process of a $900 million recapitalization program spearheaded by American Express. The restructuring, unveiled last month, followed announcements that Shearson would lay off hundreds of employees and make deep cuts in stockbroker commissions. American Express officials were quick to point out that Nippon's current investment plans have nothing to do with Shearson. ``The timing was coincidental,'' Stover said. ``We have a relationship with Nippon, we've done a lot of things with them. They have expressed an interest in investing in American Express, and now they're doing it.'' Stover called the investment a ``reflection of the close cooperation between the two companies.'' Japanese firms have had a long-standing interest in investing in American financial companies. In 1986 Sumitomo Bank Ltd. invested about $500 million in Goldman, Sachs & Co. in return for a non-voting stake in the firm. Little more than a year later, Yasuda Mutual Life Insurance Co. paid $300 million for an 18 percent voting stake in PaineWebber Group Inc. And in 1988 Japan's largest brokerage, Nomura Securities Co., acquired a 20 percent stake in the takeover boutique Wasserstein, Perella & Co. for $100 million. Howard Clark Jr., American Express's chief financial officer, said the deal ``adds $200 million to our equity base, broadens and deepens our existing relationship with Nippon Life and fits in with our goal to expand our strategic global alliances.'' American Express reported net income of $899.8 million, or $2.09 a share for the nine months ended Sept. 30, up 11.4 percent from $807.5 million, or $1.89 a share a year earlier. Revenue rose 24 percent to $18.73 billion from $15.09 billion a year earlier. Figures for the full year will be released later this month.

DOC.HEAD: Federated Eliminates 52 Jobs
DOC.TEXT: Federated Department Stores Inc. said Friday it is elimimating 52 jobs at its corporate headquarters here, reducing the staff at the base of Campeau Corp.'s U.S. retail operations by 14 percent. About one-third of the jobs were related to operating and maintaining four corporate aircraft that are being sold to cut back expenses and help with cash flow, Federated said. The rest of the jobs are in the areas of store planning and real estate, indicating Federated expects fewer new store openings. Federated and Allied Stores Corp., also based in Cincinnati, warned last month that they might be forced to file for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code unless bondholders agree to reschedule certain debts. Their corporate parent, Campeau, a Canadian retail and real estate company, has been trying to cope with cash crunch. Campeau took over Federated in 1988 in a $6.7 billion acquisition after acquiring Allied in 1986 for $3.4 billion. Allied and Federated won a temporary reprieve this week from a threat by bank lenders to declare the stores in technical default on a $2.34 billion loan. The banking syndicate led by Citibank agreed to give the chains until Jan. 15 to show they're making progress in bringing their financial problems under control.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed; Gold Soars
Precede LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar staged a turnaround Friday, closing mostly higher in domestic dealings after taking a sharp hit in overseas markets that were focusing on events in Eastern Europe. Gold prices soared by as much as $9 an ounce. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery jumped $7.70 to settle at $406.30 a troy ounce. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $406.25 an ounce, up $7.50 from Thursday's late bid. News that Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev canceled January appointments with foreign officials so he could deal with domestic problems sparked the hike in gold prices but sent stock prices skidding and frightened currency markets worldwide. ``So much depends on him keeping peace in the Eastern bloc and to give enough room for progress to continue,'' said Jack Barbanel, managing director of First Global Managers in Princeton, N.J. While foreign markets focused on Gorbachev's political health, domestic traders keyed in on a Labor Department report that showed the unemployment rate held steady at 5.3 percent last month, while the addition of 142,000 non-farm jobs was weaker than expected. ``The dollar dropped off rather sharply on the weak number,'' said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. The report gave further fuel to the argument that the U.S. economy is slowing and that the Federal Reserve might move to lower interest rates. Foreign appetite for dollars is dampened when the yields on U.S. securities decline. Traders also noted that the Fed entered the market to sell dollars for yen, pushing the dollar lower against the Japanese currency. A lower dollar will help ensure ``we have some advantage in continuing the level of exports (to Japan),'' which in turn aids in improving the trade deficit, Barbanel noted. Despite the negative news, technical factors pushed the dollar higher at the close of trading. ``The volume was high, and trading was somewhat chaotic,'' Flanagan said. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to 144.15 Japanese yen, from 145.20 yen on Thursday. Later in London, it fell to 143.75 yen. In New York, the dollar finished at 144.50 yen, up from 143.65 yen on Thursday. In London, the British pound rose to $1.6375 from $1.6290 late Thursday. In New York, it cost $1.6350 to buy one pound, unchanged fom Thursday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Thursday, included: 1.6895 West German marks, up from 1.6800; 1.5445 Swiss francs, up from 1.5395; 5.5778 French francs, down from 5.7450; 1,276.25 Italian lire, up from 1,263.00, and 1.1608 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1607. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday included: 1.6810 West German marks, down from 1.6825; 1.5365 Swiss francs, down from 1.5410; 5.7405 French francs, down from 5.7500; 1.9030 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9275; 1,263.00 Italian lire, down from 1,265.25, and 1.1595 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1610. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $404.50 a troy ounce, from $395 bid late Thursday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $405.50, from $395.70 bid late Thursday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose $6.03 to close at a bid $400.92. Silver prices rose. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $5.318 an ounce, from $5.268 an ounce on Thursday. In London, the metal rose to a late bid price of $5.27 a troy ounce, from $5.22 bid late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Rates Cut By Budget Bill
DOC.NOTE: EDS: 33.67 cents per bushel cq for both wheat and corn. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department announced on Friday the rates for advance federal payments when farmers begin to sign up for 1990 crop programs later in the month. Keith Bjerke, executive vice president of the department's Commodity Credit Corp., said the advance payments will be reduced by 1.4 percent as required by the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1989. Farmers will be able to sign up in 1990 crop programs Jan. 16 through April 13 at local offices of the department's Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service. The cash advances are made to help tide farmers over until crops are harvested and will be deducted from their total ``deficiency'' payments at the end of the season. Deficiency payments _ based on a crop's acreage and program yield per acre _ make up the difference between a target price and the average market price during a specified period of the marketing season. Adjusted advance deficiency payment rates for 1990, allowing for the 1.4 percent budget reductions, include: _Wheat, 33.67 cents per bushel. _Corn, 33.67 cents per bushel. _Sorghum, 34.19 cents per bushel. _Barley, 8.4 cents per bushel. _Oats, none. _Upland cotton, 3.685 cents per pound. _Extra-long staple cotton, none. _Rice, $1.5725 per 100 pounds.

Stock prices declined Friday in the face of economic uncertainties and worries over political developments in the Soviet Union. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 22.83 to 2,773.25, reducing its gain for the week to 20.05 points. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 5 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 591 up, 931 down and 453 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 158.53 million shares, down from 177 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 191.73 million shares. The Labor Department reported that the civilian unemployment rate held steady at 5.3 percent in December. The data showed a smaller-than-expected 142,000 increase in nonfarm payroll employment. Traders in the bond market took that as favorable news, suggesting that the pace of the economy remained sluggish enough to allow the Federal Reserve to consider further moves toward easier credit. But stock-market investors evidently read the figures as a sign that further weakness might be in store for corporate earnings in the months ahead. Analysts also said the market was unsettled by reports that Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev canceled foreign engagements to deal with domestic problems. Several Europen country funds gave up some of their recent gains on the chance that the Soviet situation might delay or disrupt new trade opportunities in eastern Europe. Germany Fund fell 2} to 17, posting the day's biggest percentage loss among NYSE issues; Austria Fund was down 1\ at 20|, and Italy Fund lost } to 15{. Malaysia Fund, by contrast, gained 1} to 21~, and First Philippine Fund rose ~ to 14}. Regional telephone stocks sold off in a general flow of money out of the ``defensive'' issues that gained many followers in late 1989. Southwestern Bell dropped 3 to 59\; Pacific Telesis 1{ to 47}; Bell South 1~ to 55|, and Nynex 1[ to 86]. Losers among other actively traded blue chips included General Electric, down | at 65|; Merck, down 1| at 77; American Telephone & Telegraph, down } at 44|, and McDonald's, down | at 33\. International Business Machines, which had been rallying from depressed levels in recent sessions, slipped back \ to 99}. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $26.40 billion, or 0.77 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped 1.66 to 194.63. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 3.39 to 404.20, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down 3.47 at 352.20. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market slipped 1.17 to 458.22. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 382.45, up .29.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Agency Turns Over Courthouse Flood Investigation to FBI
DOC.NOTE: Eds; SUBS 4th graf, Diamond said... to restore dropped word `building.' ^By MARCY GORDON
DOC.TEXT: The General Services Administration has asked the FBI to investigate whether vandalism caused a serious flood at U.S. Bankruptcy Court that knocked out power to the building and forced judges and staff to relocate, a GSA official said Friday. William J. Diamond, GSA's regional administrator for the Northeast, told The Associated Press there was ``sufficient evidence'' to believe vandalism was behind the Christmas Eve flood in the basement of the landmark courthouse in lower Manhattan. However, he declined to say whether it appeared that the damage was directed at any particular case being handled by the court, whose docket includes the Eastern Airlines bankruptcy proceeding and numerous other cases. Diamond said the flood knocked out all phone service and power, including auxiliary generators, and submerged utility equipment in about 5{ feet of water. The building now is empty except for repair crews. Diamond said the flood caused an estimated $500,000 damage to the building. He said a valve apparently was removed from the water main feeding the building's fire sprinkler system, thereby unleashing the flood. A subway station across the street from the Art Deco-era building, also was flooded and was closed temporarily. The FBI and GSA have jurisdiction over investigations regarding federal buildings. The courthouse is the site of hearings on numerous bankruptcy cases, including Eastern's Chapter 11 reorganization. No documents related to the cases currently are available to the public due to space restrictions in the area where they temporarily are housed. The bankruptcy judges have been hearing cases in a federal courthouse several blocks away. Clerks and other staff temporarily have been relocated across the street. Diamond said the investigation was turned over to the FBI on Thursday. FBI officials didn't immediately return calls Friday seeking comment. ``The building is not habitable right now,'' said Kathleen Farrell, chief deputy clerk of the bankruptcy court. She said things should be back to normal ``hopefully by the end of January,'' as contractors and repair crews work around the clock in the building. The computer used to store data related to the Eastern bankruptcy proceeding has been down since the flood, she said.

DOC.HEAD: SAS to Purchase 30 Percent Share In Chilean Airline
DOC.TEXT: Scandinavian Airlines System has agreed to pay around $15 million for a 30 percent share in LAN, the Chilean flag carrier, LAN President Guillermo Carey said. Carey told the Santiago newspaper El Mercurio that the agreement will not affect LAN's present traffic rights, which include profitable routes to the United States and several Latin American countries. LAN, which was established four decades ago as a state-owned airline, was sold last year to a private investment group headed by Carey, as part of a far-reaching program to privatize government companies launched by the military government. Carey told the newspaper that the agreement, among other things, will allow LAN to share office space with SAS in many cities, ``which will mean not only a larger international coverage for us, but also a considerable money saving.'' He said SAS also will participate in a planned $30 million capital increase. He gave no details, however.

DOC.HEAD: Farm Leaders Talk About Problems, Solutions for World Trade
DOC.TEXT: HOWEY-IN-THE-HILLS, Fla. (AP) _ Europe's top agricultural official disagreed with major trading partners Friday, saying a summit had done little to resolve major differences over import restrictions and export subsidies. But Ray MacSharry _ representing the 12-nation European Community in informal talks with the United States, Japan, Canada and Australia _ conceded ``We did see where we need to make progress.'' U.S. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter and farm ministers from Canada and Australia said the closed-door sessions had smoothed the path toward final negotiations for a trade pact being hammered out by the 96 nations of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The European Community, which plans to dismantle internal trade barriers in 1992, is in serious conflict with the U.S. and other nations over farm supports and subsidies. MacSharry contends European farming is too diverse and that the EC's 10 million farmers need government support, import restrictions, export subsidies and other assistance to continue feeding 300 million people. Yeutter, Australia's John Kerin and Canada's Donald Mazankowski emphasized their discussions were meant to advance the GATT negotiations for more liberal trade policies. Yeutter was especially outspoken over what he called ``subsidies that are distortive to world trade.'' MacSharry told reporters after the 1{-day meeting at the Mission Inn resort that the EC didn't like U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills' ``tarrification'' proposal and would continue to insist on ``rebalancing.'' Yeutter explained the concept of tarrification like this at a news conference: ``The principal import restrictions (around the world) are non-tariff measures. The way to deal with that is to convert them into tariffs and negotiate those tariffs down.'' Yeutter called the EC's ``rebalancing'' policy _ to liberalize trade restrictions on some products but tighten them in others _ as ``antithetical to the spirit of the GATT. ... It is a barrier to trade. I don't see any support for rebalancing outside the EC.'' Australia's Kerin agreed, saying, ``Rebalancing is just another denial of market access.'' Mazankowski told reporters that the leaders of the world's major farm-production areas had ``a determined resolve to address the issues'' on international competition. The GATT negotiations are scheduled for completion at the end of the year. Michihiko Kano, Japan's minister of agriculture, forestry and fisheries, was asked whether his country's farmers would gain anything from a strong GATT agreement. Japan has been harshly criticized by Yeutter and others for what they call overly tough protectionist policies. Speaking through an interpreter, Kano avoided any direct comment on its policy on imports of rice and other farm products. As for any benefits to Japanese farmers, Kano said: ``The meeting was not for negotiation. It was to exchange views, and that's where the significance lies.'' The ministers generally agreed to establish what they called a crisis-management plan to deal with situations such as the scares over cyanide in Chilean grapes and the use of the chemical Alar on some American apples. Mazankowski, Canada's deputy prime minister and minister of agriculture, took the lead on that issue. The U.S. is to provide a research grant and assist in putting together such a plan. Food safety was a major issue in the talks, and the ministers called for more research and a consumer-education campaign on such things as fertilizers, pesticides and other products used to treat commodities. ``There was probably a greater consensus on the food safety issue than on the others,'' said Yeutter.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Regulators Approve KKR Divestiture of Del Monte Ketchup
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Trade Commission announced Friday it approved KKR Associates' divestiture of Del Monte ketchup assets to a newly formed company. The ketchup assets will be acquired by DMPF Holdings Corp., a group formed by Merrill Lynch & Co., Citicorp Capital Investors Ltd., Kikkoman Corp. and members of Del Monte management. The divestiture was part of the sale of the entire Del Monte processed foods business by KKR, a unit of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., which acquired Del Monte as part of its $24.53 billion buyout of RJR Nabisco Inc. last year. FTC approval of the divestiture was required by a consent order under which Kohlberg Kravis was forced to sell either Del Monte or its competing Beatrice-Hunt-Wesson ketchup assets. As a result of the consent order, the company also sold Beatrice's Fisher Nut line, which competedwith RJR Nabisco's Planters division, and one of its two oriental food lines.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Weighing Ways to Revitalize Panama's Economy
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Inserts 3 grafs with AID reopening office after 9th graf pvs, While recommendations ... Also moving on general news wires.
Eds: Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Friday he is considering housing programs, business development and bank loans to help Panama's shattered economy recover from the U.S. invasion and years of economic sanctions. Bush was not more specific on what the United States might do to help Panama recover from invasion-related damage, estimated at perhaps $2 billion, and from two years of economic decline that flowed partly from the U.S. sanctions against Manuel Antonio Noriega. Nor did Bush address where his administration will find money to help Panama in a foreign aid budget already strained past its limits. Foreign assistance is among the least popular programs on Capitol Hill, where the president would have to secure approval for aid to Panama. It was learned separately that Bush administration officials are looking into possible aid that includes: _Building houses for people left homeless by the bombing and combat. _Helping Panama to pay its $543 million in foreign debt so it can get new loans. _Getting other nations involved in the recovery effort. _Loans to help businesses recover. While recommendations have yet to be drawn up and presented to Bush, one administration source said ``there's a sense of urgency and we want to move quickly and respond quickly.'' The Agency For International Development, meanwhile, announced it will reopen its Panama City office. Before it was closed on Noriega's orders in December 1987, the office had helped Panama stabilize its economy through development assistance. The State Department agency said it is allocating $700,000 in emergency assistance to remove rubble in the fire-ravaged Panama City neighborhood of El Chorrillo, care for displaced people and distribute food and medical supplies. The fire damage was widely believed to be caused by Noriega's paramilitary supporters, known as Dignity Battalions. One U.S. official, who, like the others, requested anonymity, said it also is likely the administration will move up from March the date on which officials must certify whether Panama is cooperating in antidrug efforts. By speeding up the evaluation, the administration could enable Panama to receive U.S. trade benefits and Caribbean Basin Initiative benefits and have its sugar quota reinstated, that official said. The embryonic, U.S.-installed government of President Guillermo Endara has expressed strong antidrug sentiments and would be expected to win certification, said the official. Such certification was denied to Panama under Noriega, now in U.S. custody on a variety of drug charges. ``The revitalization of the Panamanian economy is a major priority in the months ahead,'' Bush told a White House news conference, ``as are our efforts for humanitarian assistance. ``I can report today that considerable progress has been made so far in returning Panama to a normal state of affairs. The new government has taken charge, and President Endara is working tirelessly to meet the needs of his people.'' Bush said the team led by Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger that visited Panama this week had praised the Endara government. ``They are discussing housing programs, business development, bank loans that will help spur economic growth. We are committed to be a part of that process,'' Bush said. The president noted that he already has released nearly $400 million in assets in U.S. banks that was frozen under the sanctions against the Noriega regime. U.S. officials involved in the discussions with Panama said Endara did not present a laundry list of economic requests, but rather talked about general needs. ``The Endara government has to sort out its priorities,'' said one official, who also requested anonymity. Just how much money the administration might find to help Panama is an unanswered question. Bush's press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, acknowledged this week that the current 1991 budget, to be sent to Congress on Jan. 29, includes no money to help Panama. The Endara government indicated to the Eagleburger team that it recognizes that private businesses in Panama will play a major role in restoring the economy and does not expect the U.S. governement to do everything, said one source. It is expected the administration will turn to friends around the world to help Panama. In particular, officials have mentioned Japan. Japanese ambassador Ryohei Murata discussed the matter Friday with Vice President Dan Quayle. Afterward, Quayle's press secretary, David Beckwith, said he could not disclose the substance of the discussion other than to say, ``The vice president complimented Japan for considering extending aid.'' Japan retained its ties with the Noriega government despite U.S. urgings that the Tokyo government help isolate the dictator. Japan has had substantial economic interests in Panama.

DOC.HEAD: Collapse Of Heating Oil Futures Linked To Warmer Weather
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 14-15 to CORRECT time frame of gold losses to Tuesday and Wednesday, CORRECT style on Gorbachev. Picks up 16th graf, Gold settled...
DOC.TEXT: Heating oil futures prices plunged more than 5 cents a gallon for the second straight day Friday on the New York Mercantile Exchange as warm temperatures in the Northeast flushed speculators from the market. On other commodity markets, orange juice futures rebounded strongly; precious metals were sharply higher; pork futures surged while cattle futures were mixed; and grains and soybeans were mixed. Wholesale home heating oil futures settled 2.27 cents to 5.36 cents lower with the contract for delivery in February at 67.83 cents a gallon. West Texas Intermediate crude oil finished 33 cents to 58 cents lower with February at 23.08 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 2 cents to 3.07 cents lower with February at 62.22 cents a gallon. The sell-off in the energy markets extended a move begun Thursday, reflecting a full-scale retreat by speculators who bought in during last month's dramatic, weather-driven rally. A warming trend that roughly coincided with the beginning of the new year has reduced heating-oil demand and eased the strain on oil refineries, analysts said. But the key to the collapse appears to have been the market's reluctance to rally Thursday after the American Petroleum Institute released weekly inventory figures showing larger-than-expected declines in U.S. stocks of gasoline and petroleum distillates, which include heating oil. ``When the market negated that, you had your classic commodities downturn with everybody wanting to get out at the same time, and it was ugly,'' said analyst Jerry Samuels of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. Orange juice futures prices soared the permitted daily limit on the New York Cotton Exchange, more than offsetting Thursday's losses, amid new concerns about frost damage to the Florida orange groves. The market seems to have factored in all the damage done to the oranges. But new fears have surfaced that the Christmas weekend freeze and subsequent warmup may have hurt the trees, too, which could adversely affect next year's crop. ``The assessment from Florida is that the situation is a lot more critical than we anticipated before,'' said Celeste Georkakis, an analyst with Cargill Investor Services Inc. An Agriculture Department crop report due out on Thursday is not expected to indicate the full extent of the damage, she said. All contracts for future deliveries of frozen concentrated orange juice rose the 5-cent limit except the limitless January contract, which settled 8.65 cents higher at $1.7965 a pound. Gold futures rallied strongly on New York's Commodity Exchange, extending gains posted Thursday and entirely erasing the losses registered on Tuesday and Wednesday. Analysts cited a resurgence of bullion sales, possibly indicating a ``flight to safety'' by investors spooked by the sharp drop in stock prices around the world Friday following news that Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev had canceled meetings with foreign leaders. Gold settled $7.70 to $7.80 higher with February at $408.50 a troy ounce; silver was 5 cents to 5.1 cents higher with February at $5.344 a troy ounce. Pork futures rose sharply for the second straight day on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in response to Wednesday's Agriculture Department report showing a smaller-than-expected U.S. hog herd. Live hogs settled .45 cent to the limit 1.5 cents higher with February at 50.95 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.1 cents to the limit 2 cents higher with February at 53.47 cents a pound; live cattle futures finished .20 cent lower to .15 cent higher with February at 76.87 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .17 cent lower to .05 cent higher with January at 84.57 cents a pound. DOC.HEAD: Prices Mostly Lower
DOC.TEXT: Prices of long-term government bonds sank Friday on new inflation fears and a government employment report that apparently offered no hope of lower interest rates. The Treasury's closely watched 30-year bond fell \ point, or $2.50 for every $1,000 in face value. Its yield rose to 8.06 percent from 8.03 percent late Thursday. Shorter-term Treasury yields were mixed. The credit markets had little initial reaction to a Labor Department report that the unemployment held steady at 5.3 percent in December as gains in service industries offset the ninth consecutive monthly drop in manufacturing jobs. But after receiving no signal from the Federal Reserve Board on the future course of monetary policy, traders began to sell bonds in the long end of the market. Traders have been hopeful that in order to spur economic growth the Fed would lower interest rates, which makes bonds more valuable and raises their prices. But recent reports have pointed to some strength in the economy, which could cause inflation and discourage the Fed from easing credit _ bad news for bonds. ``The employment data indicated clearly the economy is clearly slowing but there were some indication that wage inflation is beginning to pick up,'' said economist Steven A. Wood at BankAmerica Capital Markets in San Francisco. The government said average hourly earnings rose 0.6 percent, translating into annual gains more than 7 percent, well above the 4.1 percent over the past year. Sharp rises in oil prices earlier this week also have renewed inflation fears, Wood said. Prices of crude and home heating oil fell on Thursday and Friday, giving back some of their sharp gains from earlier in the week. In the secondary market for Treasury securities, short-term government issues were unchanged to up 3-32 point, intermediate issues were unchanged to down 1-16 point and long-term issues were down 3-32 point to 11-32 point, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, fell 0.34 to 1,184.60. Yields on three-month Treasury bills declined to 7.77 percent as the discount fell 3 basis points to 7.53 percent. Yields on six-month bills fell to 7.84 percent as the discount dropped 1 basis point to 7.45 percent. Yields on one-year bills slipped to 7.77 percent as the discount lost 2 basis points to 7.27 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, was quoted at 8[ percent, down from 8\ percent late Thursday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds was 93 1-16, down [. The average yield to maturity rose to 7.28 percent from 7.27 percent late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Cold Weather Sends Oil Prices To Four-Year High
DOC.TEXT: Domestic oil prices, driven by falling temperatures and rising demand, have hit the highest level in four years, already topping what many petroleum industry analysts had expected as a peak for 1990. Many said the Wednesday surge to levels approaching $24 a barrel for February delivery of West Texas Intermediate crude oil probably couldn't last long. Nonetheless, they were busy revising their forecasts for the year. ``At the 20 bucks that we saw in November, I forecast a trail off to $17 or $18 by April, and then I expected things to recover in the balance of the year,'' said Stephen A. Smith, an analyst at Bear Stearns & Co. in New York. ``Now it won't go a lot lower than 19 bucks,'' he said Friday. Others were looking for a drop of about $2 to $3 per barrel. After Wednesday's high of $23.68, the price fell back 27 cents on Thursday and 33 cents Friday to close the week at $23.08, vs. $21.50 a week earlier. The so-called posted price, what refiners are willing to pay for immediate delivery, also jumped $1.50 during the week to $22.50, before some refiners began pulling back to $22 late Friday. Except for a one-day jump last April, the levels were the highest since 1986, when oil prices began to fall from the high $20s before bottoming out in the $10 per barrel range. The runup was caused by a number of things but mainly cold weather in the Northeast and in Europe. George Gaspar, analyst at Robert W. Baird & Co. in Milwaukee, said the weather, coupled with problems at domestic refineries, reduced finished product stocks by 30 million barrels, forcing refineries to rush to restock and get ready for the summer gasoline season. ``Generally there's a steady decline in finished product _ light fuel, gasoline _ through March, but we're far and above ahead of the decline,'' he said. Analysts said the demand for crude oil to replenish the stock likely will keep the price from falling rapidly, although they expect a decline before prices climb again toward the end of the year, perhaps to $24 a barrel. For consumers, the recent jump in oil prices already has made a stiff impact, especially for users of home-heating oil. Gasoline users haven't faced a dramatic rise at the pump yet, but airline passengers are getting socked with fuel surcharges, the first time that's happened since the 1970s oil crises. Some industry analysts say the sudden surge in demand for oil has revived respect for the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, a key source of supplies. Only a few months ago when OPEC decided on a combined production level of about 22 million barrels a day, many analysts thought that was too much and would depress prices. But now that level seems about right. ``The weather may have bailed OPEC out a bit here,'' said Smith of Bear Stearns. Others said increased international demand, especially in Brazil and Japan, had soaked up any excess supplies. Even if the price retreats, the domestic industry's recovery from the price collapse a few years ago should continue, said David Lee Smith, analyst at Eppler, Guerin & Turner Inc. in Dallas. ``My sense is that most of the major oil companies test their projects at $15 a barrel,'' he said. ``If they become convinced as time goes on that we've got stable prices above that, it bodes well for the continuing recovery.'' Many of the major oil companies already plan to increase spending on exploration this year, and new technology is helping revive fields once thought to be dry. The increased prices carry some danger, warned Lysle Brinker, editor of Petroleum Outlook, in that they could persuade OPEC to increase quotas at its spring meeting. More oil would send prices back down, he said.
DOC.NOTE: End adv for weekend editions Jan. 6-7

DOC.HEAD: Keating Denies Using Lincoln as `Piggybank'
DOC.TEXT: Phoenix millionaire Charles H. Keating Jr. on Friday denied ``with all my heart and soul'' that he used a tax-sharing arrangement at his Lincoln Savings and Loan Association to siphon off $94 million. The arrangement between the now-collapsed Irvine, Calif., thrift and its holding company, American Continental Corp., is a centerpiece of regulators' contention that Keating was illegally using Lincoln as a ``piggybank'' for his massive real estate ventures. Testifying on his suit seeking to overturn the government's takeover of the $6 billion thrift last April as an ``unsafe and unsound'' institution, Keating said the tax arrangement was intended only to bring stability to the various subsidiaries of his empire. ``To me it was a housekeeping situation,'' he told U.S. District Court Judge Stanley Sporkin in his second day of testimony. A key figure in the S&L crisis and the target of a criminal grand jury investigation, Keating had refused in November to testify before the House Banking Committee about Lincoln and its alleged loss of up to $2 billion in federally insured deposits. He also is at the center of a Senate ethics investigation after raising $1.3 million for the political causes of five senators who intervened with regulators on Lincoln's behalf in 1987 when examiners then were trying to curtail its risky loans and land and junk bond investments. After his court appearance, Keating told reporters that the government failed to justify Lincoln's takeover in seven days of hearings presenting its side to Sporkin. ``To me it's obvious they have not made a case,'' he said. ``Now our turn starts. They took away an association with $5.5 billion in assets and they're supposed to have had some reason for doing that. This company made money. In my opinion it was well managed (and) ... would have survived under proper handling by the regulators.'' Attorneys for Keating said it would take them at least eight days to present his case to Sporkin, who held the top legal posts at the Securities and Exchange Commission and CIA before becoming a judge. In response to skeptical questions from Sporkin, Keating acknowledged that that he used part of the deferred taxes American Continental was holding on behalf of the thrift to make payments on the holding company's debt. But when the judge asked if that was the purpose of the arrangement _ to use Lincoln ``as a piggybank for you and American Continental'' _ Keating said no. ``With all my heart and soul, I want you to know that I categorically deny that I had any concept remotely related to that,'' he said. The tax agreement is one of several arrangements in which the government contends savers' government-insured deposits in Lincoln disappeared. Using the accord, regulators contend, Lincoln would sell land it had bought at greatly inflated prices, financing the buyers entirely, to record huge paper profits. Then using money from depositors, it would send the future taxes on those profits to American Continental, the government contends. From 1985 through 1988, the holding company collected $94 million in such deferred taxes from Lincoln although none of it was ever paid to the government. Keating also admitted Friday that Lincoln's bookkeeping hid the true buyer in one 1,000-acre soured real estate deal in which $4.4 million of allegedly owed taxes was paid by Lincoln to American Continental on a $14 million sale. However, because he knew who the true buyer was and that a $3.5 million down payment was made on property that Lincoln had bought for $3 million, regulators had no reason to be concerned about it, he said. ``The essence of the problem is that the regulators didn't like land syndications,'' Keating said, explaining that the use of ``straw buyers'' as the title holder were common in such deals. Sporkin, questioned how ``you can manage billion-dollar businesses and have transactions where the paperwork did not reflect what took place?'' ``When you run a bank or a savings and loan, you have the highest responsibility of anyone because you're not dealing just with stockholders, you're dealing with people's savings,'' the judge told Keating. ``... The only way regulators (can ensure that an institution is being run properly) is if the books and records accurately reflect transactions.'' In its takeover and a $1.1 billion civil racketeering and fraud suit the government has filed against Keating, the government has charged the entire deal was a sham. The true buyer, Arizona developer Ernest C. Garcia, had received another $20 million loan from Lincoln the same day. And regulators contend that Garcia used some of that money or proceeds from other loans and deals with Lincoln to make the 25 percent, $3.5 million down payment necessary under accounting regulations for the thrift to record the profit. Garcia, who was a participant in several interwoven deals with Lincoln and American Continental that the government contends establishes a pattern of fraud and racketeering, refused Friday to testify as a government witness in Keating's suit. Through his attorney, Garcia claimed a Fifth Amendment protection from self-incrimination and Sporkin allowed him to leave the courtroom without ever taking the stand.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Corp. Of Australia Wins In One Court, Still Faces Problems
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 6th graf pvs, `He also... to UPDATE with Bond Corp. comment; PICKS UP 7th graf pvs, `While Bond...
DOC.TEXT: Bond Corp. Holdings Ltd. won a reprieve Friday as the Western Australian Supreme Court dismissed a government petition to liquidate the media, brewing, natural resources and property empire. The court ruled against the State Government Insurance Commission, which had asked the court to appoint a provisional liquidator for Bond Corp. on the grounds that the company controlled by financier Alan Bond was insolvent. A judge ruled that the insurance commission had failed to prove its claim. ``There is no evidence that the creditors of (Bond Corp.) aren't being paid,'' the judge said. The future of Bond Corp. may be uncertain, the judge said, but a petition should not be filed on speculation ``that a company may possibly at some time in the future experience severe financial difficulties.'' He also ruled that a nearly $668,000 debt that was the basis of the petition was disputed by Bond Corp. Bond Corp. Executive Director Peter Lucas called the court decision ``a resounding victory'' for the company. While Bond Corp. succeeded on one front, the company, whose debts total $5.6 billion, was still battling in another court to overturn an order to appoint receivers and managers to its Australian brewing units. The company is also trying to negotiate with U.S. holders of debentures issued by its Bond Brewing Holdings Ltd. unit who have demanded immediate repayment of $510 million of the securities and overdue interest. Lawyers for the debenture holders said in court here Friday they intend to support continuation of receivers appointed last month to operate Bond's brewing units. The court appointed the receivers at the request of a syndicate of international banks led by National Australia Bank Ltd. U.S. noteholders were due to receive a $32.19 million interest payment from Bond's brewing arm, but the courts froze that payment at the request of the bank syndicate. Bond Brewing has asked the court to lift the bank's stop-payment notice. Alan Bond, who controls about 58 percent of Bond Corp., gained virtual hero status in Australia when he won the 1983 America's Cup yachting trophy. The millionaire industrialist has been selling assets in recent months to reduce debt. In its fiscal year ended June 30, Bond Corp. lost 980.2 million Australian dollars, the largest annual loss in Australian corporate history. Bond Corp.'s G. Heileman Brewing Co. unit in the United States so far is not involved in the receivership proceedings. Heileman spokesman Bill Eiler said in a telephone interview from Pittsburgh Thursday the U.S. brewer has separate financing from Bond Corp. and as a matter of policy does not comment on matters involving Bond. Bond purchased La Crosse, Wis.-based Heileman in 1987 for about $1.3 billion and reportedly still owes about $850 million after selling the profitable Heileman Baking Co. and other Heileman subsidiaries. Heileman officials said recently they have been meeting with creditors and reviewing alternatives ``aimed at favorably modifying Heileman's existing debt structure.'' Separately, Adolph Coors Co., the fourth-largest U.S. brewing company, acknowledged this week it has held talks with Heileman for over a year about the possible purchase of the Wisconsin brewer.
