DOC.HEAD: More Flexible Scheduling, Job Sharing and Home Work Expected in 1990s
DOC.TEXT: Flexible work schedules will become more commonplace during the 1990s, along with job sharing and work at home, according to a survey released Sunday. The Conference Board, a business-supported research organization, said it surveyed 521 of the nation's biggest companies, and found that 93 percent offer at least one kind of flexible staffing. The most common form of flexible staffing was part-time work, followed by flexible hours, job sharing, phased retirement and work at home, the Conference Board said. Some companies also offer shorter work weeks. Companies expect to make greater use of flexible staffing in the next few years, the survey said. Job sharing and work at home are most likely to be under consideration. However, while many firms are considering more flexible staffing, the employees who currently benefit the most from such arrangements tend to be women in clerical, administrative support or sales positions. Managers, professionals and executives generally do not have flexible schedules, the Conference Board said. Kathleen Christensen, a City University of New York professor who compiled the study, said companies are coming under pressure to offer flexible staffing because of the tight labor market. ``In the 1990s, flexible scheduling will be a critical issue to companies that need to keep their most valued employees and retain a competitive edge in recruitment,'' she said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for AMs Mon, Jan 8

DOC.HEAD: Travelers, Aetna Wary of Insurance for Individuals
DOC.TEXT: Travelers Corp., citing poor financial results, says it plans to stop selling major medical health insurance to individuals, and another insurance giant, Aetna Life & Casualty, is considering a similar move. Travelers spokeswoman Rosanne Hennessey said Thursday the company will honor and extend existing individual policies, but will not sell new major medical policies to individuals after Jan. 31. Major medical policies pay hospital and doctor costs. Aetna Life & Casualty Co. said Thursday it is considering withdrawing from the individual health insurance market or reducing its individual health insurance business. Neither Aetna nor Travelers is a major seller of individual health insurance. Both companies concentrate on health insurance sold to employers for their workers. Aetna, for instance, wrote $18 billion worth of insurance polices in 1988, of which 1 percent _ $180 million _ was for individuals. Hennessey said the major medical program for individuals has not generated the profits the company expected. ``Claims and expenses exceeded premiums and exceeded our expectations,'' she said. She stressed that Travelers will continue to offer other types of individual policies, including long-term disability, long-term care, accidental death and business travel and hospital indemnity. Aetna said it has not decided what steps to take regarding its individual policies. John J. Martin, president of the company's personal financial security division, said the options include making no changes or withdrawing certain lines of individual insurance. Martin complained that the individual policy business is ``very unpredictable, very volatile,'' and that it has been ``an inconsistent performer.'' He said Aetna lost about $9 million on individual policies in 1987, made about $5 million in 1988, and that 1989 ``is going to be a modest loser.'' Aetna has found that people who buy individual policies tend to be more likely to have health problems resulting in claims, Martin said. He said insurers prefer group insurance because it covers a broad spectrum of employees, people of different ages, sexes and states of health. In addition, he said, Aetna is worried that insurance regulations, concerned about the affordability of insurance, may approve rates that are too low to make such insurance profitable in the future.

DOC.HEAD: Time Warner Inc. Buys Interest It Does Not Already Own in Parenting
DOC.TEXT: Time Warner Inc. said Friday it had exercised its option to buy the interest it does not already own in Parenting magazine, which is designed for parents with children under 11 years of age. Terms were not disclosed. Parenting, which originates in San Francisco, has been published monthly since January 1987 as a joint venture between the Time Inc. Magazine Co. and Robin Wolaner, the founder and publisher of the magazine. Its circulation rate base has risen to 600,000 from 200,000 in three years.

DOC.HEAD: Microsoft Says Its Software Part of Government Contract
DOC.TEXT: Microsoft Corp.'s Windows computer software will be installed on as many as 40,000 personal computers being purchased by the Federal Aviation Administration over the next eight years, Microsoft said Thursday. Microsoft is a subcontractor to AT&T in the contract with the federal Department of Transportation, which oversees the FAA. But the Redmond-based company said its participation was crucial in selection of the AT&T bid for the air control agency's Office Automation Technology Services contract. ``We believe the FAA made its selection based in large part on the clear and demonstrable productivity increases that users realize when working in the Windows environment,'' said Bill Gates, chairman and chief executive officer of Microsoft. ``This award signals (the government's) recognition of Windows as a complete solution for increased productivity.'' The Transportation Department awarded the contract, potentially worth $853 million, to AT&T last month. The value of the subcontract to Microsoft was not disclosed. Windows and two other Microsoft products, Excel for Windows and Word for Windows, were included in the bids. Excel is a spreadsheet program and Word is for word processing. Windows provides a graphical, or picture, display to manipulate the software, rather than requiring users to type in characters to operate the software. Seventy companies worked with AT&T on the contract bid, Microsoft said.

The nation's unemployment rate held steady at 5.3 percent last month as gains in service industries offset the ninth consecutive monthly drop in manufacturing jobs, the Labor Department said. The steady civilian jobless rate, which ended 1989 just under the level where it began, gave private analysts hope Friday that the economy's current sluggish growth will not worsen into a recession.

Orders to U.S. factories for manufactured goods reached their second highest level in November, the government said. Analysts said Friday the report showed the longest peacetime economic expansion is continuing. ``This confirms our expectations that the economy won't drop into a recession,'' said Thomas Runiewicz, an economist with WEFA Group, a forecasting organization.

Stock prices in the Far East fell sharply on the news that Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev had canceled foreign engagements to deal with domestic worries. But the jitters Friday were less severe in other world markets. In Tokyo, the 225-share Nikkei index tumbled 600 points before recovering to finish 438.12 points lower at 38,274.76. The decline measured 1.1 percent and was the worst showing since Oct. 16, when the key index lost 647 points.

The arrangement between the now-collapsed thrift and its holding company, American Continental Corp., is a centerpiece of regulators' contention that Keating was illegally using Lincoln as a ``piggybank'' for his massive real estate ventures. Testifying Friday on his suit seeking to overturn the government's takeover of the $6 billion thrift last April, Keating said the tax arrangement was intended only to bring stability to the various subsidiaries of his empire.

West German automaker BMW AG is ready to move service and used-car sales networks into Eastern Europe as the Iron Curtain crumbles, company officials said. The moves are the first steps the automaker plans to take before setting up manufacturing sites in any of the newly emerging non-Communist countries, BMW Chairman Eberhard von Kuenheim said Friday.

American Express Co. said it will receive a $200 million cash infusion from Nippon Life Insurance Co., strengthening an alliance between the two financial services giants that began more than two years ago. Under terms of their agreement announced Friday, Nippon will purchase American Express exchangeable preferred shares, which can be converted at any time to American Express common stock at a share price of $42.50. Should Nippon exercise those rights, as well as a warrant issued in 1987 allowing it to purchase 2 million American Express shares at $50 apiece, the Japanese insurance giant would have a 1.6 percent stake in American Express.

Bond Corp. Holdings Ltd. won a reprieve as the Western Australian Supreme Court dismissed a government petition to liquidate the media, brewing, natural resources and real estate empire. The court ruled Friday against the State Government Insurance Commission, which had asked the court to appoint a provisional liquidator for Bond Corp. on the grounds that the company controlled by financier Alan Bond was insolvent. A judge ruled that the insurance commission had failed to prove its claim.

The Agriculture Department announced the rates for advance federal payments when farmers begin to sign up for 1990 crop programs later in the month. Keith Bjerke, executive vice president of the department's Commodity Credit Corp., said Friday the advance payments will be reduced by 1.4 percent as required by the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1989.

Socialism is not to blame for China's poverty, and the nation will eventually triumph over its capitalist rivals, the Communist Party daily newspaper said. The lengthy commentary Friday in the People's Daily came less than a month after a small group of university students, in a bold gesture of dissent, unfurled a banner in front of the state television station reading ``Motherland, why are you so poor?'' It is also part of a government propaganda campaign to convince the populace that China must stick to the socialist road, suppress political dissent and reject the reforms now sweeping Eastern Europe.

Stock prices declined Friday in the face of economic uncertainties and worries over political developments in the Soviet Union. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 22.83 points to 2,773.25. The dollar staged a turnaround, closing mostly higher in domestic dealings. Prices of long-term government bonds sank on new inflation fears. Heating oil futures prices plunged more than 5 cents a gallon for the second straight day; orange juice futures and precious metals were sharply higher; pork futures surged while cattle futures were mixed; and grains and soybeans were mixed.
